questions.question: True or false: If you end up missing one of the online lecture quizzes for a good reason, such as being sick, you should immediately contact the professor about your situation and request an extension on the quiz.

answers.text: True
answers.comment: Extensions are not granted for the online lecture quizzes for any reason. Instead, the lowest three quiz scores will be dropped automatically for each student so that you won't have to take a zero on a quiz if you miss one or two due to being sick, having your internet go out at the last moment, etc. So, please do not contact your professor and ask for an extension if you miss an online lecture quiz. It may seem that there is no harm in asking, but it gets really tough for your professor to have to write back individually to several students after every quiz explaining that they won't get an extension because their lowest three quiz scores are being dropped for situations exactly such as theirs. questions.question: How final course grades will be determined

answers.text: is a mystery.

is described in the course syllabus. The course syllabus describes the number of points that may be earned for each course activity and lists the number of points that need to be earned in order to earn different final course grades.
is on a curve.
will be determined later in the semester.

questions.correct_answer: is described in the course syllabus. The course syllabus describes the number of points that may be earned for each course activity and lists the number of points that need to be earned in order to earn different final course grades.
questions.neutral_comments: Grades in BIOL 1009 are determined using "guaranteed point cutoffs". This means that every student in the course who earns more than a certain number of points is guaranteed to receive at least a certain letter grade. In other words, the cutoffs will NOT be raised, even if that means that every student earns a final course grade of "A". The course syllabus describes the number of points that may be earned for each course activity and lists the number of points that need to be earned (i.e. the "guaranteed point cutoffs") in order to earn different final course grades. Please note that grades are NOT curved in BIOL 1009. You can download a copy of the course syllabus from the course Canvas page.
questions.all_comments:
Grades in BIOL 1009 are determined using
                                                        "guaranteed point cutoffs". This means that every student in the
                                                        course who earns more than a certain number of points is
                                                        guaranteed to receive at least a certain letter grade. In other
                                                        words, the cutoffs will NOT be raised, even if that means that
                                                        every student earns a final course grade of "A". The course
                                                        syllabus describes the number of points that may be earned for
                                                        each course activity and lists the number of points that need to
                                                        be earned (i.e. the "guaranteed point cutoffs") in order to earn
                                                        different final course grades. Please note that grades are NOT
                                                        curved in BIOL 1009. You can download a copy of the course
                                                        syllabus from the course Canvas page.

questions.question: Studies have shown which of the following to be a particularly effective way for most students to learn new material?

answers.text: repeatedly going over their notes about the material
repeatedly going back over textbook readings about the material
repeatedly answering questions about the material

questions.correct_answer: repeatedly answering questions about the material
questions.neutral_comments: In one study, different groups of students were shown a list of vocabulary words. The students were then divided into three groups. The first group of students kept studying (reading over) the list of vocabulary words. The second group alternated between reading over the list of words and being tested on them. The third group kept being tested on the list of words. The first group of students did the worst on tests of the vocabulary words. Interestingly, the second and third groups of students did about equally well. This study suggests that repeatedly going over and over study questions is generally a more effective method of learning new material than repeatedly going over the reading (either from the textbook or from your notes). (And, going over your notes is likely to be more effective than going over the textbook).
questions.all_comments:
In one study, different groups of
                                                        students were shown a list of vocabulary words. The students
                                                        were then divided into three groups. The first group of students
                                                        kept studying (reading over) the list of vocabulary words. The
                                                        second group alternated between reading over the list of words
                                                        and being tested on them. The third group kept being tested on
                                                        the list of words. The first group of students did the worst on
                                                        tests of the vocabulary words. Interestingly, the second and
                                                        third groups of students did about equally well. This study
                                                        suggests that repeatedly going over and over study questions is
                                                        generally a more effective method of learning new material than
                                                        repeatedly going over the reading (either from the textbook or
                                                        from your notes). (And, going over your notes is likely to be
                                                        more effective than going over the textbook).

questions.question:
"Brad has blown off going to his lab session four times. Chloe got covid and, due to having covid, missed four lab sections. Chloe has a note from her doctor stating that she was too sick to attend class during all four of the lab sessions that she missed."

Assuming that both Brad and Chloe have done well on all the exams, quizzes, etc., who is on track to pass the course?

answers.text: Both Brad and Chloe are on track to pass the course.
Neither. Both Brad and Chloe are not going to pass the course.
Chloe is on track to pass. Brad is going to fail.

questions.correct_answer: Neither. Both Brad and Chloe are not going to pass the course.
questions.neutral_comments: The lab is a critical part of BIOL 1009. The only way to get the lab experience is to be present in lab. For that reason, to pass the course students may miss no more than three lab sessions for ANY reason.
questions.all_comments:
The lab is a critical part of BIOL 1009.
                                                        The only way to get the lab experience is to be present in lab.
                                                        For that reason, to pass the course students may miss no more
                                                        than three lab sessions for ANY reason.

questions.question:
Scholastic dishonesty, such as cheating on exams or plagiarism, is not tolerated in this course. BIOL 1009 is a required course for almost all students taking it. This means that the information covered in the course is information students will likely need to be successful in their future careers. As a result, committing scholastic dishonesty in this course is not only dis-honorable, but is also likely to negatively impact students' future careers.

Because scholastic dishonesty is not tolerated in this course, students found to have committed scholastic dishonesty, such as cheating on an exam:

answers.text: will receive a grade of "0" on the exam or assignment affected by the dishonesty and will be reported to the university's Office of Community Standards.
will be given a second chance if they promise not to do it again.
will be given an opportunity to make up some or all of the points they lost by getting a "0" on an exam or other assignment.

questions.correct_answer: will receive a grade of "0" on the exam or assignment affected by the dishonesty and will be reported to the university's Office of Community Standards.
questions.neutral_comments: Integrity is taken seriously in this course. The minimum penalty for students caught cheating or committing some other form of scholastic dishonesty will be a grade of "0" on the assignment or exam in question, with no second chances or opportunities to make up any of the lost points. In addition, 100% of students caught cheating or committing some other form of scholastic dishonesty will be reported to the UMN Office of Community Standards.
questions.all_comments:
Integrity is taken seriously in this
                                                        course. The minimum penalty for students caught cheating or
                                                        committing some other form of scholastic dishonesty will be a
                                                        grade of "0" on the assignment or exam in question, with no
                                                        second chances or opportunities to make up any of the lost
                                                        points. In addition, 100% of students caught cheating or
                                                        committing some other form of scholastic dishonesty will be
                                                        reported to the UMN Office of Community Standards.

questions.question: Which of the following looks like a good study plan for an average student hoping to earn an above average grade of "B" or "A" in the course?

answers.text: For each topic, first spend ~1 hour doing the assigned reading and going over the handout while looking at the powerpoints for that that topic. Then, watch the recordings for each topic. Next, spend ~30 minutes reviewing the handouts/powerpoints and your notes from the recordings. As soon as possible after completing the above, spend ~1 hour answering study questions on the topic. Later in the week, spend at least 3 hours answering study questions or quizzes for all the topics covered up to that time.

For each topic, first spend ~1 hour doing the assigned reading and going over the handout while looking at the powerpoints for that that topic. Then, watch the recordings for each topic. Next, spend ~30 minutes reviewing the handouts/powerpoints and your notes from the recordings. As soon as possible after completing the above, spend ~1 hour answering study questions on the topic. Later in the week, spend at least 1.5 hours answering study questions or quizzes for all the topics covered up to that time.
answers.comment: This is unlikely to be enough time spent studying outside of class for an average student to earn a grade of "B" or "A".

questions.correct_answer: For each topic, first spend ~1 hour doing the assigned reading and going over the handout while looking at the powerpoints for that that topic. Then, watch the recordings for each topic. Next, spend ~30 minutes reviewing the handouts/powerpoints and your notes from the recordings. As soon as possible after completing the above, spend ~1 hour answering study questions on the topic. Later in the week, spend at least 3 hours answering study questions or quizzes for all the topics covered up to that time.
questions.all_comments:
This is unlikely to be
                                                                        enough time spent studying outside of class for
                                                                        an average student to earn a grade of "B" or
                                                                        "A".

questions.question: When a reversible chemical reaction reaches equilibrium,

answers.text: the forward and reverse reactions stop
the relative concentrations of reactants and products continues to change
the concentrations of reactants and products are equal
the forward and reverse reactions occur at the same rate

questions.correct_answer: the forward and reverse reactions occur at the same rate
questions.neutral_comments: At equilibrium, the forward and reverse reactions occur at the same rate. This does not mean that the concentrations of reactants and products are equal. Typically one will be significantly higher than the other. But, the relative concentrations of the reactants and products will cease to change. For example, if A and B are converted to C and D, and C and D are converted to A and B in the reverse reaction, then equilibrium is reached when the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D is the same as the rate of conversion of C and D to A and B. If the reaction of A and B to form C and D is more energetically favorable than the reaction of C and D to form A and B, equilibrium may not be reached until the concentrations of C and D are significantly higher than the concentrations of A and B. At that point, even though individual molecules of A and B may be more likely to react to form molecules of C and D, because there are so many more molecules of C and D the rate at which molecules of C and D are converted to A and B becomes the same as the rate at which molecules of A and B are converted to C and D. For example, imagine a test tube in which there are 1,000 molecules each of A and B and that 10% of them interact per minute to form C and D. That would mean that the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D is 100 per minute. If the there are 10,000 molecules each of C and D in the test tube and 1% of them react per minute to form A and B, the rate of conversion of C and D to A and B would also be 100 per minute, indicating that the system is at equilibrium. If you removed some of the molecules of C and D from the test tube, right after you removed the C and D the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D would be unchanged, but the rate of conversion of C and D would decrease. So, the system would no longer be at equilibrium as the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D would be higher than the rate of conversion of C and D to A and B. Because of this, the relative concentrations of A and B versus C and D would also be changing, with C and D increasing relative to A and B. Eventually, the concentrations of C and D would increase enough and the concentrations of A and B would decrease enough so that the rates of the forward and reverse reactions would become equal, meaning that equilibrium would be re-established.
questions.all_comments: Good work!At equilibrium, the forward and reverse reactions occur at the same rate. This does not mean that the concentrations of reactants and products are equal. Typically one will be significantly higher than the other. But, the relative concentrations of the reactants and products will cease to change. For example, if A and B are converted to C and D, and C and D are converted to A and B in the reverse reaction, then equilibrium is reached when the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D is the same as the rate of conversion of C and D to A and B. If the reaction of A and B to form C and D is more energetically favorable than the reaction of C and D to form A and B, equilibrium may not be reached until the concentrations of C and D are significantly higher than the concentrations of A and B. At that point, even though individual molecules of A and B may be more likely to react to form molecules of C and D, because there are so many more molecules of C and D the rate at which molecules of C and D are converted to A and B becomes the same as the rate at which molecules of A and B are converted to C and D. For example, imagine a test tube in which there are 1,000 molecules each of A and B and that 10% of them interact per minute to form C and D. That would mean that the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D is 100 per minute. If the there are 10,000 molecules each of C and D in the test tube and 1% of them react per minute to form A and B, the rate of conversion of C and D to A and B would also be 100 per minute, indicating that the system is at equilibrium. If you removed some of the molecules of C and D from the test tube, right after you removed the C and D the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D would be unchanged, but the rate of conversion of C and D would decrease. So, the system would no longer be at equilibrium as the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D would be higher than the rate of conversion of C and D to A and B. Because of this, the relative concentrations of A and B versus C and D would also be changing, with C and D increasing relative to A and B. Eventually, the concentrations of C and D would increase enough and the concentrations of A and B would decrease enough so that the rates of the forward and reverse reactions would become equal, meaning that equilibrium would be re-established.

questions.question: Discovery science

answers.text: focuses on testing predictions
focuses on formulating hypotheses
focuses on answering specific questions
focuses on accurately describing natural structures or processes

questions.correct_answer: focuses on accurately describing natural structures or processes
questions.neutral_comments: Discovery science describes natural structures and processes as accurately as possible through careful observations and data analysis. Discovery science does NOT involve formulating hypotheses, making predictions based on those hypotheses and then testing those predictions. That is part of the process followed when doing hypothesis-based science.
questions.all_comments:
Good job!Discovery science describes natural structures
and processes as accurately as possible through careful observations and data
analysis. Discovery science does NOT involve formulating hypotheses, making
predictions based on those hypotheses and then testing those predictions. That
is part of the process followed when doing hypothesis-based science.

questions.question: Experimentation is only one part of the process of scientific inquiry, but it is a very important step because it

answers.text: gives the investigator a systematic, unbiased result
allows rejection of a hypothesis
ensures that the variable being tested is measured without error
ensures that hypotheses can be confirmed with certainty

questions.correct_answer: allows rejection of a hypothesis
questions.neutral_comments: Experiments are designed to test predictions. The prediction being tested is based on a hypothesis. Therefore, if the prediction is shown to be false, that result indicates that the hypothesis on which the prediction was based is also false. Carrying out experiments does not ensure that a hypothesis will be supported. Because hypotheses are only POSSIBLE answers to questions, many hypotheses turn out to be incorrect. In addition, it is not possible to prove that a hypothesis is correct as there will always be alternative explanations for why testing showed that a particular prediction was correct. Experiments don’t necessarily give investigators systematic unbiased results; it depends on how the experiments are designed and conducted. Similarly, it is difficult or impossible to ensure that variables being tested are measured without error.
questions.all_comments: Experiments are designed to test predictions. The prediction being tested is based on a hypothesis. Therefore, if the prediction is shown to be false, that result indicates that the hypothesis on which the prediction was based is also false. Carrying out experiments does not ensure that a hypothesis will be supported. Because hypotheses are only POSSIBLE answers to questions, many hypotheses turn out to be incorrect. In addition, it is not possible to prove that a hypothesis is correct as there will always be alternative explanations for why testing showed that a particular prediction was correct. Experiments don’t necessarily give investigators systematic unbiased results; it depends on how the experiments are designed and conducted. Similarly, it is difficult or impossible to ensure that variables being tested are measured without error.

questions.question: A hypothesis

answers.text: can NOT be proven to be correct or incorrect, regardless of experimental results
can be proven to be correct
can be proven to be correct or incorrect, depending on experimental results
can NOT be proven to be correct

questions.correct_answer: can NOT be proven to be correct
questions.neutral_comments: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is correct. Instead the results of tests (experiments) may only show that a particular hypothesis is false. For example, if your hypothesis for why a flashlight isn’t working is that the batteries are dead, you might predict that replacing the batteries will fix the flashlight. If you then test your prediction by replacing the batteries and find that the flashlight still does not work, you have disproven your original prediction that replacing the batteries would fix the flashlight and have thus shown your hypothesis to be incorrect (false). However, if the flashlight works after you replace the batteries, that finding does not prove that your hypothesis was correct. This is because you can still come up with alternative hypotheses for why the flashlight now works. For example, you could hypothesize that the reason the flashlight wasn’t working previously was because the original batteries were inserted incorrectly. Then, when you replaced the batteries, you inserted the new batteries correctly and so fixed the flashlight. If that is the case, then your original hypothesis that the old batteries were dead would be false. The bottom line is that we can never rule out that there might be a different hypothesis that also explains all of the available experimental results and that is actually the correct hypothesis.
questions.all_comments:
Good job!It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is
correct. Instead the results of tests (experiments) may only show that a
particular hypothesis is false. For example, if your hypothesis for why a
flashlight isn’t working is that the batteries are dead, you might predict that
replacing the batteries will fix the flashlight. If you then test your
prediction by replacing the batteries and find that the flashlight still does
not work, you have disproven your original prediction that replacing the batteries
would fix the flashlight and have thus shown your hypothesis to be incorrect
(false). However, if the flashlight works after you replace the batteries, that
finding does not prove that your hypothesis was correct. This is because you
can still come up with alternative hypotheses for why the flashlight now works.
For example, you could hypothesize that the reason the flashlight wasn’t
working previously was because the original batteries were inserted
incorrectly. Then, when you replaced the batteries, you inserted the new
batteries correctly and so fixed the flashlight. If that is the case, then your
original hypothesis that the old batteries were dead would be false. The bottom
line is that we can never rule out that there might be a different hypothesis
that also explains all of the available experimental results and that is
actually the correct hypothesis.

questions.question: What is the pH of an aqueous solution with a hydroxyl ion [OH<sup>-</sup>] concentration of 10<sup>-12 </sup>M?

answers.text: pH 2
pH 12
pH 10
pH 4

questions.correct_answer: pH 2
questions.neutral_comments: Remember that the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature). So, if the hydroxyl ion concentration is 10-12, the hydrogen ion concentration must be 10-14/10-12 = 10-2. The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration. The base 10 logarithm of 10-2 is -2, so the negative logarithm of 10-2 is 2. Therefore, the pH of this solution is 2.
questions.all_comments: Remember that the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature).  So, if the hydroxyl ion concentration is 10-12, the hydrogen ion concentration must be 10-14/10-12 = 10-2.  The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration.  The base 10 logarithm of 10-2 is -2, so the negative logarithm of 10-2 is 2.  Therefore, the pH of this solution is 2.

questions.correct_answer: 0.01 moles/liter
questions.neutral_comments: The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter. In other words, pH = - log [H+]. So, in this case: 12 = - log [H+]. Or, -12 = log [H+]. Or, 10-12 M = [H+]. Furthermore, the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature). So, if the hydrogen ion concentration is 10-12M (moles per liter), the hydroxyl ion concentration must be 10-14/10-12= 10-2 M, or 0.01 M, or 0.01 moles/liter.
questions.all_comments: The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter.  In other words, pH = - log [H+].  So, in this case:  12 = - log [H+].  Or, -12 = log [H+].  Or, 10-12 M = [H+].  Furthermore, the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature).  So, if the hydrogen ion concentration is 10-12M (moles per liter), the hydroxyl ion concentration must be 10-14/10-12= 10-2 M, or 0.01 M, or 0.01 moles/liter.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about valence shells is FALSE?

answers.text: Electrons in the valence shell (i.e. valence electrons) are primarily responsible for the chemical behavior of atoms.
The valence shell is the outermost electron shell of an atom.
The number of valence shells contained by a particular atom is dependent on how many electrons that atom has.
The valence shell is the highest energy electron shell an atom has.

questions.correct_answer: The number of valence shells contained by a particular atom is dependent on how many electrons that atom has.
questions.neutral_comments: Each atom has only one valence shell, corresponding to its outermost electron shell. Because the electrons in the valence shell are the outermost electrons and the energy level of an electron increases the further it is from the nucleus, the valence shell is the highest energy electron shell an atom has. Also, because atoms react to complete their valence shells, the valence electrons are primarily responsible for the chemical behavior of atoms.
questions.all_comments: Good job!Each atom has only one valence shell, corresponding to its outermost electron shell. Because the electrons in the valence shell are the outermost electrons and the energy level of an electron increases the further it is from the nucleus, the valence shell is the highest energy electron shell an atom has. Also, because atoms react to complete their valence shells, the valence electrons are primarily responsible for the chemical behavior of atoms.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about chemical reactions is FALSE?

answers.text: When hydrogen and oxygen combine to form water, the hydrogen and oxygen molecules are the “reactants” of the reaction.
When hydrogen and oxygen combine to form water, the water molecules are the “products” of the reaction.
Chemical reactions may only proceed in one direction.
Chemical reactions involve the making and breaking of chemical bonds.

questions.correct_answer: Chemical reactions may only proceed in one direction.
questions.all_comments: Good work!

form an electrical bond

questions.question: When an electron is moved further from the nucleus

answers.text: its potential energy may change, depending on how the electron was moved
its potential energy is unchanged
it loses potential energy
it gains potential energy

questions.correct_answer: it gains potential energy
questions.neutral_comments: The further an electron is from the nucleus, the greater its potential energy. Think of it this way. Negatively charged electrons are attracted to the positively charged protons in the nucleus. So, it takes work to increase the separation between an electron and the nucleus. Some of the energy spent in doing this work is stored in the form of increasing the potential energy of the moved electron. This is conceptually similar to increasing the potential energy of a ball by carrying it higher up a hill.
questions.all_comments: Good job!The further an electron is from the nucleus, the greater its potential energy.  Think of it this way. Negatively charged electrons are attracted to the positively charged protons in the nucleus.  So, it takes work to increase the separation between an electron and the nucleus.  Some of the energy spent in doing this work is stored in the form of increasing the potential energy of the moved electron.  This is conceptually similar to increasing the potential energy of a ball by carrying it higher up a hill.

questions.question: Electrons exist only at fixed levels of potential energy. However, if an atom absorbs sufficient energy, a possible result is that

answers.text: an electron may move to an electron shell closer to the nucleus.
the atom would become a negatively charged ion, or anion.
the atom may become a radioactive isotope.
an electron may move to an electron shell farther away from the nucleus.

questions.correct_answer: an electron may move to an electron shell farther away from the nucleus.
questions.all_comments: Nice job!Remember that the further an electron is from the nucleus, the more energy it has.  So, if an electron absorbs a sufficient amount of energy, it may be able to move to an electron shell that is further from the nucleus than the normal electron shell that would be occupied by that electron.

questions.question:
What would be the sequence of the DNA molecule made using the following DNA strand as a template?

5’ TCTGAA 3’

answers.text: 5’ TTCAGA 3’
5’AGACTT 3’
5’ AGACUU 3’
5’ UUCAGA 3’

questions.correct_answer: 5’ TTCAGA 3’
questions.neutral_comments: First, remember that nucleic acid strands bind to each other with an anti-parallel orientation. In other words, they bind so that the 5’ end of one strand is hydrogen bonded to the 3’ end of the other strand. Also, remember that U (for RNA) or T (for DNA) hydrogen bonds with A, and G hydrogen bonds with C. So, you have: DNA 5’ TCTGAA 3’DNA 3’ AGACTT 5’ If you then follow the convention of writing nucleic acid molecules down starting at their 5’ end, the sequence for the RNA molecule is: 5’ TTCAGA 3’
questions.all_comments: First, remember that nucleic acid strands bind to each other with an anti-parallel orientation.  In other words, they bind so that the 5’ end of one strand is hydrogen bonded to the 3’ end of the other strand.  Also, remember that U (for RNA) or T (for DNA) hydrogen bonds with A, and G hydrogen bonds with C.  So, you have: DNA                5’ TCTGAA 3’DNA                3’ AGACTT 5’ If you then follow the convention of writing nucleic acid molecules down starting at their 5’ end, the sequence for the RNA molecule is: 5’ TTCAGA 3’

questions.question: Lipids that contain one or more C=C double bonds are referred to as

answers.text: triacylglycerols
unsaturated fats
phospholipids
saturated fats

questions.correct_answer: unsaturated fats
questions.neutral_comments: Lipids that contain one or more C=C double bonds are referred to as unsaturated fats or lipids. Triacylglycerols are made by attaching three fatty acid molecules to a glycerol molecule. The fatty acids used in synthesis of triacylglycerols may or may not contain C=C double bonds. Similarly, phospholipids contain two fatty acid molecules, a glycerol molecule and a head group. The fatty acids used in synthesis of phospholipids may or may not contain C=C double bonds.
questions.all_comments: Nice job!Lipids that contain one or more C=C double bonds are referred to as unsaturated fats or lipids. Triacylglycerols are made by attaching three fatty acid molecules to a glycerol molecule. The fatty acids used in synthesis of triacylglycerols may or may not contain C=C double bonds. Similarly, phospholipids contain two fatty acid molecules, a glycerol molecule and a head group. The fatty acids used in synthesis of phospholipids may or may not contain C=C double bonds.

questions.question: How many water molecules are needed to completely hydrolyze a polymer that is 18 nucleotides long?
questions.neutral_comments: Think of it this way: How many water molecules would be needed to completely hydrolyze a “polymer” that is just two nucleotides long? You would need just one, to split the one bond joining the two monomers, right? So, how many water molecules would you need to completely hydrolyze a “polymer” that is 3 monomers long? The answer is that you would need 2 water molecules, one to split the bond between the 1stand 2nd monomers and the other to hydrolyze the bond between the 2ndand 3rd monomers. So, you to completely hydrolyze a polymer takes one less water molecule than the number of monomers in the polymer.
questions.all_comments: Good work!Think of it this way: How many water molecules would be needed to completely hydrolyze a “polymer” that is just two nucleotides long?  You would need just one, to split the one bond joining the two monomers, right?  So, how many water molecules would you need to completely hydrolyze a “polymer” that is 3 monomers long?  The answer is that you would need 2 water molecules, one to split the bond between the 1stand 2nd monomers and the other to hydrolyze the bond between the 2ndand 3rd monomers.  So, you to completely hydrolyze a polymer takes one less water molecule than the number of monomers in the polymer.

questions.question: If two molecules have the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures, the two molecules may be

answers.text: Enantiomers
Geometric isomers
All of these answers are correct
Structural isomers

questions.correct_answer: All of these answers are correct
questions.neutral_comments: Isomers of any type (structural isomers, geometric isomers and enantiomers) all meet the criteria of having the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures. Structural isomers have the further criteria that, for two molecules to be structural isomers of each other, they must differ in their covalent partnerships. In contrast, molecules that are geometric isomers or enantiomers do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships. Geometric isomers differ in the arrangement of atoms around a double bond. Enantiomers differ in the arrangement of atoms covalently bound to a central, asymmetric carbon and are mirror images of each other. Please see figure 4.7 in your textbook for a figure showing all three types of isomer.
questions.all_comments: Good work!Isomers of any type (structural isomers, geometric isomers and enantiomers) all meet the criteria of having the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures.  Structural isomers have the further criteria that, for two molecules to be structural isomers of each other, they must differ in their covalent partnerships.  In contrast, molecules that are geometric isomers or enantiomers do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships.  Geometric isomers differ in the arrangement of atoms around a double bond.  Enantiomers differ in the arrangement of atoms covalently bound to a central, asymmetric carbon and are mirror images of each other.  Please see figure 4.7 in your textbook for a figure showing all three types of isomer.

questions.question: If you were asked to build a polymer that is 20 monomers long (note that this would be an unusually short polymer), and you could use four different types of monomers, “A”, “B”, “C” and “D”, how many different polymers could you build?

answers.text: ~ 1 million

questions.neutral_comments: Think of it this way: If you were asked to build a polymer that was just one monomer long (ok, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and you had only “A” and “B” monomers available to use, you would be able to build just two different “polymers”: A and B. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 2 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and had only “A” and “B” monomers available, you would be able to build just 4 different “polymers”: AA, AB, BA and BB. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 3 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and had only “A” and “B” monomers available, you would be able to build just 8 different “polymers”: AAA, AAB, ABA, BAA, ABB, BAB. BBA and BBB. Are you seeing a pattern here? The answer to this type of question may be found using the following formula: Number of different polymers that may be formed = XY, where “X” is the number of different types of monomers available and “Y” is the number of monomers in the polymer. So, if you were asked to build a polymer that is 20 monomers long, and you could use four different types of monomers, the number of different polymers you could build would be: 420 = ~ 1 x 1012
questions.all_comments: Nice job!Think of it this way: If you were asked to build a polymer that was just one monomer long (ok, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and you had only “A” and “B” monomers available to use, you would be able to build just two different “polymers”: A and B.  If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 2 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and had only “A” and “B” monomers available, you would be able to build just 4 different “polymers”: AA, AB, BA and BB. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 3 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and had only “A” and “B” monomers available, you would be able to build just 8 different “polymers”: AAA, AAB, ABA, BAA, ABB, BAB. BBA and BBB.  Are you seeing a pattern here?  The answer to this type of question may be found using the following formula: Number of different polymers that may be formed = XY, where “X” is the number of different types of monomers available and “Y” is the number of monomers in the polymer.  So, if you were asked to build a polymer that is 20 monomers long, and you could use four different types of monomers, the number of different polymers you could build would be: 420 = ~ 1 x 1012

questions.question: Glucose and fructose are examples of

answers.text: geometric isomers
stereoisomers
all of these answers are correct
structural isomers

questions.correct_answer: structural isomers
questions.neutral_comments: Glucose and fructose have the same molecular formula (C6H12O6), but different shapes, so you can see that they are isomers of some sort. To determine what type of isomers they represent, first look to see if the two molecules (glucose and fructose), share the same covalent partnerships. If you look at them, you will see that they do not share the same covalent partnerships. For example, the position of the carbon:oxygen double bond (C=O) is different for glucose and fructose. This means that glucose and fructose are examples of structural isomers. The other two types of isomers we studied, geometric isomers and enantiomers, do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships.
questions.all_comments: Nice job!Glucose and fructose have the same molecular formula (C6H12O6), but different shapes, so you can see that they are isomers of some sort.  To determine what type of isomers they represent, first look to see if the two molecules (glucose and fructose), share the same covalent partnerships.  If you look at them, you will see that they do not share the same covalent partnerships. For example, the position of the carbon:oxygen double bond (C=O) is different for glucose and fructose.  This means that glucose and fructose are examples of structural isomers.  The other two types of isomers we studied, geometric isomers and enantiomers, do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships.

questions.question: The molecules shown below are best described as

answers.text: Geometric isomers
Isotopes
Structural isomers
Enantiomers

questions.correct_answer: Geometric isomers
questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C2N2O2H2), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers. For example, both carbon atoms in both molecules are attached to one N=O group and one hydrogen atom. However, the two molecules do have different structures. Remember that double covalent bonds are inflexible. So, the above molecules cannot rotate around their double bonds in the way that they could if the two carbon atoms were only joined by single covalent bonds. So, in the molecule on the left, the two N=O groups will always be on the opposite sides of the double bond, whereas the two N=O groups will always be on the same side of the double bond in the molecule on the right. Molecules such as these two, which have the same covalent partnerships but different spatial arrangements, are known as geometric isomers. The molecule on the left, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the N=O groups) on opposite sides of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a trans isomer. The molecule on the right, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the N=O groups) on the same side of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a cis isomer.
questions.all_comments: Good work!These two molecules have the same formula (C2N2O2H2), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but different 3-dimensional shapes.  So, they are isomers of some sort.  Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers.  For example, both carbon atoms in both molecules are attached to one N=O group and one hydrogen atom.  However, the two molecules do have different structures.  Remember that double covalent bonds are inflexible.  So, the above molecules cannot rotate around their double bonds in the way that they could if the two carbon atoms were only joined by single covalent bonds.  So, in the molecule on the left, the two N=O groups will always be on the opposite sides of the double bond, whereas the two N=O groups will always be on the same side of the double bond in the molecule on the right.  Molecules such as these two, which have the same covalent partnerships but different spatial arrangements, are known as geometric isomers.  The molecule on the left, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the N=O groups) on opposite sides of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a trans isomer.  The molecule on the right, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the N=O groups) on the same side of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a cis isomer.

questions.question: If two molecules are mirror images of each other, the two molecules may be

answers.text: Structural isomers
Enantiomers or geometric isomers
Enantiomers
Geometric isomers

questions.correct_answer: Enantiomers
questions.neutral_comments: Isomers of any type (structural isomers, geometric isomers and enantiomers) must all meet the criteria of having the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures. Structural isomers have the further criteria that, for two molecules to be structural isomers of each other, they must differ in their covalent partnerships. In contrast, molecules that are geometric isomers or enantiomers do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships. Geometric isomers differ in the arrangement of atoms around a double bond. Enantiomers differ in the arrangement of atoms covalently bound to a central, asymmetric carbon and are mirror images of each other. Please see figure 4.7 in your textbook for a figure showing all three types of isomer.
questions.all_comments: Good work!Isomers of any type (structural isomers, geometric isomers and enantiomers) must all meet the criteria of having the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures.  Structural isomers have the further criteria that, for two molecules to be structural isomers of each other, they must differ in their covalent partnerships.  In contrast, molecules that are geometric isomers or enantiomers do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships.  Geometric isomers differ in the arrangement of atoms around a double bond.  Enantiomers differ in the arrangement of atoms covalently bound to a central, asymmetric carbon and are mirror images of each other.  Please see figure 4.7 in your textbook for a figure showing all three types of isomer.

questions.question: The molecules shown below are best described as

answers.text: Geometric isomers
Enantiomers
Structural isomers
Isotopes

questions.correct_answer: Geometric isomers
questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but have different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers. For example, both carbon atoms in both molecules are attached to one hydroxyl (OH) group and one hydrogen atom. However, the two molecules do have different structures. Remember that double covalent bonds are inflexible. So, the above molecules cannot rotate around their double bonds in the way that they could if the two carbon atoms were only joined by single covalent bonds. So, in the molecule on the left, the two hydroxyl (OH) groups will always be on the opposite sides of the double bond, whereas the two hydroxyl groups will always be on the same side of the double bond in the molecule on the right. Molecules such as these two, which have the same covalent partnerships but different spatial arrangements, are known as geometric isomers. The molecule on the left, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the hydroxyl groups) on opposite sides of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a trans isomer. The molecule on the right, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the hydroxyl groups) on the same side of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a cis isomer.
questions.all_comments: Good work!These two molecules have the same formula (C2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but have different 3-dimensional shapes.  So, they are isomers of some sort.  Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers.  For example, both carbon atoms in both molecules are attached to one hydroxyl (OH) group and one hydrogen atom.  However, the two molecules do have different structures.  Remember that double covalent bonds are inflexible.  So, the above molecules cannot rotate around their double bonds in the way that they could if the two carbon atoms were only joined by single covalent bonds.  So, in the molecule on the left, the two hydroxyl (OH) groups will always be on the opposite sides of the double bond, whereas the two hydroxyl groups will always be on the same side of the double bond in the molecule on the right.  Molecules such as these two, which have the same covalent partnerships but different spatial arrangements, are known as geometric isomers.  The molecule on the left, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the hydroxyl groups) on opposite sides of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a trans isomer.  The molecule on the right, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the hydroxyl groups) on the same side of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a cis isomer.

questions.question: If you were asked to build a polymer that is 20 monomers long (note that this would be an unusually short polymer), and you could use four different types of monomers, “A”, “B”, “C” and “D”, how many different polymers could you build?

answers.text: ~ 1 million

questions.neutral_comments: Think of it this way: If you were asked to build a polymer that was just one monomer long (ok, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and you had only “A” and “B” monomers available to use, you would be able to build just two different “polymers”: A and B. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 2 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and had only “A” and “B” monomers available, you would be able to build just 4 different “polymers”: AA, AB, BA and BB. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 3 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and had only “A” and “B” monomers available, you would be able to build just 8 different “polymers”: AAA, AAB, ABA, BAA, ABB, BAB. BBA and BBB. Are you seeing a pattern here? The answer to this type of question may be found using the following formula: Number of different polymers that may be formed = XY, where “X” is the number of different types of monomers available and “Y” is the number of monomers in the polymer. So, if you were asked to build a polymer that is 20 monomers long, and you could use four different types of monomers, the number of different polymers you could build would be: 420 = ~ 1 x 1012
questions.all_comments: Nice job!Think of it this way: If you were asked to build a polymer that was just one monomer long (ok, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and you had only “A” and “B” monomers available to use, you would be able to build just two different “polymers”: A and B.  If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 2 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and had only “A” and “B” monomers available, you would be able to build just 4 different “polymers”: AA, AB, BA and BB. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 3 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and had only “A” and “B” monomers available, you would be able to build just 8 different “polymers”: AAA, AAB, ABA, BAA, ABB, BAB. BBA and BBB.  Are you seeing a pattern here?  The answer to this type of question may be found using the following formula: Number of different polymers that may be formed = XY, where “X” is the number of different types of monomers available and “Y” is the number of monomers in the polymer.  So, if you were asked to build a polymer that is 20 monomers long, and you could use four different types of monomers, the number of different polymers you could build would be: 420 = ~ 1 x 1012

questions.question: If starch and cellulose are both polymers of glucose, how come people can digest starch but not cellulose?

answers.text: When glucose monomers are joined by dehydration reactions to form cellulose, the glucose monomers are converted into non-sugar molecules that are impossible for us to digest.
When glucose monomers are joined by dehydration reactions to form cellulose, the glucose monomers are converted into xylose molecules that are impossible for us to digest.

The glucose monomers that form starch are joined together by different covalent bonds than the glucose monomers that form cellulose and the enzymes in our bodies that are able to hydrolyze (break) the covalent bonds between the glucose monomers in starch are not able to hydrolyze the covalent bonds between the glucose monomers in cellulose.
When glucose monomers are joined by dehydration reactions to form cellulose, the glucose monomers are converted into lactose molecules, which are hard for many people to digest.

questions.correct_answer: The glucose monomers that form starch are joined together by different covalent bonds than the glucose monomers that form cellulose and the enzymes in our bodies that are able to hydrolyze (break) the covalent bonds between the glucose monomers in starch are not able to hydrolyze the covalent bonds between the glucose monomers in cellulose.
questions.all_comments: Nice job!

Which of the molecules listed below can form isomers?

CH4

C4H10

All of them can form isomers

To see this, try drawing C3H8 molecules with different structures, remembering that each molecule you draw must have 3 carbon atoms and 8 hydrogen atoms and that each carbon atom must form 4 covalent bonds and each hydrogen atom must form 1 covalent bond. You will find that you can only draw one structure. In contrast, C4H10 can form isomers. For example, the two molecules shown below are structural isomers of C4H10.

questions.question: The molecules shown below are best described as

answers.text: Enantiomers
Geometric isomers
Structural isomers
Isotopes

questions.correct_answer: Enantiomers
questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C3N2O2H3), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers. In addition, because these molecules do not have 2 carbon atoms joined by a double bond, they cannot be geometric isomers. Instead, they are “enantiomers”. Enantiomers are mirror images of each other and cannot be superimposed on each other. This is quite similar to how our hands are mirror images of each other, but cannot be superimposed on each other. For example, imagine the palms of your hands as being carbon atom and the four fingers on each hand representing covalent bonds to 4 different groups. There is no way to place one hand on the other hand so that all four of your fingers will match up. Note that enantiomers only occur in molecules that have an asymmetric carbon. For a carbon to be asymmetric, it must form covalent bonds to 4 different groups. In the molecule on the left above, the asymmetric carbon is the carbon furthest to the left. In the molecule on the right above, the asymmetric carbon is the carbon furthest to the right.
questions.all_comments: Good work!These two molecules have the same formula (C3N2O2H3), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but different 3-dimensional shapes.  So, they are isomers of some sort.  Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers. In addition, because these molecules do not have 2 carbon atoms joined by a double bond, they cannot be geometric isomers.  Instead, they are “enantiomers”.  Enantiomers are mirror images of each other and cannot be superimposed on each other.  This is quite similar to how our hands are mirror images of each other, but cannot be superimposed on each other.  For example, imagine the palms of your hands as being carbon atom and the four fingers on each hand representing covalent bonds to 4 different groups.  There is no way to place one hand on the other hand so that all four of your fingers will match up.  Note that enantiomers only occur in molecules that have an asymmetric carbon.  For a carbon to be asymmetric, it must form covalent bonds to 4 different groups.  In the molecule on the left above, the asymmetric carbon is the carbon furthest to the left.  In the molecule on the right above, the asymmetric carbon is the carbon furthest to the right.

questions.question:
What would be the sequence of the RNA molecule made using the following DNA strand as a template?

5’ AATTCGC 3’

answers.text: 5’ GCGAAUU 3’
5’ UUAAGCG 3’
5’ TTAAGCG 3’
5’ GCGAATT 3’

questions.correct_answer: 5’ GCGAAUU 3’
questions.neutral_comments: First, remember that nucleic acid strands bind to each other with an anti-parallel orientation. In other words, they bind so that the 5’ end of one strand is hydrogen bonded to the 3’ end of the other strand. Also, remember that U (for RNA) or T (for DNA) hydrogen bonds with A, and G hydrogen bonds with C. So, you have: DNA 5’ AATTCGC 3’RNA 3’ UUAAGCG 5’ If you then follow the convention of writing nucleic acid molecules down starting at their 5’ end, the sequence for the RNA molecule is: 5’ GCGAAUU 3’
questions.all_comments: First, remember that nucleic acid strands bind to each other with an anti-parallel orientation.  In other words, they bind so that the 5’ end of one strand is hydrogen bonded to the 3’ end of the other strand.  Also, remember that U (for RNA) or T (for DNA) hydrogen bonds with A, and G hydrogen bonds with C.  So, you have: DNA                5’ AATTCGC 3’RNA                3’ UUAAGCG 5’ If you then follow the convention of writing nucleic acid molecules down starting at their 5’ end, the sequence for the RNA molecule is: 5’ GCGAAUU 3’

questions.question: Identify the asymmetric carbon in this molecule

answers.text: It is the 1st carbon on the left

questions.correct_answer: It is the 2nd carbon from the left
questions.neutral_comments: Asymmetric carbons are carbons that are covalently bonded to 4 different groups. The 1st carbon on the left in this molecule is bonded to only 3 different groups (a hydrogen atom, an oxygen atom and a hydrocarbon chain). The 3rd carbon is also bonded to only 3 different groups (two hydrogen atoms, a short hydrocarbon chain and the part of the molecule that is to the left of that carbon atom). The 4th carbon from the left is only bound to 3 different groups (2 hydrogen atoms, a methyl group and the rest of the molecule that is to the left of the 4th carbon). The 5th (last) carbon from the left is only bonded to 2 different groups as it forms covalent bonds with 3 hydrogen atoms and the rest of the molecule that is to the left of the 5th carbon. In contrast, the 2nd carbon from the left is bound to 4 different groups: a COH group, a hydrogen atom, an OH group and a short hydrocarbon chain. Each of the four different groups to which the second carbon from the left is bound is shown circled in red in the figure below.

questions.question: The molecules shown below are best described as

answers.text: Geometric isomers
Enantiomers
Structural isomers
Isotopes

questions.correct_answer: Geometric isomers
questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but have different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers. For example, both carbon atoms in both molecules are attached to one hydroxyl (OH) group and one hydrogen atom. However, the two molecules do have different structures. Remember that double covalent bonds are inflexible. So, the above molecules cannot rotate around their double bonds in the way that they could if the two carbon atoms were only joined by single covalent bonds. So, in the molecule on the left, the two hydroxyl (OH) groups will always be on the opposite sides of the double bond, whereas the two hydroxyl groups will always be on the same side of the double bond in the molecule on the right. Molecules such as these two, which have the same covalent partnerships but different spatial arrangements, are known as geometric isomers. The molecule on the left, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the hydroxyl groups) on opposite sides of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a trans isomer. The molecule on the right, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the hydroxyl groups) on the same side of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a cis isomer.
questions.all_comments: Good work!These two molecules have the same formula (C2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but have different 3-dimensional shapes.  So, they are isomers of some sort.  Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers.  For example, both carbon atoms in both molecules are attached to one hydroxyl (OH) group and one hydrogen atom.  However, the two molecules do have different structures.  Remember that double covalent bonds are inflexible.  So, the above molecules cannot rotate around their double bonds in the way that they could if the two carbon atoms were only joined by single covalent bonds.  So, in the molecule on the left, the two hydroxyl (OH) groups will always be on the opposite sides of the double bond, whereas the two hydroxyl groups will always be on the same side of the double bond in the molecule on the right.  Molecules such as these two, which have the same covalent partnerships but different spatial arrangements, are known as geometric isomers.  The molecule on the left, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the hydroxyl groups) on opposite sides of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a trans isomer.  The molecule on the right, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the hydroxyl groups) on the same side of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a cis isomer.

questions.question: The molecules shown below are best described as

answers.text: Geometric isomers
Structural isomers
Isotopes
Enantiomers

questions.correct_answer: Structural isomers
questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but have different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. However, despite the fact that they have a carbon-carbon double bond, they are NOT geometric isomers. Geometric isomers have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms. The pair of molecules shown above do NOT have the same covalent arrangement of their atoms. For the molecule shown on the left, each of the carbon atoms is covalently bound to one hydrogen atom and one hydroxyl (OH) group. For the molecule shown on the right, one carbon atom is covalently bound to two hydroxyl groups and the other carbon atom is covalently bound to two hydrogen atoms. So, the two molecules do not have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms. Because they differ in the covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are examples of the type of isomers known structural isomers.
questions.all_comments: Good work!These two molecules have the same formula (C2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but have different 3-dimensional shapes.  So, they are isomers of some sort.  However, despite the fact that they have a carbon-carbon double bond, they are NOT geometric isomers.  Geometric isomers have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms.  The pair of molecules shown above do NOT have the same covalent arrangement of their atoms.  For the molecule shown on the left, each of the carbon atoms is covalently bound to one hydrogen atom and one hydroxyl (OH) group.  For the molecule shown on the right, one carbon atom is covalently bound to two hydroxyl groups and the other carbon atom is covalently bound to two hydrogen atoms.  So, the two molecules do not have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms.  Because they differ in the covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are examples of the type of isomers known structural isomers.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is FALSE?

answers.text: Amino acids are the monomers from which proteins are formed.
Fatty acids are the monomers from which lipid molecules are formed.
Sugars are the monomers from which polysaccharides are formed.
Nucleotides are the monomers from which nucleic acids are formed.

questions.correct_answer: Fatty acids are the monomers from which lipid molecules are formed.
questions.neutral_comments: Fatty acids are important in lipid formation, but are not monomers as monomers are simple molecules, many of which are combined to form a polymer. In contrast, fatty acids are fairly large molecules and few of them are used to make a lipid molecule. For example, just two fatty acid molecules are used in the synthesis of a typical membrane lipid molecule (e.g. a phospholipid) and just three fatty acid molecules are used to make a typical lipid molecule in fat (e.g. a triacylglycerol molecule). In addition, monomers are linked together like cars forming a train to form a polymer. In contrast, the fatty acid molecules that are used to form lipids are not joined to each other. For example, the three fatty acid molecules used to form a triacylglycerol molecule (a type of lipid molecule) are each joined separately to different parts of a glycerol molecule. So, remember that lipids are the one type of biological macromolecule we will discuss that are NOT polymers because they are NOT composed of monomers.
questions.all_comments: Nice job!Fatty acids are important in lipid formation, but are not monomers as monomers are simple molecules, many of which are combined to form a polymer.  In contrast, fatty acids are fairly large molecules and few of them are used to make a lipid molecule.  For example, just two fatty acid molecules are used in the synthesis of a typical membrane lipid molecule (e.g. a phospholipid) and just three fatty acid molecules are used to make a typical lipid molecule in fat (e.g. a triacylglycerol molecule).  In addition, monomers are linked together like cars forming a train to form a polymer.  In contrast, the fatty acid molecules that are used to form lipids are not joined to each other.  For example, the three fatty acid molecules used to form a triacylglycerol molecule (a type of lipid molecule) are each joined separately to different parts of a glycerol molecule.  So, remember that lipids are the one type of biological macromolecule we will discuss that are NOT polymers because they are NOT composed of monomers.

To determine what type of isomers they represent, first look to see if the two molecules (glucose and fructose), share the same covalent partnerships. If you look at them, you will see that they do not share the same covalent partnerships. For example, the position of the carbon:oxygen double bond (C=O) is different for glucose and fructose. For example, the position of the carbon:oxygen double bond (C=O) is different for glucose and fructose.  This means that glucose and fructose are examples of structural isomers.  The other two types of isomers we studied, geometric isomers and enantiomers, do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships.

questions.question: If you were asked to build a polymer that is 30 monomers long, and you could use two different types of monomers, “A” and “B”, how many different polymers could you build?

answers.text: ~ 1 billion

questions.correct_answer: ~ 1 billion
questions.neutral_comments: Think of it this way: If you were asked to build a polymer that was just one monomer long (ok, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), you would be able to build just two different “polymers”: A and B. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 2 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), you would be able to build just 4 different “polymers”: AA, AB, BA and BB. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 3 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), you would be able to build just 8 different “polymers”: AAA, AAB, ABA, BAA, ABB, BAB. BBA and BBB. Are you seeing a pattern here? The answer to this type of question may be found using the following formula: Number of different polymers that may be formed = XY, where “X” is the number of different types of monomers available and “Y” is the number of monomers in the polymer. So, if you were asked to build a polymer that is 30 monomers long, and you could use two different types of monomers, “A” and “B”, the number of different polymers you could build would be: 230 = ~ 1,000,000,000
questions.all_comments: Nice job!Think of it this way: If you were asked to build a polymer that was just one monomer long (ok, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), you would be able to build just two different “polymers”: A and B.  If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 2 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), you would be able to build just 4 different “polymers”: AA, AB, BA and BB. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 3 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), you would be able to build just 8 different “polymers”: AAA, AAB, ABA, BAA, ABB, BAB. BBA and BBB. Are you seeing a pattern here? The answer to this type of question may be found using the following formula: Number of different polymers that may be formed = XY, where “X” is the number of different types of monomers available and “Y” is the number of monomers in the polymer. So, if you were asked to build a polymer that is 30 monomers long, and you could use two different types of monomers, “A” and “B”, the number of different polymers you could build would be: 230 = ~ 1,000,000,000

questions.question: When a reversible chemical reaction reaches equilibrium,

answers.text: the forward and reverse reactions occur at the same rate
the relative concentrations of reactants and products continues to change
the concentrations of reactants and products are equal
the forward and reverse reactions stop

questions.correct_answer: the forward and reverse reactions occur at the same rate
questions.neutral_comments: At equilibrium, the forward and reverse reactions occur at the same rate. This does not mean that the concentrations of reactants and products are equal. Typically one will be significantly higher than the other. But, the relative concentrations of the reactants and products will cease to change. For example, if A and B are converted to C and D, and C and D are converted to A and B in the reverse reaction, then equilibrium is reached when the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D is the same as the rate of conversion of C and D to A and B. If the reaction of A and B to form C and D is more energetically favorable than the reaction of C and D to form A and B, equilibrium may not be reached until the concentrations of C and D are significantly higher than the concentrations of A and B. At that point, even though individual molecules of A and B may be more likely to react to form molecules of C and D, because there are so many more molecules of C and D the rate at which molecules of C and D are converted to A and B becomes the same as the rate at which molecules of A and B are converted to C and D. For example, imagine a test tube in which there are 1,000 molecules each of A and B and that 10% of them interact per minute to form C and D. That would mean that the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D is 100 per minute. If the there are 10,000 molecules each of C and D in the test tube and 1% of them react per minute to form A and B, the rate of conversion of C and D to A and B would also be 100 per minute, indicating that the system is at equilibrium. If you removed some of the molecules of C and D from the test tube, right after you removed the C and D the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D would be unchanged, but the rate of conversion of C and D would decrease. So, the system would no longer be at equilibrium as the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D would be higher than the rate of conversion of C and D to A and B. Because of this, the relative concentrations of A and B versus C and D would also be changing, with C and D increasing relative to A and B. Eventually, the concentrations of C and D would increase enough and the concentrations of A and B would decrease enough so that the rates of the forward and reverse reactions would become equal, meaning that equilibrium would be re-established.
questions.all_comments: Good work!At equilibrium, the forward and reverse reactions occur at the same rate. This does not mean that the concentrations of reactants and products are equal. Typically one will be significantly higher than the other. But, the relative concentrations of the reactants and products will cease to change. For example, if A and B are converted to C and D, and C and D are converted to A and B in the reverse reaction, then equilibrium is reached when the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D is the same as the rate of conversion of C and D to A and B. If the reaction of A and B to form C and D is more energetically favorable than the reaction of C and D to form A and B, equilibrium may not be reached until the concentrations of C and D are significantly higher than the concentrations of A and B. At that point, even though individual molecules of A and B may be more likely to react to form molecules of C and D, because there are so many more molecules of C and D the rate at which molecules of C and D are converted to A and B becomes the same as the rate at which molecules of A and B are converted to C and D. For example, imagine a test tube in which there are 1,000 molecules each of A and B and that 10% of them interact per minute to form C and D. That would mean that the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D is 100 per minute. If the there are 10,000 molecules each of C and D in the test tube and 1% of them react per minute to form A and B, the rate of conversion of C and D to A and B would also be 100 per minute, indicating that the system is at equilibrium. If you removed some of the molecules of C and D from the test tube, right after you removed the C and D the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D would be unchanged, but the rate of conversion of C and D would decrease. So, the system would no longer be at equilibrium as the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D would be higher than the rate of conversion of C and D to A and B. Because of this, the relative concentrations of A and B versus C and D would also be changing, with C and D increasing relative to A and B. Eventually, the concentrations of C and D would increase enough and the concentrations of A and B would decrease enough so that the rates of the forward and reverse reactions would become equal, meaning that equilibrium would be re-established.

questions.question: A solution with a pH of 13 contains what concentration of hydroxyl ions [OH<sup>-</sup>]?

answers.text: 0.1 moles/liter
13 moles/liter
0.01 moles/liter
10-13 moles/liter

questions.correct_answer: 0.1 moles/liter
questions.neutral_comments: The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter. In other words, pH = - log [H+]. So, in this case: 13 = - log [H+]. Or, -13 = log [H+]. Or, 10-13 M = [H+]. Furthermore, the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature). So, if the hydrogen ion concentration is 10-13M (moles per liter), the hydroxyl ion concentration must be 10-14/10-13= 10-1 M, or 0.1 M, or 0.1 moles/liter.
questions.all_comments: The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter.  In other words, pH = - log [H+].  So, in this case:  13 = - log [H+].  Or, -13 = log [H+].  Or, 10-13 M = [H+].  Furthermore, the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature).  So, if the hydrogen ion concentration is 10-13M (moles per liter), the hydroxyl ion concentration must be 10-14/10-13= 10-1 M, or 0.1 M, or 0.1 moles/liter.
