questions.question: If two molecules are mirror images of each other, the two molecules may be

answers.text: Enantiomers or geometric isomers
Geometric isomers
Enantiomers
Structural isomers

questions.correct_answer: Enantiomers
questions.neutral_comments: Isomers of any type (structural isomers, geometric isomers and enantiomers) must all meet the criteria of having the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures. Structural isomers have the further criteria that, for two molecules to be structural isomers of each other, they must differ in their covalent partnerships. In contrast, molecules that are geometric isomers or enantiomers do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships. Geometric isomers differ in the arrangement of atoms around a double bond. Enantiomers differ in the arrangement of atoms covalently bound to a central, asymmetric carbon and are mirror images of each other. Please see figure 4.7 in your textbook for a figure showing all three types of isomer.
questions.all_comments: Isomers of any type (structural isomers, geometric isomers and enantiomers) must all meet the criteria of having the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures.  Structural isomers have the further criteria that, for two molecules to be structural isomers of each other, they must differ in their covalent partnerships.  In contrast, molecules that are geometric isomers or enantiomers do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships.  Geometric isomers differ in the arrangement of atoms around a double bond.  Enantiomers differ in the arrangement of atoms covalently bound to a central, asymmetric carbon and are mirror images of each other.  Please see figure 4.7 in your textbook for a figure showing all three types of isomer.

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of carrier proteins in a plasma membrane?

answers.text: All carrier proteins work against diffusion.
They always exhibit specificity for a particular type of molecule.
All carrier proteins require the expenditure of cellular energy to function.
They are peripheral membrane proteins.

questions.correct_answer: They always exhibit specificity for a particular type of molecule.
questions.neutral_comments: Some carrier proteins carry out facilitated diffusion. Facilitated diffusion is diffusion of a molecule down its concentration and/or electrical gradient that is “facilitated” by a carrier protein or channel protein that allows the molecule that is diffusing to pass more quickly through the membrane. Because the molecules being transported are moving down their concentration and/or electrical gradient, carrier proteins that act in facilitated diffusion do not require an energy expenditure. However, other carrier proteins, such as symporters and anti-porters, help carry out active transport and so do require an energy expenditure.
questions.all_comments: Some carrier proteins carry out facilitated diffusion. Facilitated diffusion is diffusion of a molecule down its concentration and/or electrical gradient that is “facilitated” by a carrier protein or channel protein that allows the molecule that is diffusing to pass more quickly through the membrane. Because the molecules being transported are moving down their concentration and/or electrical gradient, carrier proteins that act in facilitated diffusion do not require an energy expenditure. However, other carrier proteins, such as symporters and anti-porters, help carry out active transport and so do require an energy expenditure.

questions.question: An example of a hydrogen bond is the bond between:

answers.text: the H of one water molecule and the O of another water molecule
C and H in methane (CH4)
Mg+ and Cl- in MgCl2
the two hydrogen atoms in a molecule of hydrogen gas (H2)

questions.correct_answer: the H of one water molecule and the O of another water molecule
questions.neutral_comments: A hydrogen bond forms when a hydrogen covalently bonded to one electronegative atom (such as the oxygen atom in a water molecule) is also attracted to another electronegative atom (such as the oxygen atom in a second water molecule). The pair of electrons shared by the hydrogen atom and the oxygen atom to which the hydrogen atom is covalently bound will spend more time near the nucleus of the oxygen atom than near the nucleus of the hydrogen atom, as oxygen is more electronegative than hydrogen (meaning that oxygen atoms attract electrons more strongly than hydrogen atoms). As a result, the hydrogen atom will have a slight positive charge and the oxygen atom will have a slight negative charge. The slightly positively charged hydrogen atom will then be attracted to the slight positively charged oxygen of another water molecule, forming a hydrogen bond.
questions.all_comments: A hydrogen bond forms when a hydrogen covalently bonded to one electronegative atom (such as the oxygen atom in a water molecule) is also attracted to another electronegative atom (such as the oxygen atom in a second water molecule).  The pair of electrons shared by the hydrogen atom and the oxygen atom to which the hydrogen atom is covalently bound will spend more time near the nucleus of the oxygen atom than near the nucleus of the hydrogen atom, as oxygen is more electronegative than hydrogen (meaning that oxygen atoms attract electrons more strongly than hydrogen atoms).  As a result, the hydrogen atom will have a slight positive charge and the oxygen atom will have a slight negative charge.  The slightly positively charged hydrogen atom will then be attracted to the slight positively charged oxygen of another water molecule, forming a hydrogen bond.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about ribosomes is TRUE?

answers.text: Free ribosomes carry out protein synthesis while floating free in the cytosol and bound ribosomes carry out protein synthesis while attached to a membrane.

Free ribosomes are available to begin synthesizing new proteins whereas bound ribosomes are currently unavailable for synthesizing new proteins as they are already in the process of synthesizing a protein.
Free ribosomes are free to diffuse around the cytosol and bound ribosomes are confined inside the nucleus.
Bound ribosomes are attached to protein molecules whereas free ribosomes are NOT attached to protein molecules.

questions.correct_answer: Free ribosomes carry out protein synthesis while floating free in the cytosol and bound ribosomes carry out protein synthesis while attached to a membrane.
questions.neutral_comments: The terms “free” and “bound” apply to ribosomes that are floating free in the cytoplasm or are bound to the rough endoplasmic reticulum. Bound ribosomes will generally be in the process of forming a polypeptide, as the reason they are bound (attached) to the rough ER is because they are attached to the protein they are synthesizing and the protein they are synthesizing is attached to the rough ER. In contrast, a free ribosome may or may not be in the process of forming a polypeptide molecule at any given time.
questions.all_comments: The terms “free” and “bound” apply to ribosomes that are floating free in the cytoplasm or are bound to the rough endoplasmic reticulum.  Bound ribosomes will generally be in the process of forming a polypeptide, as the reason they are bound (attached) to the rough ER is because they are attached to the protein they are synthesizing and the protein they are synthesizing is attached to the rough ER.  In contrast, a free ribosome may or may not be in the process of forming a polypeptide molecule at any given time.

questions.question: The molecules shown below are best described as

answers.text: Isotopes
Geometric isomers

Structural isomers

questions.correct_answer: Structural isomers
questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but have different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. However, despite the fact that they have a carbon-carbon double bond, they are NOT geometric isomers. Geometric isomers have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms. The pair of molecules shown above do NOT have the same covalent arrangement of their atoms. For the molecule shown on the left, each of the carbon atoms is covalently bound to one hydrogen atom and one hydroxyl (OH) group. For the molecule shown on the right, one carbon atom is covalently bound to two hydroxyl groups and the other carbon atom is covalently bound to two hydrogen atoms. So, the two molecules do not have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms. Because they differ in the covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are examples of the type of isomers known structural isomers.
questions.all_comments: Despite the fact that they have a carbon-carbon double bond and are isomers, these two molecules are NOT geometric isomers.  Geometric isomers have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms.  The pair of molecules shown above do NOT have the same covalent arrangement of their atoms.  For the molecule shown on the left, each of the carbon atoms is covalently bound to one hydrogen atom and one hydroxyl (OH) group.  For the molecule shown on the right, one carbon atom is covalently bound to two hydroxyl groups and the other carbon atom is covalently bound to two hydrogen atoms. So, these two molecules are structural isomers.These two molecules have the same formula (C2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but have different 3-dimensional shapes.  So, they are isomers of some sort.  However, despite the fact that they have a carbon-carbon double bond, they are NOT geometric isomers.  Geometric isomers have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms.  The pair of molecules shown above do NOT have the same covalent arrangement of their atoms.  For the molecule shown on the left, each of the carbon atoms is covalently bound to one hydrogen atom and one hydroxyl (OH) group.  For the molecule shown on the right, one carbon atom is covalently bound to two hydroxyl groups and the other carbon atom is covalently bound to two hydrogen atoms.  So, the two molecules do not have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms.  Because they differ in the covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are examples of the type of isomers known structural isomers.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about bases is FALSE?

answers.text: Some bases reduce H+ concentrations by accepting hydrogen ions.
Bases cause the concentration of hydroxide (OH-) anions to increase and the concentration of H+ cations to decrease.
Bases cause the pH of the solution to decrease.
Some bases reduce H+ concentrations by dissociating to form hydroxide (OH-) anions.

questions.correct_answer: Bases cause the pH of the solution to decrease.
questions.all_comments:
Bases cause the hydrogen ion concentration of a solution to DECREASE. Remember that, because pH is the NEGATIVE log of the hydrogen ion concentration, when the hydrogen ion concentration of a solution decreases, the pH of that solution increases. So, bases cause the pH of a solution to INCREASE, rather than decrease.
 
Bases cause the concentration of H+ ions to decrease by one of two ways. Some bases reduce H+ concentrations by dissociating to form hydroxide (OH-) anions. The hydroxide ions from the bases then react with H+ in the water to form water molecules, thereby reducing H+ concentrations. Alternatively, some bases reduce H+ concentrations by accepting (binding with) hydrogen ions.
 
So, because the question asks which statement about bases is FALSE, the correct answer to the question is that bases cause the pH to decrease, since bases actually cause the pH to increase.

questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question. The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a selectively permeable barrier. This selectively permeable barrier is permeable to water but not to any ions. If you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of MgCl2 to side “A” and you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of NaCl to side “B”, immediately after adding the solutions to the U-tube,

answers.text: the solution in side “A” will be hypertonic compared with the solution in side “B”
the solution in side “A” will be hypotonic compared with the solution in side “B”
there will be more free water molecules on side “A”
the solution in side “A” will be isotonic compared with the solution in side “B”

questions.correct_answer: the solution in side “A” will be hypertonic compared with the solution in side “B”
questions.neutral_comments: MgCl2 and NaCl are both salts that will dissociate into their constituent ions when they come in contact with water. So, the 1 mole of MgCl2 will dissociate to form 1 mole of Mg++ and 2 moles of Cl- and the 1 mole of NaCl will dissociate to form 1 mole of Na+and 1 mole of Cl-. That means that, immediately after the solutions are added to the two sides of the tube, there will be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B, so side A will be hypertonic compared with side B. The fact that there will be more solute molecules on side A also means that more of the water molecules on side A will be interacting with solute molecules and therefore there will be fewer free water molecules on side A.
questions.all_comments: MgCl2 and NaCl are both salts that will dissociate into their constituent ions when they come in contact with water.  So, the 1 mole of MgCl2 will dissociate to form 1 mole of Mg++ and 2 moles of Cl- and the 1 mole of NaCl will dissociate to form 1 mole of Na+and 1 mole of Cl-.  That means that, immediately after the solutions are added to the two sides of the tube, there will be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B, so side A will be hypertonic compared with side B.  The fact that there will be more solute molecules on side A also means that more of the water molecules on side A will be interacting with solute molecules and therefore there will be fewer free water molecules on side A.

questions.question: How many covalent bonds do carbon atoms need to form with other atoms to complete their valence shell?

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of carrier proteins in a plasma membrane?

answers.text: They always exhibit specificity for a particular type of molecule.
They are peripheral membrane proteins.
All carrier proteins require the expenditure of cellular energy to function.
All carrier proteins work against diffusion.

questions.correct_answer: They always exhibit specificity for a particular type of molecule.
questions.neutral_comments: Some carrier proteins carry out facilitated diffusion. Facilitated diffusion is diffusion of a molecule down its concentration and/or electrical gradient that is “facilitated” by a carrier protein or channel protein that allows the molecule that is diffusing to pass more quickly through the membrane. Because the molecules being transported are moving down their concentration and/or electrical gradient, carrier proteins that act in facilitated diffusion do not require an energy expenditure. However, other carrier proteins, such as symporters and anti-porters, help carry out active transport and so do require an energy expenditure.
questions.all_comments: Nice work!Some carrier proteins carry out facilitated diffusion. Facilitated diffusion is diffusion of a molecule down its concentration and/or electrical gradient that is “facilitated” by a carrier protein or channel protein that allows the molecule that is diffusing to pass more quickly through the membrane. Because the molecules being transported are moving down their concentration and/or electrical gradient, carrier proteins that act in facilitated diffusion do not require an energy expenditure. However, other carrier proteins, such as symporters and anti-porters, help carry out active transport and so do require an energy expenditure.

questions.question: Cell membranes are asymmetrical. Which of the following is most likely to explain part of the reason for this asymmetry?

answers.text: The cell membrane forms a border between different cell types.
Proteins can only span membranes if they are hydrophobic.
Cell membranes communicate signals from one cell to another.
Cell membrane proteins are inserted into the rough ER membrane with a certain orientation as they are being synthesized.

questions.correct_answer: Cell membrane proteins are inserted into the rough ER membrane with a certain orientation as they are being synthesized.
questions.neutral_comments: Integral membrane proteins are inserted into the membrane of the rough endoplasmic reticulum (ER) as they are being synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough ER. Because many of these proteins have both hydrophobic regions, which are embedded in the membrane, and hydrophilic regions, which are exposed to the aqueous environment inside or outside of the ER, they are not able to move randomly from one side of the membrane to the other after they are made. For example, if a membrane protein is synthesized such that the last part of the protein that is made is hydrophilic and is exposed on the outside of the ER membrane, that part of that protein will remain on the outside of the ER membrane and then on the outside of the vesicle that transports it to the Golgi, on the outside of the Golgi, on the outside of the vesicle that transports it the plasma membrane and then on the inside (cytoplasmic side) of the plasma membrane. It should be noted that the lipid compositions of the two halves of a lipid bilayer are not identical either, as lipid molecules very rarely flip-flop from one side of the bilayer to the other and different species of lipid molecules are synthesized in different amounts in the two halves of the bilayer.
questions.all_comments: Nice job!Integral membrane proteins are inserted into the membrane of the rough endoplasmic reticulum (ER) as they are being synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough ER.  Because many of these proteins have both hydrophobic regions, which are embedded in the membrane, and hydrophilic regions, which are exposed to the aqueous environment inside or outside of the ER, they are not able to move randomly from one side of the membrane to the other after they are made.  For example, if a membrane protein is synthesized such that the last part of the protein that is made is hydrophilic and is exposed on the outside of the ER membrane, that part of that protein will remain on the outside of the ER membrane and then on the outside of the vesicle that transports it to the Golgi, on the outside of the Golgi, on the outside of the vesicle that transports it the plasma membrane and then on the inside (cytoplasmic side) of the plasma membrane.  It should be noted that the lipid compositions of the two halves of a lipid bilayer are not identical either, as lipid molecules very rarely flip-flop from one side of the bilayer to the other and different species of lipid molecules are synthesized in different amounts in the two halves of the bilayer.

questions.question: If the cytoplasm of a cell is at pH 7, and the mitochondrial matrix is at pH 8, this means that

answers.text: the concentration of H+ ions is tenfold higher in the mitochondrial matrix than in the cytoplasm.
the concentration of H+ ions is tenfold higher in the cytoplasm than in the mitochondrial matrix.
the concentration of H+ ions in the cytoplasm is 8/7 the concentration in the mitochondrial matrix.
the concentration of H+ ions in the cytoplasm is 7/8 the concentration in the mitochondrial matrix.

questions.correct_answer: the concentration of H+ ions is tenfold higher in the cytoplasm than in the mitochondrial matrix.
questions.all_comments:
The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter.  In other words, pH = - log [H+].  So, in this case:
7 = - log [H+].  Or, -7 = log [H+].  Or, 10-7 = [H+]. Or, 0.0000001 moles/liter (M) = [H+]
and
8 = - log [H+].  Or, -8 = log [H+].  Or, 10-8 = [H+]. Or, 0.00000001 moles/liter (M) = [H+].
So, when the pH of a solution decreases from 8 to 7, the hydrogen ion concentration in the solution increases by 10 times.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about ribosomes is TRUE?

answers.text: Free ribosomes are available to begin synthesizing new proteins whereas bound ribosomes are currently unavailable for synthesizing new proteins as they are already in the process of synthesizing a protein.
Free ribosomes are free to diffuse around the cytosol and bound ribosomes are confined inside the nucleus.
Free ribosomes carry out protein synthesis while floating free in the cytosol and bound ribosomes carry out protein synthesis while attached to a membrane.
Bound ribosomes are attached to protein molecules whereas free ribosomes are NOT attached to protein molecules.

questions.correct_answer: Free ribosomes carry out protein synthesis while floating free in the cytosol and bound ribosomes carry out protein synthesis while attached to a membrane.
questions.neutral_comments: The terms “free” and “bound” apply to ribosomes that are floating free in the cytoplasm or are bound to the rough endoplasmic reticulum. Bound ribosomes will generally be in the process of forming a polypeptide, as the reason they are bound (attached) to the rough ER is because they are attached to the protein they are synthesizing and the protein they are synthesizing is attached to the rough ER. In contrast, a free ribosome may or may not be in the process of forming a polypeptide molecule at any given time.
questions.all_comments: The terms “free” and “bound” apply to ribosomes that are floating free in the cytoplasm or are bound to the rough endoplasmic reticulum.  Bound ribosomes will generally be in the process of forming a polypeptide, as the reason they are bound (attached) to the rough ER is because they are attached to the protein they are synthesizing and the protein they are synthesizing is attached to the rough ER.  In contrast, a free ribosome may or may not be in the process of forming a polypeptide molecule at any given time.

questions.question: If two molecules have the same numbers of atoms of the same elements and the SAME covalent partnerships but different structures, the two molecules may be

answers.text: Geometric isomers
answers.comment: The molecules could be either enantiomers or geometric isomers.

answers.text: Structural isomers
Either enantiomers or geometric isomers
Enantiomers

questions.correct_answer: Either enantiomers or geometric isomers
questions.neutral_comments: Isomers of any type (structural isomers, geometric isomers and enantiomers) must all meet the criteria of having the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures. Structural isomers have the further criteria that, for two molecules to be structural isomers of each other, they must differ in their covalent partnerships. In contrast, molecules that are geometric isomers or enantiomers do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships. Geometric isomers differ in the arrangement of atoms around a double bond. Enantiomers differ in the arrangement of atoms covalently bound to a central, asymmetric carbon and are mirror images of each other. Please see figure 4.7 in your textbook for a figure showing all three types of isomer.
questions.all_comments: Isomers of any type (structural isomers, geometric isomers and enantiomers) must all meet the criteria of having the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures.  Structural isomers have the further criteria that, for two molecules to be structural isomers of each other, they must differ in their covalent partnerships.  In contrast, molecules that are geometric isomers or enantiomers do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships.  Geometric isomers differ in the arrangement of atoms around a double bond.  Enantiomers differ in the arrangement of atoms covalently bound to a central, asymmetric carbon and are mirror images of each other.  Please see figure 4.7 in your textbook for a figure showing all three types of isomer.

questions.question: A solution with a pH of 13 contains what concentration of hydroxyl ions [OH<sup>-</sup>]?

answers.text: 10-13 moles/liter
13 moles/liter

questions.correct_answer: 0.1 moles/liter
questions.neutral_comments: The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter. In other words, pH = - log [H+]. So, in this case: 13 = - log [H+]. Or, -13 = log [H+]. Or, 10-13 M = [H+]. Furthermore, the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature). So, if the hydrogen ion concentration is 10-13M (moles per liter), the hydroxyl ion concentration must be 10-14/10-13= 10-1 M, or 0.1 M, or 0.1 moles/liter.
questions.all_comments: The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter.  In other words, pH = - log [H+].  So, in this case:  13 = - log [H+].  Or, -13 = log [H+].  Or, 10-13 M = [H+].  Furthermore, the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature).  So, if the hydrogen ion concentration is 10-13M (moles per liter), the hydroxyl ion concentration must be 10-14/10-13= 10-1 M, or 0.1 M, or 0.1 moles/liter.

questions.question:
Use the diagram below to help answer this question. The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a semi-permeable barrier. This semi-permeable barrier is permeable to water and to Mg++ and Na+ ions, but not to Cl- ions. If you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of MgCl2
to side “A” and you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of NaCl to side “B”, at equilibrium

answers.text: there will have been a net flow of water from side “A” to side “B”
there will have been no movement of water molecules across the membrane
there will have been a net flow of water from side “B” to side “A”
there will have been no net flow of water between the two sides of the tube

questions.correct_answer: there will have been a net flow of water from side “B” to side “A”
questions.neutral_comments: MgCl2 and NaCl are both salts that will dissociate into their constituent ions when they come in contact with water. So, the 1 mole of MgCl2 will dissociate to form 1 mole of Mg++ and 2 moles of Cl- and the 1 mole of NaCl will dissociate to form 1 mole of Na+ and 1 mole of Cl-. That means that, immediately after the solutions are added to the two sides of the tube, there will be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B. Importantly, there will be a higher concentration of Cl- (which can’t pass the membrane) on side A than on side B. As a result, there will be more free water molecules on side B than on side A. So, there will be a net flow of water molecules from side B to side A, until the concentration of free water molecules is the same on both sides of the membrane. At that point, free water molecules will still cross the membrane, but the rate at which free water molecules cross from side B to side A will be equal to the rate at which free water molecules cross from side A to side B.
questions.all_comments: Nice work!MgCl2 and NaCl are both salts that will dissociate into their constituent ions when they come in contact with water. So, the 1 mole of MgCl2 will dissociate to form 1 mole of Mg++ and 2 moles of Cl- and the 1 mole of NaCl will dissociate to form 1 mole of Na+ and 1 mole of Cl-. That means that, immediately after the solutions are added to the two sides of the tube, there will be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B. Importantly, there will be a higher concentration of Cl- (which can’t pass the membrane) on side A than on side B. As a result, there will be more free water molecules on side B than on side A. So, there will be a net flow of water molecules from side B to side A, until the concentration of free water molecules is the same on both sides of the membrane. At that point, free water molecules will still cross the membrane, but the rate at which free water molecules cross from side B to side A will be equal to the rate at which free water molecules cross from side A to side B.

questions.question: How many covalent bonds do hydrogen atoms need to form with other atoms to complete their valence shell?
questions.neutral_comments: Hydrogen atoms have 1 electron in their valence shell, which is the 1stelectron shell. The total number of electrons needed to fill the 1stelectron shell is 2, so hydrogen needs to form one covalent bond with another atom in order to fill its valence shell. Alternatively, hydrogen can “fill” its valence shell by transferring its one electron to another atom. You might expect that hydrogen could also fill its valence shell by transferring an electron FROM another atom, but that would leave the hydrogen with 2 electrons and only one proton which, it turns out, is energetically unfavorable.
questions.all_comments: ExcellentHydrogen atoms have 1 electron in their valence shell, which is the 1stelectron shell. The total number of electrons needed to fill the 1stelectron shell is 2, so hydrogen needs to form one covalent bond with another atom in order to fill its valence shell. Alternatively, hydrogen can “fill” its valence shell by transferring its one electron to another atom. You might expect that hydrogen could also fill its valence shell by transferring an electron FROM another atom, but that would leave the hydrogen with 2 electrons and only one proton which, it turns out, is energetically unfavorable.

questions.question:
What would be the sequence of the RNA molecule made using the following DNA strand as a template?

5’ TCTGAA 3’

answers.text: 5’ TTCAGA 3’
5’ AGACUU 3’
5’AGACTT 3’
5’ UUCAGA 3’

questions.correct_answer: 5’ UUCAGA 3’
questions.neutral_comments: First, remember that nucleic acid strands bind to each other with an anti-parallel orientation. In other words, they bind so that the 5’ end of one strand is hydrogen bonded to the 3’ end of the other strand. Also, remember that U (for RNA) or T (for DNA) hydrogen bonds with A, and G hydrogen bonds with C. So, you have: DNA 5’ TCTGAA 3’RNA 3’ AGACUU 5’ If you then follow the convention of writing nucleic acid molecules down starting at their 5’ end, the sequence for the RNA molecule is: 5’ UUCAGA 3’
questions.all_comments: First, remember that nucleic acid strands bind to each other with an anti-parallel orientation.  In other words, they bind so that the 5’ end of one strand is hydrogen bonded to the 3’ end of the other strand.  Also, remember that U (for RNA) or T (for DNA) hydrogen bonds with A, and G hydrogen bonds with C.  So, you have: DNA                5’ TCTGAA 3’RNA                3’ AGACUU 5’ If you then follow the convention of writing nucleic acid molecules down starting at their 5’ end, the sequence for the RNA molecule is: 5’ UUCAGA 3’

questions.question: The molecules shown below are best described as

answers.text: Geometric isomers
Isotopes
Structural isomers
Enantiomers

questions.correct_answer: Geometric isomers
questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but have different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers. For example, both carbon atoms in both molecules are attached to one hydroxyl (OH) group and one hydrogen atom. However, the two molecules do have different structures. Remember that double covalent bonds are inflexible. So, the above molecules cannot rotate around their double bonds in the way that they could if the two carbon atoms were only joined by single covalent bonds. So, in the molecule on the left, the two hydroxyl (OH) groups will always be on the opposite sides of the double bond, whereas the two hydroxyl groups will always be on the same side of the double bond in the molecule on the right. Molecules such as these two, which have the same covalent partnerships but different spatial arrangements, are known as geometric isomers. The molecule on the left, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the hydroxyl groups) on opposite sides of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a trans isomer. The molecule on the right, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the hydroxyl groups) on the same side of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a cis isomer.
questions.all_comments: Good work!These two molecules have the same formula (C2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but have different 3-dimensional shapes.  So, they are isomers of some sort.  Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers.  For example, both carbon atoms in both molecules are attached to one hydroxyl (OH) group and one hydrogen atom.  However, the two molecules do have different structures.  Remember that double covalent bonds are inflexible.  So, the above molecules cannot rotate around their double bonds in the way that they could if the two carbon atoms were only joined by single covalent bonds.  So, in the molecule on the left, the two hydroxyl (OH) groups will always be on the opposite sides of the double bond, whereas the two hydroxyl groups will always be on the same side of the double bond in the molecule on the right.  Molecules such as these two, which have the same covalent partnerships but different spatial arrangements, are known as geometric isomers.  The molecule on the left, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the hydroxyl groups) on opposite sides of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a trans isomer.  The molecule on the right, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the hydroxyl groups) on the same side of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a cis isomer.

questions.question: What gives rise to the cohesiveness of water molecules?

answers.text: Hydrogen bonds
Nonpolar covalent bonds
Hydrophobic interactions
Ionic bonds

questions.correct_answer: Hydrogen bonds
questions.neutral_comments: Water molecules stick to each other because the oxygen atom in a water molecule carries a partial negative charge and the two hydrogen atoms each carry a partial positive charge. As a result, the partially positively charged hydrogen atoms of one water molecule are attracted to the partially negatively charged oxygen atoms of other water molecules. The reason that the hydrogen atoms carry partial positive charges and the oxygen atoms carry partial negative charges is that the covalent bonds within a water molecule are polar. Each electron pair forming a covalent bond between an oxygen atom and a hydrogen atom spends more time near oxygen than near hydrogen, as oxygen atoms are more electronegative than hydrogen atoms.
questions.all_comments: Water molecules stick to each other because the oxygen atom in a water molecule carries a partial negative charge and the two hydrogen atoms each carry a partial positive charge.  As a result, the partially positively charged hydrogen atoms of one water molecule are attracted to the partially negatively charged oxygen atoms of other water molecules. The reason that the hydrogen atoms carry partial positive charges and the oxygen atoms carry partial negative charges is that the covalent bonds within a water molecule are polar. Each electron pair forming a covalent bond between an oxygen atom and a hydrogen atom spends more time near oxygen than near hydrogen, as oxygen atoms are more electronegative than hydrogen atoms.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is FALSE?

answers.text: Fatty acids are the monomers from which lipid molecules are formed.
Nucleotides are the monomers from which nucleic acids are formed.
Amino acids are the monomers from which proteins are formed.
Sugars are the monomers from which polysaccharides are formed.

questions.correct_answer: Fatty acids are the monomers from which lipid molecules are formed.
questions.neutral_comments: Fatty acids are important in lipid formation, but are not monomers as monomers are simple molecules, many of which are combined to form a polymer. In contrast, fatty acids are fairly large molecules and few of them are used to make a lipid molecule. For example, just two fatty acid molecules are used in the synthesis of a typical membrane lipid molecule (e.g. a phospholipid) and just three fatty acid molecules are used to make a typical lipid molecule in fat (e.g. a triacylglycerol molecule). In addition, monomers are linked together like cars forming a train to form a polymer. In contrast, the fatty acid molecules that are used to form lipids are not joined to each other. For example, the three fatty acid molecules used to form a triacylglycerol molecule (a type of lipid molecule) are each joined separately to different parts of a glycerol molecule. So, remember that lipids are the one type of biological macromolecule we will discuss that are NOT polymers because they are NOT composed of monomers.
questions.all_comments: Fatty acids are important in lipid formation, but are not monomers as monomers are simple molecules, many of which are combined to form a polymer.  In contrast, fatty acids are fairly large molecules and few of them are used to make a lipid molecule.  For example, just two fatty acid molecules are used in the synthesis of a typical membrane lipid molecule (e.g. a phospholipid) and just three fatty acid molecules are used to make a typical lipid molecule in fat (e.g. a triacylglycerol molecule).  In addition, monomers are linked together like cars forming a train to form a polymer.  In contrast, the fatty acid molecules that are used to form lipids are not joined to each other.  For example, the three fatty acid molecules used to form a triacylglycerol molecule (a type of lipid molecule) are each joined separately to different parts of a glycerol molecule.  So, remember that lipids are the one type of biological macromolecule we will discuss that are NOT polymers because they are NOT composed of monomers.

questions.question: The molar mass of glucose is 180 g/mol. Which of the following procedures should you carry out to make a 1 M (molar) solution of glucose?

answers.text: Dissolve 1 g of glucose in 1 L of water.
Dissolve 180 g of glucose in 0.8 L of water, and then add more water until the total volume of the solution is 1 L.
Dissolve 180 g of glucose in 180 g of water.
Dissolve 180 g of glucose in 1 L of water.

questions.correct_answer: Dissolve 180 g of glucose in 0.8 L of water, and then add more water until the total volume of the solution is 1 L.
questions.all_comments:
A one molar solution has one mole of solute molecules for every liter of solution.  So, to make 1 liter of a 1 molar solution of glucose, you can mix 1 mole of glucose molecules with enough water to bring the total volume of the solution to 1 liter. 
Note that if you add one liter of solvent, when you then add the solute the total volume of the solution will be greater than 1 liter.  So, your solution will have one mole of solute molecules but a total volume that is greater than 1 liter. As a result, your solution will be too dilute.
Also, the weight of a molecule in daltons is equal to the weight of a mole of those same molecules in grams.  In other words, if a single molecule of glucose weighs 180 daltons, than a mole of glucose molecules (i.e. 6.02 X 1023 glucose molecules) will weigh 180 grams.  So, you need 180 g of glucose to have 1 mole of glucose molecules.

questions.question: If starch and cellulose are both polymers of glucose, how come people can digest starch but not cellulose?

answers.text: When glucose monomers are joined by dehydration reactions to form cellulose, the glucose monomers are converted into xylose molecules that are impossible for us to digest.

The glucose monomers that form starch are joined together by different covalent bonds than the glucose monomers that form cellulose and the enzymes in our bodies that are able to hydrolyze (break) the covalent bonds between the glucose monomers in starch are not able to hydrolyze the covalent bonds between the glucose monomers in cellulose.
When glucose monomers are joined by dehydration reactions to form cellulose, the glucose monomers are converted into non-sugar molecules that are impossible for us to digest.
When glucose monomers are joined by dehydration reactions to form cellulose, the glucose monomers are converted into lactose molecules, which are hard for many people to digest.

questions.question: A solution with a pH of 12 contains what concentration of hydroxyl ions [OH<sup>-</sup>]?

answers.text: 0.01 moles/liter
0.12 moles/liter
2 moles/liter
10-12 moles/liter

questions.correct_answer: 0.01 moles/liter
questions.neutral_comments: The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter. In other words, pH = - log [H+]. So, in this case: 12 = - log [H+]. Or, -12 = log [H+]. Or, 10-12 M = [H+]. Furthermore, the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature). So, if the hydrogen ion concentration is 10-12M (moles per liter), the hydroxyl ion concentration must be 10-14/10-12= 10-2 M, or 0.01 M, or 0.01 moles/liter.
questions.all_comments: The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter.  In other words, pH = - log [H+].  So, in this case:  12 = - log [H+].  Or, -12 = log [H+].  Or, 10-12 M = [H+].  Furthermore, the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature).  So, if the hydrogen ion concentration is 10-12M (moles per liter), the hydroxyl ion concentration must be 10-14/10-12= 10-2 M, or 0.01 M, or 0.01 moles/liter.

questions.question: How many covalent bonds do carbon atoms need to form with other atoms to complete their valence shell?
questions.neutral_comments: Carbon atoms have 4 electrons in their valence shell, which is the 2ndelectron shell. The total number of electrons needed to fill the 2ndelectron shell is 8, so carbon needs to form 4 covalent bonds so that it is sharing a total of 8 electrons (2 electrons per covalent bond).
questions.all_comments: Carbon atoms have 4 electrons in their valence shell, which is the 2ndelectron shell. The total number of electrons needed to fill the 2ndelectron shell is 8, so carbon needs to form 4 covalent bonds so that it is sharing a total of 8 electrons (2 electrons per covalent bond).

questions.question: The molecules shown below are best described as

answers.text: Geometric isomers
Isotopes
Structural isomers
Enantiomers

questions.correct_answer: Geometric isomers
questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C2N2O2H2), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers. For example, both carbon atoms in both molecules are attached to one N=O group and one hydrogen atom. However, the two molecules do have different structures. Remember that double covalent bonds are inflexible. So, the above molecules cannot rotate around their double bonds in the way that they could if the two carbon atoms were only joined by single covalent bonds. So, in the molecule on the left, the two N=O groups will always be on the opposite sides of the double bond, whereas the two N=O groups will always be on the same side of the double bond in the molecule on the right. Molecules such as these two, which have the same covalent partnerships but different spatial arrangements, are known as geometric isomers. The molecule on the left, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the N=O groups) on opposite sides of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a trans isomer. The molecule on the right, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the N=O groups) on the same side of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a cis isomer.
questions.all_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C2N2O2H2), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but different 3-dimensional shapes.  So, they are isomers of some sort.  Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers.  For example, both carbon atoms in both molecules are attached to one N=O group and one hydrogen atom.  However, the two molecules do have different structures.  Remember that double covalent bonds are inflexible.  So, the above molecules cannot rotate around their double bonds in the way that they could if the two carbon atoms were only joined by single covalent bonds.  So, in the molecule on the left, the two N=O groups will always be on the opposite sides of the double bond, whereas the two N=O groups will always be on the same side of the double bond in the molecule on the right.  Molecules such as these two, which have the same covalent partnerships but different spatial arrangements, are known as geometric isomers.  The molecule on the left, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the N=O groups) on opposite sides of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a trans isomer.  The molecule on the right, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the N=O groups) on the same side of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a cis isomer.

questions.question:
What would be the sequence of the RNA molecule made using the following DNA strand as a template?

5’ TCTGAA 3’

answers.text: 5’ UUCAGA 3’
5’ AGACUU 3’
5’AGACTT 3’
5’ TTCAGA 3’

questions.correct_answer: 5’ UUCAGA 3’
questions.neutral_comments: First, remember that nucleic acid strands bind to each other with an anti-parallel orientation. In other words, they bind so that the 5’ end of one strand is hydrogen bonded to the 3’ end of the other strand. Also, remember that U (for RNA) or T (for DNA) hydrogen bonds with A, and G hydrogen bonds with C. So, you have: DNA 5’ TCTGAA 3’RNA 3’ AGACUU 5’ If you then follow the convention of writing nucleic acid molecules down starting at their 5’ end, the sequence for the RNA molecule is: 5’ UUCAGA 3’
questions.all_comments: First, remember that nucleic acid strands bind to each other with an anti-parallel orientation.  In other words, they bind so that the 5’ end of one strand is hydrogen bonded to the 3’ end of the other strand.  Also, remember that U (for RNA) or T (for DNA) hydrogen bonds with A, and G hydrogen bonds with C.  So, you have: DNA                5’ TCTGAA 3’RNA                3’ AGACUU 5’ If you then follow the convention of writing nucleic acid molecules down starting at their 5’ end, the sequence for the RNA molecule is: 5’ UUCAGA 3’

questions.question: Which of the following statements about hypotheses is FALSE?

answers.text: Hypotheses should be testable.
Hypotheses should be provable.
Hypotheses should be falsifiable.
Hypotheses should be possible answers to specific questions.

questions.correct_answer: Hypotheses should be provable.
questions.neutral_comments: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is correct. Instead the results of tests (experiments) may only show that a particular hypothesis is false. For example, if your hypothesis for why a flashlight isn’t working is that the batteries are dead, you might predict that replacing the batteries will fix the flashlight. If you then test your prediction by replacing the batteries and find that the flashlight still does not work, you have disproven your original prediction that replacing the batteries would fix the flashlight and have thus shown your hypothesis to be incorrect (false). However, if the flashlight works after you replace the batteries, that finding does not prove that your prediction was correct and thus does not prove that your hypothesis was correct. This is because you can still come up with alternative hypotheses for why the flashlight now works. For example, you could hypothesize that the reason the flashlight wasn’t working previously was because the original batteries were inserted incorrectly. Then, when you replaced the batteries, you inserted the new batteries correctly and so fixed the flashlight. If that is the case, then your original hypothesis that the old batteries were dead would be false.
questions.all_comments:
It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is
correct. Instead the results of tests (experiments) may only show that a
particular hypothesis is false. For example, if your hypothesis for why a
flashlight isn’t working is that the batteries are dead, you might predict that
replacing the batteries will fix the flashlight. If you then test your
prediction by replacing the batteries and find that the flashlight still does
not work, you have disproven your original prediction that replacing the
batteries would fix the flashlight and have thus shown your hypothesis to be incorrect
(false). However, if the flashlight works after you replace the batteries, that
finding does not prove that your prediction was correct and thus does not prove
that your hypothesis was correct. This is because you can still come up with
alternative hypotheses for why the flashlight now works. For example, you could
hypothesize that the reason the flashlight wasn’t working previously was
because the original batteries were inserted incorrectly. Then, when you
replaced the batteries, you inserted the new batteries correctly and so fixed
the flashlight. If that is the case, then your original hypothesis that the old
batteries were dead would be false.

Therefore, the molecular weight of hydrogen molecules is 2 Daltons and a mole of hydrogen molecules will weigh 2 g.

questions.question:
Scholastic dishonesty, such as cheating on exams or plagiarism, is not tolerated in this course. BIOL 1009 is a required course for almost all students taking it. This means that the information covered in the course is information students will likely need to be successful in their future careers. As a result, committing scholastic dishonesty in this course is not only dis-honorable, but is also likely to negatively impact students' future careers.

Because scholastic dishonesty is not tolerated in this course, students found to have committed scholastic dishonesty, such as cheating on an exam:

answers.text: will receive a grade of "0" on the exam or assignment affected by the dishonesty and will be reported to the university's Office of Community Standards.
will be given an opportunity to make up some or all of the points they lost by getting a "0" on an exam or other assignment.
will be given a second chance if they promise not to do it again.

questions.correct_answer: will receive a grade of "0" on the exam or assignment affected by the dishonesty and will be reported to the university's Office of Community Standards.
questions.neutral_comments: Integrity is taken seriously in this course. The minimum penalty for students caught cheating or committing some other form of scholastic dishonesty will be a grade of "0" on the assignment or exam in question, with no second chances or opportunities to make up any of the lost points. In addition, 100% of students caught cheating or committing some other form of scholastic dishonesty will be reported to the UMN Office of Community Standards.
questions.all_comments: Integrity is taken seriously in this course. The minimum penalty for students caught cheating or committing some other form of scholastic dishonesty will be a grade of "0" on the assignment or exam in question, with no second chances or opportunities to make up any of the lost points. In addition, 100% of students caught cheating or committing some other form of scholastic dishonesty will be reported to the UMN Office of Community Standards.

Quizzes must be completed on time, by the dates listed on the last page of the course syllabus. For that reason, each student's three lowest quiz scores will automatically be dropped. That way, if you forget a quiz or your internet quits or something, you will not have to take a zero on a quiz.

questions.correct_answer: Quizzes must be completed on time, by the dates listed on the last page of the course syllabus. For that reason, each student's three lowest quiz scores will automatically be dropped. That way, if you forget a quiz or your internet quits or something, you will not have to take a zero on a quiz.
questions.neutral_comments: Quizzes must be taken on time by the dates listed on the last page of the course syllabus. Because “stuff happens”, each student's three lowest quiz scores will automatically be dropped. So, if you do miss a quiz for any reason, that quiz will simply count as one of your three dropped quizzes and you won't have to take a zero on that quiz. To avoid missing quizzes, it is strongly recommended that you take each quiz at least once at least a day before that quiz is due. Conversely, it is strongly recommended that you NOT wait until shortly before a quiz is due to attempt it for the first time. Remember, you can take each quiz up to three times with only your highest score counting, so it makes sense to take each quiz at least once a day or two before it's due so it won't matter so much if it slips your mind the day it's due.
questions.all_comments: Quizzes must be taken on time by the dates listed on the last page of the course syllabus. questions.neutral_comments: Grades in BIOL 1009 are determined using "guaranteed point cutoffs". This means that every student in the course who earns more than a certain number of points is guaranteed to receive at least a certain letter grade. In other words, the cutoffs will NOT be raised, even if that means that every student earns a final course grade of "A". The course syllabus describes the number of points that may be earned for each course activity and lists the number of points that need to be earned (i.e. the "guaranteed point cutoffs") in order to earn different final course grades. Please note that grades are NOT curved in BIOL 1009. You can download a copy of the course syllabus from the course Canvas page.

questions.question: Regarding the online quizzes:

answers.text: Quizzes must be completed on time, by the dates listed on the last page of the course syllabus. For that reason, each student's three lowest quiz scores will automatically be dropped. That way, if you forget a quiz or your internet quits or something, you will not have to take a zero on a quiz.
If you are sick when a quiz is due, you can take it late
If you forget the deadline for a quiz, you can take it late
If you are about to submit a quiz right before the deadline and the power or internet goes out (i.e. something happens that was completely outside of your control), you can take the quiz late

questions.correct_answer: Quizzes must be completed on time, by the dates listed on the last page of the course syllabus. For that reason, each student's three lowest quiz scores will automatically be dropped. That way, if you forget a quiz or your internet quits or something, you will not have to take a zero on a quiz.
questions.neutral_comments: Quizzes must be taken on time by the dates listed on the last page of the course syllabus. Because “stuff happens”, each student's three lowest quiz scores will automatically be dropped. So, if you do miss a quiz for any reason, that quiz will simply count as one of your three dropped quizzes and you won't have to take a zero on that quiz. To avoid missing quizzes, it is strongly recommended that you take each quiz at least once at least a day before that quiz is due. Conversely, it is strongly recommended that you NOT wait until shortly before a quiz is due to attempt it for the first time. Remember, you can take each quiz up to three times with only your highest score counting, so it makes sense to take each quiz at least once a day or two before it's due so it won't matter so much if it slips your mind the day it's due.
questions.all_comments: Quizzes must be taken on time by the dates listed on the last page of the course syllabus. Because “stuff happens”, each student's three lowest quiz scores will automatically be dropped. So, if you do miss a quiz for any reason, that quiz will simply count as one of your three dropped quizzes and you won't have to take a zero on that quiz. To avoid missing quizzes, it is strongly recommended that you take each quiz at least once at least a day before that quiz is due. Conversely, it is strongly recommended that you NOT wait until shortly before a quiz is due to attempt it for the first time. Remember, you can take each quiz up to three times with only your highest score counting, so it makes sense to take each quiz at least once a day or two before it's due so it won't matter so much if it slips your mind the day it's due.

hypothesis

questions.question: A hypothesis

answers.text: is a prediction scientists make based on many careful observations
is a tentative answer to a question
is the same thing as a theory

questions.correct_answer: is a tentative answer to a question
questions.neutral_comments: A hypothesis is a tentative answer to a question. Ideally, hypothesis-based science is carried out in the following steps: 1) Make observations. 2) Ask a question about those observations. 3) Form one or more hypotheses (= tentative answers to the question). 4) Make predictions based on the hypotheses. 5) Test predictions (e.g. by doing experiments). 6) Determine whether the results of the tests do or do not falsify the hypothesis. NOTE: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is correct. Instead, depending on the results, tests (experiments) may only show that a particular hypothesis is false.

question. Ideally, hypothesis-based science is carried out in the following

predictions based on the hypotheses. 5) Test predictions (e.g. by doing
experiments). 6) Determine whether the results of the tests do or do not
falsify the hypothesis. NOTE: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is
correct. Instead, depending on the results, tests (experiments) may only show
that a particular hypothesis is false.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the logic of hypothesis-based science?

answers.text: If I generate a testable hypothesis, tests and observations will support it.

questions.neutral_comments: A hypothesis is a possible answer to a specific question. Because hypotheses are only POSSIBLE answers to questions, and you will often have multiple hypotheses for each question that you ask, the data you obtain will not necessarily support a particular hypothesis.

Nice job!A hypothesis is a possible answer to a specific
question. Predictions are made based on the hypothesis and those predictions
are tested (e.g. by carrying out appropriate experiments). Because hypotheses
are only POSSIBLE answers to questions, and you will often have multiple
hypotheses for each question that you ask, the data you obtain will not
necessarily support a particular hypothesis.

questions.question: A hypothesis

answers.text: is a prediction scientists make based on many careful observations
is the same thing as a theory
is a specific question formulated by scientists after making many careful observations
is a tentative answer to a question

questions.correct_answer: is a tentative answer to a question
questions.neutral_comments: A hypothesis is a tentative answer to a question. Ideally, hypothesis-based science is carried out in the following steps: 1) Make observations. 2) Ask a question about those observations. 3) Form one or more hypotheses (= tentative answers to the question). 4) Make predictions based on the hypotheses. 5) Test predictions (e.g. by doing experiments). 6) Determine whether the results of the tests do or do not falsify the hypothesis. NOTE: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is correct. Instead, depending on the results, tests (experiments) may only show that a particular hypothesis is false.

questions.question: A hypothesis

answers.text: can NOT be proven to be correct
can be proven to be correct or incorrect, depending on experimental results
can be proven to be correct
can NOT be proven to be correct or incorrect, regardless of experimental results

questions.correct_answer: can NOT be proven to be correct
questions.neutral_comments: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is correct. Instead the results of tests (experiments) may only show that a particular hypothesis is false. For example, if your hypothesis for why a flashlight isn’t working is that the batteries are dead, you might predict that replacing the batteries will fix the flashlight. If you then test your prediction by replacing the batteries and find that the flashlight still does not work, you have disproven your original prediction that replacing the batteries would fix the flashlight and have thus shown your hypothesis to be incorrect (false). However, if the flashlight works after you replace the batteries, that finding does not prove that your hypothesis was correct. This is because you can still come up with alternative hypotheses for why the flashlight now works. For example, you could hypothesize that the reason the flashlight wasn’t working previously was because the original batteries were inserted incorrectly. Then, when you replaced the batteries, you inserted the new batteries correctly and so fixed the flashlight. If that is the case, then your original hypothesis that the old batteries were dead would be false. The bottom line is that we can never rule out that there might be a different hypothesis that also explains all of the available experimental results and that is actually the correct hypothesis.
questions.all_comments:
Good job!It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is
correct. Instead the results of tests (experiments) may only show that a
particular hypothesis is false. For example, if your hypothesis for why a
flashlight isn’t working is that the batteries are dead, you might predict that
replacing the batteries will fix the flashlight. If you then test your
prediction by replacing the batteries and find that the flashlight still does

that also explains all of the available experimental results and that is
actually the correct hypothesis.

questions.question: A hypothesis

answers.text: is a prediction scientists make based on many careful observations
is the same thing as a theory
is a specific question formulated by scientists after making many careful observations
is a tentative answer to a question

questions.correct_answer: is a tentative answer to a question
questions.neutral_comments: A hypothesis is a tentative answer to a question. Ideally, hypothesis-based science is carried out in the following steps: 1) Make observations. 2) Ask a question about those observations. 3) Form one or more hypotheses (= tentative answers to the question). 4) Make predictions based on the hypotheses. 5) Test predictions (e.g. by doing experiments). 6) Determine whether the results of the tests do or do not falsify the hypothesis. NOTE: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is correct. Instead, depending on the results, tests (experiments) may only show that a particular hypothesis is false.

question. Ideally, hypothesis-based science is carried out in the following

questions.question: What are two methods of scientific inquiry?

questions.question: A hypothesis

answers.text: can NOT be proven to be correct or incorrect, regardless of experimental results
can be proven to be correct
can NOT be proven to be correct
can be proven to be correct or incorrect, depending on experimental results

questions.correct_answer: can NOT be proven to be correct
questions.neutral_comments: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is correct. Instead the results of tests (experiments) may only show that a particular hypothesis is false. For example, if your hypothesis for why a flashlight isn’t working is that the batteries are dead, you might predict that replacing the batteries will fix the flashlight. If you then test your prediction by replacing the batteries and find that the flashlight still does not work, you have disproven your original prediction that replacing the batteries would fix the flashlight and have thus shown your hypothesis to be incorrect (false). However, if the flashlight works after you replace the batteries, that finding does not prove that your hypothesis was correct. This is because you can still come up with alternative hypotheses for why the flashlight now works. For example, you could hypothesize that the reason the flashlight wasn’t working previously was because the original batteries were inserted incorrectly. Then, when you replaced the batteries, you inserted the new batteries correctly and so fixed the flashlight. If that is the case, then your original hypothesis that the old batteries were dead would be false. The bottom line is that we can never rule out that there might be a different hypothesis that also explains all of the available experimental results and that is actually the correct hypothesis.
questions.all_comments:
Good job!It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is
correct. Instead the results of tests (experiments) may only show that a
particular hypothesis is false. For example, if your hypothesis for why a
flashlight isn’t working is that the batteries are dead, you might predict that
replacing the batteries will fix the flashlight. If you then test your

questions.question: Experimentation is only one part of the process of scientific inquiry, but it is a very important step because it

answers.text: gives the investigator a systematic, unbiased result
allows rejection of a hypothesis
ensures that the variable being tested is measured without error
ensures that hypotheses can be confirmed with certainty

questions.correct_answer: allows rejection of a hypothesis
questions.neutral_comments: Experiments are designed to test predictions. The prediction being tested is based on a hypothesis. Therefore, if the prediction is shown to be false, that result indicates that the hypothesis on which the prediction was based is also false. Carrying out experiments does not ensure that a hypothesis will be supported. Because hypotheses are only POSSIBLE answers to questions, many hypotheses turn out to be incorrect. In addition, it is not possible to prove that a hypothesis is correct as there will always be alternative explanations for why testing showed that a particular prediction was correct. Experiments don’t necessarily give investigators systematic unbiased results; it depends on how the experiments are designed and conducted. Similarly, it is difficult or impossible to ensure that variables being tested are measured without error.
questions.all_comments: Experiments are designed to test predictions. The prediction being tested is based on a hypothesis. Therefore, if the prediction is shown to be false, that result indicates that the hypothesis on which the prediction was based is also false. Similarly, it is difficult or impossible to ensure that variables being tested are measured without error.

However, if the flashlight works after you replace the batteries, that finding does not prove that your prediction was correct and thus does not prove that your hypothesis was correct. This is because you can still come up with alternative hypotheses for why the flashlight now works. For example, you could hypothesize that the reason the flashlight wasn’t working previously was because the original batteries were inserted incorrectly. Then, when you replaced the batteries, you inserted them correctly and so fixed the flashlight. If that is the case, then your original hypothesis that the old batteries were dead would be false. The bottom line is that we can never rule out that there might be a different hypothesis that also explains all of the available experimental results and that is actually the correct hypothesis.

Good job!It is not possible to PROVE that a theory or
hypothesis is correct. Instead the results of tests (experiments) may only show
that a particular theory or hypothesis is false. For example, if your

questions.question: A hypothesis

answers.text: is a tentative answer to a question
is the same thing as a theory

is a specific question formulated by scientists after making many careful observations

questions.correct_answer: is a tentative answer to a question
questions.neutral_comments: A hypothesis is a tentative answer to a question. Ideally, hypothesis-based science is carried out in the following steps: 1) Make observations. 2) Ask a question about those observations. 3) Form one or more hypotheses (= tentative answers to the question). 4) Make predictions based on the hypotheses. 5) Test predictions (e.g. by doing experiments). 6) Determine whether the results of the tests do or do not falsify the hypothesis. NOTE: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is correct. Instead, depending on the results, tests (experiments) may only show that a particular hypothesis is false.

That is part of the process followed when doing hypothesis-based science.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the logic of hypothesis-based science?

answers.text: If my hypothesis is correct, I can expect certain results.
If my prediction is correct, it will lead to a testable hypothesis.
If I generate a testable hypothesis, tests and observations will support it.
If my observations are accurate, they will support my hypothesis.

questions.correct_answer: If my hypothesis is correct, I can expect certain results.
questions.neutral_comments: A hypothesis is a possible answer to a specific question. Predictions are made based on the hypothesis and those predictions are tested (e.g. by carrying out appropriate experiments). Because hypotheses are only POSSIBLE answers to questions, and you will often have multiple hypotheses for each question that you ask, the data you obtain will not necessarily support a particular hypothesis.
questions.all_comments:
Nice job!A hypothesis is a possible answer to a specific
question. Predictions are made based on the hypothesis and those predictions
are tested (e.g. by carrying out appropriate experiments). Because hypotheses
are only POSSIBLE answers to questions, and you will often have multiple
hypotheses for each question that you ask, the data you obtain will not
necessarily support a particular hypothesis.

questions.question: Experimentation is only one part of the process of scientific inquiry, but it is a very important step because it

answers.text: gives the investigator a systematic, unbiased result
ensures that hypotheses can be confirmed with certainty
ensures that the variable being tested is measured without error
allows rejection of a hypothesis

questions.correct_answer: allows rejection of a hypothesis
questions.neutral_comments: Experiments are designed to test predictions. The prediction being tested is based on a hypothesis. Therefore, if the prediction is shown to be false, that result indicates that the hypothesis on which the prediction was based is also false. Carrying out experiments does not ensure that a hypothesis will be supported. Because hypotheses are only POSSIBLE answers to questions, many hypotheses turn out to be incorrect. In addition, it is not possible to prove that a hypothesis is correct as there will always be alternative explanations for why testing showed that a particular prediction was correct. Experiments don’t necessarily give investigators systematic unbiased results; it depends on how the experiments are designed and conducted. Similarly, it is difficult or impossible to ensure that variables being tested are measured without error.
questions.all_comments: Experiments are designed to test predictions. The prediction being tested is based on a hypothesis. Therefore, if the prediction is shown to be false, that result indicates that the hypothesis on which the prediction was based is also false. Carrying out experiments does not ensure that a hypothesis will be supported. Because hypotheses are only POSSIBLE answers to questions, many hypotheses turn out to be incorrect. questions.question: During peer-review of a manuscript

questions.question: Which of the following statements about moles is true?

answers.text: One mole of hydrogen atoms weighs 1 g
One mole of hydrogen molecules (H2) weighs 2 g
All of these answers are correct.
A mole is 6.02 X 1023

questions.correct_answer: All of these answers are correct.
questions.neutral_comments: All of these answers are correct. A mole is 6.02 X 1023. A hydrogen atom weighs one Dalton so one mole of hydrogen atoms weighs 1 g. One mole of hydrogen molecules (H2) weighs 2 g. This is because hydrogen molecules have the formula: H2. Therefore, the molecular weight of hydrogen molecules is 2 Daltons and a mole of hydrogen molecules will weigh 2 g.

questions.question: What is the pH of a solution with a hydroxyl ion [OH<sup>-</sup>] concentration of 10<sup>-4.5 </sup>M?

answers.text: pH 2
pH 12
pH 9.5
pH 4.5

questions.correct_answer: pH 9.5
questions.neutral_comments: Remember that the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 M (moles per liter) in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature). So, if the hydroxyl ion concentration is 10-4.5 M, the hydrogen ion concentration must be 10-14/10-4.5= 10-9.5 M. The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration. The base 10 logarithm of 10-9.5 is -9.5, so the negative logarithm of 10-9.5is 9.5. Therefore, the pH of this solution is 9.5.

questions.question: How many covalent bonds do nitrogen atoms need to form with other atoms to complete their valence shell?
questions.neutral_comments: Nitrogen atoms have 5 electrons in their valence shell, which is the 2ndelectron shell. The total number of electrons needed to fill the 2ndelectron shell is 8, so nitrogen needs to form 3 covalent bonds with other atoms so that it has 3 pairs of electrons that it is sharing via covalent bonds and one pair of electrons that it is not sharing, for a total of 4 pairs of electrons, or 8 total electrons.
questions.all_comments: ExcellentNitrogen atoms have 5 electrons in their valence shell, which is the 2ndelectron shell. The total number of electrons needed to fill the 2ndelectron shell is 8, so nitrogen needs to form 3 covalent bonds with other atoms so that it has 3 pairs of electrons that it is sharing via covalent bonds and one pair of electrons that it is not sharing, for a total of 4 pairs of electrons, or 8 total electrons.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about valence shells is FALSE?

answers.text: Electrons in the valence shell (i.e. valence electrons) are primarily responsible for the chemical behavior of atoms.
The number of valence shells contained by a particular atom is dependent on how many electrons that atom has.
The valence shell is the highest energy electron shell an atom has.
The valence shell is the outermost electron shell of an atom.

questions.correct_answer: The number of valence shells contained by a particular atom is dependent on how many electrons that atom has.
questions.neutral_comments: Each atom has only one valence shell, corresponding to its outermost electron shell. Because the electrons in the valence shell are the outermost electrons and the energy level of an electron increases the further it is from the nucleus, the valence shell is the highest energy electron shell an atom has. Also, because atoms react to complete their valence shells, the valence electrons are primarily responsible for the chemical behavior of atoms.
questions.all_comments: Good job!Each atom has only one valence shell, corresponding to its outermost electron shell. Because the electrons in the valence shell are the outermost electrons and the energy level of an electron increases the further it is from the nucleus, the valence shell is the highest energy electron shell an atom has. Also, because atoms react to complete their valence shells, the valence electrons are primarily responsible for the chemical behavior of atoms.

the potential energy of the valence shell

questions.correct_answer: the existence of unpaired electrons in the valence shell
