questions.question: What gives rise to the cohesiveness of water molecules?

answers.text: Nonpolar covalent bonds
Hydrogen bonds
Ionic bonds
Hydrophobic interactions

questions.correct_answer: Hydrogen bonds
questions.neutral_comments: Water molecules stick to each other because the oxygen atom in a water molecule carries a partial negative charge and the two hydrogen atoms each carry a partial positive charge. As a result, the partially positively charged hydrogen atoms of one water molecule are attracted to the partially negatively charged oxygen atoms of other water molecules. The reason that the hydrogen atoms carry partial positive charges and the oxygen atoms carry partial negative charges is that the covalent bonds within a water molecule are polar. Each electron pair forming a covalent bond between an oxygen atom and a hydrogen atom spends more time near oxygen than near hydrogen, as oxygen atoms are more electronegative than hydrogen atoms.
questions.all_comments: Water molecules stick to each other because the oxygen atom in a water molecule carries a partial negative charge and the two hydrogen atoms each carry a partial positive charge.  As a result, the partially positively charged hydrogen atoms of one water molecule are attracted to the partially negatively charged oxygen atoms of other water molecules. The reason that the hydrogen atoms carry partial positive charges and the oxygen atoms carry partial negative charges is that the covalent bonds within a water molecule are polar. Each electron pair forming a covalent bond between an oxygen atom and a hydrogen atom spends more time near oxygen than near hydrogen, as oxygen atoms are more electronegative than hydrogen atoms.

questions.question: If the pH of a solution is decreased from 9 to 8, it means that the

answers.text: concentration of H+ has increased tenfold (10X) compared to what it was at pH 9.
concentration of OH- has increased tenfold (10X) compared to what it was at pH 9.
concentration of H+ has decreased to one-tenth (1/10) what it was at pH 9.
the concentration of both OH- and H+ increased tenfold (10X) compared to what they were at pH 9

questions.correct_answer: concentration of H+ has increased tenfold (10X) compared to what it was at pH 9.
questions.all_comments:
The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter.  In other words, pH = - log [H+].  So, in this case:
9 = - log [H+].  Or, -9 = log [H+].  Or, 10-9 = [H+]. Or, 0.000000001 M = [H+]
and
8 = - log [H+].  Or, -8 = log [H+].  Or, 10-8 = [H+]. Or, 0.00000001 M = [H+].
So, when the pH of a solution decreases from 9 to 8, the hydrogen ion concentration in the solution increases 10 fold. In an aqueous solution at 25 °C, it is also true that [H+] X [OH-] = 10-14. So, in an aqueous solution, when the hydrogen ion increases 10 fold, the hydroxyl ion concentration must decrease 10 fold.

questions.question: When a sodium atom and a chlorine atom interact to complete their valence shells

answers.text: an electron is transferred from sodium to chlorine, turning the sodium atom into a cation and the chlorine atom into an anion and allowing the two atoms to form an ionic bond
they form 1 polar covalent bond
they form 2 polar covalent bonds
an electron is transferred from sodium to chlorine, turning the sodium atom into an anion and the chlorine atom into a cation and allowing the two atoms to form an ionic bond

questions.correct_answer: an electron is transferred from sodium to chlorine, turning the sodium atom into a cation and the chlorine atom into an anion and allowing the two atoms to form an ionic bond
questions.neutral_comments: Chlorine is so much more electronegative than sodium that, rather than sharing a pair of electrons, the lone electron in the valence (= 3rd) shell of sodium is transferred to chlorine. That leaves the sodium cation with no electrons in the 3rd electron shell and a full set (8) of electrons in the 2nd electron shell. The 1 electron transferred to the chlorine atom is sufficient to complete the valence shell of that atom. Because chlorine now has one more electron than it has protons, the chlorine anion will have a charge of negative 1. Negatively charged ions are called “anions” and positively charged ions are called “cations”.
questions.all_comments: Good work!Chlorine is so much more electronegative than sodium that, rather than sharing a pair of electrons, the lone electron in the valence (= 3rd) shell of sodium is transferred to chlorine. That leaves the sodium cation with no electrons in the 3rd electron shell and a full set (8) of electrons in the 2nd electron shell.  The 1 electron transferred to the chlorine atom is sufficient to complete the valence shell of that atom. Because chlorine now has one more electron than it has protons, the chlorine anion will have a charge of negative 1.  Negatively charged ions are called “anions” and positively charged ions are called “cations”.

questions.question:
Why does the structure shown below fail to make sense chemically?

H-C=C-H

answers.text: Each hydrogen atom only has 1 covalent bond.
Carbon is more electronegative than hydrogen and should thus remove electrons from hydrogen, rather than forming a covalent bond with hydrogen.
The two carbon atoms share more than 1 bond.
Each carbon atom only has 3 covalent bonds.

questions.correct_answer: Each carbon atom only has 3 covalent bonds.
questions.neutral_comments: Carbon atoms need to form 4 covalent bonds, rather than just 3, to complete their valence shell. Carbon is only slightly more electronegative than hydrogen and so will not remove electrons from hydrogen. In addition, removing 4 electrons from hydrogen atoms to complete its valence shell would leave carbon with 4 more electrons than protons, which is energetically extremely unfavorable.
questions.all_comments: Good work!Carbon atoms need to form 4 covalent bonds, rather than just 3, to complete their valence shell.  Carbon is only slightly more electronegative than hydrogen and so will not remove electrons from hydrogen. In addition, removing 4 electrons from hydrogen atoms to complete its valence shell would leave carbon with 4 more electrons than protons, which is energetically extremely unfavorable.

questions.question: The further on average an electron is from the nucleus

answers.text: the greater its potential energy
the more highly charged it is
the less highly charged it is
the lower its potential energy

questions.correct_answer: the greater its potential energy
questions.neutral_comments: The further an electron is from the nucleus, the greater its potential energy. Think of it this way. Negatively charged electrons are attracted to the positively charged protons in the nucleus. So, it takes work to increase the separation between an electron and the nucleus. Some of the energy spent in doing this work is stored in the form of increasing the potential energy of the moved electron. This is conceptually similar to increasing the potential energy of a ball by carrying it higher up a hill.
questions.all_comments:

                            potential energy.  Think of it this way.  Negatively charged electrons are
                            attracted to the positively charged protons in the nucleus. So, it takes work to increase
                            the separation between an electron and the nucleus. Some of the energy spent in doing this
                            work is stored in the form of increasing the potential energy of the moved electron. This is
                            conceptually similar to increasing the potential energy of a ball by carrying it higher up a
                            hill.

questions.question: The molar mass of glucose is 180 g/mol. Which of the following procedures should you carry out to make a 1 M (molar) solution of glucose?

answers.text: Dissolve 1 g of glucose in 1 L of water.
Dissolve 180 g of glucose in 1 L of water.
Dissolve 180 g of glucose in 180 g of water.
Dissolve 180 g of glucose in 0.8 L of water, and then add more water until the total volume of the solution is 1 L.

questions.correct_answer: Dissolve 180 g of glucose in 0.8 L of water, and then add more water until the total volume of the solution is 1 L.
questions.all_comments:
A one molar solution has one mole of solute molecules for every liter of solution. 
                            So, to make 1 liter of a 1 molar solution of glucose, you can mix 1 mole of glucose
                            molecules with enough water to bring the total volume of the solution to 1 liter. 
Note that if you add one liter of solvent, when you then add the solute the total volume of
                            the solution will be greater than 1 liter.  So, your solution will have one mole of
                            solute molecules but a total volume that is greater than 1 liter. As a result, your solution
                            will be too dilute.
Also, the weight of a molecule in daltons is equal to the weight of a mole of those same
                            molecules in grams.  In other words, if a single molecule of glucose weighs 180
                            daltons, than a mole of glucose molecules (i.e. 6.02 X 1023 glucose molecules)
                            will weigh 180 grams.  So, you need 180 g of glucose to have 1 mole of glucose
                            molecules.

questions.question: What is the pH of a solution with a hydroxyl ion [OH<sup>-</sup>] concentration of 10<sup>-4 </sup>M?

answers.text: pH 2
pH 12
pH 10
pH 4

questions.correct_answer: pH 10
questions.neutral_comments: Remember that the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature). So, if the hydroxyl ion concentration is 10-4M (moles per liter), the hydrogen ion concentration must be 10-14/10-4= 10-10 M. The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration. The base 10 logarithm of 10-10 is -10, so the negative logarithm of 10-10is 10. Therefore, the pH of this solution is 10.

questions.question: In humans, blood pH is around 7.4, and a decrease in blood pH to 6.4 would be fatal. A drop by 1 pH unit represents which of the following?

answers.text: ten times as many H+ ions in the solution
1/10 as many H+ ions in the solution
1/2 as many H+ ions in the solution
twice as many H+ ions in the solution

questions.correct_answer: ten times as many H+ ions in the solution
questions.all_comments:
The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion
                            concentration in moles per liter.  In other words, pH = - log [H+]. 
                            So, for example:
If the pH = 1, than:
1 = - log [H+].  Or, -1 = log [H+].  Or, 10-1 =
                            [H+]. Or, 0.1 moles/liter (M) = [H+]
and
If the pH = 2, than:
2 = - log [H+].  Or, -2 = log [H+].  Or, 10-2 =
                            [H+]. Or, 0.01 moles/liter (M) = [H+].
So, when the pH of a solution decreases from 2 to 1, the hydrogen ion concentration
                            in the solution increases by 10 times.  Similarly, when the pH decreases from
                            7.4 to 6.4, the hydrogen ion concentration increases by 10 times.

questions.question: How many covalent bonds do carbon atoms need to form with other atoms to complete their valence shell?
questions.neutral_comments: Carbon atoms have 4 electrons in their valence shell, which is the 2ndelectron shell. The total number of electrons needed to fill the 2ndelectron shell is 8, so carbon needs to form 4 covalent bonds so that it is sharing a total of 8 electrons (2 electrons per covalent bond).
questions.all_comments: ExcellentCarbon atoms have 4 electrons in their valence shell, which is the 2ndelectron shell. The total number of electrons needed to fill the 2ndelectron shell is 8, so carbon needs to form 4 covalent bonds so that it is sharing a total of 8 electrons (2 electrons per covalent bond).

questions.question: The lowest energy mechanism by which a carbon atom may complete its valence shell is to

answers.text: transfer the 4 electrons in its valence shell to other atoms or transfer 4 electrons from other atoms to its valence shell
transfer the 2 electrons in its valence shell to other atoms or transfer 2 electrons from other atoms to its valence shell
form 2 covalent bonds with other atoms
form 4 covalent bonds with other atoms

questions.correct_answer: form 4 covalent bonds with other atoms
questions.neutral_comments: Forming only 2 covalent bonds with other atoms would not be sufficient for a carbon atom to complete its shell, as carbon atoms have 4 electrons in their valence shell (= the 2nd electron shell) and 8 electrons are needed to complete that shell. In theory the outermost shell could be completed by transferring 4 electrons from other atoms, but in practice this would leave the carbon atom with 4 more electrons than protons which is very unfavorable energetically. In theory the outermost shell could also be completed by transferring 4 electrons FROM carbon to other atoms, in which case the carbon atom would have no electrons in its 2nd shell and 2 electrons in its 1st shell, which would make the 1st shell its outermost, or valence, shell and that shell would be complete since it only takes 2 electrons to fill the 1st electron shell. However, this situation would leave the carbon atom with 4 less electrons than protons, which is a big difference in the number of electrons and protons and is extremely unstable in this case.
questions.all_comments: ExcellentForming only 2 covalent bonds with other atoms would not be sufficient for a carbon atom to complete its shell, as carbon atoms have 4 electrons in their valence shell (= the 2nd electron shell) and 8 electrons are needed to complete that shell. In theory the outermost shell could be completed by transferring 4 electrons from other atoms, but in practice this would leave the carbon atom with 4 more electrons than protons which is very unfavorable energetically. In theory the outermost shell could also be completed by transferring 4 electrons FROM carbon to other atoms, in which case the carbon atom would have no electrons in its 2nd shell and 2 electrons in its 1st shell, which would make the 1st shell its outermost, or valence, shell and that shell would be complete since it only takes 2 electrons to fill the 1st electron shell.  However, this situation would leave the carbon atom with 4 less electrons than protons, which is a big difference in the number of electrons and protons and is extremely unstable in this case.

questions.question: Depending on how far an electron is moved from the nucleus

answers.text: you can decrease its potential energy by any amount

questions.correct_answer: you can increase its potential energy by only certain amounts
questions.neutral_comments: The potential energy of electrons increases the further they are from the nucleus. However, electrons may only occupy certain defined orbitals that have certain defined average distances from the nucleus and thus certain energy levels. Think of it like a ball being moved up or down a set of steps. If a ball is moved up two steps its energy level will increase twice as much as if it is moved up one step (assuming the steps are of equal height). However, it is not feasible to increase the potential energy of the ball by 0.5 or 1.5 steps.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about electrons is FALSE?

answers.text: two electrons may occupy the same electron orbital

electrons are attracted to nuclei by the positive charges of the protons in the nuclei

questions.correct_answer: the closer an electron is to the nucleus, the more strongly the electron is attracted to the nucleus and therefore the more potential energy the electron has
questions.neutral_comments: It is true that the closer an electron is to the nucleus, the more strongly the electron is attracted to the nucleus. However, it is NOT true that an electron has more potential energy when it is closer to the nucleus. In fact, it will have less potential energy the closer it gets to the nucleus. Think of it this way, the further from the earth you send a rocket, the less strongly it is attracted to the earth by gravity, but the more potential energy it has.
questions.all_comments: Good job!It is true that the closer an electron is to the nucleus, the more strongly the electron is attracted to the nucleus.  However, it is NOT true that an electron has more potential energy when it is closer to the nucleus. In fact, it will have less potential energy the closer it gets to the nucleus.  Think of it this way, the further from the earth you send a rocket, the less strongly it is attracted to the earth by gravity, but the more potential energy it has.

questions.question: When a sodium atom and a chlorine atom interact to complete their valence shells

answers.text: an electron is transferred from sodium to chlorine, turning the sodium atom into a cation and the chlorine atom into an anion and allowing the two atoms to form an ionic bond
an electron is transferred from sodium to chlorine, turning the sodium atom into an anion and the chlorine atom into a cation and allowing the two atoms to form an ionic bond
they form 1 polar covalent bond
they form 2 polar covalent bonds

questions.correct_answer: an electron is transferred from sodium to chlorine, turning the sodium atom into a cation and the chlorine atom into an anion and allowing the two atoms to form an ionic bond
questions.neutral_comments: Chlorine is so much more electronegative than sodium that, rather than sharing a pair of electrons, the lone electron in the valence (= 3rd) shell of sodium is transferred to chlorine. That leaves the sodium cation with no electrons in the 3rd electron shell and a full set (8) of electrons in the 2nd electron shell. The 1 electron transferred to the chlorine atom is sufficient to complete the valence shell of that atom. Because chlorine now has one more electron than it has protons, the chlorine anion will have a charge of negative 1. Negatively charged ions are called “anions” and positively charged ions are called “cations”.
questions.all_comments: Good work!Chlorine is so much more electronegative than sodium that, rather than sharing a pair of electrons, the lone electron in the valence (= 3rd) shell of sodium is transferred to chlorine. questions.question: What gives rise to the cohesiveness of water molecules?

answers.text: Hydrophobic interactions
Ionic bonds
Nonpolar covalent bonds
Hydrogen bonds

questions.correct_answer: Hydrogen bonds
questions.neutral_comments: Water molecules stick to each other because the oxygen atom in a water molecule carries a partial negative charge and the two hydrogen atoms each carry a partial positive charge. As a result, the partially positively charged hydrogen atoms of one water molecule are attracted to the partially negatively charged oxygen atoms of other water molecules. The reason that the hydrogen atoms carry partial positive charges and the oxygen atoms carry partial negative charges is that the covalent bonds within a water molecule are polar. Each electron pair forming a covalent bond between an oxygen atom and a hydrogen atom spends more time near oxygen than near hydrogen, as oxygen atoms are more electronegative than hydrogen atoms.
questions.all_comments: Water molecules stick to each other because the oxygen atom in a water molecule carries a partial negative charge and the two hydrogen atoms each carry a partial positive charge.  As a result, the partially positively charged hydrogen atoms of one water molecule are attracted to the partially negatively charged oxygen atoms of other water molecules. The reason that the hydrogen atoms carry partial positive charges and the oxygen atoms carry partial negative charges is that the covalent bonds within a water molecule are polar. Each electron pair forming a covalent bond between an oxygen atom and a hydrogen atom spends more time near oxygen than near hydrogen, as oxygen atoms are more electronegative than hydrogen atoms.

Note that you do NOT need to know the exact value of 10-1.5 to identify the correct answer for this question. If you realize that 10-1.5 is between 10-1(= 0.1) and 10-2 (= 0.01) in value, than you will see that the only answer that lies within this range is 0.03 moles/liter.

questions.neutral_comments: The chemical behavior of atoms is mostly dependent on their valence electrons, which are the electrons in their outermost, or valence, electron shell. Depending on the number of electrons the atoms of a particular element have, the electrons may be sufficient to fill only the 1st electron shell, leaving the 1st shell as the outermost shell. Atoms of elements with more electrons may have sufficient electrons to fill the first electron shell and to partially or fully fill the 2nd shell, but not to place any electrons in the 3rd electron shell. In that case, the 2ndshell would be the outermost shell that has electrons and would thus be the valence shell.

If a ball is moved up two steps its energy level will increase twice as much as if it is moved up one step (assuming the steps are of equal height). However, it is not feasible to increase the potential energy of the ball by 0.5 or 1.5 steps.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about bases is FALSE?

answers.text: Some bases reduce H+ concentrations by accepting hydrogen ions.
Some bases reduce H+ concentrations by dissociating to form hydroxide (OH-) anions.
Bases cause the pH of the solution to decrease.
Bases cause the concentration of hydroxide (OH-) anions to increase and the concentration of H+ cations to decrease.

questions.correct_answer: Bases cause the pH of the solution to decrease.
questions.all_comments:
Bases cause the hydrogen ion concentration of a solution to DECREASE. Remember that, because pH is the NEGATIVE log of the hydrogen ion concentration, when the hydrogen ion concentration of a solution decreases, the pH of that solution increases. So, bases cause the pH of a solution to INCREASE, rather than decrease.
 
Bases cause the concentration of H+ ions to decrease by one of two ways. Some bases reduce H+ concentrations by dissociating to form hydroxide (OH-) anions. The hydroxide ions from the bases then react with H+ in the water to form water molecules, thereby reducing H+ concentrations. Alternatively, some bases reduce H+ concentrations by accepting (binding with) hydrogen ions.
 
So, because the question asks which statement about bases is FALSE, the correct answer to the question is that bases cause the pH to decrease, since bases actually cause the pH to increase.

Atoms of elements with more electrons may have sufficient electrons to fill the first electron shell and to partially or fully fill the 2nd shell, but not to place any electrons in the 3rd electron shell. In that case, the 2ndshell would be the outermost shell that has electrons and would thus be the valence shell.

This means the bond will be a polar covalent bond.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about moles is true?

answers.text: All of these answers are correct.
One mole of hydrogen molecules (H2) weighs 2 g
One mole of hydrogen atoms weighs 1 g
A mole is 6.02 X 1023

questions.correct_answer: All of these answers are correct.
questions.neutral_comments: All of these answers are correct. A mole is 6.02 X 1023. A hydrogen atom weighs one Dalton so one mole of hydrogen atoms weighs 1 g. One mole of hydrogen molecules (H2) weighs 2 g. This is because hydrogen molecules have the formula: H2. Therefore, the molecular weight of hydrogen molecules is 2 Daltons and a mole of hydrogen molecules will weigh 2 g.
questions.all_comments: All of these answers are correct. A mole is 6.02 X 1023. A hydrogen atom weighs one Dalton so one mole of hydrogen atoms weighs 1 g. One mole of hydrogen molecules (H2) weighs 2 g. This is because hydrogen molecules have the formula: H2. questions.question: A solution with a pH of 13 contains what concentration of hydroxyl ions [OH<sup>-</sup>]?

answers.text: 0.1 moles/liter
10-13 moles/liter
0.01 moles/liter
13 moles/liter

questions.correct_answer: 0.1 moles/liter
questions.neutral_comments: The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter. In other words, pH = - log [H+]. So, in this case: 13 = - log [H+]. Or, -13 = log [H+]. Or, 10-13 M = [H+]. Furthermore, the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature). So, if the hydrogen ion concentration is 10-13M (moles per liter), the hydroxyl ion concentration must be 10-14/10-13= 10-1 M, or 0.1 M, or 0.1 moles/liter.
questions.all_comments: The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter.  In other words, pH = - log [H+].  So, in this case:  13 = - log [H+].  Or, -13 = log [H+].  Or, 10-13 M = [H+].  Furthermore, the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature).  So, if the hydrogen ion concentration is 10-13M (moles per liter), the hydroxyl ion concentration must be 10-14/10-13= 10-1 M, or 0.1 M, or 0.1 moles/liter.

questions.question: If the pH of a solution is decreased from 9 to 8, it means that the

answers.text: concentration of OH- has increased tenfold (10X) compared to what it was at pH 9.
the concentration of both OH- and H+ increased tenfold (10X) compared to what they were at pH 9
concentration of H+ has increased tenfold (10X) compared to what it was at pH 9.
concentration of H+ has decreased to one-tenth (1/10) what it was at pH 9.

questions.correct_answer: concentration of H+ has increased tenfold (10X) compared to what it was at pH 9.
questions.all_comments:
The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter.  In other words, pH = - log [H+].  So, in this case:
9 = - log [H+].  Or, -9 = log [H+].  Or, 10-9 = [H+]. Or, 0.000000001 M = [H+]
and
8 = - log [H+].  Or, -8 = log [H+].  Or, 10-8 = [H+]. Or, 0.00000001 M = [H+].
So, when the pH of a solution decreases from 9 to 8, the hydrogen ion concentration in the solution increases 10 fold. In an aqueous solution at 25 °C, it is also true that [H+] X [OH-] = 10-14. So, in an aqueous solution, when the hydrogen ion increases 10 fold, the hydroxyl ion concentration must decrease 10 fold.

questions.all_comments: When water vaporizes, the bonds within individual water molecules (which are polar covalent bonds), are not broken. Instead, it is the bonds BETWEEN different water molecules that are broken.  The bonds between different water molecules are hydrogen bonds.

questions.question: How many covalent bonds do hydrogen atoms need to form with other atoms to complete their valence shell?
questions.neutral_comments: Hydrogen atoms have 1 electron in their valence shell, which is the 1stelectron shell. The total number of electrons needed to fill the 1stelectron shell is 2, so hydrogen needs to form one covalent bond with another atom in order to fill its valence shell. Alternatively, hydrogen can “fill” its valence shell by transferring its one electron to another atom. You might expect that hydrogen could also fill its valence shell by transferring an electron FROM another atom, but that would leave the hydrogen with 2 electrons and only one proton which, it turns out, is energetically unfavorable.
questions.all_comments: ExcellentHydrogen atoms have 1 electron in their valence shell, which is the 1stelectron shell. The total number of electrons needed to fill the 1stelectron shell is 2, so hydrogen needs to form one covalent bond with another atom in order to fill its valence shell. Alternatively, hydrogen can “fill” its valence shell by transferring its one electron to another atom. You might expect that hydrogen could also fill its valence shell by transferring an electron FROM another atom, but that would leave the hydrogen with 2 electrons and only one proton which, it turns out, is energetically unfavorable.

questions.question: With regards to orbitals, which of the following statements is FALSE?

answers.text: An orbital is occupied by one or two electrons.
An orbital is a defined path that an electron follows as it orbits the nucleus.
An orbital is a region surrounding the nucleus where the probability of finding an electron is high.
An orbital can be depicted as a cloud where an electron may be located.

questions.correct_answer: An orbital is a defined path that an electron follows as it orbits the nucleus.
questions.neutral_comments: Electrons do not follow defined paths and the position of an electron cannot be precisely known. Instead, we can only say that there is a high probability of a particular electron being located somewhere within a space defined by the orbital for that electron.

questions.question: The further on average an electron is from the nucleus

answers.text: the greater its potential energy
the lower its potential energy
the less highly charged it is
the more highly charged it is

questions.correct_answer: the greater its potential energy
questions.neutral_comments: The further an electron is from the nucleus, the greater its potential energy. Think of it this way. Negatively charged electrons are attracted to the positively charged protons in the nucleus. So, it takes work to increase the separation between an electron and the nucleus. Some of the energy spent in doing this work is stored in the form of increasing the potential energy of the moved electron. This is conceptually similar to increasing the potential energy of a ball by carrying it higher up a hill.
questions.all_comments: Good job!The further an electron is from the nucleus, the greater its potential energy.  Think of it this way.  Negatively charged electrons are attracted to the positively charged protons in the nucleus. So, it takes work to increase the separation between an electron and the nucleus. Some of the energy spent in doing this work is stored in the form of increasing the potential energy of the moved electron. This is conceptually similar to increasing the potential energy of a ball by carrying it higher up a hill.

questions.question: The molar mass of glucose is 180 g/mol. Which of the following procedures should you carry out to make a 1 M (molar) solution of glucose?

answers.text: Dissolve 180 g of glucose in 0.8 L of water, and then add more water until the total volume of the solution is 1 L.
Dissolve 180 g of glucose in 180 g of water.
Dissolve 1 g of glucose in 1 L of water.
Dissolve 180 g of glucose in 1 L of water.

questions.correct_answer: Dissolve 180 g of glucose in 0.8 L of water, and then add more water until the total volume of the solution is 1 L.
questions.all_comments:
A one molar solution has one mole of solute molecules for every liter of solution.  So, to make 1 liter of a 1 molar solution of glucose, you can mix 1 mole of glucose molecules with enough water to bring the total volume of the solution to 1 liter. 
Note that if you add one liter of solvent, when you then add the solute the total volume of the solution will be greater than 1 liter.  So, your solution will have one mole of solute molecules but a total volume that is greater than 1 liter. As a result, your solution will be too dilute.
Also, the weight of a molecule in daltons is equal to the weight of a mole of those same molecules in grams.  In other words, if a single molecule of glucose weighs 180 daltons, than a mole of glucose molecules (i.e. 6.02 X 1023 glucose molecules) will weigh 180 grams.  So, you need 180 g of glucose to have 1 mole of glucose molecules.

questions.question: A solution with a pH of 1.5 contains what concentration of hydrogen ions [H<sup>+</sup>]?

answers.text: 1.5 moles/liter
0.001 moles/liter
0.03 moles/liter
0.15 moles/liter

questions.correct_answer: 0.03 moles/liter
questions.neutral_comments: The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter. In other words, pH = - log [H+]. So, in this case: 1.5 = - log [H+]. Or, -1.5 = log [H+]. Or, 10-1.5 = [H+]. Or, 0.03 moles/liter = [H+]. Note that you do NOT need to know the exact value of 10-1.5 to identify the correct answer for this question. If you realize that 10-1.5 is between 10-1(= 0.1) and 10-2 (= 0.01) in value, than you will see that the only answer that lies within this range is 0.03 moles/liter.
questions.all_comments: The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter.  In other words, pH = - log [H+].  So, in this case:  1.5 = - log [H+].  Or, -1.5 = log [H+].  Or, 10-1.5 = [H+]. Or, 0.03 moles/liter = [H+].  Note that you do NOT need to know the exact value of 10-1.5 to identify the correct answer for this question.  If you realize that 10-1.5 is between 10-1(= 0.1) and 10-2 (= 0.01) in value, than you will see that the only answer that lies within this range is 0.03 moles/liter.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about bases is FALSE?

answers.text: Bases cause the concentration of hydroxide (OH-) anions to increase and the concentration of H+ cations to decrease.
Some bases reduce H+ concentrations by dissociating to form hydroxide (OH-) anions.
Bases cause the pH of the solution to decrease.
Some bases reduce H+ concentrations by accepting hydrogen ions.

questions.correct_answer: Bases cause the pH of the solution to decrease.
questions.all_comments:
Bases cause the hydrogen ion concentration of a solution to DECREASE. Remember that, because pH is the NEGATIVE log of the hydrogen ion concentration, when the hydrogen ion concentration of a solution decreases, the pH of that solution increases. So, bases cause the pH of a solution to INCREASE, rather than decrease.
 
Bases cause the concentration of H+ ions to decrease by one of two ways. Some bases reduce H+ concentrations by dissociating to form hydroxide (OH-) anions. The hydroxide ions from the bases then react with H+ in the water to form water molecules, thereby reducing H+ concentrations. Alternatively, some bases reduce H+ concentrations by accepting (binding with) hydrogen ions.
 
So, because the question asks which statement about bases is FALSE, the correct answer to the question is that bases cause the pH to decrease, since bases actually cause the pH to increase.

questions.question: In humans, blood pH is around 7.4, and a decrease in blood pH to 6.4 would be fatal. A drop by 1 pH unit represents which of the following?

answers.text: twice as many H+ ions in the solution
1/2 as many H+ ions in the solution
1/10 as many H+ ions in the solution
ten times as many H+ ions in the solution

questions.correct_answer: ten times as many H+ ions in the solution
questions.all_comments:
The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter.  In other words, pH = - log [H+].  So, for example:
If the pH = 1, than:
1 = - log [H+].  Or, -1 = log [H+].  Or, 10-1 = [H+]. Or, 0.1 moles/liter (M) = [H+]
and
If the pH = 2, than:
2 = - log [H+].  Or, -2 = log [H+].  Or, 10-2 = [H+]. Or, 0.01 moles/liter (M) = [H+].
So, when the pH of a solution decreases from 2 to 1, the hydrogen ion concentration in the solution increases by 10 times.  Similarly, when the pH decreases from 7.4 to 6.4, the hydrogen ion concentration increases by 10 times.

questions.question: If two molecules have the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures, the two molecules may be

answers.text: Geometric isomers
Structural isomers
Enantiomers
All of these answers are correct

questions.correct_answer: All of these answers are correct
questions.neutral_comments: Isomers of any type (structural isomers, geometric isomers and enantiomers) all meet the criteria of having the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures. Structural isomers have the further criteria that, for two molecules to be structural isomers of each other, they must differ in their covalent partnerships. In contrast, molecules that are geometric isomers or enantiomers do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships. Geometric isomers differ in the arrangement of atoms around a double bond. Enantiomers differ in the arrangement of atoms covalently bound to a central, asymmetric carbon and are mirror images of each other. Please see figure 4.7 in your textbook for a figure showing all three types of isomer.

questions.correct_answer: Structural isomers
questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C4H10), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements (i.e. they each have 4 carbon atoms and 10 hydrogen atoms), but different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. Because they differ in the covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are examples of the type of isomers known structural isomers.

questions.correct_answer: Enantiomers
questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (CN2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers. In addition, because these molecules do not have 2 carbon atoms joined by a double bond, they cannot be geometric isomers. Instead, they are “enantiomers”. Enantiomers are mirror images of each other and cannot be superimposed on each other. This is quite similar to how our hands are mirror images of each other, but cannot be superimposed on each other. For example, imagine the palms of your hands as being carbon atom and the four fingers on each hand representing covalent bonds to 4 different groups. There is no way to place one hand on the other hand so that all four of your fingers will match up. Note that enantiomers only occur in molecules that have an asymmetric carbon. For a carbon to be asymmetric, it must form covalent bonds to 4 different groups.
questions.all_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (CN2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but different 3-dimensional shapes.  So, they are isomers of some sort.  Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers. questions.correct_answer: Geometric isomers
questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but have different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers. For example, both carbon atoms in both molecules are attached to one hydroxyl (OH) group and one hydrogen atom. However, the two molecules do have different structures. Remember that double covalent bonds are inflexible. So, the above molecules cannot rotate around their double bonds in the way that they could if the two carbon atoms were only joined by single covalent bonds. So, in the molecule on the left, the two hydroxyl (OH) groups will always be on the opposite sides of the double bond, whereas the two hydroxyl groups will always be on the same side of the double bond in the molecule on the right. Molecules such as these two, which have the same covalent partnerships but different spatial arrangements, are known as geometric isomers. The molecule on the left, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the hydroxyl groups) on opposite sides of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a trans isomer. The molecule on the right, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the hydroxyl groups) on the same side of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a cis isomer.

The 1st carbon on the left in this molecule is bonded to only 3 different groups (a hydrogen atom, an oxygen atom and a hydrocarbon chain). The 3rd carbon is also bonded to only 3 different groups (two hydrogen atoms, a short hydrocarbon chain and the part of the molecule that is to the left of that carbon atom). The 4th carbon from the left is only bound to 3 different groups (2 hydrogen atoms, a methyl group and the rest of the molecule that is to the left of the 4th carbon). The 5th (last) carbon from the left is only bonded to 2 different groups as it forms covalent bonds with 3 hydrogen atoms and the rest of the molecule that is to the left of the 5th carbon. In contrast, the 2nd carbon from the left is bound to 4 different groups: a COH group, a hydrogen atom, an OH group and a short hydrocarbon chain. Each of the four different groups to which the second carbon from the left is bound is shown circled in red in the figure below.

questions.question: If two molecules have the same numbers of atoms of the same elements and the SAME covalent partnerships but different structures, the two molecules may be

answers.text: Enantiomers
Geometric isomers
Either enantiomers or geometric isomers
Structural isomers

questions.correct_answer: Either enantiomers or geometric isomers
questions.neutral_comments: Isomers of any type (structural isomers, geometric isomers and enantiomers) must all meet the criteria of having the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures. Structural isomers have the further criteria that, for two molecules to be structural isomers of each other, they must differ in their covalent partnerships. In contrast, molecules that are geometric isomers or enantiomers do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships. Geometric isomers differ in the arrangement of atoms around a double bond. Enantiomers differ in the arrangement of atoms covalently bound to a central, asymmetric carbon and are mirror images of each other. Please see figure 4.7 in your textbook for a figure showing all three types of isomer.

questions.neutral_comments: Isomers of any type (structural isomers, geometric isomers and enantiomers) must all meet the criteria of having the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures. Structural isomers have the further criteria that, for two molecules to be structural isomers of each other, they must differ in their covalent partnerships. In contrast, molecules that are geometric isomers or enantiomers do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships. Geometric isomers differ in the arrangement of atoms around a double bond. Enantiomers differ in the arrangement of atoms covalently bound to a central, asymmetric carbon and are mirror images of each other. Please see figure 4.7 in your textbook for a figure showing all three types of isomer.

questions.question: The molecules shown below are best described as

answers.text: Geometric isomers
Isotopes
Structural isomers
Enantiomers

questions.correct_answer: Geometric isomers
questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but have different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers. For example, both carbon atoms in both molecules are attached to one hydroxyl (OH) group and one hydrogen atom. However, the two molecules do have different structures. Remember that double covalent bonds are inflexible. So, the above molecules cannot rotate around their double bonds in the way that they could if the two carbon atoms were only joined by single covalent bonds. So, in the molecule on the left, the two hydroxyl (OH) groups will always be on the opposite sides of the double bond, whereas the two hydroxyl groups will always be on the same side of the double bond in the molecule on the right. Molecules such as these two, which have the same covalent partnerships but different spatial arrangements, are known as geometric isomers. The molecule on the left, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the hydroxyl groups) on opposite sides of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a trans isomer. The molecule on the right, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the hydroxyl groups) on the same side of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a cis isomer.
questions.all_comments: Good work!These two molecules have the same formula (C2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but have different 3-dimensional shapes.  So, they are isomers of some sort.  Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers.  For example, both carbon atoms in both molecules are attached to one hydroxyl (OH) group and one hydrogen atom.  However, the two molecules do have different structures.  Remember that double covalent bonds are inflexible.  So, the above molecules cannot rotate around their double bonds in the way that they could if the two carbon atoms were only joined by single covalent bonds.  So, in the molecule on the left, the two hydroxyl (OH) groups will always be on the opposite sides of the double bond, whereas the two hydroxyl groups will always be on the same side of the double bond in the molecule on the right.  Molecules such as these two, which have the same covalent partnerships but different spatial arrangements, are known as geometric isomers.  The molecule on the left, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the hydroxyl groups) on opposite sides of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a trans isomer.  The molecule on the right, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the hydroxyl groups) on the same side of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a cis isomer.

questions.question: The molecules shown below are best described as

answers.text: Structural isomers
Geometric isomers
Enantiomers
Isotopes

questions.correct_answer: Enantiomers
questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C3N2O2H3), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers. In addition, because these molecules do not have 2 carbon atoms joined by a double bond, they cannot be geometric isomers. Instead, they are “enantiomers”. Enantiomers are mirror images of each other and cannot be superimposed on each other. This is quite similar to how our hands are mirror images of each other, but cannot be superimposed on each other. For example, imagine the palms of your hands as being carbon atom and the four fingers on each hand representing covalent bonds to 4 different groups. There is no way to place one hand on the other hand so that all four of your fingers will match up. Note that enantiomers only occur in molecules that have an asymmetric carbon. For a carbon to be asymmetric, it must form covalent bonds to 4 different groups. In the molecule on the left above, the asymmetric carbon is the carbon furthest to the left. In the molecule on the right above, the asymmetric carbon is the carbon furthest to the right.

In this molecule, the carbon atoms are making covalent bonds to just 3 other atoms, because the two carbon atoms are forming a double covalent bond with each other.

questions.question: The molecules shown below are best described as

answers.text: Structural isomers
Isotopes
Geometric isomers
Enantiomers

questions.correct_answer: Geometric isomers
questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C2N2O2H2), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers. For example, both carbon atoms in both molecules are attached to one N=O group and one hydrogen atom. However, the two molecules do have different structures. Remember that double covalent bonds are inflexible. So, the above molecules cannot rotate around their double bonds in the way that they could if the two carbon atoms were only joined by single covalent bonds. So, in the molecule on the left, the two N=O groups will always be on the opposite sides of the double bond, whereas the two N=O groups will always be on the same side of the double bond in the molecule on the right. Molecules such as these two, which have the same covalent partnerships but different spatial arrangements, are known as geometric isomers. The molecule on the left, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the N=O groups) on opposite sides of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a trans isomer. The molecule on the right, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the N=O groups) on the same side of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a cis isomer.

questions.question: Which of the following terms most accurately describes the shape of an ethylene molecule?

answers.text: flat
spherical
tetrahedral
cubical

questions.correct_answer: flat
questions.neutral_comments: The double bond between the two carbon atoms means that all the covalent bonds formed by the carbon atoms lie in a single plane. Therefore this molecule is flat. Remember that the covalent bonds formed by carbon atoms point towards the 4 corners of a tetrahedron only when the carbon atom makes bonds to 4 other atoms. In this molecule, the carbon atoms are making covalent bonds to just 3 other atoms, because the two carbon atoms are forming a double covalent bond with each other.

questions.question: If two molecules have the same numbers of atoms of the same elements and the SAME covalent partnerships but different structures, the two molecules may be

answers.text: Geometric isomers
Structural isomers
Enantiomers
answers.comment: The molecules could be either enantiomers or geometric isomers.

answers.text: Either enantiomers or geometric isomers

questions.correct_answer: Either enantiomers or geometric isomers
questions.neutral_comments: Isomers of any type (structural isomers, geometric isomers and enantiomers) must all meet the criteria of having the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures. Structural isomers have the further criteria that, for two molecules to be structural isomers of each other, they must differ in their covalent partnerships. In contrast, molecules that are geometric isomers or enantiomers do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships. Geometric isomers differ in the arrangement of atoms around a double bond. Enantiomers differ in the arrangement of atoms covalently bound to a central, asymmetric carbon and are mirror images of each other. Please see figure 4.7 in your textbook for a figure showing all three types of isomer.
questions.all_comments: Isomers of any type (structural isomers, geometric isomers and enantiomers) must all meet the criteria of having the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures.  Structural isomers have the further criteria that, for two molecules to be structural isomers of each other, they must differ in their covalent partnerships.  In contrast, molecules that are geometric isomers or enantiomers do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships.  Geometric isomers differ in the arrangement of atoms around a double bond.  Enantiomers differ in the arrangement of atoms covalently bound to a central, asymmetric carbon and are mirror images of each other.  Please see figure 4.7 in your textbook for a figure showing all three types of isomer.

questions.correct_answer: Structural isomers
questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C2N2O2H2), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. For example, both carbon atoms in the molecule on the left are attached to one N=O and one hydrogen. questions.question: Which of the following statements is FALSE?

answers.text: Nucleotides are the monomers from which nucleic acids are formed.
Fatty acids are the monomers from which lipid molecules are formed.
Amino acids are the monomers from which proteins are formed.
Sugars are the monomers from which polysaccharides are formed.

questions.correct_answer: Fatty acids are the monomers from which lipid molecules are formed.
questions.neutral_comments: Fatty acids are important in lipid formation, but are not monomers as monomers are simple molecules, many of which are combined to form a polymer. In contrast, fatty acids are fairly large molecules and few of them are used to make a lipid molecule. For example, just two fatty acid molecules are used in the synthesis of a typical membrane lipid molecule (e.g. a phospholipid) and just three fatty acid molecules are used to make a typical lipid molecule in fat (e.g. a triacylglycerol molecule). In addition, monomers are linked together like cars forming a train to form a polymer. In contrast, the fatty acid molecules that are used to form lipids are not joined to each other. For example, the three fatty acid molecules used to form a triacylglycerol molecule (a type of lipid molecule) are each joined separately to different parts of a glycerol molecule. So, remember that lipids are the one type of biological macromolecule we will discuss that are NOT polymers because they are NOT composed of monomers.
questions.all_comments: Nice job!Fatty acids are important in lipid formation, but are not monomers as monomers are simple molecules, many of which are combined to form a polymer.  In contrast, fatty acids are fairly large molecules and few of them are used to make a lipid molecule.  For example, just two fatty acid molecules are used in the synthesis of a typical membrane lipid molecule (e.g. a phospholipid) and just three fatty acid molecules are used to make a typical lipid molecule in fat (e.g. a triacylglycerol molecule).  In addition, monomers are linked together like cars forming a train to form a polymer.  In contrast, the fatty acid molecules that are used to form lipids are not joined to each other.  For example, the three fatty acid molecules used to form a triacylglycerol molecule (a type of lipid molecule) are each joined separately to different parts of a glycerol molecule.  So, remember that lipids are the one type of biological macromolecule we will discuss that are NOT polymers because they are NOT composed of monomers.

questions.question: If you were asked to build a polymer that is two monomers long (ok, that wouldn’t really be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and you could use two different types of monomers, “A” and “B”, how many different polymers could you build?
questions.neutral_comments: You could build 4 different polymers: A-A, B-B, A-B and B-A. You might wonder if A-B and B-A are really the same thing. They are not the same thing because one end of a polymer has a hydrogen attached and the other end of the polymer has a hydroxyl group. In other words, you could write the above molecules as: H-O-A-B-H and H-O-B-A-H, which makes it clear that they are not the same molecule.

They are not the same thing because one end of a polymer has a hydrogen attached and the other end of the polymer has a hydroxyl group. In other words, you could write the above molecules as: H-O-A-B-H and H-O-B-A-H, which makes it clear that they are not the same molecule.

questions.question: L-methionine and D-methionine are examples of

answers.text: geometric isomers
enantiomers
all of these answers are correct
structural isomers

questions.correct_answer: enantiomers
questions.neutral_comments: All amino acids except glycine have an asymmetric carbon, meaning a carbon atom that is covalently bound to 4 different groups. In the case of all amino acids except glycine, those groups are: a carboxyl group, an amino group, a hydrogen and an "R" group. The reason that glycine does not have an asymmetric carbon is because the R group of glycine is hydrogen. So, the central carbon of a glycine molecule is only bound to 3 different groups, since it is bound to two hydrogen atoms. Molecules with asymmetric carbons may occur as two different isomers, known as enantiomers. Enantiomers have the same covalent partnerships (i.e. they do NOT differ in which elements are covalently bound to which other elements), but are instead mirror images of each other. L-methionine and D-methionine meet this definition and so are enantiomers. Please see figure 4.7 in your book for a figure illustrating the different types of isomers.
questions.all_comments: Good work!All amino acids except glycine have an asymmetric carbon, meaning a carbon atom that is covalently bound to 4 different groups.  In the case of all amino acids except glycine, those groups are: a carboxyl group, an amino group, a hydrogen and an "R" group.  The reason that glycine does not have an asymmetric carbon is because the R group of glycine is hydrogen.  So, the central carbon of a glycine molecule is only bound to 3 different groups, since it is bound to two hydrogen atoms.   Molecules with asymmetric carbons may occur as two different isomers, known as enantiomers.  Enantiomers have the same covalent partnerships (i.e. they do NOT differ in which elements are covalently bound to which other elements), but are instead mirror images of each other.  L-methionine and D-methionine meet this definition and so are enantiomers.  Please see figure 4.7 in your book for a figure illustrating the different types of isomers.

questions.question: Glucose and fructose are examples of

answers.text: geometric isomers
all of these answers are correct

questions.correct_answer: structural isomers
questions.neutral_comments: Glucose and fructose have the same molecular formula (C6H12O6), but different shapes, so you can see that they are isomers of some sort. To determine what type of isomers they represent, first look to see if the two molecules (glucose and fructose), share the same covalent partnerships. If you look at them, you will see that they do not share the same covalent partnerships. For example, the position of the carbon:oxygen double bond (C=O) is different for glucose and fructose. This means that glucose and fructose are examples of structural isomers. The other two types of isomers we studied, geometric isomers and enantiomers, do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships.

questions.question: If you were asked to build a polymer that is 30 monomers long, and you could use two different types of monomers, “A” and “B”, how many different polymers could you build?

answers.text: ~ 1 billion

questions.correct_answer: ~ 1 billion
questions.neutral_comments: Think of it this way: If you were asked to build a polymer that was just one monomer long (ok, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), you would be able to build just two different “polymers”: A and B. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 2 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), you would be able to build just 4 different “polymers”: AA, AB, BA and BB. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 3 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), you would be able to build just 8 different “polymers”: AAA, AAB, ABA, BAA, ABB, BAB. BBA and BBB. Are you seeing a pattern here? The answer to this type of question may be found using the following formula: Number of different polymers that may be formed = XY, where “X” is the number of different types of monomers available and “Y” is the number of monomers in the polymer. So, if you were asked to build a polymer that is 30 monomers long, and you could use two different types of monomers, “A” and “B”, the number of different polymers you could build would be: 230 = ~ 1,000,000,000
questions.all_comments: Nice job!Think of it this way: If you were asked to build a polymer that was just one monomer long (ok, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), you would be able to build just two different “polymers”: A and B.  If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 2 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), you would be able to build just 4 different “polymers”: AA, AB, BA and BB. questions.question: L-methionine and D-methionine are examples of

answers.text: geometric isomers
all of these answers are correct
structural isomers
enantiomers

questions.correct_answer: enantiomers
questions.neutral_comments: All amino acids except glycine have an asymmetric carbon, meaning a carbon atom that is covalently bound to 4 different groups. In the case of all amino acids except glycine, those groups are: a carboxyl group, an amino group, a hydrogen and an "R" group. The reason that glycine does not have an asymmetric carbon is because the R group of glycine is hydrogen. So, the central carbon of a glycine molecule is only bound to 3 different groups, since it is bound to two hydrogen atoms. Molecules with asymmetric carbons may occur as two different isomers, known as enantiomers. Enantiomers have the same covalent partnerships (i.e. they do NOT differ in which elements are covalently bound to which other elements), but are instead mirror images of each other. L-methionine and D-methionine meet this definition and so are enantiomers. Please see figure 4.7 in your book for a figure illustrating the different types of isomers.

Good work!

questions.question: If you were asked to build a polymer that is 20 monomers long (note that this would be an unusually short polymer), and you could use four different types of monomers, “A”, “B”, “C” and “D”, how many different polymers could you build?

answers.text: ~ 1 million

questions.neutral_comments: Think of it this way: If you were asked to build a polymer that was just one monomer long (ok, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and you had only “A” and “B” monomers available to use, you would be able to build just two different “polymers”: A and B. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 2 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and had only “A” and “B” monomers available, you would be able to build just 4 different “polymers”: AA, AB, BA and BB. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 3 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and had only “A” and “B” monomers available, you would be able to build just 8 different “polymers”: AAA, AAB, ABA, BAA, ABB, BAB. BBA and BBB. Are you seeing a pattern here? The answer to this type of question may be found using the following formula: Number of different polymers that may be formed = XY, where “X” is the number of different types of monomers available and “Y” is the number of monomers in the polymer. So, if you were asked to build a polymer that is 20 monomers long, and you could use four different types of monomers, the number of different polymers you could build would be: 420 = ~ 1 x 1012

questions.question: Which of the following statements is FALSE?

answers.text: Amino acids are the monomers from which proteins are formed.
Nucleotides are the monomers from which nucleic acids are formed.
Sugars are the monomers from which polysaccharides are formed.
Fatty acids are the monomers from which lipid molecules are formed.

questions.correct_answer: Fatty acids are the monomers from which lipid molecules are formed.
questions.neutral_comments: Fatty acids are important in lipid formation, but are not monomers as monomers are simple molecules, many of which are combined to form a polymer. In contrast, fatty acids are fairly large molecules and few of them are used to make a lipid molecule. For example, just two fatty acid molecules are used in the synthesis of a typical membrane lipid molecule (e.g. a phospholipid) and just three fatty acid molecules are used to make a typical lipid molecule in fat (e.g. a triacylglycerol molecule). In addition, monomers are linked together like cars forming a train to form a polymer. In contrast, the fatty acid molecules that are used to form lipids are not joined to each other. For example, the three fatty acid molecules used to form a triacylglycerol molecule (a type of lipid molecule) are each joined separately to different parts of a glycerol molecule. So, remember that lipids are the one type of biological macromolecule we will discuss that are NOT polymers because they are NOT composed of monomers.
questions.all_comments: Nice job!Fatty acids are important in lipid formation, but are not monomers as monomers are simple molecules, many of which are combined to form a polymer.  In contrast, fatty acids are fairly large molecules and few of them are used to make a lipid molecule.  For example, just two fatty acid molecules are used in the synthesis of a typical membrane lipid molecule (e.g. a phospholipid) and just three fatty acid molecules are used to make a typical lipid molecule in fat (e.g. a triacylglycerol molecule).  In addition, monomers are linked together like cars forming a train to form a polymer.  In contrast, the fatty acid molecules that are used to form lipids are not joined to each other.  For example, the three fatty acid molecules used to form a triacylglycerol molecule (a type of lipid molecule) are each joined separately to different parts of a glycerol molecule.  So, remember that lipids are the one type of biological macromolecule we will discuss that are NOT polymers because they are NOT composed of monomers.

questions.question: How many water molecules are needed to completely hydrolyze a polymer that is 18 nucleotides long?
questions.neutral_comments: Think of it this way: How many water molecules would be needed to completely hydrolyze a “polymer” that is just two nucleotides long? You would need just one, to split the one bond joining the two monomers, right? So, how many water molecules would you need to completely hydrolyze a “polymer” that is 3 monomers long? The answer is that you would need 2 water molecules, one to split the bond between the 1stand 2nd monomers and the other to hydrolyze the bond between the 2ndand 3rd monomers. So, you to completely hydrolyze a polymer takes one less water molecule than the number of monomers in the polymer.
questions.all_comments: Good work!Think of it this way: How many water molecules would be needed to completely hydrolyze a “polymer” that is just two nucleotides long?  You would need just one, to split the one bond joining the two monomers, right?  So, how many water molecules would you need to completely hydrolyze a “polymer” that is 3 monomers long?  The answer is that you would need 2 water molecules, one to split the bond between the 1stand 2nd monomers and the other to hydrolyze the bond between the 2ndand 3rd monomers.  So, you to completely hydrolyze a polymer takes one less water molecule than the number of monomers in the polymer.

questions.question: If you were asked to build a polymer that is two monomers long (ok, that wouldn’t really be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and you could use two different types of monomers, “A” and “B”, how many different polymers could you build?

In other words, you could write the above molecules as: H-O-A-B-H and H-O-B-A-H, which makes it clear that they are not the same molecule.

questions.question: A dehydration reaction joins two glucose molecules to form maltose. The formula for glucose is C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>12</sub>O<sub>6</sub>. What is the correct formula for maltose?
questions.neutral_comments: You are joining two molecules of glucose to form maltose, so maltose will have twice as many atoms of each element as glucose, except that you have to remember that a water molecule is lost during the dehydration reaction. So, maltose will have 12 carbon atoms, but only 22 hydrogen atoms instead of 24 because of the two hydrogen atoms lost during formation of the water molecule. Similarly, maltose will have 11 oxygen atoms instead of 12, as one oxygen atom is used to form the water molecule.
questions.all_comments: Good work!You are joining two molecules of glucose to form maltose, so maltose will have twice as many atoms of each element as glucose, except that you have to remember that a water molecule is lost during the dehydration reaction.  So, maltose will have 12 carbon atoms, but only 22 hydrogen atoms instead of 24 because of the two hydrogen atoms lost during formation of the water molecule.  Similarly, maltose will have 11 oxygen atoms instead of 12, as one oxygen atom is used to form the water molecule.

questions.question: If starch and cellulose are both polymers of glucose, how come people can digest starch but not cellulose?

answers.text: The glucose monomers that form starch are joined together by different covalent bonds than the glucose monomers that form cellulose and the enzymes in our bodies that are able to hydrolyze (break) the covalent bonds between the glucose monomers in starch are not able to hydrolyze the covalent bonds between the glucose monomers in cellulose.
When glucose monomers are joined by dehydration reactions to form cellulose, the glucose monomers are converted into xylose molecules that are impossible for us to digest.
When glucose monomers are joined by dehydration reactions to form cellulose, the glucose monomers are converted into non-sugar molecules that are impossible for us to digest.
When glucose monomers are joined by dehydration reactions to form cellulose, the glucose monomers are converted into lactose molecules, which are hard for many people to digest.

questions.all_comments: Nice job!

questions.question: If you were asked to build a polymer that is 20 monomers long (note that this would be an unusually short polymer), and you could use four different types of monomers, “A”, “B”, “C” and “D”, how many different polymers could you build?

answers.text: ~ 1 million

questions.neutral_comments: Think of it this way: If you were asked to build a polymer that was just one monomer long (ok, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and you had only “A” and “B” monomers available to use, you would be able to build just two different “polymers”: A and B. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 2 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and had only “A” and “B” monomers available, you would be able to build just 4 different “polymers”: AA, AB, BA and BB. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 3 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and had only “A” and “B” monomers available, you would be able to build just 8 different “polymers”: AAA, AAB, ABA, BAA, ABB, BAB. BBA and BBB. Are you seeing a pattern here? The answer to this type of question may be found using the following formula: Number of different polymers that may be formed = XY, where “X” is the number of different types of monomers available and “Y” is the number of monomers in the polymer. So, if you were asked to build a polymer that is 20 monomers long, and you could use four different types of monomers, the number of different polymers you could build would be: 420 = ~ 1 x 1012
questions.all_comments: Think of it this way: If you were asked to build a polymer that was just one monomer long (ok, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and you had only “A” and “B” monomers available to use, you would be able to build just two different “polymers”: A and B.  If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 2 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and had only “A” and “B” monomers available, you would be able to build just 4 different “polymers”: AA, AB, BA and BB. questions.question:
What would be the sequence of the DNA molecule made using the following DNA strand as a template?

5’ GAGGCTT 3’

answers.text: 5’ AAGCCUC 3’
5’ AAGCCTC 3’
5’ CUCCGAA 3’
5’ CTCCGAA 3’

questions.correct_answer: 5’ AAGCCTC 3’
questions.neutral_comments: First, remember that nucleic acid strands bind to each other with an anti-parallel orientation. In other words, they bind so that the 5’ end of one strand is hydrogen bonded to the 3’ end of the other strand. Also, remember that U (for RNA) or T (for DNA) hydrogen bonds with A, and G hydrogen bonds with C. So, you have: DNA 5’ GAGGCTT 3’DNA 3’ CTCCGAA 5’ If you then follow the convention of writing nucleic acid molecules down starting at their 5’ end, the sequence for the RNA molecule is: 5’ AAGCCTC 3’
questions.all_comments: First, remember that nucleic acid strands bind to each other with an anti-parallel orientation.  In other words, they bind so that the 5’ end of one strand is hydrogen bonded to the 3’ end of the other strand.  Also, remember that U (for RNA) or T (for DNA) hydrogen bonds with A, and G hydrogen bonds with C.  So, you have: DNA                5’ GAGGCTT 3’DNA                3’ CTCCGAA 5’ If you then follow the convention of writing nucleic acid molecules down starting at their 5’ end, the sequence for the RNA molecule is: 5’ AAGCCTC 3’

questions.question: L-methionine and D-methionine are examples of

answers.text: structural isomers
geometric isomers
enantiomers
all of these answers are correct

questions.correct_answer: enantiomers
questions.neutral_comments: All amino acids except glycine have an asymmetric carbon, meaning a carbon atom that is covalently bound to 4 different groups. In the case of all amino acids except glycine, those groups are: a carboxyl group, an amino group, a hydrogen and an "R" group. The reason that glycine does not have an asymmetric carbon is because the R group of glycine is hydrogen. So, the central carbon of a glycine molecule is only bound to 3 different groups, since it is bound to two hydrogen atoms. Molecules with asymmetric carbons may occur as two different isomers, known as enantiomers. Enantiomers have the same covalent partnerships (i.e. they do NOT differ in which elements are covalently bound to which other elements), but are instead mirror images of each other. L-methionine and D-methionine meet this definition and so are enantiomers. Please see figure 4.7 in your book for a figure illustrating the different types of isomers.
questions.all_comments: Good work!All amino acids except glycine have an asymmetric carbon, meaning a carbon atom that is covalently bound to 4 different groups.  In the case of all amino acids except glycine, those groups are: a carboxyl group, an amino group, a hydrogen and an "R" group.  The reason that glycine does not have an asymmetric carbon is because the R group of glycine is hydrogen.  So, the central carbon of a glycine molecule is only bound to 3 different groups, since it is bound to two hydrogen atoms.   Molecules with asymmetric carbons may occur as two different isomers, known as enantiomers.  Enantiomers have the same covalent partnerships (i.e. they do NOT differ in which elements are covalently bound to which other elements), but are instead mirror images of each other.  L-methionine and D-methionine meet this definition and so are enantiomers.  Please see figure 4.7 in your book for a figure illustrating the different types of isomers.

questions.question: Cell membranes are asymmetrical. Which of the following is most likely to explain part of the reason for this asymmetry?

answers.text: Cell membranes communicate signals from one cell to another.
Proteins can only span membranes if they are hydrophobic.
Cell membrane proteins are inserted into the rough ER membrane with a certain orientation as they are being synthesized.
The cell membrane forms a border between different cell types.

questions.correct_answer: Cell membrane proteins are inserted into the rough ER membrane with a certain orientation as they are being synthesized.
questions.neutral_comments: Integral membrane proteins are inserted into the membrane of the rough endoplasmic reticulum (ER) as they are being synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough ER. Because many of these proteins have both hydrophobic regions, which are embedded in the membrane, and hydrophilic regions, which are exposed to the aqueous environment inside or outside of the ER, they are not able to move randomly from one side of the membrane to the other after they are made. For example, if a membrane protein is synthesized such that the last part of the protein that is made is hydrophilic and is exposed on the outside of the ER membrane, that part of that protein will remain on the outside of the ER membrane and then on the outside of the vesicle that transports it to the Golgi, on the outside of the Golgi, on the outside of the vesicle that transports it the plasma membrane and then on the inside (cytoplasmic side) of the plasma membrane. It should be noted that the lipid compositions of the two halves of a lipid bilayer are not identical either, as lipid molecules very rarely flip-flop from one side of the bilayer to the other and different species of lipid molecules are synthesized in different amounts in the two halves of the bilayer.
questions.all_comments: Nice job!Integral membrane proteins are inserted into the membrane of the rough endoplasmic reticulum (ER) as they are being synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough ER.  Because many of these proteins have both hydrophobic regions, which are embedded in the membrane, and hydrophilic regions, which are exposed to the aqueous environment inside or outside of the ER, they are not able to move randomly from one side of the membrane to the other after they are made.  For example, if a membrane protein is synthesized such that the last part of the protein that is made is hydrophilic and is exposed on the outside of the ER membrane, that part of that protein will remain on the outside of the ER membrane and then on the outside of the vesicle that transports it to the Golgi, on the outside of the Golgi, on the outside of the vesicle that transports it the plasma membrane and then on the inside (cytoplasmic side) of the plasma membrane.  It should be noted that the lipid compositions of the two halves of a lipid bilayer are not identical either, as lipid molecules very rarely flip-flop from one side of the bilayer to the other and different species of lipid molecules are synthesized in different amounts in the two halves of the bilayer.
