questions.question: A patient had a serious accident and lost a lot of blood. In an attempt to replenish body fluids, distilled water, equal to the volume of blood lost, is transferred directly into one of his veins. What will be the most probable result of this transfusion?

answers.text: The patient’s red blood cells will shrink because the blood fluid is hypotonic compared to the red blood cells.
The patient’s red blood cells will shrink because the blood fluid is hypertonic compared to the red blood cells.
The patient’s red blood cells will swell, and possibly burst, because the blood fluid is hypotonic compared to the red blood cells.
The patient’s red blood cells will swell, and possibly burst, because the blood fluid is hypertonic compared to the red blood cells.

questions.correct_answer: The patient’s red blood cells will swell, and possibly burst, because the blood fluid is hypotonic compared to the red blood cells.
questions.neutral_comments: Pure water, which by definition contains no solutes, will be hypotonic compared to the solution inside of the patient’s red blood cells, which contain lots of solutes. That means that adding pure water to the patient’s blood stream will cause there to be more water molecules interacting with solute molecules inside of the red blood cells than outside. That in turn means that there will be fewer free water molecules inside of the patient’s red blood cells than outside of them. Water will thus flow into the red blood cells, causing the cells to swell and possibly burst.
questions.all_comments: Nice work!Pure water, which by definition contains no solutes, will be hypotonic compared to the solution inside of the patient’s red blood cells, which contain lots of solutes.  That means that adding pure water to the patient’s blood stream will cause there to be more water molecules interacting with solute molecules inside of the red blood cells than outside.  That in turn means that there will be fewer free water molecules inside of the patient’s red blood cells than outside of them.  Water will thus flow into the red blood cells, causing the cells to swell and possibly burst.

questions.question: What are the membrane structures that function in active transport?

cholesterol
glycolipids
integral proteins

questions.all_comments: Nice work!Active transport is carried out by proteins.  To transport a molecule across a membrane, the protein will need to be in the membrane and will therefore need to be an integral membrane protein.

questions.question: The sodium-potassium pump in animal cells requires cytoplasmic ATP to pump ions across the plasma membrane. When the proteins of the pump are first synthesized in the rough ER, what side of the ER membrane will the ATP binding site be on?

answers.text: It could be on either side because the orientation of proteins is scrambled in the Golgi apparatus.
It will be inside the membrane and will become exposed once it reaches the plasma membrane.
It will be on the side facing the interior of the ER (i.e. the lumenal side).
It will be on the cytoplasmic side of the ER.

questions.correct_answer: It will be on the cytoplasmic side of the ER.
questions.neutral_comments: Protein domains that are on the cytoplasmic side of the ER will end up on the cytoplasmic side of the vesicles that bud off of the ER, than on the cytoplasmic side of the Golgi, then on the cytoplasmic side of the vesicles that bud off of the Golgi apparatus and then on the cytoplasmic side of the plasma membrane after the vesicle fuses with the plasma membrane (see figure below, paying special attention to the orientation of the small, green carbohydrates that are attached to the protein molecules in the rough ER).
questions.all_comments: Nice work!Protein domains that are on the cytoplasmic side of the ER will end up on the cytoplasmic side of the vesicles that bud off of the ER, than on the cytoplasmic side of the Golgi, then on the cytoplasmic side of the vesicles that bud off of the Golgi apparatus and then on the cytoplasmic side of the plasma membrane after the vesicle fuses with the plasma membrane (see figure below, paying special attention to the orientation of the small, green carbohydrates that are attached to the protein molecules in the rough ER).

the free energy of the system decreases.
the free energy of the system increases.

questions.question: Sucrose-H<sup>+</sup> cotransporters transport sucrose and H<sup>+</sup> from outside to inside of a cell. Which of the following would increase the rate of sucrose transport into the cell?

answers.text: adding a substance that makes the membrane more permeable to H+
decreasing the concentration of sucrose outside of the cell
increasing the pH of the solution outside of the cell
decreasing the pH of the solution outside of the cell

questions.correct_answer: decreasing the pH of the solution outside of the cell
questions.neutral_comments: Decreasing the pH of the solution outside of the cell would increase the concentration of H+ outside of the cell. Therefore decreasing the pH outside of the cell would increase the H+ gradient from the outside to the inside of the cell and would thus increase the rate at which H+and sucrose are transported into the cell.

questions.question: Which of the following shows the correct pathway for synthesis of plasma membrane proteins?

answers.text: Smooth ER to vesicle to Golgi to vesicle to plasma membrane
Rough ER to vesicle to Golgi to vesicle to plasma membrane
Smooth ER to rough ER to vesicle to Golgi to vesicle to plasma membrane
Golgi to vesicle to rough ER to vesicle to plasma membrane

questions.correct_answer: Rough ER to vesicle to Golgi to vesicle to plasma membrane
questions.neutral_comments: Plasma membrane proteins are synthesized at the rough ER, which is called the “rough” ER because of all the ribosomes stuck to it. Smooth ER is not involved in the synthesis of plasma membrane proteins. After being synthesized in the rough ER and possibly having carbohydrates added, plasma membrane proteins are transported via vesicles to the Golgi apparatus where they are modified and then transported via vesicles to the plasma membrane.

questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question. The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a selectively permeable barrier. This selectively permeable barrier is permeable to water but not to any ions. If you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of MgCl2 to side “A” and you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of NaCl to side “B”, at equilibrium

answers.text: there will have been a net flow of water from side “B” to side “A”
there will have been no net flow of water between the two sides of the tube
there will have been a net flow of water from side “A” to side “B”
there will have been no movement of water molecules across the membrane

questions.correct_answer: there will have been a net flow of water from side “B” to side “A”
questions.neutral_comments: MgCl2 and NaCl are both salts that will dissociate into their constituent ions when they come in contact with water. So, the 1 mole of MgCl2 will dissociate to form 1 mole of Mg++ and 2 moles of Cl- and the 1 mole of NaCl will dissociate to form 1 mole of Na+and 1 mole of Cl-. That means that, immediately after the solutions are added to the two sides of the tube, there will be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B. As a result, more water molecules will be interacting with solute molecules on side A and there will therefore be a lower concentration of free water molecules on side A than on side B. That, in turn, means there will be a net flow of water molecules from side B to side A, until equilibrium is reached.
questions.all_comments: Nice work!MgCl2 and NaCl are both salts that will dissociate into their constituent ions when they come in contact with water.  So, the 1 mole of MgCl2 will dissociate to form 1 mole of Mg++ and 2 moles of Cl- and the 1 mole of NaCl will dissociate to form 1 mole of Na+and 1 mole of Cl-.  That means that, immediately after the solutions are added to the two sides of the tube, there will be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B.  As a result, more water molecules will be interacting with solute molecules on side A and there will therefore be a lower concentration of free water molecules on side A than on side B.  That, in turn, means there will be a net flow of water molecules from side B to side A, until equilibrium is reached.

questions.question: When a plant cell is submerged in a very hypotonic solution, what is likely to occur?

answers.text: the cell membrane will lyse
the cell will burst
the cell will become turgid (solid, due to being inflated)
the cell will become limp

questions.correct_answer: the cell will become turgid (solid, due to being inflated)
questions.neutral_comments: Hypotonic solutions have a lower concentration of solutes. As a result, hypotonic solutions have fewer water molecules interacting with solute molecules and therefore have more free water molecules. Free water molecules will thus diffuse into the plant cell, causing it to expand against the cell wall, making it more solid, or turgid.
questions.all_comments: Nice work!Hypotonic solutions have a lower concentration of solutes.  As a result, hypotonic solutions have fewer water molecules interacting with solute molecules and therefore have more free water molecules.  Free water molecules will thus diffuse into the plant cell, causing it to expand against the cell wall, making it more solid, or turgid.

Triacylglycerols are fats and are rare in membranes.

questions.question: The two layers of a lipid bilayer

answers.text: none of these answers are correct
have almost identical lipid compositions as lipid molecules can move freely between the two layers
have both similar lipid and integral membrane protein compositions
are similar in terms of the types and numbers of their integral membrane proteins as proteins can move freely between the two layers

questions.correct_answer: none of these answers are correct
questions.neutral_comments: The two layers of a lipid bilayer have different lipid and different protein compositions. Remember that although lipid molecules can diffuse laterally within 1 face of a membrane, it is very rare for a lipid molecule to flip-flop from on ½ (face) of a membrane to the other because for that to happen the hydrophilic part of the lipid molecule (e.g. the phosphate and groups attached to the phosphate of a phospholipid molecule) would need to pass through the hydrophobic core of the membrane. Similarly, protein molecules may not be able to move between the two layers of a lipid bilayer.
questions.all_comments: Good job!The two layers of a lipid bilayer have different lipid and different protein compositions. Remember that although lipid molecules can diffuse laterally within 1 face of a membrane, it is very rare for a lipid molecule to flip-flop from on ½ (face) of a membrane to the other because for that to happen the hydrophilic part of the lipid molecule (e.g. the phosphate and groups attached to the phosphate of a phospholipid molecule) would need to pass through the hydrophobic core of the membrane.  Similarly, protein molecules may not be able to move between the two layers of a lipid bilayer.

questions.question: Which of the following is one of the ways that the membranes of winter wheat are able to remain fluid when it is extremely cold?

answers.text: by using active transport
by increasing the percentage of unsaturated phospholipids in the membrane
by increasing the percentage of cholesterol molecules in the membrane
by decreasing the number of hydrophobic proteins in the membrane

questions.correct_answer: by increasing the percentage of unsaturated phospholipids in the membrane
questions.neutral_comments: Increasing the percentage of unsaturated phospholipids make membranes more fluid, even at lower temperatures, by inhibiting close packing of the fatty acid chains of the molecules, thus disrupting hydrophobic interactions between the molecules. Cholesterol does lower the freezing temperatures of membranes in animal cells, but is not found in plant cells. The percentage of hydrophobic proteins in the membrane has little or no effect on the temperature at which the membrane will freeze.
questions.all_comments: Nice job!Increasing the percentage of unsaturated phospholipids make membranes more fluid, even at lower temperatures, by inhibiting close packing of the fatty acid chains of the molecules, thus disrupting hydrophobic interactions between the molecules.  Cholesterol does lower the freezing temperatures of membranes in animal cells, but is not found in plant cells.  The percentage of hydrophobic proteins in the membrane has little or no effect on the temperature at which the membrane will freeze.

questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question. The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a semi-permeable barrier. This semi-permeable barrier is permeable to water and glucose, but not to sucrose. If you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 2 moles of sucrose and 1 mole of glucose to side “A” of the tube, and 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of sucrose and 2 moles of glucose to side “B” of the tube, after the system reaches equilibrium, what changes are observed?

answers.text: The concentration of glucose on side A is less than 1 M and the concentration of sucrose on side A is 2 M.
The concentration of glucose on side A is less than 1 M and the concentration of sucrose on side A is less than 2 M.
The concentration of glucose on side A is 1.5 M and the concentration of sucrose on side A is less than 2 M.
The concentration of glucose on side A is 1.5 M and the concentration of sucrose on side A is 2 M.

questions.correct_answer: The concentration of glucose on side A is 1.5 M and the concentration of sucrose on side A is less than 2 M.
questions.neutral_comments: Because the membrane is permeable to glucose, right after the solutions are added to the U-tube the rate at which glucose molecules move from side B to side A will be higher than the rate at which glucose molecules move from side A to side B. This will continue until the system reaches equilibrium, at which point there will be an equal concentration of glucose molecules on both sides of the tube. As the system started out with 1 l of a 1 M glucose solution and 1 l of a 2 M glucose solution, at equilibrium there will be 2 l of a 1.5 M glucose solution. So, the glucose concentration on both sides of the U-tube at equilibrium will be 1.5 M. Because the membrane is not permeable to sucrose, the net movement of glucose molecules from side B to side A before equilibrium is reached will cause there to be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B. That means there will be a lower concentration of free water molecules on side A than on side B, which in turn means that there will be a net flow of water molecules from side B to side A until equilibrium is reached. At that point, there will be more than 1 l of solution on side A and therefore the sucrose concentration will have dropped to less than 2 M on side A.
questions.all_comments: Nice work!Because the membrane is permeable to glucose, right after the solutions are added to the U-tube the rate at which glucose molecules move from side B to side A will be higher than the rate at which glucose molecules move from side A to side B.  This will continue until the system reaches equilibrium, at which point there will be an equal concentration of glucose molecules on both sides of the tube.  As the system started out with 1 l of a 1 M glucose solution and 1 l of a 2 M glucose solution, at equilibrium there will be 2 l of a 1.5 M glucose solution.  So, the glucose concentration on both sides of the U-tube at equilibrium will be 1.5 M.  Because the membrane is not permeable to sucrose, the net movement of glucose molecules from side B to side A before equilibrium is reached will cause there to be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B.  That means there will be a lower concentration of free water molecules on side A than on side B, which in turn means that there will be a net flow of water molecules from side B to side A until equilibrium is reached.  At that point, there will be more than 1 l of solution on side A and therefore the sucrose concentration will have dropped to less than 2 M on side A.

adding more unsaturated fatty acids to the phospholipids composing your membranes

questions.question: In what way do the membranes of eukaryotic cells vary?

answers.text: Only certain membranes of the cell are selectively permeable
Certain proteins are unique to each membrane.
Phospholipids are found in only certain membranes.
Only certain membranes are constructed of amphipathic molecules

questions.correct_answer: Certain proteins are unique to each membrane.
questions.neutral_comments: All membranes are selectively permeable (although they may differ in the nature of the molecules to which they are permeable) and are composed of phospholipids, which are amphipathic molecules (= molecules having both hydrophobic and hydrophilic regions). The primary way in which membranes differ is in their protein compositions.
questions.all_comments: Good job!All membranes are selectively permeable (although they may differ in the nature of the molecules to which they are permeable) and are composed of phospholipids, which are amphipathic molecules (= molecules having both hydrophobic and hydrophilic regions).  The primary way in which membranes differ is in their protein compositions.

questions.question: When a plant cell is submerged in a very hypotonic solution, what is likely to occur?

answers.text: the cell will become limp
the cell membrane will lyse
the cell will become turgid (solid, due to being inflated)
the cell will burst

questions.correct_answer: the cell will become turgid (solid, due to being inflated)
questions.neutral_comments: Hypotonic solutions have a lower concentration of solutes. As a result, hypotonic solutions have fewer water molecules interacting with solute molecules and therefore have more free water molecules. Free water molecules will thus diffuse into the plant cell, causing it to expand against the cell wall, making it more solid, or turgid.

questions.question: Which of the following is one of the ways that the membranes of winter wheat are able to remain fluid when it is extremely cold?

answers.text: by using active transport
by decreasing the number of hydrophobic proteins in the membrane
by increasing the percentage of cholesterol molecules in the membrane
by increasing the percentage of unsaturated phospholipids in the membrane

questions.correct_answer: by increasing the percentage of unsaturated phospholipids in the membrane
questions.neutral_comments: Increasing the percentage of unsaturated phospholipids make membranes more fluid, even at lower temperatures, by inhibiting close packing of the fatty acid chains of the molecules, thus disrupting hydrophobic interactions between the molecules. Cholesterol does lower the freezing temperatures of membranes in animal cells, but is not found in plant cells. The percentage of hydrophobic proteins in the membrane has little or no effect on the temperature at which the membrane will freeze.
questions.all_comments: Nice job!Increasing the percentage of unsaturated phospholipids make membranes more fluid, even at lower temperatures, by inhibiting close packing of the fatty acid chains of the molecules, thus disrupting hydrophobic interactions between the molecules.  Cholesterol does lower the freezing temperatures of membranes in animal cells, but is not found in plant cells.  The percentage of hydrophobic proteins in the membrane has little or no effect on the temperature at which the membrane will freeze.

questions.neutral_comments: Plasma membrane proteins are synthesized at the rough ER, which is called the “rough” ER because of all the ribosomes stuck to it. Smooth ER is not involved in the synthesis of plasma membrane proteins. After being synthesized in the rough ER and possibly having carbohydrates added, plasma membrane proteins are transported via vesicles to the Golgi apparatus where they are modified and then transported via vesicles to the plasma membrane.

questions.question: Sucrose-H<sup>+</sup> cotransporters transport sucrose and H<sup>+</sup> from outside to inside of a cell. Which of the following would increase the rate of sucrose transport into the cell?

Therefore decreasing the pH outside of the cell would increase the H+ gradient from the outside to the inside of the cell and would thus increase the rate at which H+and sucrose are transported into the cell.

questions.question: Which of the following membrane activities require energy from ATP hydrolysis?

answers.text: facilitated diffusion
movement of solutes by channel proteins
proton pumps
movement of solutes by co-transporters

questions.correct_answer: proton pumps
questions.all_comments:
Channel proteins carry out “facilitated diffusion”. In facilitated diffusion molecules are moving down their concentration and/or electrical gradient, which is a passive process that does not require an energy expenditure.
Co-transporters move two substances simultaneously. One of the substances is moving down its electrochemical gradient and the other substance is moving up its electrochemical gradient. The energy needed to move one of the substances up its electrochemical gradient is provided by the energy released as the second substance moves down its electrochemical gradient rather than by ATP hydrolysis.

questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question. The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a semi-permeable barrier. This semi-permeable barrier is permeable to water and glucose, but not to sucrose. If you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 2 moles of sucrose and 1 mole of glucose to side “A” of the tube, and 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of sucrose and 2 moles of glucose to side “B” of the tube, after the system reaches equilibrium, what changes are observed?

answers.text: The concentration of glucose on side A is 1.5 M and the concentration of sucrose on side A is 2 M.
The concentration of glucose on side A is 1.5 M and the concentration of sucrose on side A is less than 2 M.
The concentration of glucose on side A is less than 1 M and the concentration of sucrose on side A is 2 M.
The concentration of glucose on side A is less than 1 M and the concentration of sucrose on side A is less than 2 M.

questions.correct_answer: The concentration of glucose on side A is 1.5 M and the concentration of sucrose on side A is less than 2 M.
questions.neutral_comments: Because the membrane is permeable to glucose, right after the solutions are added to the U-tube the rate at which glucose molecules move from side B to side A will be higher than the rate at which glucose molecules move from side A to side B. This will continue until the system reaches equilibrium, at which point there will be an equal concentration of glucose molecules on both sides of the tube. As the system started out with 1 l of a 1 M glucose solution and 1 l of a 2 M glucose solution, at equilibrium there will be 2 l of a 1.5 M glucose solution. So, the glucose concentration on both sides of the U-tube at equilibrium will be 1.5 M. Because the membrane is not permeable to sucrose, the net movement of glucose molecules from side B to side A before equilibrium is reached will cause there to be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B. That means there will be a lower concentration of free water molecules on side A than on side B, which in turn means that there will be a net flow of water molecules from side B to side A until equilibrium is reached. At that point, there will be more than 1 l of solution on side A and therefore the sucrose concentration will have dropped to less than 2 M on side A.
questions.all_comments: Because the membrane is permeable to glucose, right after the solutions are added to the U-tube the rate at which glucose molecules move from side B to side A will be higher than the rate at which glucose molecules move from side A to side B.  This will continue until the system reaches equilibrium, at which point there will be an equal concentration of glucose molecules on both sides of the tube.  As the system started out with 1 l of a 1 M glucose solution and 1 l of a 2 M glucose solution, at equilibrium there will be 2 l of a 1.5 M glucose solution.  So, the glucose concentration on both sides of the U-tube at equilibrium will be 1.5 M.  Because the membrane is not permeable to sucrose, the net movement of glucose molecules from side B to side A before equilibrium is reached will cause there to be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B.  That means there will be a lower concentration of free water molecules on side A than on side B, which in turn means that there will be a net flow of water molecules from side B to side A until equilibrium is reached.  At that point, there will be more than 1 l of solution on side A and therefore the sucrose concentration will have dropped to less than 2 M on side A.

questions.question: Carbohydrates attached to some proteins and lipids of the plasma membrane are added as the membrane is made and refined in the ER and Golgi apparatus: the new membrane then forms transport vesicles that travel to the cell surface. Which of the following statements is TRUE?

answers.text: The carbohydrates that are part of the glycolipid and glycoprotein molecules will be on the inside of the vesicle and the inside (cytoplasmic side) of the plasma membrane.
The carbohydrates that are part of the glycolipid and glycoprotein molecules will be on the outside of the vesicle and then on the inside (cytoplasmic side) of the plasma membrane.
The carbohydrates that are part of the glycolipid and glycoprotein molecules will be on the outside of the vesicle and then on the outside (extracellular side) of the plasma membrane.
The carbohydrates that are part of the glycolipid and glycoprotein molecules will be on the inside of the vesicle and then on the outside (extracellular side) of the plasma membrane.

questions.correct_answer: The carbohydrates that are part of the glycolipid and glycoprotein molecules will be on the inside of the vesicle and then on the outside (extracellular side) of the plasma membrane.
questions.neutral_comments: Carbohydrates that are attached to lipids or proteins on the inside face of the ER membrane will end up on the inside face of the membrane of vesicles that bud off of the ER, than on the inside face of the Golgi apparatus membrane, then on the inside face of the membrane of vesicles that bud off of the Golgi apparatus and then on the extracellular face of the plasma membrane after the vesicle fuses with the plasma membrane (see figure below, paying special attention to the orientation of the small, green carbohydrates that are attached to the protein molecules in the rough ER to help you keep track of the orientation of membrane components). Also, remember that lipid molecules can diffuse laterally within 1 face of a membrane, but that it is very rare for a lipid molecule to flip-flop from on ½ (face) of a membrane to the other because for that to happen the hydrophilic part of the lipid molecule (e.g. the phosphate and groups attached to the phosphate of a phospholipid molecule) would need to pass through the hydrophobic core of the membrane.
questions.all_comments: Carbohydrates that are attached to lipids or proteins on the inside face of the ER membrane will end up on the inside face of the membrane of vesicles that bud off of the ER, than on the inside face of the Golgi apparatus membrane, then on the inside face of the membrane of vesicles that bud off of the Golgi apparatus and then on the extracellular face of the plasma membrane after the vesicle fuses with the plasma membrane (see figure below, paying special attention to the orientation of the small, green carbohydrates that are attached to the protein molecules in the rough ER to help you keep track of the orientation of membrane components).  Also, remember that lipid molecules can diffuse laterally within 1 face of a membrane, but that it is very rare for a lipid molecule to flip-flop from on ½ (face) of a membrane to the other because for that to happen the hydrophilic part of the lipid molecule (e.g. the phosphate and groups attached to the phosphate of a phospholipid molecule) would need to pass through the hydrophobic core of the membrane.

questions.question: Cell membranes are asymmetrical. Which of the following is most likely to explain part of the reason for this asymmetry?

answers.text: Cell membrane proteins are inserted into the rough ER membrane with a certain orientation as they are being synthesized.
The cell membrane forms a border between different cell types.
Cell membranes communicate signals from one cell to another.
Proteins can only span membranes if they are hydrophobic.

questions.correct_answer: Cell membrane proteins are inserted into the rough ER membrane with a certain orientation as they are being synthesized.
questions.neutral_comments: Integral membrane proteins are inserted into the membrane of the rough endoplasmic reticulum (ER) as they are being synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough ER. Because many of these proteins have both hydrophobic regions, which are embedded in the membrane, and hydrophilic regions, which are exposed to the aqueous environment inside or outside of the ER, they are not able to move randomly from one side of the membrane to the other after they are made. For example, if a membrane protein is synthesized such that the last part of the protein that is made is hydrophilic and is exposed on the outside of the ER membrane, that part of that protein will remain on the outside of the ER membrane and then on the outside of the vesicle that transports it to the Golgi, on the outside of the Golgi, on the outside of the vesicle that transports it the plasma membrane and then on the inside (cytoplasmic side) of the plasma membrane. It should be noted that the lipid compositions of the two halves of a lipid bilayer are not identical either, as lipid molecules very rarely flip-flop from one side of the bilayer to the other and different species of lipid molecules are synthesized in different amounts in the two halves of the bilayer.
questions.all_comments: Integral membrane proteins are inserted into the membrane of the rough endoplasmic reticulum (ER) as they are being synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough ER.  Because many of these proteins have both hydrophobic regions, which are embedded in the membrane, and hydrophilic regions, which are exposed to the aqueous environment inside or outside of the ER, they are not able to move randomly from one side of the membrane to the other after they are made.  For example, if a membrane protein is synthesized such that the last part of the protein that is made is hydrophilic and is exposed on the outside of the ER membrane, that part of that protein will remain on the outside of the ER membrane and then on the outside of the vesicle that transports it to the Golgi, on the outside of the Golgi, on the outside of the vesicle that transports it the plasma membrane and then on the inside (cytoplasmic side) of the plasma membrane.  It should be noted that the lipid compositions of the two halves of a lipid bilayer are not identical either, as lipid molecules very rarely flip-flop from one side of the bilayer to the other and different species of lipid molecules are synthesized in different amounts in the two halves of the bilayer.

questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question. The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a selectively permeable barrier. This selectively permeable barrier is permeable to water but not to any ions. If you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of MgCl2 to side “A” and you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of NaCl to side “B”, immediately after adding the solutions to the U-tube,

answers.text: the solution in side “A” will be hypertonic compared with the solution in side “B”
there will be more free water molecules on side “A”
the solution in side “A” will be hypotonic compared with the solution in side “B”
the solution in side “A” will be isotonic compared with the solution in side “B”

questions.correct_answer: the solution in side “A” will be hypertonic compared with the solution in side “B”
questions.neutral_comments: MgCl2 and NaCl are both salts that will dissociate into their constituent ions when they come in contact with water. So, the 1 mole of MgCl2 will dissociate to form 1 mole of Mg++ and 2 moles of Cl- and the 1 mole of NaCl will dissociate to form 1 mole of Na+and 1 mole of Cl-. That means that, immediately after the solutions are added to the two sides of the tube, there will be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B, so side A will be hypertonic compared with side B. The fact that there will be more solute molecules on side A also means that more of the water molecules on side A will be interacting with solute molecules and therefore there will be fewer free water molecules on side A.
questions.all_comments: MgCl2 and NaCl are both salts that will dissociate into their constituent ions when they come in contact with water.  So, the 1 mole of MgCl2 will dissociate to form 1 mole of Mg++ and 2 moles of Cl- and the 1 mole of NaCl will dissociate to form 1 mole of Na+and 1 mole of Cl-.  That means that, immediately after the solutions are added to the two sides of the tube, there will be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B, so side A will be hypertonic compared with side B.  The fact that there will be more solute molecules on side A also means that more of the water molecules on side A will be interacting with solute molecules and therefore there will be fewer free water molecules on side A.

questions.question: When a hydrogen ion (= a proton) enters a cell, it is

answers.text: moving down its electrochemical gradient as the hydrogen ion concentration is greater outside of cells and the outsides of cells are positively charged relative to the insides

moving down its electrochemical gradient because the outsides of cells are positively charged relative to the insides and that offsets the fact that the hydrogen ion concentration inside of cells is greater than outside of cells
moving up its electrochemical gradient as the hydrogen ion concentration is lower outside of cells and the outsides of cells are negatively charged relative to the insides

moving down its electrochemical gradient as the hydrogen ion concentration is so much greater outside of cells than inside that this effect offsets the effect of the outsides of cells being negatively charged relative to the insides

questions.correct_answer: moving down its electrochemical gradient as the hydrogen ion concentration is greater outside of cells and the outsides of cells are positively charged relative to the insides

questions.question: Which of the following span the phospholipid bilayer, usually a number of times?

answers.text: peripheral proteins
transmembrane proteins
integrins

questions.correct_answer: transmembrane proteins

questions.question: Ions always diffuse across membranes down their

answers.text: electrochemical gradients
concentration gradients
chemical gradients
electrical gradients

questions.correct_answer: electrochemical gradients
questions.neutral_comments: Ions are charged molecules or atoms. They will tend to diffuse down their concentration gradient and down their electrical gradient. For example, a positively charged ion will tend to have a net flow towards the side of the membrane that is more negatively charged. If a positively charged ion is in a higher concentration inside of a cell than outside of the cell, the ion may or may not have a net movement to the outside of the cell because the outsides of cells are positively charged relative to their insides. So, whether a positively charged ion would have a net flow to the outside of a cell would depend on how steep its concentration gradient is relative to how steep its electrical gradient is. The bottom line is that the net movement of an ion is down its electrochemical gradient, which takes into account both the tendency for all substances to move down their concentration gradients along with the tendency for positively charged ions to flow towards the more negatively charged side of a membrane and vice versa.
questions.all_comments: It is possible for an ion to diffuse up its electrical gradient if, at the same time, it is diffusing down an even stronger concentration (chemical) gradient.Ions are charged molecules or atoms.  They will tend to diffuse down their concentration gradient and down their electrical gradient.  For example, a positively charged ion will tend to have a net flow towards the side of the membrane that is more negatively charged.  If a positively charged ion is in a higher concentration inside of a cell than outside of the cell, the ion may or may not have a net movement to the outside of the cell because the outsides of cells are positively charged relative to their insides.  So, whether a positively charged ion would have a net flow to the outside of a cell would depend on how steep its concentration gradient is relative to how steep its electrical gradient is.  The bottom line is that the net movement of an ion is down its electrochemical gradient, which takes into account both the tendency for all substances to move down their concentration gradients along with the tendency for positively charged ions to flow towards the more negatively charged side of a membrane and vice versa.

questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question. The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a semi-permeable barrier. This semi-permeable barrier is permeable to water and glucose, but not to sucrose. If you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 2 moles of sucrose and 1 mole of glucose to side “A” of the tube, and 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of sucrose and 2 moles of glucose to side “B” of the tube, after the system reaches equilibrium, what changes are observed?

answers.text: The concentration of glucose on side A is 1.5 M and the concentration of sucrose on side A is 2 M.
The concentration of glucose on side A is less than 1 M and the concentration of sucrose on side A is 2 M.
The concentration of glucose on side A is 1.5 M and the concentration of sucrose on side A is less than 2 M.
The concentration of glucose on side A is less than 1 M and the concentration of sucrose on side A is less than 2 M.

questions.correct_answer: The concentration of glucose on side A is 1.5 M and the concentration of sucrose on side A is less than 2 M.
questions.neutral_comments: Because the membrane is permeable to glucose, right after the solutions are added to the U-tube the rate at which glucose molecules move from side B to side A will be higher than the rate at which glucose molecules move from side A to side B. This will continue until the system reaches equilibrium, at which point there will be an equal concentration of glucose molecules on both sides of the tube. As the system started out with 1 l of a 1 M glucose solution and 1 l of a 2 M glucose solution, at equilibrium there will be 2 l of a 1.5 M glucose solution. So, the glucose concentration on both sides of the U-tube at equilibrium will be 1.5 M. Because the membrane is not permeable to sucrose, the net movement of glucose molecules from side B to side A before equilibrium is reached will cause there to be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B. That means there will be a lower concentration of free water molecules on side A than on side B, which in turn means that there will be a net flow of water molecules from side B to side A until equilibrium is reached. At that point, there will be more than 1 l of solution on side A and therefore the sucrose concentration will have dropped to less than 2 M on side A.
questions.all_comments: Because the membrane is permeable to glucose, right after the solutions are added to the U-tube the rate at which glucose molecules move from side B to side A will be higher than the rate at which glucose molecules move from side A to side B.  This will continue until the system reaches equilibrium, at which point there will be an equal concentration of glucose molecules on both sides of the tube.  As the system started out with 1 l of a 1 M glucose solution and 1 l of a 2 M glucose solution, at equilibrium there will be 2 l of a 1.5 M glucose solution.  So, the glucose concentration on both sides of the U-tube at equilibrium will be 1.5 M.  Because the membrane is not permeable to sucrose, the net movement of glucose molecules from side B to side A before equilibrium is reached will cause there to be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B.  That means there will be a lower concentration of free water molecules on side A than on side B, which in turn means that there will be a net flow of water molecules from side B to side A until equilibrium is reached.  At that point, there will be more than 1 l of solution on side A and therefore the sucrose concentration will have dropped to less than 2 M on side A.

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of carrier proteins in a plasma membrane?

answers.text: They are peripheral membrane proteins.
They always exhibit specificity for a particular type of molecule.
All carrier proteins require the expenditure of cellular energy to function.
All carrier proteins work against diffusion.

questions.correct_answer: They always exhibit specificity for a particular type of molecule.
questions.neutral_comments: Some carrier proteins carry out facilitated diffusion. Facilitated diffusion is diffusion of a molecule down its concentration and/or electrical gradient that is “facilitated” by a carrier protein or channel protein that allows the molecule that is diffusing to pass more quickly through the membrane. Because the molecules being transported are moving down their concentration and/or electrical gradient, carrier proteins that act in facilitated diffusion do not require an energy expenditure. However, other carrier proteins, such as symporters and anti-porters, help carry out active transport and so do require an energy expenditure.
questions.all_comments: Some carrier proteins carry out facilitated diffusion. Facilitated diffusion is diffusion of a molecule down its concentration and/or electrical gradient that is “facilitated” by a carrier protein or channel protein that allows the molecule that is diffusing to pass more quickly through the membrane. Because the molecules being transported are moving down their concentration and/or electrical gradient, carrier proteins that act in facilitated diffusion do not require an energy expenditure. However, other carrier proteins, such as symporters and anti-porters, help carry out active transport and so do require an energy expenditure.

questions.question: In order for a protein to be a transmembrane protein it would have to be which of the following?

answers.text: a glycoprotein
hydrophobic
amphipathic
hydrophilic

questions.correct_answer: amphipathic
questions.neutral_comments: Transmembrane proteins go all the way across membranes. They need to have hydrophobic (water fearing) segments that can be inserted inside the membrane and hydrophilic sections that are exposed to the aqueous solution on either side of the membrane. They are thus amphipathic molecules, meaning molecules with both hydrophobic and hydrophilic parts.
questions.all_comments: Transmembrane proteins go all the way across membranes.  They need to have hydrophobic (water fearing) segments that can be inserted inside the membrane and hydrophilic sections that are exposed to the aqueous solution on either side of the membrane.  They are thus amphipathic molecules, meaning molecules with both hydrophobic and hydrophilic parts.

questions.question: Which of the following membrane activities require energy from ATP hydrolysis?

answers.text: movement of solutes by channel proteins
proton pumps
movement of solutes by co-transporters
facilitated diffusion

questions.correct_answer: proton pumps
questions.all_comments:
Channel proteins carry out “facilitated diffusion”. In facilitated diffusion molecules are moving down their concentration and/or electrical gradient, which is a passive process that does not require an energy expenditure.
Co-transporters move two substances simultaneously. One of the substances is moving down its electrochemical gradient and the other substance is moving up its electrochemical gradient. The energy needed to move one of the substances up its electrochemical gradient is provided by the energy released as the second substance moves down its electrochemical gradient rather than by ATP hydrolysis.

questions.question: Glucose diffuses slowly through artificial phospholipid bilayers. The cells lining the small intestine, however, rapidly move large quantities of glucose from glucose-rich foods into their glucose-poor cytoplasm. Using this information, which transport mechanism is most probably functioning in the intestinal cells?

answers.text: Active transport pumps
Facilitated diffusion
Simple diffusion
Glucoport

questions.correct_answer: Facilitated diffusion
questions.neutral_comments: The information that glucose diffuses poorly through artificial phospholipid bilayers tells you that glucose will diffuse poorly on its own through cell membranes. Because you are also told that glucose is entering the intestinal cells quickly, this rules out simple diffusion as a possibility. Because glucose is moving down its concentration gradient as it enters the intestinal cells, no energy should be required for its movement which makes active transport of any means in unlikely possibility. “Glucoport” is a made up term, which leaves facilitated diffusion as the most likely possibility. In facilitated diffusion, channel proteins or carrier proteins in the membrane allow specific molecules that do not easily cross membranes on their own to cross membranes rapidly. So, diffusion (which is always a passive process) is “facilitated” by these proteins.
questions.all_comments: The information that glucose diffuses poorly through artificial phospholipid bilayers tells you that glucose will diffuse poorly on its own through cell membranes.  Because you are also told that glucose is entering the intestinal cells quickly, this rules out simple diffusion as a possibility.  Because glucose is moving down its concentration gradient as it enters the intestinal cells, no energy should be required for its movement which makes active transport of any means in unlikely possibility.  “Glucoport” is a made up term, which leaves facilitated diffusion as the most likely possibility.  In facilitated diffusion, channel proteins or carrier proteins in the membrane allow specific molecules that do not easily cross membranes on their own to cross membranes rapidly. So, diffusion (which is always a passive process) is “facilitated” by these proteins.

questions.question: Carbohydrates attached to some proteins and lipids of the plasma membrane are added as the membrane is made and refined in the ER and Golgi apparatus: the new membrane then forms transport vesicles that travel to the cell surface. Which of the following statements is TRUE?

The carbohydrates that are part of the glycolipid and glycoprotein molecules will be on the outside of the vesicle and then on the inside (cytoplasmic side) of the plasma membrane.
The carbohydrates that are part of the glycolipid and glycoprotein molecules will be on the outside of the vesicle and then on the outside (extracellular side) of the plasma membrane.

questions.correct_answer: The carbohydrates that are part of the glycolipid and glycoprotein molecules will be on the inside of the vesicle and then on the outside (extracellular side) of the plasma membrane.
questions.neutral_comments: Carbohydrates that are attached to lipids or proteins on the inside face of the ER membrane will end up on the inside face of the membrane of vesicles that bud off of the ER, than on the inside face of the Golgi apparatus membrane, then on the inside face of the membrane of vesicles that bud off of the Golgi apparatus and then on the extracellular face of the plasma membrane after the vesicle fuses with the plasma membrane (see figure below, paying special attention to the orientation of the small, green carbohydrates that are attached to the protein molecules in the rough ER to help you keep track of the orientation of membrane components). Also, remember that lipid molecules can diffuse laterally within 1 face of a membrane, but that it is very rare for a lipid molecule to flip-flop from on ½ (face) of a membrane to the other because for that to happen the hydrophilic part of the lipid molecule (e.g. the phosphate and groups attached to the phosphate of a phospholipid molecule) would need to pass through the hydrophobic core of the membrane.

questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question. The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a selectively permeable barrier. This selectively permeable barrier is permeable to water, but not to glucose. If you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of glucose to side “A” and you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of glucose to side “B”,

answers.text: there will be no movement of water molecules across the membrane
there will be no net flow of water between the two sides of the tube
there will be a net flow of water from side “B” to side “A”

So, free water molecules WILL still cross the membrane, but there will be not NET flow of water between the two sides of the tube.

questions.question: Which of the following is a form of ACTIVE transport?

answers.text: Simple diffusion
Facilitated diffusion by a carrier protein
Transport by a cotransporter
Facilitated diffusion by a channel protein

questions.correct_answer: Transport by a cotransporter
questions.neutral_comments: All types of diffusion are passive processes where molecules move down their concentration and/or electrical gradients. Transport by cotransporters is a form of active transport. Cotransporters work by transporting two different molecules together. One of the molecules being transported is moving down its concentration and/or electrical gradient. The other molecule being transported is moving up its concentration and/or electrical gradient. The energy required to move the molecule that’s moving up its concentration and/or electrical gradient is provided by the molecule moving down its concentration and/or electrical gradient. Example: A cotransporter moving H+ down its electrochemical gradient while moving sucrose up its concentration gradient is using the potential energy that is stored in the form H+ moving down its electrochemical gradient to do the work of moving sucrose up its concentration gradient.
questions.all_comments: Nice job!All types of diffusion are passive processes where molecules move down their concentration and/or electrical gradients.  Transport by cotransporters is a form of active transport.  Cotransporters work by transporting two different molecules together.  One of the molecules being transported is moving down its concentration and/or electrical gradient.  The other molecule being transported is moving up its concentration and/or electrical gradient.  The energy required to move the molecule that’s moving up its concentration and/or electrical gradient is provided by the molecule moving down its concentration and/or electrical gradient.  Example: A cotransporter moving H+ down its electrochemical gradient while moving sucrose up its concentration gradient is using the potential energy that is stored in the form H+ moving down its electrochemical gradient to do the work of moving sucrose up its concentration gradient.

questions.neutral_comments: Osmosis (= diffusion of free water molecules down their concentration gradient), diffusion of solute across a membrane and transport of an ion down its electrochemical gradient are all forms of passive transport, meaning that they do not require an energy expenditure by the cell.
questions.all_comments: Osmosis (= diffusion of free water molecules down their concentration gradient), diffusion of solute across a membrane and transport of an ion down its electrochemical gradient are all forms of passive transport, meaning that they do not require an energy expenditure by the cell.

questions.question: When a plant cell is submerged in a very hypotonic solution, what is likely to occur?

answers.text: the cell will become limp
the cell will become turgid (solid, due to being inflated)
the cell will burst
the cell membrane will lyse

questions.correct_answer: the cell will become turgid (solid, due to being inflated)
questions.neutral_comments: Hypotonic solutions have a lower concentration of solutes. As a result, hypotonic solutions have fewer water molecules interacting with solute molecules and therefore have more free water molecules. Free water molecules will thus diffuse into the plant cell, causing it to expand against the cell wall, making it more solid, or turgid.
questions.all_comments: Hypotonic solutions have a lower concentration of solutes.  As a result, hypotonic solutions have fewer water molecules interacting with solute molecules and therefore have more free water molecules.  Free water molecules will thus diffuse into the plant cell, causing it to expand against the cell wall, making it more solid, or turgid.

questions.question: Why are lipids and some proteins free to move laterally in membranes?

answers.text: The hydrophilic portions of the lipids are in the interior of the membrane.
The interior of the membrane is filled with liquid water.
There are only weak hydrophobic interactions in the interior of the membrane.
Molecules such as cellulose can pull them in various directions.

questions.correct_answer: There are only weak hydrophobic interactions in the interior of the membrane.

questions.question: Which of the following membrane activities require energy from ATP hydrolysis?

answers.text: movement of solutes by channel proteins
facilitated diffusion
movement of solutes by co-transporters
proton pumps

questions.correct_answer: proton pumps
questions.all_comments:
Channel proteins carry out “facilitated diffusion”. In facilitated diffusion molecules are moving down their concentration and/or electrical gradient, which is a passive process that does not require an energy expenditure.
Co-transporters move two substances simultaneously. One of the substances is moving down its electrochemical gradient and the other substance is moving up its electrochemical gradient. The energy needed to move one of the substances up its electrochemical gradient is provided by the energy released as the second substance moves down its electrochemical gradient rather than by ATP hydrolysis.

questions.question: Which of the following membrane activities do NOT require energy from ATP hydrolysis?

answers.text: all of these answers are correct
movement of solutes by channel proteins
movement of solutes by co-transporters
simple diffusion

questions.correct_answer: all of these answers are correct
questions.all_comments:
Channel proteins carry out “facilitated diffusion”. In facilitated diffusion molecules are moving down their concentration and/or electrical gradient, which is a passive process that does not require an energy expenditure.
Co-transporters move two substances simultaneously. One of the substances is moving down its electrochemical gradient and the other substance is moving up its electrochemical gradient. The energy needed to move one of the substances up its electrochemical gradient is provided by the energy released as the second substance moves down its electrochemical gradient rather than by ATP hydrolysis.
“Passive diffusion” is movement of a substance down its concentration gradient without the need for a channel or carrier protein to facilitate movement of the substance. Because the substance is moving down its concentration gradient, no energy source is required for this process to occur.

questions.question: Which of the following is one of the ways that the membranes of winter wheat are able to remain fluid when it is extremely cold?

answers.text: by increasing the percentage of unsaturated phospholipids in the membrane
by increasing the percentage of cholesterol molecules in the membrane
by using active transport
by decreasing the number of hydrophobic proteins in the membrane

questions.correct_answer: by increasing the percentage of unsaturated phospholipids in the membrane
questions.neutral_comments: Increasing the percentage of unsaturated phospholipids make membranes more fluid, even at lower temperatures, by inhibiting close packing of the fatty acid chains of the molecules, thus disrupting hydrophobic interactions between the molecules. Cholesterol does lower the freezing temperatures of membranes in animal cells, but is not found in plant cells. The percentage of hydrophobic proteins in the membrane has little or no effect on the temperature at which the membrane will freeze.
questions.all_comments: Increasing the percentage of unsaturated phospholipids make membranes more fluid, even at lower temperatures, by inhibiting close packing of the fatty acid chains of the molecules, thus disrupting hydrophobic interactions between the molecules.  Cholesterol does lower the freezing temperatures of membranes in animal cells, but is not found in plant cells.  The percentage of hydrophobic proteins in the membrane has little or no effect on the temperature at which the membrane will freeze.

questions.question: Which of these are not embedded in the lipid bilayer at all?

answers.text: transmembrane proteins
integral proteins
glycoproteins
peripheral proteins

questions.correct_answer: peripheral proteins
questions.neutral_comments: Peripheral proteins, by definition, are attached to the periphery of the membrane rather than being embedded in it.
questions.all_comments: Peripheral proteins, by definition, are attached to the periphery of the membrane rather than being embedded in it.

questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question. The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a selectively permeable barrier. This selectively permeable barrier is permeable to water and glucose, but not to sucrose. If you add 1 liter of water, 2 moles of sucrose and 1 mole of glucose to side “A” of the tube, and 1 liter of water, 1 mole of sucrose and 2 moles of glucose to side “B” of the tube, after the system reaches equilibrium, what changes are observed?

answers.text: The water level is higher on side A than on side B.
The molarity of glucose is higher on side A than on side B.
The water level is higher on side B than on side A.
The molarity of glucose is lower on side A than on side B.

questions.correct_answer: The water level is higher on side A than on side B.
questions.neutral_comments: Because the glucose molecules can cross the selectively permeable membrane and initially there is a higher concentration of glucose molecules on side B, more glucose molecules will move from side B to side A than from side A to side B. In other words, there will be a net movement of glucose molecules from side B to side A. Because the membrane is not permeable to sucrose, there will be no movement of sucrose molecules. This means that the total concentration of solute molecules (= glucose and sucrose molecules in this example) will become higher on side A than on side B. That means that more water molecules will be interacting with solute molecules on side A than on side B. This in turn means that there will be a lower concentration of free water molecules on side A than on side B. More free water molecules will thus flow through the selectively permeable membrane from side B to side A than from side A to side B. In other words, there will be a net flow of free water molecules from side B to side A. This will raise the water level on side A.
questions.all_comments: Because the glucose molecules can cross the selectively permeable membrane and initially there is a higher concentration of glucose molecules on side B, more glucose molecules will move from side B to side A than from side A to side B.  In other words, there will be a net movement of glucose molecules from side B to side A.  Because the membrane is not permeable to sucrose, there will be no movement of sucrose molecules.  This means that the total concentration of solute molecules (= glucose and sucrose molecules in this example) will become higher on side A than on side B.  That means that more water molecules will be interacting with solute molecules on side A than on side B.  This in turn means that there will be a lower concentration of free water molecules on side A than on side B.  More free water molecules will thus flow through the selectively permeable membrane from side B to side A than from side A to side B.  In other words, there will be a net flow of free water molecules from side B to side A.  This will raise the water level on side A.

questions.question: Ions always diffuse across membranes down their

answers.text: chemical gradients
electrical gradients
concentration gradients
electrochemical gradients

questions.correct_answer: electrochemical gradients
questions.neutral_comments: Ions are charged molecules or atoms. They will tend to diffuse down their concentration gradient and down their electrical gradient. For example, a positively charged ion will tend to have a net flow towards the side of the membrane that is more negatively charged. If a positively charged ion is in a higher concentration inside of a cell than outside of the cell, the ion may or may not have a net movement to the outside of the cell because the outsides of cells are positively charged relative to their insides. So, whether a positively charged ion would have a net flow to the outside of a cell would depend on how steep its concentration gradient is relative to how steep its electrical gradient is. The bottom line is that the net movement of an ion is down its electrochemical gradient, which takes into account both the tendency for all substances to move down their concentration gradients along with the tendency for positively charged ions to flow towards the more negatively charged side of a membrane and vice versa.
questions.all_comments: It is possible for an ion to diffuse up its electrical gradient if, at the same time, it is diffusing down an even stronger concentration (chemical) gradient.Ions are charged molecules or atoms.  They will tend to diffuse down their concentration gradient and down their electrical gradient.  For example, a positively charged ion will tend to have a net flow towards the side of the membrane that is more negatively charged.  If a positively charged ion is in a higher concentration inside of a cell than outside of the cell, the ion may or may not have a net movement to the outside of the cell because the outsides of cells are positively charged relative to their insides.  So, whether a positively charged ion would have a net flow to the outside of a cell would depend on how steep its concentration gradient is relative to how steep its electrical gradient is.  The bottom line is that the net movement of an ion is down its electrochemical gradient, which takes into account both the tendency for all substances to move down their concentration gradients along with the tendency for positively charged ions to flow towards the more negatively charged side of a membrane and vice versa.

questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question. The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a selectively permeable barrier. This selectively permeable barrier is permeable to water, but not to glucose or sucrose. If you add 3 liters of an aqueous solution containing 2 moles of sucrose and 1 mole of glucose to side “A” of the tube, and 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of sucrose and 2 moles of glucose to side “B” of the tube, the solution in side A with respect to that in side B is

answers.text: isotonic
hypotonic
hypertonic
saturated

questions.correct_answer: hypotonic
questions.neutral_comments: Solution A contains 2 moles of sucrose and one mole of glucose in a volume of 3 liters. That means it has a total of 3 moles of solute molecules in a volume of 3 liters, so solution A is a one molar (= 1 M) solution. Solution B has 1 mole of sucrose and 2 moles of glucose in a volume of 1 liter. That means solution B has a total of 3 moles of solute molecules in a volume of 1 liter, so solution B is a 3 molar (= 3 M) solution. Therefore, solution A is hypotonic (has a lower concentration of solute molecules) with respect to solution B.
questions.all_comments: Solution A contains 2 moles of sucrose and one mole of glucose in a volume of 3 liters. That means it has a total of 3 moles of solute molecules in a volume of 3 liters, so solution A is a one molar (= 1 M) solution. Solution B has 1 mole of sucrose and 2 moles of glucose in a volume of 1 liter. That means solution B has a total of 3 moles of solute molecules in a volume of 1 liter, so solution B is a 3 molar (= 3 M) solution. Therefore, solution A is hypotonic (has a lower concentration of solute molecules) with respect to solution B.

questions.question: The two layers of a lipid bilayer

answers.text: none of these answers are correct
have almost identical lipid compositions as lipid molecules can move freely between the two layers
are similar in terms of the types and numbers of their integral membrane proteins as proteins can move freely between the two layers
have both similar lipid and integral membrane protein compositions

questions.correct_answer: none of these answers are correct
questions.neutral_comments: The two layers of a lipid bilayer have different lipid and different protein compositions. Remember that although lipid molecules can diffuse laterally within 1 face of a membrane, it is very rare for a lipid molecule to flip-flop from on ½ (face) of a membrane to the other because for that to happen the hydrophilic part of the lipid molecule (e.g. the phosphate and groups attached to the phosphate of a phospholipid molecule) would need to pass through the hydrophobic core of the membrane. Similarly, protein molecules may not be able to move between the two layers of a lipid bilayer.
questions.all_comments: The two layers of a lipid bilayer have different lipid and different protein compositions. Remember that although lipid molecules can diffuse laterally within 1 face of a membrane, it is very rare for a lipid molecule to flip-flop from on ½ (face) of a membrane to the other because for that to happen the hydrophilic part of the lipid molecule (e.g. the phosphate and groups attached to the phosphate of a phospholipid molecule) would need to pass through the hydrophobic core of the membrane.  Similarly, protein molecules may not be able to move between the two layers of a lipid bilayer.

So, free water molecules WILL still cross the membrane, but there will be not NET flow of water between the two sides of the tube.

It's just that the rate at which they cross from side A to side B will be equal to the rate at which they cross from side B to side A.In this case, the concentration of glucose is the same on both sides of the tube. questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question. The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a selectively permeable barrier. This selectively permeable barrier is permeable to water but not to any ions. If you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of MgCl2 to side “A” and you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of NaCl to side “B”, at equilibrium

answers.text: there will have been no net flow of water between the two sides of the tube
there will have been a net flow of water from side “A” to side “B”
there will have been no movement of water molecules across the membrane
there will have been a net flow of water from side “B” to side “A”

questions.correct_answer: there will have been a net flow of water from side “B” to side “A”
questions.neutral_comments: MgCl2 and NaCl are both salts that will dissociate into their constituent ions when they come in contact with water. So, the 1 mole of MgCl2 will dissociate to form 1 mole of Mg++ and 2 moles of Cl- and the 1 mole of NaCl will dissociate to form 1 mole of Na+and 1 mole of Cl-. That means that, immediately after the solutions are added to the two sides of the tube, there will be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B. As a result, more water molecules will be interacting with solute molecules on side A and there will therefore be a lower concentration of free water molecules on side A than on side B. That, in turn, means there will be a net flow of water molecules from side B to side A, until equilibrium is reached.
questions.all_comments: MgCl2 and NaCl are both salts that will dissociate into their constituent ions when they come in contact with water.  So, the 1 mole of MgCl2 will dissociate to form 1 mole of Mg++ and 2 moles of Cl- and the 1 mole of NaCl will dissociate to form 1 mole of Na+and 1 mole of Cl-.  That means that, immediately after the solutions are added to the two sides of the tube, there will be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B.  As a result, more water molecules will be interacting with solute molecules on side A and there will therefore be a lower concentration of free water molecules on side A than on side B.  That, in turn, means there will be a net flow of water molecules from side B to side A, until equilibrium is reached.

questions.question: Carbohydrates attached to some proteins and lipids of the plasma membrane are added as the membrane is made and refined in the ER and Golgi apparatus: the new membrane then forms transport vesicles that travel to the cell surface. Which of the following statements is TRUE?

questions.question: Glucose diffuses slowly through artificial phospholipid bilayers. The cells lining the small intestine, however, rapidly move large quantities of glucose from glucose-rich foods into their glucose-poor cytoplasm. Using this information, which transport mechanism is most probably functioning in the intestinal cells?

answers.text: Glucoport
Active transport pumps
Simple diffusion
Facilitated diffusion

questions.correct_answer: Facilitated diffusion
questions.neutral_comments: The information that glucose diffuses poorly through artificial phospholipid bilayers tells you that glucose will diffuse poorly on its own through cell membranes. Because you are also told that glucose is entering the intestinal cells quickly, this rules out simple diffusion as a possibility. Because glucose is moving down its concentration gradient as it enters the intestinal cells, no energy should be required for its movement which makes active transport of any means in unlikely possibility. “Glucoport” is a made up term, which leaves facilitated diffusion as the most likely possibility. In facilitated diffusion, channel proteins or carrier proteins in the membrane allow specific molecules that do not easily cross membranes on their own to cross membranes rapidly. So, diffusion (which is always a passive process) is “facilitated” by these proteins.
questions.all_comments: The information that glucose diffuses poorly through artificial phospholipid bilayers tells you that glucose will diffuse poorly on its own through cell membranes.  Because you are also told that glucose is entering the intestinal cells quickly, this rules out simple diffusion as a possibility.  Because glucose is moving down its concentration gradient as it enters the intestinal cells, no energy should be required for its movement which makes active transport of any means in unlikely possibility.  “Glucoport” is a made up term, which leaves facilitated diffusion as the most likely possibility.  In facilitated diffusion, channel proteins or carrier proteins in the membrane allow specific molecules that do not easily cross membranes on their own to cross membranes rapidly. So, diffusion (which is always a passive process) is “facilitated” by these proteins.

questions.question: In order for a protein to be a transmembrane protein it would have to be which of the following?

hydrophilic
amphipathic

questions.correct_answer: amphipathic

They need to have hydrophobic (water fearing) segments that can be inserted inside the membrane and hydrophilic sections that are exposed to the aqueous solution on either side of the membrane. They are thus amphipathic molecules, meaning molecules with both hydrophobic and hydrophilic parts.
questions.all_comments: Transmembrane proteins go all the way across membranes.  They need to have hydrophobic (water fearing) segments that can be inserted inside the membrane and hydrophilic sections that are exposed to the aqueous solution on either side of the membrane.  They are thus amphipathic molecules, meaning molecules with both hydrophobic and hydrophilic parts.

questions.question: Which of the following would likely move through the lipid bilayer of a plasma membrane most rapidly?

answers.text: an amino acid
glucose
CO2
K+

questions.correct_answer: CO2
questions.neutral_comments: Amino acids and K+ are charged molecules. They will therefore pass very poorly through the hydrophobic core of a membrane. Glucose molecules have many polar covalent bonds, due to having many hydroxyl groups. So, glucose molecules will also pass poorly through membranes. In contrast, CO2 is a small molecule that is relatively nonpolar and so will pass through membranes with relative ease.
questions.all_comments: Amino acids and K+ are charged molecules.  They will therefore pass very poorly through the hydrophobic core of a membrane.  Glucose molecules have many polar covalent bonds, due to having many hydroxyl groups.  So, glucose molecules will also pass poorly through membranes.  In contrast, CO2 is a small molecule that is relatively nonpolar and so will pass through membranes with relative ease.

questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question. The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a selectively permeable barrier. This selectively permeable barrier is permeable to water but not to any ions. If you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of MgCl2 to side “A” and you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of NaCl to side “B”, at equilibrium

answers.text: there will have been a net flow of water from side “A” to side “B”
there will have been no movement of water molecules across the membrane
there will have been a net flow of water from side “B” to side “A”
there will have been no net flow of water between the two sides of the tube

questions.correct_answer: there will have been a net flow of water from side “B” to side “A”
questions.neutral_comments: MgCl2 and NaCl are both salts that will dissociate into their constituent ions when they come in contact with water. So, the 1 mole of MgCl2 will dissociate to form 1 mole of Mg++ and 2 moles of Cl- and the 1 mole of NaCl will dissociate to form 1 mole of Na+and 1 mole of Cl-. That means that, immediately after the solutions are added to the two sides of the tube, there will be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B. As a result, more water molecules will be interacting with solute molecules on side A and there will therefore be a lower concentration of free water molecules on side A than on side B. That, in turn, means there will be a net flow of water molecules from side B to side A, until equilibrium is reached.
questions.all_comments: MgCl2 and NaCl are both salts that will dissociate into their constituent ions when they come in contact with water.  So, the 1 mole of MgCl2 will dissociate to form 1 mole of Mg++ and 2 moles of Cl- and the 1 mole of NaCl will dissociate to form 1 mole of Na+and 1 mole of Cl-.  That means that, immediately after the solutions are added to the two sides of the tube, there will be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B.  As a result, more water molecules will be interacting with solute molecules on side A and there will therefore be a lower concentration of free water molecules on side A than on side B.  That, in turn, means there will be a net flow of water molecules from side B to side A, until equilibrium is reached.

questions.question: A hypothesis

is a specific question formulated by scientists after making many careful observations
is a prediction scientists make based on many careful observations
is a tentative answer to a question

questions.correct_answer: is a tentative answer to a question
questions.neutral_comments: A hypothesis is a tentative answer to a question. Ideally, hypothesis-based science is carried out in the following steps: 1) Make observations. 2) Ask a question about those observations. 3) Form one or more hypotheses (= tentative answers to the question). 4) Make predictions based on the hypotheses. 5) Test predictions (e.g. by doing experiments). 6) Determine whether the results of the tests do or do not falsify the hypothesis. NOTE: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is correct. Instead, depending on the results, tests (experiments) may only show that a particular hypothesis is false.

questions.question: Depending on how far an electron is moved from the nucleus

answers.text: you can increase its potential energy by any amount
you can decrease its potential energy by only certain amounts
you can decrease its potential energy by any amount
you can increase its potential energy by only certain amounts

questions.correct_answer: you can increase its potential energy by only certain amounts
questions.neutral_comments: The potential energy of electrons increases the further they are from the nucleus. However, electrons may only occupy certain defined orbitals that have certain defined average distances from the nucleus and thus certain energy levels. Think of it like a ball being moved up or down a set of steps. If a ball is moved up two steps its energy level will increase twice as much as if it is moved up one step (assuming the steps are of equal height). However, it is not feasible to increase the potential energy of the ball by 0.5 or 1.5 steps.
