questions.question: A solution with a pH of 12 contains what concentration of hydroxyl ions [OH<sup>-</sup>]?

answers.text: 10-12 moles/liter
2 moles/liter
0.12 moles/liter
0.01 moles/liter

questions.correct_answer: 0.01 moles/liter
questions.neutral_comments: The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter. In other words, pH = - log [H+]. So, in this case: 12 = - log [H+]. Or, -12 = log [H+]. Or, 10-12 M = [H+]. Furthermore, the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature). So, if the hydrogen ion concentration is 10-12M (moles per liter), the hydroxyl ion concentration must be 10-14/10-12= 10-2 M, or 0.01 M, or 0.01 moles/liter.
questions.all_comments: The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter.  In other words, pH = - log [H+].  So, in this case:  12 = - log [H+].  Or, -12 = log [H+].  Or, 10-12 M = [H+].  Furthermore, the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature).  So, if the hydrogen ion concentration is 10-12M (moles per liter), the hydroxyl ion concentration must be 10-14/10-12= 10-2 M, or 0.01 M, or 0.01 moles/liter.

questions.question: If you were asked to build a polymer that is 30 monomers long, and you could use two different types of monomers, “A” and “B”, how many different polymers could you build?

answers.text: ~ 1 billion

questions.correct_answer: ~ 1 billion
questions.neutral_comments: Think of it this way: If you were asked to build a polymer that was just one monomer long (ok, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), you would be able to build just two different “polymers”: A and B. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 2 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), you would be able to build just 4 different “polymers”: AA, AB, BA and BB. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 3 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), you would be able to build just 8 different “polymers”: AAA, AAB, ABA, BAA, ABB, BAB. BBA and BBB. Are you seeing a pattern here? The answer to this type of question may be found using the following formula: Number of different polymers that may be formed = XY, where “X” is the number of different types of monomers available and “Y” is the number of monomers in the polymer. So, if you were asked to build a polymer that is 30 monomers long, and you could use two different types of monomers, “A” and “B”, the number of different polymers you could build would be: 230 = ~ 1,000,000,000
questions.all_comments: Nice job!Think of it this way: If you were asked to build a polymer that was just one monomer long (ok, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), you would be able to build just two different “polymers”: A and B.  If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 2 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), you would be able to build just 4 different “polymers”: AA, AB, BA and BB. questions.question: Which of the following statements is FALSE?

answers.text: Nucleotides are the monomers from which nucleic acids are formed.
Fatty acids are the monomers from which lipid molecules are formed.
Amino acids are the monomers from which proteins are formed.
Sugars are the monomers from which polysaccharides are formed.

questions.correct_answer: Fatty acids are the monomers from which lipid molecules are formed.
questions.neutral_comments: Fatty acids are important in lipid formation, but are not monomers as monomers are simple molecules, many of which are combined to form a polymer. In contrast, fatty acids are fairly large molecules and few of them are used to make a lipid molecule. For example, just two fatty acid molecules are used in the synthesis of a typical membrane lipid molecule (e.g. a phospholipid) and just three fatty acid molecules are used to make a typical lipid molecule in fat (e.g. a triacylglycerol molecule). In addition, monomers are linked together like cars forming a train to form a polymer. In contrast, the fatty acid molecules that are used to form lipids are not joined to each other. For example, the three fatty acid molecules used to form a triacylglycerol molecule (a type of lipid molecule) are each joined separately to different parts of a glycerol molecule. So, remember that lipids are the one type of biological macromolecule we will discuss that are NOT polymers because they are NOT composed of monomers.
questions.all_comments: Nice job!Fatty acids are important in lipid formation, but are not monomers as monomers are simple molecules, many of which are combined to form a polymer.  In contrast, fatty acids are fairly large molecules and few of them are used to make a lipid molecule.  For example, just two fatty acid molecules are used in the synthesis of a typical membrane lipid molecule (e.g. a phospholipid) and just three fatty acid molecules are used to make a typical lipid molecule in fat (e.g. a triacylglycerol molecule).  In addition, monomers are linked together like cars forming a train to form a polymer.  In contrast, the fatty acid molecules that are used to form lipids are not joined to each other.  For example, the three fatty acid molecules used to form a triacylglycerol molecule (a type of lipid molecule) are each joined separately to different parts of a glycerol molecule.  So, remember that lipids are the one type of biological macromolecule we will discuss that are NOT polymers because they are NOT composed of monomers.

questions.question:
What would be the sequence of the RNA molecule made using the following DNA strand as a template?

5’ TCTGAA 3’

answers.text: 5’ TTCAGA 3’
5’ UUCAGA 3’
5’AGACTT 3’
5’ AGACUU 3’

questions.correct_answer: 5’ UUCAGA 3’
questions.neutral_comments: First, remember that nucleic acid strands bind to each other with an anti-parallel orientation. In other words, they bind so that the 5’ end of one strand is hydrogen bonded to the 3’ end of the other strand. Also, remember that U (for RNA) or T (for DNA) hydrogen bonds with A, and G hydrogen bonds with C. So, you have: DNA 5’ TCTGAA 3’RNA 3’ AGACUU 5’ If you then follow the convention of writing nucleic acid molecules down starting at their 5’ end, the sequence for the RNA molecule is: 5’ UUCAGA 3’
questions.all_comments: Good work!First, remember that nucleic acid strands bind to each other with an anti-parallel orientation.  In other words, they bind so that the 5’ end of one strand is hydrogen bonded to the 3’ end of the other strand.  Also, remember that U (for RNA) or T (for DNA) hydrogen bonds with A, and G hydrogen bonds with C.  So, you have: DNA                5’ TCTGAA 3’RNA                3’ AGACUU 5’ If you then follow the convention of writing nucleic acid molecules down starting at their 5’ end, the sequence for the RNA molecule is: 5’ UUCAGA 3’

So, they are isomers of some sort. However, despite the fact that they have a carbon-carbon double bond, they are NOT geometric isomers. Geometric isomers have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms. The pair of molecules shown above do NOT have the same covalent arrangement of their atoms. For the molecule shown on the left, each of the carbon atoms is covalently bound to one hydrogen atom and one hydroxyl (OH) group. For the molecule shown on the right, one carbon atom is covalently bound to two hydroxyl groups and the other carbon atom is covalently bound to two hydrogen atoms. So, the two molecules do not have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms. Because they differ in the covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are examples of the type of isomers known structural isomers.

questions.question: A hypothesis

answers.text: is a tentative answer to a question
is a prediction scientists make based on many careful observations
is the same thing as a theory
is a specific question formulated by scientists after making many careful observations

questions.correct_answer: is a tentative answer to a question
questions.neutral_comments: A hypothesis is a tentative answer to a question. Ideally, hypothesis-based science is carried out in the following steps: 1) Make observations. 2) Ask a question about those observations. 3) Form one or more hypotheses (= tentative answers to the question). 4) Make predictions based on the hypotheses. 5) Test predictions (e.g. by doing experiments). 6) Determine whether the results of the tests do or do not falsify the hypothesis. NOTE: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is correct. Instead, depending on the results, tests (experiments) may only show that a particular hypothesis is false.

steps: 1) Make observations. 2) Ask a question about those observations. 3)

experiments). 6) Determine whether the results of the tests do or do not
falsify the hypothesis. NOTE: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is
correct. Instead, depending on the results, tests (experiments) may only show
that a particular hypothesis is false.

questions.question: L-methionine and D-methionine are examples of

answers.text: geometric isomers
structural isomers
all of these answers are correct
enantiomers

questions.correct_answer: enantiomers
questions.neutral_comments: All amino acids except glycine have an asymmetric carbon, meaning a carbon atom that is covalently bound to 4 different groups. In the case of all amino acids except glycine, those groups are: a carboxyl group, an amino group, a hydrogen and an "R" group. The reason that glycine does not have an asymmetric carbon is because the R group of glycine is hydrogen. So, the central carbon of a glycine molecule is only bound to 3 different groups, since it is bound to two hydrogen atoms. Molecules with asymmetric carbons may occur as two different isomers, known as enantiomers. Enantiomers have the same covalent partnerships (i.e. they do NOT differ in which elements are covalently bound to which other elements), but are instead mirror images of each other. L-methionine and D-methionine meet this definition and so are enantiomers. Please see figure 4.7 in your book for a figure illustrating the different types of isomers.
questions.all_comments: Good work!All amino acids except glycine have an asymmetric carbon, meaning a carbon atom that is covalently bound to 4 different groups.  In the case of all amino acids except glycine, those groups are: a carboxyl group, an amino group, a hydrogen and an "R" group.  The reason that glycine does not have an asymmetric carbon is because the R group of glycine is hydrogen.  So, the central carbon of a glycine molecule is only bound to 3 different groups, since it is bound to two hydrogen atoms.   Molecules with asymmetric carbons may occur as two different isomers, known as enantiomers.  Enantiomers have the same covalent partnerships (i.e. they do NOT differ in which elements are covalently bound to which other elements), but are instead mirror images of each other.  L-methionine and D-methionine meet this definition and so are enantiomers.  Please see figure 4.7 in your book for a figure illustrating the different types of isomers.

questions.question: A hypothesis

answers.text: can be proven to be correct
can NOT be proven to be correct
can NOT be proven to be correct or incorrect, regardless of experimental results
can be proven to be correct or incorrect, depending on experimental results

questions.correct_answer: can NOT be proven to be correct
questions.neutral_comments: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is correct. Instead the results of tests (experiments) may only show that a particular hypothesis is false. For example, if your hypothesis for why a flashlight isn’t working is that the batteries are dead, you might predict that replacing the batteries will fix the flashlight. If you then test your prediction by replacing the batteries and find that the flashlight still does not work, you have disproven your original prediction that replacing the batteries would fix the flashlight and have thus shown your hypothesis to be incorrect (false). However, if the flashlight works after you replace the batteries, that finding does not prove that your hypothesis was correct. This is because you can still come up with alternative hypotheses for why the flashlight now works. For example, you could hypothesize that the reason the flashlight wasn’t working previously was because the original batteries were inserted incorrectly. Then, when you replaced the batteries, you inserted the new batteries correctly and so fixed the flashlight. If that is the case, then your original hypothesis that the old batteries were dead would be false. The bottom line is that we can never rule out that there might be a different hypothesis that also explains all of the available experimental results and that is actually the correct hypothesis.

correct. Instead the results of tests (experiments) may only show that a
particular hypothesis is false. For example, if your hypothesis for why a

questions.question: The molecules shown below are best described as

answers.text: Structural isomers
Isotopes
Geometric isomers
Enantiomers

questions.correct_answer: Geometric isomers
questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C2N2O2H2), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers. For example, both carbon atoms in both molecules are attached to one N=O group and one hydrogen atom. However, the two molecules do have different structures. Remember that double covalent bonds are inflexible. So, the above molecules cannot rotate around their double bonds in the way that they could if the two carbon atoms were only joined by single covalent bonds. So, in the molecule on the left, the two N=O groups will always be on the opposite sides of the double bond, whereas the two N=O groups will always be on the same side of the double bond in the molecule on the right. Molecules such as these two, which have the same covalent partnerships but different spatial arrangements, are known as geometric isomers. The molecule on the left, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the N=O groups) on opposite sides of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a trans isomer. The molecule on the right, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the N=O groups) on the same side of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a cis isomer.
questions.all_comments: Good work!These two molecules have the same formula (C2N2O2H2), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but different 3-dimensional shapes.  So, they are isomers of some sort.  Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers.  For example, both carbon atoms in both molecules are attached to one N=O group and one hydrogen atom.  However, the two molecules do have different structures.  Remember that double covalent bonds are inflexible.  So, the above molecules cannot rotate around their double bonds in the way that they could if the two carbon atoms were only joined by single covalent bonds.  So, in the molecule on the left, the two N=O groups will always be on the opposite sides of the double bond, whereas the two N=O groups will always be on the same side of the double bond in the molecule on the right.  Molecules such as these two, which have the same covalent partnerships but different spatial arrangements, are known as geometric isomers.  The molecule on the left, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the N=O groups) on opposite sides of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a trans isomer.  The molecule on the right, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the N=O groups) on the same side of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a cis isomer.

questions.question: You have a freshly prepared 1 M (molar) solution of glucose in water. You carefully pour out a 100 mL sample of that solution. How many glucose molecules are included in that 100 mL sample?
questions.neutral_comments: Remember that a mole is a number just like a “dozen” is a number. A “dozen” means “12”, and a “mole” means “6.02 X 1023”. A one molar solution has one mole of solute molecules per liter of solution, or 6.02 X 1023 molecules of solute per liter of solution. So, a 0.1 liters of a 1 molar solution will have 0.1 moles of solute molecules. 0.1 moles X (6.02 X 1023 molecules/mole) = 6.02 X 1022 molecules.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about bases is FALSE?

answers.text: Bases cause the concentration of hydroxide (OH-) anions to increase and the concentration of H+ cations to decrease.
Bases cause the pH of the solution to decrease.
Some bases reduce H+ concentrations by accepting hydrogen ions.
Some bases reduce H+ concentrations by dissociating to form hydroxide (OH-) anions.

questions.correct_answer: Bases cause the pH of the solution to decrease.
questions.all_comments:
Bases cause the hydrogen ion concentration of a solution to DECREASE. Remember that, because pH is the NEGATIVE log of the hydrogen ion concentration, when the hydrogen ion concentration of a solution decreases, the pH of that solution increases. So, bases cause the pH of a solution to INCREASE, rather than decrease.
 
Bases cause the concentration of H+ ions to decrease by one of two ways. Some bases reduce H+ concentrations by dissociating to form hydroxide (OH-) anions. The hydroxide ions from the bases then react with H+ in the water to form water molecules, thereby reducing H+ concentrations. Alternatively, some bases reduce H+ concentrations by accepting (binding with) hydrogen ions.
 
So, because the question asks which statement about bases is FALSE, the correct answer to the question is that bases cause the pH to decrease, since bases actually cause the pH to increase.

questions.neutral_comments: Isomers of any type (structural isomers, geometric isomers and enantiomers) must all meet the criteria of having the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures. Structural isomers have the further criteria that, for two molecules to be structural isomers of each other, they must differ in their covalent partnerships. In contrast, molecules that are geometric isomers or enantiomers do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships. Geometric isomers differ in the arrangement of atoms around a double bond. Enantiomers differ in the arrangement of atoms covalently bound to a central, asymmetric carbon and are mirror images of each other. Please see figure 4.7 in your textbook for a figure showing all three types of isomer.
questions.all_comments: Good work!Isomers of any type (structural isomers, geometric isomers and enantiomers) must all meet the criteria of having the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures.  Structural isomers have the further criteria that, for two molecules to be structural isomers of each other, they must differ in their covalent partnerships.  In contrast, molecules that are geometric isomers or enantiomers do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships.  Geometric isomers differ in the arrangement of atoms around a double bond.  Enantiomers differ in the arrangement of atoms covalently bound to a central, asymmetric carbon and are mirror images of each other.  Please see figure 4.7 in your textbook for a figure showing all three types of isomer.

questions.question: How many covalent bonds do oxygen atoms need to form with other atoms to complete their valence shell?
questions.neutral_comments: Oxygen atoms have 6 electrons in their valence shell, which is the 2nd electron shell. The total number of electrons needed to fill the 2ndelectron shell is 8, so oxygen needs to form 2 covalent bonds with other atoms so that it has 2 pairs of electrons that it is sharing via covalent bonds and 2 pairs of electrons that it is not sharing, for a total of 4 pairs of electrons, or 8 total electrons.
questions.all_comments: ExcellentOxygen atoms have 6 electrons in their valence shell, which is the 2nd electron shell. The total number of electrons needed to fill the 2ndelectron shell is 8, so oxygen needs to form 2 covalent bonds with other atoms so that it has 2 pairs of electrons that it is sharing via covalent bonds and 2 pairs of electrons that it is not sharing, for a total of 4 pairs of electrons, or 8 total electrons.

questions.question: Experimentation is only one part of the process of scientific inquiry, but it is a very important step because it

answers.text: gives the investigator a systematic, unbiased result
ensures that the variable being tested is measured without error
allows rejection of a hypothesis
ensures that hypotheses can be confirmed with certainty

questions.correct_answer: allows rejection of a hypothesis
questions.neutral_comments: Experiments are designed to test predictions. The prediction being tested is based on a hypothesis. Therefore, if the prediction is shown to be false, that result indicates that the hypothesis on which the prediction was based is also false. Carrying out experiments does not ensure that a hypothesis will be supported. Because hypotheses are only POSSIBLE answers to questions, many hypotheses turn out to be incorrect. In addition, it is not possible to prove that a hypothesis is correct as there will always be alternative explanations for why testing showed that a particular prediction was correct. Experiments don’t necessarily give investigators systematic unbiased results; it depends on how the experiments are designed and conducted. Similarly, it is difficult or impossible to ensure that variables being tested are measured without error.
questions.all_comments: Experiments are designed to test predictions. The prediction being tested is based on a hypothesis. Therefore, if the prediction is shown to be false, that result indicates that the hypothesis on which the prediction was based is also false. Carrying out experiments does not ensure that a hypothesis will be supported. Because hypotheses are only POSSIBLE answers to questions, many hypotheses turn out to be incorrect. In addition, it is not possible to prove that a hypothesis is correct as there will always be alternative explanations for why testing showed that a particular prediction was correct. Experiments don’t necessarily give investigators systematic unbiased results; it depends on how the experiments are designed and conducted. Similarly, it is difficult or impossible to ensure that variables being tested are measured without error.

questions.question: The molecules shown below are best described as

answers.text: Enantiomers
Structural isomers
Isotopes
Geometric isomers

questions.correct_answer: Enantiomers
questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (CN2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers. In addition, because these molecules do not have 2 carbon atoms joined by a double bond, they cannot be geometric isomers. Instead, they are “enantiomers”. Enantiomers are mirror images of each other and cannot be superimposed on each other. This is quite similar to how our hands are mirror images of each other, but cannot be superimposed on each other. For example, imagine the palms of your hands as being carbon atom and the four fingers on each hand representing covalent bonds to 4 different groups. There is no way to place one hand on the other hand so that all four of your fingers will match up. Note that enantiomers only occur in molecules that have an asymmetric carbon. For a carbon to be asymmetric, it must form covalent bonds to 4 different groups.
questions.all_comments: Good work!These two molecules have the same formula (CN2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but different 3-dimensional shapes.  So, they are isomers of some sort.  Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers. In addition, because these molecules do not have 2 carbon atoms joined by a double bond, they cannot be geometric isomers.  Instead, they are “enantiomers”.  Enantiomers are mirror images of each other and cannot be superimposed on each other.  This is quite similar to how our hands are mirror images of each other, but cannot be superimposed on each other.  For example, imagine the palms of your hands as being carbon atom and the four fingers on each hand representing covalent bonds to 4 different groups.  There is no way to place one hand on the other hand so that all four of your fingers will match up.  Note that enantiomers only occur in molecules that have an asymmetric carbon.  For a carbon to be asymmetric, it must form covalent bonds to 4 different groups.

questions.question: Through careful experimentation or observations, it is possible to prove

answers.text: a theory, but not a hypothesis
a hypothesis, but not a theory
either a hypothesis or a theory
neither a hypothesis nor a theory

questions.correct_answer: neither a hypothesis nor a theory
questions.neutral_comments: It is not possible to PROVE that a theory or hypothesis is correct. Instead the results of tests (experiments) may only show that a particular theory or hypothesis is false. For example, if your hypothesis for why a flashlight isn’t working is that the batteries are dead, you might predict that replacing the batteries will fix the flashlight. If you then test your prediction by replacing the batteries and find that the flashlight still does not work, you have disproven your original prediction that replacing the batteries would fix the flashlight and have thus shown your hypothesis to be incorrect (false). However, if the flashlight works after you replace the batteries, that finding does not prove that your prediction was correct and thus does not prove that your hypothesis was correct. This is because you can still come up with alternative hypotheses for why the flashlight now works. For example, you could hypothesize that the reason the flashlight wasn’t working previously was because the original batteries were inserted incorrectly. Then, when you replaced the batteries, you inserted them correctly and so fixed the flashlight. If that is the case, then your original hypothesis that the old batteries were dead would be false. The bottom line is that we can never rule out that there might be a different hypothesis that also explains all of the available experimental results and that is actually the correct hypothesis.
questions.all_comments:
Good job!It is not possible to PROVE that a theory or
hypothesis is correct. Instead the results of tests (experiments) may only show
that a particular theory or hypothesis is false. For example, if your

questions.question:
What would be the sequence of the RNA molecule made using the following DNA strand as a template?

5’ TCTGAA 3’

answers.text: 5’AGACTT 3’
5’ UUCAGA 3’
5’ AGACUU 3’
5’ TTCAGA 3’

questions.correct_answer: 5’ UUCAGA 3’
questions.neutral_comments: First, remember that nucleic acid strands bind to each other with an anti-parallel orientation. In other words, they bind so that the 5’ end of one strand is hydrogen bonded to the 3’ end of the other strand. Also, remember that U (for RNA) or T (for DNA) hydrogen bonds with A, and G hydrogen bonds with C. So, you have: DNA 5’ TCTGAA 3’RNA 3’ AGACUU 5’ If you then follow the convention of writing nucleic acid molecules down starting at their 5’ end, the sequence for the RNA molecule is: 5’ UUCAGA 3’
questions.all_comments: Good work!First, remember that nucleic acid strands bind to each other with an anti-parallel orientation.  In other words, they bind so that the 5’ end of one strand is hydrogen bonded to the 3’ end of the other strand.  Also, remember that U (for RNA) or T (for DNA) hydrogen bonds with A, and G hydrogen bonds with C.  So, you have: DNA                5’ TCTGAA 3’RNA                3’ AGACUU 5’ If you then follow the convention of writing nucleic acid molecules down starting at their 5’ end, the sequence for the RNA molecule is: 5’ UUCAGA 3’

questions.question: How many more electrons do hydrogen atoms need to complete their valence shell?
questions.neutral_comments: Hydrogen atoms have 1 electron. This electron goes in the 1stelectron shell. There is only one orbital in the 1st electron shell. Every electron orbital can have a maximum of 2 electrons. So, the maximum number of electrons that can go in the 1st electron shell, and thus the total number of electrons needed to fill the 1st electron shell, is 2. Since hydrogen has 1 to start with, it needs 1 more electron to fill its valence shell.

Every electron orbital can have a maximum of 2 electrons. So, the maximum number of electrons that can go in the 1st electron shell, and thus the total number of electrons needed to fill the 1st electron shell, is 2. Since hydrogen has 1 to start with, it needs 1 more electron to fill its valence shell.

questions.question: The molecules shown below are best described as

answers.text: Structural isomers
Isotopes
Geometric isomers
Enantiomers

questions.correct_answer: Geometric isomers
questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C2N2O2H2), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers. For example, both carbon atoms in both molecules are attached to one N=O group and one hydrogen atom. However, the two molecules do have different structures. Remember that double covalent bonds are inflexible. So, the above molecules cannot rotate around their double bonds in the way that they could if the two carbon atoms were only joined by single covalent bonds. So, in the molecule on the left, the two N=O groups will always be on the opposite sides of the double bond, whereas the two N=O groups will always be on the same side of the double bond in the molecule on the right. Molecules such as these two, which have the same covalent partnerships but different spatial arrangements, are known as geometric isomers. The molecule on the left, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the N=O groups) on opposite sides of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a trans isomer. The molecule on the right, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the N=O groups) on the same side of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a cis isomer.
questions.all_comments: Good work!These two molecules have the same formula (C2N2O2H2), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but different 3-dimensional shapes.  So, they are isomers of some sort.  Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers.  For example, both carbon atoms in both molecules are attached to one N=O group and one hydrogen atom.  However, the two molecules do have different structures.  Remember that double covalent bonds are inflexible.  So, the above molecules cannot rotate around their double bonds in the way that they could if the two carbon atoms were only joined by single covalent bonds.  So, in the molecule on the left, the two N=O groups will always be on the opposite sides of the double bond, whereas the two N=O groups will always be on the same side of the double bond in the molecule on the right.  Molecules such as these two, which have the same covalent partnerships but different spatial arrangements, are known as geometric isomers.  The molecule on the left, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the N=O groups) on opposite sides of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a trans isomer.  The molecule on the right, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the N=O groups) on the same side of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a cis isomer.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about hypotheses is FALSE?

answers.text: Hypotheses should be testable.
Hypotheses should be falsifiable.
Hypotheses should be possible answers to specific questions.
Hypotheses should be provable.

questions.correct_answer: Hypotheses should be provable.
questions.neutral_comments: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is correct. Instead the results of tests (experiments) may only show that a particular hypothesis is false. For example, if your hypothesis for why a flashlight isn’t working is that the batteries are dead, you might predict that replacing the batteries will fix the flashlight. If you then test your prediction by replacing the batteries and find that the flashlight still does not work, you have disproven your original prediction that replacing the batteries would fix the flashlight and have thus shown your hypothesis to be incorrect (false). However, if the flashlight works after you replace the batteries, that finding does not prove that your prediction was correct and thus does not prove that your hypothesis was correct. This is because you can still come up with alternative hypotheses for why the flashlight now works. For example, you could hypothesize that the reason the flashlight wasn’t working previously was because the original batteries were inserted incorrectly. Then, when you replaced the batteries, you inserted the new batteries correctly and so fixed the flashlight. If that is the case, then your original hypothesis that the old batteries were dead would be false.

Good job!It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is
correct. Instead the results of tests (experiments) may only show that a
particular hypothesis is false. For example, if your hypothesis for why a
flashlight isn’t working is that the batteries are dead, you might predict that
replacing the batteries will fix the flashlight. If you then test your
prediction by replacing the batteries and find that the flashlight still does
not work, you have disproven your original prediction that replacing the
batteries would fix the flashlight and have thus shown your hypothesis to be incorrect
(false). However, if the flashlight works after you replace the batteries, that
finding does not prove that your prediction was correct and thus does not prove
that your hypothesis was correct. This is because you can still come up with
alternative hypotheses for why the flashlight now works. For example, you could
hypothesize that the reason the flashlight wasn’t working previously was
because the original batteries were inserted incorrectly. Then, when you
replaced the batteries, you inserted the new batteries correctly and so fixed
the flashlight. If that is the case, then your original hypothesis that the old
batteries were dead would be false.

questions.question: The molecules shown below are best described as

answers.text: Geometric isomers
Enantiomers
Isotopes
Structural isomers

questions.correct_answer: Structural isomers
questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but have different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. However, despite the fact that they have a carbon-carbon double bond, they are NOT geometric isomers. Geometric isomers have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms. The pair of molecules shown above do NOT have the same covalent arrangement of their atoms. For the molecule shown on the left, each of the carbon atoms is covalently bound to one hydrogen atom and one hydroxyl (OH) group. For the molecule shown on the right, one carbon atom is covalently bound to two hydroxyl groups and the other carbon atom is covalently bound to two hydrogen atoms. So, the two molecules do not have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms. Because they differ in the covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are examples of the type of isomers known structural isomers.
questions.all_comments: Good work!These two molecules have the same formula (C2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but have different 3-dimensional shapes.  So, they are isomers of some sort.  However, despite the fact that they have a carbon-carbon double bond, they are NOT geometric isomers.  Geometric isomers have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms.  The pair of molecules shown above do NOT have the same covalent arrangement of their atoms.  For the molecule shown on the left, each of the carbon atoms is covalently bound to one hydrogen atom and one hydroxyl (OH) group.  For the molecule shown on the right, one carbon atom is covalently bound to two hydroxyl groups and the other carbon atom is covalently bound to two hydrogen atoms.  So, the two molecules do not have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms.  Because they differ in the covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are examples of the type of isomers known structural isomers.

questions.question: A solution with a pH of 10 contains what concentration of hydroxyl ions [OH<sup>-</sup>]?

answers.text: 10 moles/liter
10-10 moles/liter
0.0001 moles/liter
0.01 moles/liter

questions.correct_answer: 0.0001 moles/liter
questions.neutral_comments: The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter. In other words, pH = - log [H+]. So, in this case: 10 = - log [H+]. Or, -10 = log [H+]. Or, 10-10 M = [H+]. Furthermore, the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature). So, if the hydrogen ion concentration is 10-10M (moles per liter), the hydroxyl ion concentration must be 10-14/10-10= 10-4 M, or 0.0001 M, or 0.0001 moles/liter.
questions.all_comments: The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter.  In other words, pH = - log [H+].  So, in this case:  10 = - log [H+].  Or, -10 = log [H+].  Or, 10-10 M = [H+].  Furthermore, the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature).  So, if the hydrogen ion concentration is 10-10M (moles per liter), the hydroxyl ion concentration must be 10-14/10-10= 10-4 M, or 0.0001 M, or 0.0001 moles/liter.

questions.question: Which of the following are NOT polymers:

answers.text: Proteins
Lipids
Nucleic acids
Polysaccharides

questions.correct_answer: Lipids
questions.neutral_comments: Lipids are large biological molecules. However they are not polymers because they are not composed of repeating units of simple monomers. In contrast, polysaccharides are polymers composed of repeating monomers (= monosaccharides), polypeptides (proteins) are polymers composed of repeating monomers (= amino acids) and nucleic acids are polymers composed of monomers (nucleotides).
questions.all_comments: Nice job!Lipids are large biological molecules.  However they are not polymers because they are not composed of repeating units of simple monomers.  In contrast, polysaccharides are polymers composed of repeating monomers (= monosaccharides), polypeptides (proteins) are polymers composed of repeating monomers (= amino acids) and nucleic acids are polymers composed of monomers (nucleotides).

questions.question: How many water molecules are needed to completely hydrolyze a polymer that is 18 nucleotides long?
questions.neutral_comments: Think of it this way: How many water molecules would be needed to completely hydrolyze a “polymer” that is just two nucleotides long? You would need just one, to split the one bond joining the two monomers, right? So, how many water molecules would you need to completely hydrolyze a “polymer” that is 3 monomers long? The answer is that you would need 2 water molecules, one to split the bond between the 1stand 2nd monomers and the other to hydrolyze the bond between the 2ndand 3rd monomers. So, you to completely hydrolyze a polymer takes one less water molecule than the number of monomers in the polymer.
questions.all_comments: Good work!Think of it this way: How many water molecules would be needed to completely hydrolyze a “polymer” that is just two nucleotides long?  You would need just one, to split the one bond joining the two monomers, right?  So, how many water molecules would you need to completely hydrolyze a “polymer” that is 3 monomers long?  The answer is that you would need 2 water molecules, one to split the bond between the 1stand 2nd monomers and the other to hydrolyze the bond between the 2ndand 3rd monomers.  So, you to completely hydrolyze a polymer takes one less water molecule than the number of monomers in the polymer.

questions.question: Which pathway is generally followed by a protein produced for secretion?

answers.text: Smooth ER, vesicle, Golgi, vesicle
Rough ER, vesicle, Golgi, vesicle
Golgi, vesicle, rough ER, vesicle
Golgi, vesicle, smooth ER, vesicle

questions.correct_answer: Rough ER, vesicle, Golgi, vesicle
questions.neutral_comments: Remember that proteins produced for secretion and proteins that will become part of one of the membranes of the endomembrane system are made by bound ribosomes (= ribosomes bound to the rough ER or nuclear envelope). Proteins made by ribosomes attached to the rough ER are transported via vesicles to the Golgi apparatus where they may be modified. The proteins are next transported via vesicles to their next destination (= the plasma membrane, in the case of secreted proteins). In contrast, “free ribosomes” (= ribosomes that are NOT bound to the rough ER or to the nuclear envelope) produce proteins that float freely in the cytosol or that are transported into the nucleus, mitochondria or chloroplasts.
questions.all_comments: Remember that proteins produced for secretion and proteins that will become part of one of the membranes of the endomembrane system are made by bound ribosomes (= ribosomes bound to the rough ER or nuclear envelope). Proteins made by ribosomes attached to the rough ER are transported via vesicles to the Golgi apparatus where they may be modified. The proteins are next transported via vesicles to their next destination (= the plasma membrane, in the case of secreted proteins). In contrast, “free ribosomes” (= ribosomes that are NOT bound to the rough ER or to the nuclear envelope) produce proteins that float freely in the cytosol or that are transported into the nucleus, mitochondria or chloroplasts.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about ribosomes is TRUE?

answers.text: Bound ribosomes are attached to protein molecules whereas free ribosomes are NOT attached to protein molecules.

Free ribosomes are available to begin synthesizing new proteins whereas bound ribosomes are currently unavailable for synthesizing new proteins as they are already in the process of synthesizing a protein.

questions.neutral_comments: The terms “free” and “bound” apply to ribosomes that are floating free in the cytoplasm or are bound to the rough endoplasmic reticulum. Bound ribosomes will generally be in the process of forming a polypeptide, as the reason they are bound (attached) to the rough ER is because they are attached to the protein they are synthesizing and the protein they are synthesizing is attached to the rough ER. In contrast, a free ribosome may or may not be in the process of forming a polypeptide molecule at any given time.
questions.all_comments: The terms “free” and “bound” apply to ribosomes that are floating free in the cytoplasm or are bound to the rough endoplasmic reticulum.  Bound ribosomes will generally be in the process of forming a polypeptide, as the reason they are bound (attached) to the rough ER is because they are attached to the protein they are synthesizing and the protein they are synthesizing is attached to the rough ER.  In contrast, a free ribosome may or may not be in the process of forming a polypeptide molecule at any given time.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about ribosomes is TRUE?

answers.text: Free ribosomes carry out protein synthesis while floating free in the cytosol and bound ribosomes carry out protein synthesis while attached to a membrane.

Free ribosomes are available to begin synthesizing new proteins whereas bound ribosomes are currently unavailable for synthesizing new proteins as they are already in the process of synthesizing a protein.
Free ribosomes are free to diffuse around the cytosol and bound ribosomes are confined inside the nucleus.
Bound ribosomes are attached to protein molecules whereas free ribosomes are NOT attached to protein molecules.

questions.correct_answer: Free ribosomes carry out protein synthesis while floating free in the cytosol and bound ribosomes carry out protein synthesis while attached to a membrane.
questions.neutral_comments: The terms “free” and “bound” apply to ribosomes that are floating free in the cytoplasm or are bound to the rough endoplasmic reticulum. Bound ribosomes will generally be in the process of forming a polypeptide, as the reason they are bound (attached) to the rough ER is because they are attached to the protein they are synthesizing and the protein they are synthesizing is attached to the rough ER. In contrast, a free ribosome may or may not be in the process of forming a polypeptide molecule at any given time.
questions.all_comments: The terms “free” and “bound” apply to ribosomes that are floating free in the cytoplasm or are bound to the rough endoplasmic reticulum.  Bound ribosomes will generally be in the process of forming a polypeptide, as the reason they are bound (attached) to the rough ER is because they are attached to the protein they are synthesizing and the protein they are synthesizing is attached to the rough ER.  In contrast, a free ribosome may or may not be in the process of forming a polypeptide molecule at any given time.

questions.question: Why have plants been referred to as “supracellular” organisms?

answers.text: Plant cells are able to carry out photosynthesis.
The vast majority of the cells in a plant are connected by plasmodesmata, forming a sort of “super cell”
The cell walls surrounding plant cells make them super strong.
Plant cells tend to be larger than animal cells.

questions.correct_answer: The vast majority of the cells in a plant are connected by plasmodesmata, forming a sort of “super cell”
questions.neutral_comments: Unicellular organisms are organisms that have only a single cell. Multi-cellular organisms, such as people, are organisms that have multiple cells. Plants have been referred to as “supracellular” organisms because almost all of the cells in a plants are directly connected by pores that run through their cell walls. These pores are called plasmodesmata. Plasmodesmata allow small molecules to diffuse between different cells in a plant without having to cross a plasma membrane. So, most of the cells in a plant can be thought of as being joined together in a giant “super cell”.
questions.all_comments: Unicellular organisms are organisms that have only a single cell.  Multi-cellular organisms, such as people, are organisms that have multiple cells.  Plants have been referred to as “supracellular” organisms because almost all of the cells in a plants are directly connected by pores that run through their cell walls.  These pores are called plasmodesmata.  Plasmodesmata allow small molecules to diffuse between different cells in a plant without having to cross a plasma membrane.  So, most of the cells in a plant can be thought of as being joined together in a giant “super cell”.

Free ribosomes are available to begin synthesizing new proteins whereas bound ribosomes are currently unavailable for synthesizing new proteins as they are already in the process of synthesizing a protein.
Bound ribosomes are attached to protein molecules whereas free ribosomes are NOT attached to protein molecules.

questions.correct_answer: Free ribosomes carry out protein synthesis while floating free in the cytosol and bound ribosomes carry out protein synthesis while attached to a membrane.
questions.neutral_comments: The terms “free” and “bound” apply to ribosomes that are floating free in the cytoplasm or are bound to the rough endoplasmic reticulum. Bound ribosomes will generally be in the process of forming a polypeptide, as the reason they are bound (attached) to the rough ER is because they are attached to the protein they are synthesizing and the protein they are synthesizing is attached to the rough ER. In contrast, a free ribosome may or may not be in the process of forming a polypeptide molecule at any given time.
questions.all_comments: The terms “free” and “bound” apply to ribosomes that are floating free in the cytoplasm or are bound to the rough endoplasmic reticulum.  Bound ribosomes will generally be in the process of forming a polypeptide, as the reason they are bound (attached) to the rough ER is because they are attached to the protein they are synthesizing and the protein they are synthesizing is attached to the rough ER.  In contrast, a free ribosome may or may not be in the process of forming a polypeptide molecule at any given time.

questions.question: The wavelength of light

answers.text: limits the magnifying power of light microscopes
limits the contrast of light microscopes
all of these answers are correct
limits the resolution of light microscopes

questions.correct_answer: limits the resolution of light microscopes
questions.neutral_comments: The longer the wavelength of the radiation used for imaging, the less possible it is to resolve two structures that are close together. The ability of light microscopes to resolve structures is thus limited by the wavelength of light. You could use a light microscope to view images at really high magnifications, but that wouldn’t be useful because the images would just become more and more blurry as the magnification increased.
questions.all_comments: The longer the wavelength of the radiation used for imaging, the less possible it is to resolve two structures that are close together.  The ability of light microscopes to resolve structures is thus limited by the wavelength of light.  You could use a light microscope to view images at really high magnifications, but that wouldn’t be useful because the images would just become more and more blurry as the magnification increased.

In scanning em the electron beam is focused across the surface of the specimen or through the specimen.
In scanning em the electron beam is focused across the surface of the specimen
In transmission em the electron beam is focused across the surface of the specimen

questions.correct_answer: In scanning em the electron beam is focused across the surface of the specimen
questions.all_comments: Nice work!

questions.question: Which structure is the site of the synthesis of protein that may be exported from the cell?

answers.text: Golgi vesicles
mitochondrion
rough endoplasmic reticulum
smooth endoplasmic reticulum

questions.correct_answer: rough endoplasmic reticulum
questions.neutral_comments: Secreted proteins are synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough endoplasmic reticulum. Remember that the rough ER gets its name from the fact that it has a “rough” appearance when looked at using a microscope. The reason is has a “rough” appearance is because of the ribosomes that are bound to it. After proteins destined for export are synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough ER, vesicles bud off of the rough endoplasmic reticulum and transport those proteins to the Golgi apparatus where they are modified. Vesicles than bud off of the Golgi apparatus and transport the proteins to the plasma membrane. The vesicles fuse with the plasma membrane, releasing the proteins to the outside of the cell.
questions.all_comments: Secreted proteins are synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough endoplasmic reticulum.  Remember that the rough ER gets its name from the fact that it has a “rough” appearance when looked at using a microscope.  The reason is has a “rough” appearance is because of the ribosomes that are bound to it.  After proteins destined for export are synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough ER, vesicles bud off of the rough endoplasmic reticulum and transport those proteins to the Golgi apparatus where they are modified.  Vesicles than bud off of the Golgi apparatus and transport the proteins to the plasma membrane.  The vesicles fuse with the plasma membrane, releasing the proteins to the outside of the cell.

questions.question: Why do grocery stores spray vegetables with water?

answers.text: The cells of the vegetables will absorb water and expand against their cell walls, making the vegetables crisper.
The water will be hypotonic relative to the interacellular fluid of the vegetables, allowing the cells to excrete excess ions
The water will help keep the vegetable’s cell membranes fluid.
The water will be hypertonic relative to the intracellular fluid of the vegetables, allowing the cells to lose excess water.

questions.correct_answer: The cells of the vegetables will absorb water and expand against their cell walls, making the vegetables crisper.
questions.neutral_comments: Water will be hypotonic compared with the fluid inside the vegetable cells. That means there will be a lower concentration of free water molecules inside the vegetable cells, leading to a net flow of water molecules from outside to inside of the cells. This will cause the cells to expand against their cell walls, making the vegetables crisper.
questions.all_comments: Good job!Water will be hypotonic compared with the fluid inside the vegetable cells.  That means there will be a lower concentration of free water molecules inside the vegetable cells, leading to a net flow of water molecules from outside to inside of the cells.  This will cause the cells to expand against their cell walls, making the vegetables crisper.

questions.question: What are the membrane structures that function in active transport?

answers.text: glycolipids
peripheral proteins
integral proteins
cholesterol

questions.correct_answer: integral proteins
questions.neutral_comments: Active transport is carried out by proteins. To transport a molecule across a membrane, the protein will need to be in the membrane and will therefore need to be an integral membrane protein.
questions.all_comments: Nice work!Active transport is carried out by proteins.  To transport a molecule across a membrane, the protein will need to be in the membrane and will therefore need to be an integral membrane protein.

questions.question: Why would a doctor inject a dilute salt solution rather than pure water into the bloodstream of a patient who has suffered severe blood loss?

answers.text: Because pure water might cause the patient’s red blood cells to burst.
Because salt will assist in co-transport of needed nutrients into the patient’s cells.
Because salt will help prevent bacterial infections.
Because pure water might cause the patient’s red blood cells to shrink.

questions.correct_answer: Because pure water might cause the patient’s red blood cells to burst.
questions.neutral_comments: Pure water, which by definition contains no solutes, will be hypotonic compared to the solution inside of the patient’s red blood cells, which contain lots of solutes. That means that adding pure water to the patient’s blood stream will cause there to be more water molecules interacting with solute molecules inside of the red blood cells than outside. That in turn means that there will be fewer free water molecules inside of the patient’s red blood cells than outside of them. Water will thus flow into the red blood cells, causing the cells to swell and possibly burst. So, the doctor uses a dilute salt solution to avoid this problem.
questions.all_comments: Nice work!Pure water, which by definition contains no solutes, will be hypotonic compared to the solution inside of the patient’s red blood cells, which contain lots of solutes.  That means that adding pure water to the patient’s blood stream will cause there to be more water molecules interacting with solute molecules inside of the red blood cells than outside.  That in turn means that there will be fewer free water molecules inside of the patient’s red blood cells than outside of them.  Water will thus flow into the red blood cells, causing the cells to swell and possibly burst.  So, the doctor uses a dilute salt solution to avoid this problem.

questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question. The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a selectively permeable barrier. This selectively permeable barrier is permeable to water but not to any ions. If you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of MgCl2 to side “A” and you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of NaCl to side “B”, immediately after adding the solutions to the U-tube,

answers.text: the solution in side “A” will be hypertonic compared with the solution in side “B”
the solution in side “A” will be isotonic compared with the solution in side “B”
there will be more free water molecules on side “A”
the solution in side “A” will be hypotonic compared with the solution in side “B”

questions.correct_answer: the solution in side “A” will be hypertonic compared with the solution in side “B”
questions.neutral_comments: MgCl2 and NaCl are both salts that will dissociate into their constituent ions when they come in contact with water. So, the 1 mole of MgCl2 will dissociate to form 1 mole of Mg++ and 2 moles of Cl- and the 1 mole of NaCl will dissociate to form 1 mole of Na+and 1 mole of Cl-. That means that, immediately after the solutions are added to the two sides of the tube, there will be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B, so side A will be hypertonic compared with side B. The fact that there will be more solute molecules on side A also means that more of the water molecules on side A will be interacting with solute molecules and therefore there will be fewer free water molecules on side A.
questions.all_comments: Nice work!MgCl2 and NaCl are both salts that will dissociate into their constituent ions when they come in contact with water.  So, the 1 mole of MgCl2 will dissociate to form 1 mole of Mg++ and 2 moles of Cl- and the 1 mole of NaCl will dissociate to form 1 mole of Na+and 1 mole of Cl-.  That means that, immediately after the solutions are added to the two sides of the tube, there will be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B, so side A will be hypertonic compared with side B.  The fact that there will be more solute molecules on side A also means that more of the water molecules on side A will be interacting with solute molecules and therefore there will be fewer free water molecules on side A.

questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question. The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a selectively permeable barrier. This selectively permeable barrier is permeable to water, but not to glucose. If you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of glucose to side “A” and you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of glucose to side “B”,

answers.text: there will be no movement of water molecules across the membrane
there will be a net flow of water from side “B” to side “A”
there will be no net flow of water between the two sides of the tube
there will be a net flow of water from side “A” to side “B”

questions.correct_answer: there will be no net flow of water between the two sides of the tube
questions.neutral_comments: In this case, the concentration of glucose is the same on both sides of the tube. So, the concentration of free water molecules is the same on both sides of the tube. Free water molecules will still cross the membrane, but the rate at which free water molecules cross from side A to side B will be equal to the rate at which free water molecules cross from side B to side A. So, free water molecules WILL still cross the membrane, but there will be not NET flow of water between the two sides of the tube.
questions.all_comments: Nice work!In this case, the concentration of glucose is the same on both sides of the tube. So, the concentration of free water molecules is the same on both sides of the tube. Free water molecules will still cross the membrane, but the rate at which free water molecules cross from side A to side B will be equal to the rate at which free water molecules cross from side B to side A. So, free water molecules WILL still cross the membrane, but there will be not NET flow of water between the two sides of the tube.

questions.question: Which of the following membrane activities require energy from ATP hydrolysis?

answers.text: movement of solutes by channel proteins
facilitated diffusion
movement of solutes by co-transporters
proton pumps

questions.correct_answer: proton pumps
questions.all_comments:
Nice work!Channel proteins carry out “facilitated diffusion”. In facilitated diffusion molecules are moving down their concentration and/or electrical gradient, which is a passive process that does not require an energy expenditure.
Co-transporters move two substances simultaneously. One of the substances is moving down its electrochemical gradient and the other substance is moving up its electrochemical gradient. The energy needed to move one of the substances up its electrochemical gradient is provided by the energy released as the second substance moves down its electrochemical gradient rather than by ATP hydrolysis.

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of carrier proteins in a plasma membrane?

answers.text: All carrier proteins require the expenditure of cellular energy to function.
They are peripheral membrane proteins.
They always exhibit specificity for a particular type of molecule.
All carrier proteins work against diffusion.

questions.correct_answer: They always exhibit specificity for a particular type of molecule.
questions.neutral_comments: Some carrier proteins carry out facilitated diffusion. Facilitated diffusion is diffusion of a molecule down its concentration and/or electrical gradient that is “facilitated” by a carrier protein or channel protein that allows the molecule that is diffusing to pass more quickly through the membrane. Because the molecules being transported are moving down their concentration and/or electrical gradient, carrier proteins that act in facilitated diffusion do not require an energy expenditure. However, other carrier proteins, such as symporters and anti-porters, help carry out active transport and so do require an energy expenditure.
questions.all_comments: Nice work!Some carrier proteins carry out facilitated diffusion. Facilitated diffusion is diffusion of a molecule down its concentration and/or electrical gradient that is “facilitated” by a carrier protein or channel protein that allows the molecule that is diffusing to pass more quickly through the membrane. Because the molecules being transported are moving down their concentration and/or electrical gradient, carrier proteins that act in facilitated diffusion do not require an energy expenditure. However, other carrier proteins, such as symporters and anti-porters, help carry out active transport and so do require an energy expenditure.

questions.question: Glucose diffuses slowly through artificial phospholipid bilayers. The cells lining the small intestine, however, rapidly move large quantities of glucose from glucose-rich foods into their glucose-poor cytoplasm. Using this information, which transport mechanism is most probably functioning in the intestinal cells?

answers.text: Active transport pumps
Simple diffusion
Glucoport
Facilitated diffusion

questions.correct_answer: Facilitated diffusion
questions.neutral_comments: The information that glucose diffuses poorly through artificial phospholipid bilayers tells you that glucose will diffuse poorly on its own through cell membranes. Because you are also told that glucose is entering the intestinal cells quickly, this rules out simple diffusion as a possibility. Because glucose is moving down its concentration gradient as it enters the intestinal cells, no energy should be required for its movement which makes active transport of any means in unlikely possibility. “Glucoport” is a made up term, which leaves facilitated diffusion as the most likely possibility. In facilitated diffusion, channel proteins or carrier proteins in the membrane allow specific molecules that do not easily cross membranes on their own to cross membranes rapidly. So, diffusion (which is always a passive process) is “facilitated” by these proteins.
questions.all_comments: Nice job!The information that glucose diffuses poorly through artificial phospholipid bilayers tells you that glucose will diffuse poorly on its own through cell membranes.  Because you are also told that glucose is entering the intestinal cells quickly, this rules out simple diffusion as a possibility.  Because glucose is moving down its concentration gradient as it enters the intestinal cells, no energy should be required for its movement which makes active transport of any means in unlikely possibility.  “Glucoport” is a made up term, which leaves facilitated diffusion as the most likely possibility.  In facilitated diffusion, channel proteins or carrier proteins in the membrane allow specific molecules that do not easily cross membranes on their own to cross membranes rapidly. So, diffusion (which is always a passive process) is “facilitated” by these proteins.

questions.question: When a plant cell is submerged in a very hypotonic solution, what is likely to occur?

questions.neutral_comments: Hypotonic solutions have a lower concentration of solutes. As a result, hypotonic solutions have fewer water molecules interacting with solute molecules and therefore have more free water molecules. Free water molecules will thus diffuse into the plant cell, causing it to expand against the cell wall, making it more solid, or turgid.
questions.all_comments: Nice work!Hypotonic solutions have a lower concentration of solutes.  As a result, hypotonic solutions have fewer water molecules interacting with solute molecules and therefore have more free water molecules.  Free water molecules will thus diffuse into the plant cell, causing it to expand against the cell wall, making it more solid, or turgid.

questions.question: According to the fluid mosaic model of cell membranes, which of the following statements about membrane phospholipids is TRUE?

answers.text: They can move laterally along the plane of the membrane.
They have hydrophilic tails in the interior of the membrane.
They frequently flip-flop from one side of the membrane to the other.
The occur in an uninterrupted bilayer, with membrane proteins restricted to the surface of the membrane.

questions.correct_answer: They can move laterally along the plane of the membrane.
questions.neutral_comments: Membrane phospholipids can move laterally in the plane of the membrane but it is rare for them to flip-flop from one side of the membrane to the other because that would require that their phosphate head group, which is quite hydrophilic, pass through the hydrophobic core of the membrane that is formed by the fatty acid chains of the phospholipids. Membrane proteins occur in a “mosaic” and may be embedded in the membrane (integral membrane proteins) or attached to its surface (peripheral membrane proteins).
questions.all_comments: Nice job!Membrane phospholipids can move laterally in the plane of the membrane but it is rare for them to flip-flop from one side of the membrane to the other because that would require that their phosphate head group, which is quite hydrophilic, pass through the hydrophobic core of the membrane that is formed by the fatty acid chains of the phospholipids.  Membrane proteins occur in a “mosaic” and may be embedded in the membrane (integral membrane proteins) or attached to its surface (peripheral membrane proteins).

questions.question: Why have plants been referred to as “supracellular” organisms?

answers.text: The cell walls surrounding plant cells make them super strong.
Plant cells tend to be larger than animal cells.
The vast majority of the cells in a plant are connected by plasmodesmata, forming a sort of “super cell”
Plant cells are able to carry out photosynthesis.

questions.correct_answer: The vast majority of the cells in a plant are connected by plasmodesmata, forming a sort of “super cell”
questions.neutral_comments: Unicellular organisms are organisms that have only a single cell. Multi-cellular organisms, such as people, are organisms that have multiple cells. Plants have been referred to as “supracellular” organisms because almost all of the cells in a plants are directly connected by pores that run through their cell walls. These pores are called plasmodesmata. Plasmodesmata allow small molecules to diffuse between different cells in a plant without having to cross a plasma membrane. So, most of the cells in a plant can be thought of as being joined together in a giant “super cell”.
questions.all_comments: Unicellular organisms are organisms that have only a single cell.  Multi-cellular organisms, such as people, are organisms that have multiple cells.  Plants have been referred to as “supracellular” organisms because almost all of the cells in a plants are directly connected by pores that run through their cell walls.  These pores are called plasmodesmata.  Plasmodesmata allow small molecules to diffuse between different cells in a plant without having to cross a plasma membrane.  So, most of the cells in a plant can be thought of as being joined together in a giant “super cell”.

questions.question: Cell membranes are asymmetrical. Which of the following is most likely to explain part of the reason for this asymmetry?

answers.text: Cell membranes communicate signals from one cell to another.
Cell membrane proteins are inserted into the rough ER membrane with a certain orientation as they are being synthesized.
Proteins can only span membranes if they are hydrophobic.
The cell membrane forms a border between different cell types.

questions.correct_answer: Cell membrane proteins are inserted into the rough ER membrane with a certain orientation as they are being synthesized.
questions.neutral_comments: Integral membrane proteins are inserted into the membrane of the rough endoplasmic reticulum (ER) as they are being synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough ER. Because many of these proteins have both hydrophobic regions, which are embedded in the membrane, and hydrophilic regions, which are exposed to the aqueous environment inside or outside of the ER, they are not able to move randomly from one side of the membrane to the other after they are made. For example, if a membrane protein is synthesized such that the last part of the protein that is made is hydrophilic and is exposed on the outside of the ER membrane, that part of that protein will remain on the outside of the ER membrane and then on the outside of the vesicle that transports it to the Golgi, on the outside of the Golgi, on the outside of the vesicle that transports it the plasma membrane and then on the inside (cytoplasmic side) of the plasma membrane. It should be noted that the lipid compositions of the two halves of a lipid bilayer are not identical either, as lipid molecules very rarely flip-flop from one side of the bilayer to the other and different species of lipid molecules are synthesized in different amounts in the two halves of the bilayer.
questions.all_comments: Integral membrane proteins are inserted into the membrane of the rough endoplasmic reticulum (ER) as they are being synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough ER.  Because many of these proteins have both hydrophobic regions, which are embedded in the membrane, and hydrophilic regions, which are exposed to the aqueous environment inside or outside of the ER, they are not able to move randomly from one side of the membrane to the other after they are made.  For example, if a membrane protein is synthesized such that the last part of the protein that is made is hydrophilic and is exposed on the outside of the ER membrane, that part of that protein will remain on the outside of the ER membrane and then on the outside of the vesicle that transports it to the Golgi, on the outside of the Golgi, on the outside of the vesicle that transports it the plasma membrane and then on the inside (cytoplasmic side) of the plasma membrane.  It should be noted that the lipid compositions of the two halves of a lipid bilayer are not identical either, as lipid molecules very rarely flip-flop from one side of the bilayer to the other and different species of lipid molecules are synthesized in different amounts in the two halves of the bilayer.

questions.question: Which structure is the site of the synthesis of protein that may be exported from the cell?

answers.text: smooth endoplasmic reticulum
Golgi vesicles
rough endoplasmic reticulum
mitochondrion

questions.correct_answer: rough endoplasmic reticulum
questions.neutral_comments: Secreted proteins are synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough endoplasmic reticulum. Remember that the rough ER gets its name from the fact that it has a “rough” appearance when looked at using a microscope. The reason is has a “rough” appearance is because of the ribosomes that are bound to it. After proteins destined for export are synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough ER, vesicles bud off of the rough endoplasmic reticulum and transport those proteins to the Golgi apparatus where they are modified. Vesicles than bud off of the Golgi apparatus and transport the proteins to the plasma membrane. The vesicles fuse with the plasma membrane, releasing the proteins to the outside of the cell.
questions.all_comments: Secreted proteins are synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough endoplasmic reticulum.  Remember that the rough ER gets its name from the fact that it has a “rough” appearance when looked at using a microscope.  The reason is has a “rough” appearance is because of the ribosomes that are bound to it.  After proteins destined for export are synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough ER, vesicles bud off of the rough endoplasmic reticulum and transport those proteins to the Golgi apparatus where they are modified.  Vesicles than bud off of the Golgi apparatus and transport the proteins to the plasma membrane.  The vesicles fuse with the plasma membrane, releasing the proteins to the outside of the cell.

questions.question: Which of the following membrane activities do NOT require energy from ATP hydrolysis?

answers.text: movement of solutes by channel proteins
all of these answers are correct
movement of solutes by co-transporters
simple diffusion

questions.correct_answer: all of these answers are correct
questions.all_comments:
Channel proteins carry out “facilitated diffusion”. In facilitated diffusion molecules are moving down their concentration and/or electrical gradient, which is a passive process that does not require an energy expenditure.
Co-transporters move two substances simultaneously. One of the substances is moving down its electrochemical gradient and the other substance is moving up its electrochemical gradient. The energy needed to move one of the substances up its electrochemical gradient is provided by the energy released as the second substance moves down its electrochemical gradient rather than by ATP hydrolysis.
“Passive diffusion” is movement of a substance down its concentration gradient without the need for a channel or carrier protein to facilitate movement of the substance. Because the substance is moving down its concentration gradient, no energy source is required for this process to occur.

questions.question: Amphipathic molecules

answers.text: have both hydrophilic and hydrophobic regions
have modified carbohydrates
have both positively charged and negatively charged regions
are only found in membranes

questions.correct_answer: have both hydrophilic and hydrophobic regions
questions.neutral_comments: Amphipathic molecules have both hydrophilic (“water loving”) and hydrophobic (“water fearing”) regions. For example, the hydrocarbon chains of phospholipid molecules are hydrophobic whereas the phosphate and other parts of the head group of phospholipid molecules are hydrophilic, so phospholipid molecules are amphipathic molecules.
questions.all_comments: Amphipathic molecules have both hydrophilic (“water loving”) and hydrophobic (“water fearing”) regions.  For example, the hydrocarbon chains of phospholipid molecules are hydrophobic whereas the phosphate and other parts of the head group of phospholipid molecules are hydrophilic, so phospholipid molecules are amphipathic molecules.

The ability of light microscopes to resolve structures is thus limited by the wavelength of light. You could use a light microscope to view images at really high magnifications, but that wouldn’t be useful because the images would just become more and more blurry as the magnification increased.
