questions.question: A patient had a serious accident and lost a lot of blood. In an attempt to replenish body fluids, distilled water, equal to the volume of blood lost, is transferred directly into one of his veins. What will be the most probable result of this transfusion?

answers.text: The patient’s red blood cells will swell, and possibly burst, because the blood fluid is hypotonic compared to the red blood cells.
The patient’s red blood cells will shrink because the blood fluid is hypotonic compared to the red blood cells.
The patient’s red blood cells will swell, and possibly burst, because the blood fluid is hypertonic compared to the red blood cells.
The patient’s red blood cells will shrink because the blood fluid is hypertonic compared to the red blood cells.

questions.correct_answer: The patient’s red blood cells will swell, and possibly burst, because the blood fluid is hypotonic compared to the red blood cells.
questions.neutral_comments: Pure water, which by definition contains no solutes, will be hypotonic compared to the solution inside of the patient’s red blood cells, which contain lots of solutes. That means that adding pure water to the patient’s blood stream will cause there to be more water molecules interacting with solute molecules inside of the red blood cells than outside. That in turn means that there will be fewer free water molecules inside of the patient’s red blood cells than outside of them. Water will thus flow into the red blood cells, causing the cells to swell and possibly burst.
questions.all_comments: Pure water, which by definition contains no solutes, will be hypotonic compared to the solution inside of the patient’s red blood cells, which contain lots of solutes.  That means that adding pure water to the patient’s blood stream will cause there to be more water molecules interacting with solute molecules inside of the red blood cells than outside.  That in turn means that there will be fewer free water molecules inside of the patient’s red blood cells than outside of them.  Water will thus flow into the red blood cells, causing the cells to swell and possibly burst.

questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question. The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a selectively permeable barrier. This selectively permeable barrier is permeable to water but not to any ions. If you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of MgCl2 to side “A” and you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of NaCl to side “B”, immediately after adding the solutions to the U-tube,

answers.text: the solution in side “A” will be hypertonic compared with the solution in side “B”
there will be more free water molecules on side “A”
the solution in side “A” will be hypotonic compared with the solution in side “B”
the solution in side “A” will be isotonic compared with the solution in side “B”

questions.correct_answer: the solution in side “A” will be hypertonic compared with the solution in side “B”
questions.neutral_comments: MgCl2 and NaCl are both salts that will dissociate into their constituent ions when they come in contact with water. So, the 1 mole of MgCl2 will dissociate to form 1 mole of Mg++ and 2 moles of Cl- and the 1 mole of NaCl will dissociate to form 1 mole of Na+and 1 mole of Cl-. That means that, immediately after the solutions are added to the two sides of the tube, there will be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B, so side A will be hypertonic compared with side B. The fact that there will be more solute molecules on side A also means that more of the water molecules on side A will be interacting with solute molecules and therefore there will be fewer free water molecules on side A.
questions.all_comments: MgCl2 and NaCl are both salts that will dissociate into their constituent ions when they come in contact with water.  So, the 1 mole of MgCl2 will dissociate to form 1 mole of Mg++ and 2 moles of Cl- and the 1 mole of NaCl will dissociate to form 1 mole of Na+and 1 mole of Cl-.  That means that, immediately after the solutions are added to the two sides of the tube, there will be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B, so side A will be hypertonic compared with side B.  The fact that there will be more solute molecules on side A also means that more of the water molecules on side A will be interacting with solute molecules and therefore there will be fewer free water molecules on side A.

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of carrier proteins in a plasma membrane?

answers.text: All carrier proteins work against diffusion.
They always exhibit specificity for a particular type of molecule.
All carrier proteins require the expenditure of cellular energy to function.
They are peripheral membrane proteins.

questions.correct_answer: They always exhibit specificity for a particular type of molecule.
questions.neutral_comments: Some carrier proteins carry out facilitated diffusion. Facilitated diffusion is diffusion of a molecule down its concentration and/or electrical gradient that is “facilitated” by a carrier protein or channel protein that allows the molecule that is diffusing to pass more quickly through the membrane. Because the molecules being transported are moving down their concentration and/or electrical gradient, carrier proteins that act in facilitated diffusion do not require an energy expenditure. However, other carrier proteins, such as symporters and anti-porters, help carry out active transport and so do require an energy expenditure.
questions.all_comments: Some carrier proteins carry out facilitated diffusion. Facilitated diffusion is diffusion of a molecule down its concentration and/or electrical gradient that is “facilitated” by a carrier protein or channel protein that allows the molecule that is diffusing to pass more quickly through the membrane. Because the molecules being transported are moving down their concentration and/or electrical gradient, carrier proteins that act in facilitated diffusion do not require an energy expenditure. However, other carrier proteins, such as symporters and anti-porters, help carry out active transport and so do require an energy expenditure.

Also, remember that lipid molecules can diffuse laterally within 1 face of a membrane, but that it is very rare for a lipid molecule to flip-flop from on ½ (face) of a membrane to the other because for that to happen the hydrophilic part of the lipid molecule (e.g. the phosphate and groups attached to the phosphate of a phospholipid molecule) would need to pass through the hydrophobic core of the membrane.

questions.question: Why have plants been referred to as “supracellular” organisms?

answers.text: The cell walls surrounding plant cells make them super strong.
Plant cells are able to carry out photosynthesis.
The vast majority of the cells in a plant are connected by plasmodesmata, forming a sort of “super cell”
Plant cells tend to be larger than animal cells.

questions.correct_answer: The vast majority of the cells in a plant are connected by plasmodesmata, forming a sort of “super cell”
questions.neutral_comments: Unicellular organisms are organisms that have only a single cell. Multi-cellular organisms, such as people, are organisms that have multiple cells. Plants have been referred to as “supracellular” organisms because almost all of the cells in a plants are directly connected by pores that run through their cell walls. These pores are called plasmodesmata. Plasmodesmata allow small molecules to diffuse between different cells in a plant without having to cross a plasma membrane. So, most of the cells in a plant can be thought of as being joined together in a giant “super cell”.
questions.all_comments: Unicellular organisms are organisms that have only a single cell.  Multi-cellular organisms, such as people, are organisms that have multiple cells.  Plants have been referred to as “supracellular” organisms because almost all of the cells in a plants are directly connected by pores that run through their cell walls.  These pores are called plasmodesmata.  Plasmodesmata allow small molecules to diffuse between different cells in a plant without having to cross a plasma membrane.  So, most of the cells in a plant can be thought of as being joined together in a giant “super cell”.

questions.question: Ions always diffuse across membranes down their

answers.text: concentration gradients
electrochemical gradients
chemical gradients
electrical gradients

questions.correct_answer: electrochemical gradients
questions.neutral_comments: Ions are charged molecules or atoms. They will tend to diffuse down their concentration gradient and down their electrical gradient. For example, a positively charged ion will tend to have a net flow towards the side of the membrane that is more negatively charged. If a positively charged ion is in a higher concentration inside of a cell than outside of the cell, the ion may or may not have a net movement to the outside of the cell because the outsides of cells are positively charged relative to their insides. So, whether a positively charged ion would have a net flow to the outside of a cell would depend on how steep its concentration gradient is relative to how steep its electrical gradient is. The bottom line is that the net movement of an ion is down its electrochemical gradient, which takes into account both the tendency for all substances to move down their concentration gradients along with the tendency for positively charged ions to flow towards the more negatively charged side of a membrane and vice versa.
questions.all_comments: Nice work!Ions are charged molecules or atoms.  They will tend to diffuse down their concentration gradient and down their electrical gradient.  For example, a positively charged ion will tend to have a net flow towards the side of the membrane that is more negatively charged.  If a positively charged ion is in a higher concentration inside of a cell than outside of the cell, the ion may or may not have a net movement to the outside of the cell because the outsides of cells are positively charged relative to their insides.  So, whether a positively charged ion would have a net flow to the outside of a cell would depend on how steep its concentration gradient is relative to how steep its electrical gradient is.  The bottom line is that the net movement of an ion is down its electrochemical gradient, which takes into account both the tendency for all substances to move down their concentration gradients along with the tendency for positively charged ions to flow towards the more negatively charged side of a membrane and vice versa.

questions.question: Glucose diffuses slowly through artificial phospholipid bilayers. The cells lining the small intestine, however, rapidly move large quantities of glucose from glucose-rich foods into their glucose-poor cytoplasm. Using this information, which transport mechanism is most probably functioning in the intestinal cells?

answers.text: Simple diffusion
Glucoport
Facilitated diffusion
Active transport pumps

questions.correct_answer: Facilitated diffusion
questions.neutral_comments: The information that glucose diffuses poorly through artificial phospholipid bilayers tells you that glucose will diffuse poorly on its own through cell membranes. Because you are also told that glucose is entering the intestinal cells quickly, this rules out simple diffusion as a possibility. Because glucose is moving down its concentration gradient as it enters the intestinal cells, no energy should be required for its movement which makes active transport of any means in unlikely possibility. “Glucoport” is a made up term, which leaves facilitated diffusion as the most likely possibility. In facilitated diffusion, channel proteins or carrier proteins in the membrane allow specific molecules that do not easily cross membranes on their own to cross membranes rapidly. So, diffusion (which is always a passive process) is “facilitated” by these proteins.
questions.all_comments: Nice job!The information that glucose diffuses poorly through artificial phospholipid bilayers tells you that glucose will diffuse poorly on its own through cell membranes.  Because you are also told that glucose is entering the intestinal cells quickly, this rules out simple diffusion as a possibility.  Because glucose is moving down its concentration gradient as it enters the intestinal cells, no energy should be required for its movement which makes active transport of any means in unlikely possibility.  “Glucoport” is a made up term, which leaves facilitated diffusion as the most likely possibility.  In facilitated diffusion, channel proteins or carrier proteins in the membrane allow specific molecules that do not easily cross membranes on their own to cross membranes rapidly. So, diffusion (which is always a passive process) is “facilitated” by these proteins.

questions.question: The presence of cholesterol in the plasma membranes of some animals

answers.text: acts in transport of water molecules across the phopholipid bilayer
enables the animal to add hydrogen atoms to unsaturated phospholipids.
enables the animal to remove hydrogen atoms from saturated phospholipids.
enables the membrane to stay fluid more easily when cell temperature drops.

questions.correct_answer: enables the membrane to stay fluid more easily when cell temperature drops.
questions.neutral_comments: The effects of cholesterol on membrane fluidity are somewhat complicated. At normal body temperatures (i.e. about 98.6°F), cholesterol interacts with phospholipid molecules, restricting their movement and thereby making the membranes less fluid. However, as the temperature drops, cholesterol molecules interfere with the tight packing of the hydrocarbon chains of the phospholipid molecules, making the membranes more fluid (i.e. decreasing the temperature at which membranes lose a lot of their fluidity and so become less functional).
questions.all_comments: Nice job!The effects of cholesterol on membrane fluidity are somewhat complicated. At normal body temperatures (i.e. about 98.6°F), cholesterol interacts with phospholipid molecules, restricting their movement and thereby making the membranes less fluid. However, as the temperature drops, cholesterol molecules interfere with the tight packing of the hydrocarbon chains of the phospholipid molecules, making the membranes more fluid (i.e. decreasing the temperature at which membranes lose a lot of their fluidity and so become less functional).

questions.neutral_comments: Lipids that are on the inside face of the ER membrane will end up on the inside face of the membrane of vesicles that bud off of the ER, than on the inside face of the Golgi apparatus membrane, then on the inside face of the membrane of vesicles that bud off of the Golgi apparatus and then on the extracellular face of the plasma membrane after the vesicle fuses with the plasma membrane (see figure below, paying special attention to the orientation of the small, green carbohydrates that are attached to the protein molecules in the rough ER to help you keep track of the orientation of membrane components). Also, remember that lipid molecules can diffuse laterally within 1 face of a membrane, but that it is very rare for a lipid molecule to flip-flop from on ½ (face) of a membrane to the other because for that to happen the hydrophilic part of the lipid molecule (e.g. the phosphate and groups attached to the phosphate of a phospholipid molecule) would need to pass through the hydrophobic core of the membrane.

questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question. The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a selectively permeable barrier. This selectively permeable barrier is permeable to water but not to any ions. If you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of MgCl2 to side “A” and you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of NaCl to side “B”, at equilibrium

answers.text: there will have been a net flow of water from side “B” to side “A”
there will have been a net flow of water from side “A” to side “B”
there will have been no movement of water molecules across the membrane
there will have been no net flow of water between the two sides of the tube

questions.correct_answer: there will have been a net flow of water from side “B” to side “A”
questions.neutral_comments: MgCl2 and NaCl are both salts that will dissociate into their constituent ions when they come in contact with water. So, the 1 mole of MgCl2 will dissociate to form 1 mole of Mg++ and 2 moles of Cl- and the 1 mole of NaCl will dissociate to form 1 mole of Na+and 1 mole of Cl-. That means that, immediately after the solutions are added to the two sides of the tube, there will be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B. As a result, more water molecules will be interacting with solute molecules on side A and there will therefore be a lower concentration of free water molecules on side A than on side B. That, in turn, means there will be a net flow of water molecules from side B to side A, until equilibrium is reached.
questions.all_comments: MgCl2 and NaCl are both salts that will dissociate into their constituent ions when they come in contact with water.  So, the 1 mole of MgCl2 will dissociate to form 1 mole of Mg++ and 2 moles of Cl- and the 1 mole of NaCl will dissociate to form 1 mole of Na+and 1 mole of Cl-.  That means that, immediately after the solutions are added to the two sides of the tube, there will be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B.  As a result, more water molecules will be interacting with solute molecules on side A and there will therefore be a lower concentration of free water molecules on side A than on side B.  That, in turn, means there will be a net flow of water molecules from side B to side A, until equilibrium is reached.

questions.question: Which of the following is one of the ways that the membranes of winter wheat are able to remain fluid when it is extremely cold?

answers.text: by decreasing the number of hydrophobic proteins in the membrane
by increasing the percentage of cholesterol molecules in the membrane
by increasing the percentage of unsaturated phospholipids in the membrane

questions.correct_answer: by increasing the percentage of unsaturated phospholipids in the membrane
questions.neutral_comments: Increasing the percentage of unsaturated phospholipids make membranes more fluid, even at lower temperatures, by inhibiting close packing of the fatty acid chains of the molecules, thus disrupting hydrophobic interactions between the molecules. Cholesterol does lower the freezing temperatures of membranes in animal cells, but is not found in plant cells. The percentage of hydrophobic proteins in the membrane has little or no effect on the temperature at which the membrane will freeze.
questions.all_comments: Increasing the percentage of unsaturated phospholipids make membranes more fluid, even at lower temperatures, by inhibiting close packing of the fatty acid chains of the molecules, thus disrupting hydrophobic interactions between the molecules.  Cholesterol does lower the freezing temperatures of membranes in animal cells, but is not found in plant cells.  The percentage of hydrophobic proteins in the membrane has little or no effect on the temperature at which the membrane will freeze.

questions.question: Ions always diffuse across membranes down their

answers.text: chemical gradients
electrochemical gradients
electrical gradients
concentration gradients

questions.correct_answer: electrochemical gradients
questions.neutral_comments: Ions are charged molecules or atoms. They will tend to diffuse down their concentration gradient and down their electrical gradient. For example, a positively charged ion will tend to have a net flow towards the side of the membrane that is more negatively charged. If a positively charged ion is in a higher concentration inside of a cell than outside of the cell, the ion may or may not have a net movement to the outside of the cell because the outsides of cells are positively charged relative to their insides. So, whether a positively charged ion would have a net flow to the outside of a cell would depend on how steep its concentration gradient is relative to how steep its electrical gradient is. The bottom line is that the net movement of an ion is down its electrochemical gradient, which takes into account both the tendency for all substances to move down their concentration gradients along with the tendency for positively charged ions to flow towards the more negatively charged side of a membrane and vice versa.
questions.all_comments: It is possible for an ion to diffuse up its electrical gradient if, at the same time, it is diffusing down an even stronger concentration (chemical) gradient.Ions are charged molecules or atoms.  They will tend to diffuse down their concentration gradient and down their electrical gradient.  For example, a positively charged ion will tend to have a net flow towards the side of the membrane that is more negatively charged.  If a positively charged ion is in a higher concentration inside of a cell than outside of the cell, the ion may or may not have a net movement to the outside of the cell because the outsides of cells are positively charged relative to their insides.  So, whether a positively charged ion would have a net flow to the outside of a cell would depend on how steep its concentration gradient is relative to how steep its electrical gradient is.  The bottom line is that the net movement of an ion is down its electrochemical gradient, which takes into account both the tendency for all substances to move down their concentration gradients along with the tendency for positively charged ions to flow towards the more negatively charged side of a membrane and vice versa.

questions.question: A chemical reaction that has a positive ∆G is correctly described as

answers.text: endergonic
exergonic
none of these answers are correct
spontaneous

questions.correct_answer: endergonic
questions.neutral_comments: Reactions that have a positive ∆G (i.e. reactions where the total free energy of the reactants is less than the total free energy of the products) are known as endergonic reactions. Reactions that have a negative ∆G are known as exergonic or spontaneous reactions.
questions.all_comments: Reactions that have a positive ∆G (i.e. reactions where the total free energy of the reactants is less than the total free energy of the products) are known as endergonic reactions.  Reactions that have a negative ∆G are known as exergonic or spontaneous reactions.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is representative of the second law of thermodynamics?

answers.text: Conversion of energy from one form to another is always accompanied by some gain of free energy.
Cells require a constant input of energy to maintain their high level of organization.
Every energy transformation by a cell decreases the entropy of the universe.
Without an input of energy, organisms would tend toward decreasing entropy.

questions.correct_answer: Cells require a constant input of energy to maintain their high level of organization.
questions.neutral_comments: According to the 2nd law of thermodynamics the entropy of the universe as a whole is always increasing. Living organisms, such as cells, are able to use energy inputs to maintain a high level of order, and thus a low level of entropy. However, by doing this living organisms cause an increase in the entropy of their surroundings that more than compensates for the decrease in entropy within the organism. So, the total amount of entropy within the universe increases and the 2ndlaw of thermodynamics is not violated.
questions.all_comments: According to the 2nd law of thermodynamics the entropy of the universe as a whole is always increasing.  Living organisms, such as cells, are able to use energy inputs to maintain a high level of order, and thus a low level of entropy.  However, by doing this living organisms cause an increase in the entropy of their surroundings that more than compensates for the decrease in entropy within the organism.  So, the total amount of entropy within the universe increases and the 2ndlaw of thermodynamics is not violated.

questions.question: The mathematical expression for the change in the free energy of a system is ∆G = ∆H – T∆S. Which of the following is (are) TRUE?

answers.text: ∆S is the change in entropy.
∆H is the change in free energy.
T is the temperature in degrees Celsius.
∆G is the change in enthalpy.

questions.correct_answer: ∆S is the change in entropy.
questions.neutral_comments: ∆G = the change in the Gibb’s free energy of the system. ∆H = the change in the enthalpy of the system. T = the temperature of the system in degrees Kelvin (zero degrees Kelvin = -273 °C. Zero degrees Kelvin corresponds to the theoretical temperature at which entropy reaches a minimum). ∆S = the change in the entropy of the system.
questions.all_comments: ∆G = the change in the Gibb’s free energy of the system.  ∆H = the change in the enthalpy of the system.  T = the temperature of the system in degrees Kelvin (zero degrees Kelvin = -273 °C.  Zero degrees Kelvin corresponds to the theoretical temperature at which entropy reaches a minimum).  ∆S = the change in the entropy of the system.

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE for all exergonic reactions in open systems (e.g. a cell)?

answers.text: The products have less free energy than the reactants
The products have less entropy than the reactants
The products have less total energy than the reactants
The products have more entropy than the reactants

questions.correct_answer: The products have less free energy than the reactants
questions.neutral_comments: By definition, exergonic reactions are reactions that result in a decrease in free energy. Regarding entropy, remember that in an open system, depending on the reaction that occurs, the entropy of the SYSTEM may increase or decrease. However, also remember that, according to the 2nd law of thermodynamics, the entropy of the universe as a whole must always increase. So, if the entropy of the system decreases, that must be balanced by an even greater magnitude increase in the entropy of the rest of the universe.
questions.all_comments: By definition, exergonic reactions are reactions that result in a decrease in free energy. Regarding entropy, remember that in an open system, depending on the reaction that occurs, the entropy of the SYSTEM may increase or decrease. However, also remember that, according to the 2nd law of thermodynamics, the entropy of the universe as a whole must always increase. So, if the entropy of the system decreases, that must be balanced by an even greater magnitude increase in the entropy of the rest of the universe.

the difference between the potential energy in the bonds of ATP and the water molecule, minus the potential energy in the bonds of ADP and Pi. questions.all_comments: Nice work!

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE for all endergonic reactions in open systems (e.g. a cell)?

answers.text: The products have more total energy than the reactants
The products have more free energy than the reactants
The products have less free energy than the reactants
The products have less total energy than the reactants

questions.correct_answer: The products have more free energy than the reactants
questions.neutral_comments: The definition of an endergonic reaction is a reaction where there is an increase in FREE energy. So, in an endergonic reaction the products of the reaction will have more FREE energy than the reactants used in the reaction. The fact that a reaction is an "endergonic" reaction does NOT tell you what the change in TOTAL energy, as opposed to FREE energy, will be.
questions.all_comments: The definition of an endergonic reaction is a reaction where there is an increase in FREE energy.  So, in an endergonic reaction the products of the reaction will have more FREE energy than the reactants used in the reaction.  The fact that a reaction is an "endergonic" reaction does NOT tell you what the change in TOTAL energy, as opposed to FREE energy, will be.

questions.question: How do living organisms create macromolecules, organelles, cells, tissues, and complex higher-order structures?

Living organisms create order by using energy from the sun.

questions.correct_answer: Living organisms create order locally, but the energy transformations generate waste heat that increases the entropy of the universe as a whole.
questions.neutral_comments: The 2nd law of thermodynamics states that the entropy of the universe as a whole must increase. If the entropy of a cell decreases, that decrease can be made up for by an even greater increase in the entropy of the environment around the cell, so that the total amount of entropy in the universe increases.
questions.all_comments: The 2nd law of thermodynamics states that the entropy of the universe as a whole must increase.  If the entropy of a cell decreases, that decrease can be made up for by an even greater increase in the entropy of the environment around the cell, so that the total amount of entropy in the universe increases.

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE for ALL exergonic reactions?

answers.text: If the reaction proceeds there will be a net decrease in free energy.
A net input of energy from the surroundings is required for the reactions to proceed.
The reactions are nonspontaneous.
The products have more total energy than the reactants.

questions.correct_answer: If the reaction proceeds there will be a net decrease in free energy.
questions.neutral_comments: By definition, exergonic reactions are reactions where the reaction results in a decrease in free energy. In contrast, it is possible for an exergonic reaction to result in an increase in the TOTAL energy of the system. For that to occur, the increase in the total energy of the system must be more than offset by an increase in entropy. Because exergonic reactions are reactions that result in a decrease in free energy, there is no need for an energy input in order for an exergonic reaction to occur.
questions.all_comments: By definition, exergonic reactions are reactions where the reaction results in a decrease in free energy.  In contrast, it is possible for an exergonic reaction to result in an increase in the TOTAL energy of the system.  For that to occur, the increase in the total energy of the system must be more than offset by an increase in entropy. Because exergonic reactions are reactions that result in a decrease in free energy, there is no need for an energy input in order for an exergonic reaction to occur.

questions.question: Many of the reactions that occur during metabolism are reversible. Given the laws of thermodynamics, how is that possible?

answers.text: Even in the same solution, some of the molecules of a particular species may have more energy than others.
These reactions are reversible in theory, but proceed in only one direction so that the laws of thermodynamics are not violated.
The free energy of the system will decrease when the reaction proceeds in one direction, but the total energy of the system will decrease when the reaction proceeds in the other direction.
Energy is used to drive a reversible reaction in one of the two possible directions.

questions.correct_answer: Even in the same solution, some of the molecules of a particular species may have more energy than others.
questions.neutral_comments: For a reaction to be a spontaneous reaction, the free energy of the reactant molecules must be greater than the free energy of the product molecules, so that free energy decreases as a result of the reaction. So, if you imagine a reaction where “A” is converted to “B”, the conversion of a molecule of A to a molecule of B will be spontaneous if the free energy of molecule A is greater than the free energy of molecule B. So, if on average A molecules have a free energy of 5 kcal/mole and B molecules have a free energy of 4.9 kcal/mole, the average free energy of a molecule of A will be greater than the average free energy of a molecule of B and therefore the conversion of an average molecule of A to an average molecule of B will represent an exergonic, or spontaneous, reaction. However, what we have to realize is that different molecules of A in a solution will have slightly different free energies and different molecules of B will have slightly free different energies. So, if the AVERAGE free energy of a molecule of B is 4.9 kcal/mole, there may be some molecules of B that have a free energy of greater than 5 kcal/mole. Those molecules of B that have a free energy that is greater than 5 kcal/mole can then be converted to molecules of A via a reaction that will be exergonic (spontaneous). Note that this does NOT mean that the conversion of B to A will occur at as high a rate as the conversion of A to B. If there are only a very small number of molecules of B that have a high enough free energy level to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction, the rate of conversion of A to B will be higher than the rate of conversion of B to A. Eventually, the high rate of conversion of A to B will result in there being enough molecules of B with sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction that the rate of conversion of B to A will equal the rate of conversion of A to B. At that point, the reaction will have reached equilibrium and both reactions will occur at the same rate (note that, in this example, at equilibrium there will be more molecules of B than of A, but a smaller percentage of the molecules of B will have sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction). In addition, there is a tendency for reactions to be reversible because there is greater entropy in a mixture of substances than in a pure substance. In other words, a system that contains a mixture of "A" and "B" molecules will have greater entropy than a system that has just "A" or just "B" molecules.
questions.all_comments: For a reaction to be a spontaneous reaction, the free energy of the reactant molecules must be greater than the free energy of the product molecules, so that free energy decreases as a result of the reaction.  So, if you imagine a reaction where “A” is converted to “B”, the conversion of a molecule of A to a molecule of B will be spontaneous if the free energy of molecule A is greater than the free energy of molecule B.  So, if on average A molecules have a free energy of 5 kcal/mole and B molecules have a free energy of 4.9 kcal/mole, the average free energy of a molecule of A will be greater than the average free energy of a molecule of B and therefore the conversion of an average molecule of A to an average molecule of B will represent an exergonic, or spontaneous, reaction.  However, what we have to realize is that different molecules of A in a solution will have slightly different free energies and different molecules of B will have slightly free different energies.  So, if the AVERAGE free energy of a molecule of B is 4.9 kcal/mole, there may be some molecules of B that have a free energy of greater than 5 kcal/mole.  Those molecules of B that have a free energy that is greater than 5 kcal/mole can then be converted to molecules of A via a reaction that will be exergonic (spontaneous).  Note that this does NOT mean that the conversion of B to A will occur at as high a rate as the conversion of A to B.  If there are only a very small number of molecules of B that have a high enough free energy level to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction, the rate of conversion of A to B will be higher than the rate of conversion of B to A.  Eventually, the high rate of conversion of A to B will result in there being enough reaction will have reached equilibrium and both reactions will occur at the same rate (note that, in this example, at equilibrium there will be more molecules of B than of A, but a smaller percentage of the molecules of B will have sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction).  In addition, there is a tendency for reactions to be reversible because there is greater entropy in a mixture of substances than in a pure substance.  In other words, a system that contains a mixture of "A" and "B" molecules will have greater entropy than a system that has just "A" or just "B" molecules.

questions.neutral_comments: At equilibrium, the free energy change is zero and no work can be done. So, a cell where most reactions are at equilibrium would not be able to do enough work and so would be dead. Also, the "products" of reversible reactions are frequently converted to other substances or transported to other cellular compartments before they can be metabolized via the reverse reaction, which also prevents many cellular reactions from reaching equilibrium.
questions.all_comments: At equilibrium, the free energy change is zero and no work can be done.  So, a cell where most reactions are at equilibrium would not be able to do enough work and so would be dead.  Also, the "products" of reversible reactions are frequently converted to other substances or transported to other cellular compartments before they can be metabolized via the reverse reaction, which also prevents many cellular reactions from reaching equilibrium.

questions.question: Many of the reactions that occur during metabolism are reversible. Given the laws of thermodynamics, how is that possible?

answers.text: Energy is used to drive a reversible reaction in one of the two possible directions.
These reactions are reversible in theory, but proceed in only one direction so that the laws of thermodynamics are not violated.
Even in the same solution, some of the molecules of a particular species may have more energy than others.
The free energy of the system will decrease when the reaction proceeds in one direction, but the total energy of the system will decrease when the reaction proceeds in the other direction.

questions.correct_answer: Even in the same solution, some of the molecules of a particular species may have more energy than others.
questions.neutral_comments: For a reaction to be a spontaneous reaction, the free energy of the reactant molecules must be greater than the free energy of the product molecules, so that free energy decreases as a result of the reaction. So, if you imagine a reaction where “A” is converted to “B”, the conversion of a molecule of A to a molecule of B will be spontaneous if the free energy of molecule A is greater than the free energy of molecule B. So, if on average A molecules have a free energy of 5 kcal/mole and B molecules have a free energy of 4.9 kcal/mole, the average free energy of a molecule of A will be greater than the average free energy of a molecule of B and therefore the conversion of an average molecule of A to an average molecule of B will represent an exergonic, or spontaneous, reaction. However, what we have to realize is that different molecules of A in a solution will have slightly different free energies and different molecules of B will have slightly free different energies. So, if the AVERAGE free energy of a molecule of B is 4.9 kcal/mole, there may be some molecules of B that have a free energy of greater than 5 kcal/mole. Those molecules of B that have a free energy that is greater than 5 kcal/mole can then be converted to molecules of A via a reaction that will be exergonic (spontaneous). Note that this does NOT mean that the conversion of B to A will occur at as high a rate as the conversion of A to B. If there are only a very small number of molecules of B that have a high enough free energy level to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction, the rate of conversion of A to B will be higher than the rate of conversion of B to A. Eventually, the high rate of conversion of A to B will result in there being enough molecules of B with sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction that the rate of conversion of B to A will equal the rate of conversion of A to B. At that point, the reaction will have reached equilibrium and both reactions will occur at the same rate (note that, in this example, at equilibrium there will be more molecules of B than of A, but a smaller percentage of the molecules of B will have sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction). In addition, there is a tendency for reactions to be reversible because there is greater entropy in a mixture of substances than in a pure substance. In other words, a system that contains a mixture of "A" and "B" molecules will have greater entropy than a system that has just "A" or just "B" molecules.
questions.all_comments: For a reaction to be a spontaneous reaction, the free energy of the reactant molecules must be greater than the free energy of the product molecules, so that free energy decreases as a result of the reaction.  So, if you imagine a reaction where “A” is converted to “B”, the conversion of a molecule of A to a molecule of B will be spontaneous if the free energy of of B to A will occur at as high a rate as the conversion of A to B.  If there are only a very small number of molecules of B that have a high enough free energy level to be converted to A via an entropy in a mixture of substances than in a pure substance.  In other words, a system that contains a mixture of "A" and "B" molecules will have greater entropy than a system that has just "A" or just "B" molecules.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is representative of the second law of thermodynamics?

answers.text: Without an input of energy, organisms would tend toward decreasing entropy.
Every energy transformation by a cell decreases the entropy of the universe.
Conversion of energy from one form to another is always accompanied by some gain of free energy.
Cells require a constant input of energy to maintain their high level of organization.

questions.correct_answer: Cells require a constant input of energy to maintain their high level of organization.
questions.neutral_comments: According to the 2nd law of thermodynamics the entropy of the universe as a whole is always increasing. Living organisms, such as cells, are able to use energy inputs to maintain a high level of order, and thus a low level of entropy. However, by doing this living organisms cause an increase in the entropy of their surroundings that more than compensates for the decrease in entropy within the organism. So, the total amount of entropy within the universe increases and the 2ndlaw of thermodynamics is not violated.
questions.all_comments: According to the 2nd law of thermodynamics the entropy of the universe as a whole is always increasing.  Living organisms, such as cells, are able to use energy inputs to maintain a high level of order, and thus a low level of entropy.  However, by doing this living organisms cause an increase in the entropy of their surroundings that more than compensates for the decrease in entropy within the organism.  So, the total amount of entropy within the universe increases and the 2ndlaw of thermodynamics is not violated.

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE for all endergonic reactions in open systems (e.g. a cell)?

answers.text: The products have more total energy than the reactants
The products have less free energy than the reactants
The products have less total energy than the reactants
The products have more free energy than the reactants

questions.correct_answer: The products have more free energy than the reactants
questions.neutral_comments: The definition of an endergonic reaction is a reaction where there is an increase in FREE energy. So, in an endergonic reaction the products of the reaction will have more FREE energy than the reactants used in the reaction. The fact that a reaction is an "endergonic" reaction does NOT tell you what the change in TOTAL energy, as opposed to FREE energy, will be.
questions.all_comments: The definition of an endergonic reaction is a reaction where there is an increase in FREE energy.  So, in an endergonic reaction the products of the reaction will have more FREE energy than the reactants used in the reaction.  The fact that a reaction is an "endergonic" reaction does NOT tell you what the change in TOTAL energy, as opposed to FREE energy, will be.

questions.question: The total energy of a biological system is represented by

answers.text: temperature (T)
free energy (G)
entropy (S)
enthalpy (H)

questions.correct_answer: enthalpy (H)

questions.question: Living organisms don’t violate the 2<sup>nd</sup> law of thermodynamics because:

answers.text: They increase the free energy of their surroundings
They typically increase the entropy of their surroundings
Trick question, living organisms do violate the 2nd law of thermodynamics!
They typically increase their own entropy

questions.correct_answer: They typically increase the entropy of their surroundings
questions.neutral_comments: The entropy of a biological system can decrease (and very often does decrease) without violating the 2nd law of thermodynamics, as long as the decrease in the entropy of the system is balanced by an even greater magnitude increase in the entropy of the rest of the universe.
questions.all_comments: The entropy of a biological system can decrease (and very often does decrease) without violating the 2nd law of thermodynamics, as long as the decrease in the entropy of the system is balanced by an even greater magnitude increase in the entropy of the rest of the universe.

questions.question: What is the term for metabolic pathways that release stored energy by breaking down complex molecules?

answers.text: catabolic pathways
anabolic pathways
thermodynamic pathways
bioenergetic pathways

questions.correct_answer: catabolic pathways
questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic pathways are pathways where complex, energy-rich molecules are broken down (think of a “cat” tearing something up) to smaller, less complex and less energy-rich molecules. Anabolism is the opposite. In other words, in anabolism larger, more complex and energy-rich molecules are formed from smaller, less complex and energy-rich molecules.
questions.all_comments: Catabolic pathways are pathways where complex, energy-rich molecules are broken down (think of a “cat” tearing something up) to smaller, less complex and less energy-rich molecules.  Anabolism is the opposite.  In other words, in anabolism larger, more complex and energy-rich molecules are formed from smaller, less complex and energy-rich molecules.

questions.question: Spontaneous reactions

answers.text: do not require an energy input to occur
always occur, and do not require an energy input
always proceed rapidly
all of these answers are correct

questions.correct_answer: do not require an energy input to occur
questions.neutral_comments: Spontaneous reactions are defined as reactions that do not require an energy input to occur. However, it is critical to realize that the word “spontaneous” is used in a different way when discussing chemical reactions than when discussing every day life. So a “spontaneous” chemical reaction may proceed very slowly or not at all, if the activation energy barrier for the reaction is high.
questions.all_comments: Spontaneous reactions are defined as reactions that do not require an energy input to occur.  However, it is critical to realize that the word “spontaneous” is used in a different way when discussing chemical reactions than when discussing every day life.  So a “spontaneous” chemical reaction may proceed very slowly or not at all, if the activation energy barrier for the reaction is high.

questions.question: Why is ATP an important molecule in metabolism?

answers.text: It helps drive exergonic reactions.
All of these answers are correct.
It is formed by endergonic reactions.
It provides energy coupling between exergonic and endergonic reactions.

questions.correct_answer: It provides energy coupling between exergonic and endergonic reactions.

questions.question: The breakdown of polymers to their constituent monomers occurs during

answers.text: anabolism
condensation reactions
dehydration reactions
catabolism

questions.correct_answer: catabolism
questions.neutral_comments: The breakdown of polymers (and other large biological molecules) occurs during catabolism. Anabolism refers to the part of metabolism where larger, more complex molecules are synthesized from smaller, less complex molecules. Many anabolic reactions occur via dehydration reactions, which are one type of dehydration reaction.
questions.all_comments: The breakdown of polymers (and other large biological molecules) occurs during catabolism.  Anabolism refers to the part of metabolism where larger, more complex molecules are synthesized from smaller, less complex molecules.  Many anabolic reactions occur via dehydration reactions, which are one type of dehydration reaction.

has three phosphate groups.

is a high energy molecule due to having unstable covalent bonds

questions.question: Most cells cannot harness heat to perform work because

answers.text: heat can never be used to do work.
heat is not a form of energy.
cells do not have much heat; they are relatively cool.
temperature is usually uniform throughout a cell.

questions.correct_answer: temperature is usually uniform throughout a cell.
questions.neutral_comments: Heat can only be used to perform work where there is a temperature differential. For example, using heat to cause the air in a piston to expand, allowing the piston to do work, only works if the temperature of the air inside the piston is greater than the temperature of the air outside of the piston. Because the temperature across a cell is generally fairly uniform, cells cannot typically use heat to perform work.
questions.all_comments: Heat can only be used to perform work where there is a temperature differential.  For example, using heat to cause the air in a piston to expand, allowing the piston to do work, only works if the temperature of the air inside the piston is greater than the temperature of the air outside of the piston.  Because the temperature across a cell is generally fairly uniform, cells cannot typically use heat to perform work.

questions.question: The synthesis of polymers from their constituent monomers occurs during

answers.text: catabolism
all of these answers are correct
anabolism
hydrolysis

questions.correct_answer: anabolism
questions.neutral_comments: Anabolism refers to the part of metabolism where larger, more complex molecules are synthesized from smaller, less complex molecules. In contrast, the breakdown of polymers (and other large biological molecules) occurs during catabolism. The breakdown of polymers during catabolism often occurs via hydrolysis (“splitting with water”) reactions. Remember a cat tearing up an object to help remember that catalysis is breaking up large molecules to form smaller ones and anabolism is the opposite.
questions.all_comments: Anabolism refers to the part of metabolism where larger, more complex  molecules are synthesized from smaller, less complex molecules. In contrast, the breakdown of polymers (and other large biological molecules) occurs during catabolism. The breakdown of polymers during catabolism often occurs via hydrolysis (“splitting with water”) reactions.  Remember a cat tearing up an object to help remember that catalysis is breaking up large molecules to form smaller ones and anabolism is the opposite.

questions.question: Choose the pair of terms that correctly completes this sentence: Catabolism is to anabolism as ________ is to ________.

entropy; enthalpy

exergonic; spontaneous

questions.correct_answer: exergonic; endergonic

Anabolic reactions are endergonic reactions where small molecules are combined to form larger molecules that have a greater amount of free energy than the reactant molecules.
questions.all_comments: Catabolic reactions are exergonic reactions where large molecules are broken down to smaller molecules that have less free energy than the reactant molecule.  Anabolic reactions are endergonic reactions where small molecules are combined to form larger molecules that have a greater amount of free energy than the reactant molecules.

questions.question: Which term precisely describes the cellular process of breaking down large molecules into smaller ones?

answers.text: catalysis
catabolism
anabolism
metabolism

questions.all_comments: Catabolism is the breaking down of large molecules (think of a “cat”, for “catabolism”, tearing something up).  Anabolism is the cellular process by which large molecules are formed.  Metabolism refers to both catabolism and anabolism.

questions.question: In a particular metabolic pathway, “A” is converted to “B” which is converted to “C”. Which of the following is likely to be TRUE about catalysis of the steps in this pathway?

answers.text: It is not possible to know without more information about “A”, “B” and “C”.
Each step in the pathway will likely be catalyzed by the same enzyme.
Some steps in the pathway may be catalyzed by the same enzyme and some steps may be catalyzed by different enzymes.
Each step in the pathway will likely be catalyzed by a different enzyme.

questions.correct_answer: Each step in the pathway will likely be catalyzed by a different enzyme.
questions.neutral_comments: Different steps in a metabolic pathway are almost always catalyzed by different enzymes. This is because enzymes are very specific for the substrates they will recognize and the reaction they will catalyze using that substrate.

questions.question: Which of the following types of reactions would decrease the entropy of a cell?

answers.text: respiration
catabolism
dehydration reactions
hydrolysis

questions.correct_answer: dehydration reactions
questions.neutral_comments: Reactions, such as dehydration reactions, that result in the formation of one large molecule from multiple small molecules create more order and therefore less entropy. Reactions that break down a large molecule to more than one small molecule (e.g. hydrolysis reactions, respiration, catabolism) create less order in the system and therefore greater entropy.
questions.all_comments: Reactions, such as dehydration reactions, that result in the formation of one large molecule from multiple small molecules create more order and therefore less entropy.  Reactions that break down a large molecule to more than one small molecule (e.g. hydrolysis reactions, respiration, catabolism) create less order in the system and therefore greater entropy.

T is the temperature in degrees Celsius.
∆H is the change in free energy.
∆S is the change in entropy.

questions.correct_answer: ∆S is the change in entropy.

Zero degrees Kelvin corresponds to the theoretical temperature at which entropy reaches a minimum). ∆S = the change in the entropy of the system.

Hydrolysis of ATP to form ADP and inorganic phosphate is a highly exergonic reaction
Hydrolysis of ATP to form ADP and inorganic phosphate is a highly endergonic reaction
