molecules of B with sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction that the rate of conversion of B to A will equal the rate of conversion of A to B.  At that point, the reaction will have reached equilibrium and both reactions will occur at the same rate (note that, in this example, at equilibrium there will be more molecules of B than of A, but a smaller percentage of the molecules of B will have sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction).

questions.question: If most metabolic reactions are reversible, why is equilibrium rarely reached for these reactions?

answers.text: The enzymes that catalyze these reactions drive the reactions more in one direction than in the other.
Most of the products of the reactions are removed from the system.
Because living organisms increase the entropy of the universe.
The activation energy barrier for the reaction is lower in one direction than in the other.

questions.correct_answer: Most of the products of the reactions are removed from the system.
questions.all_comments: Good job!

questions.question: Energy that goes to increase the entropy of the universe is

answers.text: lost forever
no longer available to perform work
all of these answers are correct
stored as potential energy

questions.correct_answer: no longer available to perform work
questions.neutral_comments: According to the 1st law of thermodynamics, energy can be transferred or transformed but can not be created or destroyed. So, energy that is used to increase the entropy of the universe is not lost. However, that energy is no longer available to perform work.
questions.all_comments: According to the 1st law of thermodynamics, energy can be transferred or transformed but can not be created or destroyed.  So, energy that is used to increase the entropy of the universe is not lost.  However, that energy is no longer available to perform work.

questions.question: A consequence of the fact that Gibb’s free energy must decrease in a spontaneous reaction is

answers.text: that all reactions may proceed in only one direction unless there is an input of energy into the system to drive the reaction in the other direction.
that all reactions may proceed in only one direction unless ATP is added to the system.
that all reactions may proceed spontaneously in only one direction.
that a given reaction may proceed spontaneously in both directions, due to the fact that different reactant and product molecules will have slightly different energies.

questions.correct_answer: that a given reaction may proceed spontaneously in both directions, due to the fact that different reactant and product molecules will have slightly different energies.
questions.neutral_comments: For a reaction to be a spontaneous reaction, the free energy of the reactant molecules must be greater than the free energy of the product molecules, so that free energy decreases as a result of the reaction. So, if you imagine a reaction where “A” is converted to “B”, the conversion of a molecule of A to a molecule of B will be spontaneous if the free energy of molecule A is greater than the free energy of molecule B. So, if on average A molecules have a free energy of 5 kcal/mole and B molecules have a free energy of 4.9 kcal/mole, the average free energy of a molecule of A will be greater than the average free energy of a molecule of B and therefore the conversion of an average molecule of A to an average molecule of B will represent an exergonic, or spontaneous, reaction. However, what we have to realize is that different molecules of A in a solution will have slightly different free energies and different molecules of B will have slightly free different energies. So, if the AVERAGE free energy of a molecule of B is 4.9 kcal/mole, there may be some molecules of B that have a free energy of greater than 5 kcal/mole. Those molecules of B that have a free energy that is greater than 5 kcal/mole can then be converted to molecules of A via a reaction that will be exergonic (spontaneous). Note that this does NOT mean that the conversion of B to A will occur at as high a rate as the conversion of A to B. If there are only a very small number of molecules of B that have a high enough free energy level to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction, the rate of conversion of A to B will be higher than the rate of conversion of B to A. Eventually, the high rate of conversion of A to B will result in there being enough molecules of B with sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction that the rate of conversion of B to A will equal the rate of conversion of A to B. At that point, the reaction will have reached equilibrium and both reactions will occur at the same rate (note that, in this example, at equilibrium there will be more molecules of B than of A, but a smaller percentage of the molecules of B will have sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction).
questions.all_comments: For a reaction to be a spontaneous reaction, the free energy of the reactant molecules must be greater than the free energy of the product molecules, so that free energy decreases as a result of the reaction.  So, if you imagine a reaction where “A” is converted to “B”, the conversion of a molecule of A to a molecule of B will be spontaneous if the free energy of molecule A is greater than the free energy of molecule B.  So, if on average A molecules have a free energy of 5 kcal/mole and B molecules have a free energy of 4.9 kcal/mole, the average free energy of a molecule of A will be greater than the average free energy of a molecule of B and therefore the conversion of an average molecule of A to an average molecule of B will represent an exergonic, or spontaneous, reaction.  However, what we have to realize is that different molecules of A in a solution will have slightly different free energies and different molecules of B will have slightly free different energies.  So, if the AVERAGE free energy of a molecule of B is 4.9 kcal/mole, there may be some molecules of B that have a free energy of greater than 5 kcal/mole.  Those molecules of B that have a free energy that is greater than 5 kcal/mole can then be converted to molecules of A via a reaction that will be exergonic (spontaneous).  Note that this does NOT mean that the conversion of B to A will occur at as high a rate as the conversion of A to B.  If there are only a very small number of molecules of B that have a high enough free energy level to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction, the rate of conversion of A to B will be higher than the rate of conversion of B to A.  Eventually, the high rate of conversion of A to B will result in there being enough molecules of B with sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction that the rate of conversion of B to A will equal the rate of conversion of A to B.  At that point, the reaction will have reached equilibrium and both reactions will occur at the same rate (note that, in this example, at equilibrium there will be more molecules of B than of A, but a smaller percentage of the molecules of B will have sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction).

questions.question: The mathematical expression for the change in the free energy of a system is ∆G = ∆H – T∆S. Which of the following is (are) TRUE?

answers.text: ∆G is the change in entropy.
∆S is the change in free energy.
∆H is the change in enthalpy.
T is the temperature in degrees Celsius.

questions.correct_answer: ∆H is the change in enthalpy.
questions.neutral_comments: ∆G = the change in the Gibb’s free energy of the system. ∆H = the change in the enthalpy of the system. T = the temperature of the system in degrees Kelvin (zero degrees Kelvin = -273 °C. Zero degrees Kelvin corresponds to the theoretical temperature at which entropy reaches a minimum). ∆S = the change in the entropy of the system.
questions.all_comments: ∆G = the change in the Gibb’s free energy of the system.  ∆H = the change in the enthalpy of the system.  T = the temperature of the system in degrees Kelvin (zero degrees Kelvin = -273 °C.  Zero degrees Kelvin corresponds to the theoretical temperature at which entropy reaches a minimum).  ∆S = the change in the entropy of the system.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of potential rather than kinetic energy?

answers.text: an increase in air temperature as a meteor passes through the atmosphere
water flowing in a river
a food molecule
a hockey puck hitting the boards

questions.correct_answer: a food molecule
questions.neutral_comments: Kinetic energy is energy due to movement whereas potential energy is energy that is stored in matter that is not due to movement. So, a food molecule has potential energy as a result of the energy stored in the chemical bonds holding together the atoms that form that molecule.
questions.all_comments: Kinetic energy is energy due to movement whereas potential energy is energy that is stored in matter that is not due to movement.  So, a food molecule has potential energy as a result of the energy stored in the chemical bonds holding together the atoms that form that molecule.

questions.question: “Every energy transfer or transformation increases the entropy of the universe”

answers.text: is a statement of the first law of thermodynamics
is true, except for living organisms
is a statement of the third law of thermodynamics
is a statement of the second law of thermodynamics

questions.correct_answer: is a statement of the second law of thermodynamics
questions.all_comments: Nice work!

questions.question: Which of the following is (are) TRUE for anabolic pathways?

answers.text: They consume energy to build up polymers from monomers.
They are usually highly spontaneous chemical reactions.
They release energy as they degrade polymers to monomers.
They do not depend on enzymes.

questions.correct_answer: They consume energy to build up polymers from monomers.
questions.all_comments: Nice job!

questions.question: Whenever energy is transformed, there is always an increase in the

answers.text: Free energy of the universe
Entropy of the universe
Free energy of the system
Entropy of the system

questions.correct_answer: Entropy of the universe
questions.neutral_comments: According to the 2nd law of thermodynamics: “Every energy transfer or transformation increases the entropy of the universe”. So, the entropy of the universe as a whole is always increasing.
questions.all_comments: According to the 2nd law of thermodynamics:  “Every energy transfer or transformation increases the entropy of the universe”.  So, the entropy of the universe as a whole is always increasing.

questions.question: If I try to hit a hockey puck, but miss and hit the ice instead, isn’t that a violation of the first law of thermodynamics because my stick is no longer moving and neither is the puck?

answers.text: A hockey game is a closed system. The first law of thermodynamics applies to the universe as a whole.
No, because the kinetic energy from the motion of my stick will have been transferred/transformed into increased heat energy in the ice.
None of these answers are correct.
This is a trick question since, of course, I NEVER miss the puck!

questions.correct_answer: No, because the kinetic energy from the motion of my stick will have been transferred/transformed into increased heat energy in the ice.
questions.all_comments: Good job!

questions.question: Entropy

answers.text: is a measure of the total energy of a biological system
is a measure of the total energy of a system
is a measure of the energy in a system that is available to do work
is a measure of disorder or randomness

questions.correct_answer: is a measure of disorder or randomness
questions.all_comments: Good job!

questions.question: “Conservation of energy” is another way of stating

answers.text: the third law of thermodynamics
the first law of thermodynamics
the second law of thermodynamics
that the universe expends as little energy as possible in carrying out fundamental processes

questions.correct_answer: the first law of thermodynamics
questions.all_comments: Good job!

questions.question: Which of the following most accurately describe kinetic and potential energy?

answers.text: potential energy includes energy from molecular movement
kinetic energy includes the energy in a stretched rubber band
kinetic energy includes energy from the attraction of the earth to the moon
kinetic energy is due to movement and potential energy is energy that is stored in matter that is not due to movement

questions.correct_answer: kinetic energy is due to movement and potential energy is energy that is stored in matter that is not due to movement
questions.all_comments: Good job!

questions.question: The ATP used by the cell for energy coupling

answers.text: is identical to one of the four nucleotides used for RNA synthesis.
has three phosphate groups.
is a high energy molecule due to having unstable covalent bonds
All of these answers are correct.

questions.correct_answer: All of these answers are correct.
questions.all_comments: Good job!

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of potential rather than kinetic energy?

answers.text: water flowing in a river
a food molecule
a hockey puck hitting the boards
an increase in air temperature as a meteor passes through the atmosphere

questions.correct_answer: a food molecule
questions.neutral_comments: Kinetic energy is energy due to movement whereas potential energy is energy that is stored in matter that is not due to movement. So, a food molecule has potential energy as a result of the energy stored in the chemical bonds holding together the atoms that form that molecule.
questions.all_comments: Kinetic energy is energy due to movement whereas potential energy is energy that is stored in matter that is not due to movement.  So, a food molecule has potential energy as a result of the energy stored in the chemical bonds holding together the atoms that form that molecule.

questions.question: Which of the following statements concerning catabolic pathways is TRUE?

answers.text: They are usually coupled with anabolic pathways to which they supply energy in the form of ATP.
They are spontaneous and do not need enzyme catalysis.
They combine molecules into more energy-rich foods.
They are endergonic.

questions.correct_answer: They are usually coupled with anabolic pathways to which they supply energy in the form of ATP.
questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic pathways are metabolic pathways that result in the breakdown of large biological molecules to simpler molecules. As a result, they increase the entropy of the system. They are also exergonic reactions as the reactant molecules (i.e. the large biological molecules) have greater amounts of free energy than the product molecules (i.e. the smaller molecules that are formed by breaking down the large molecules). Reactions that result in a decrease in free energy are known as exergonic, or “spontaneous”, reactions. Please remember that the fact that a reaction is a “spontaneous” reaction does NOT mean that reaction will occur at a high rate. In fact, the reaction may not occur at all, depending on the height of the activation energy barrier.
questions.all_comments: Catabolic pathways are metabolic pathways that result in the breakdown of large biological molecules to simpler molecules.  As a result, they increase the entropy of the system.  They are also exergonic reactions as the reactant molecules (i.e. the large biological molecules) have greater amounts of free energy than the product molecules (i.e. the smaller molecules that are formed by breaking down the large molecules).  Reactions that result in a decrease in free energy are known as exergonic, or “spontaneous”, reactions.   Please remember that the fact that a reaction is a “spontaneous” reaction does NOT mean that reaction will occur at a high rate.  In fact, the reaction may not occur at all, depending on the height of the activation energy barrier.

questions.question: Which of the following is a statement of the first law of thermodynamics?

answers.text: The entropy of the universe is increasing.
Energy cannot be created or destroyed
The entropy of the universe is constant.
The entropy of the universe is decreasing

questions.correct_answer: Energy cannot be created or destroyed
questions.all_comments: Nice job!

questions.question: A reaction has a ∆G of -5.6 kcal/mol. Which of the following would most likely be TRUE?

answers.text: The reaction would result in an increase in entropy (S) and a decrease in the energy content (H) of the system.
The reaction would result in products with a greater free energy content than in the initial reactants.
The reaction could be coupled to power an endergonic reaction with a ∆G of +8.8 kcal/mol.
The reaction would result in a decrease in entropy (S) and an increase in the energy content (H) of the system.

questions.correct_answer: The reaction would result in an increase in entropy (S) and a decrease in the energy content (H) of the system.
questions.neutral_comments: ∆G = ∆H – T∆S. If ∆G is a negative number, the products of the reaction must have a lower free energy content than the initial reactants. Also, in order for ∆G to be negative, it is not possible for ∆H to be positive and ∆S to be negative. The energy released by a reaction can only be used to power a reaction that requires an amount of energy to occur that is less than the amount of energy being released.
questions.all_comments: ∆G = ∆H – T∆S.  If ∆G is a negative number, the products of the reaction must have a lower free energy content than the initial reactants.  Also, in order for ∆G to be negative, it is not possible for ∆H to be positive and ∆S to be negative.  The energy released by a reaction can only be used to power a reaction that requires an amount of energy to occur that is less than the amount of energy being released.

questions.question: At zero degrees Kelvin, in theory,

answers.text: all of these answers are correct
water will be frozen
entropy will reach a minimum value
you will be frozen

questions.correct_answer: all of these answers are correct
questions.neutral_comments: 0 degrees Kelvin is known as “absolute zero”. It corresponds to the theoretical temperature at which entropy reaches its minimum value. (In classical theory it was considered the temperature at which molecular motion ceases, but we now know that’s not accurate). 0 degrees Kelvin = -273° C, so both water and you would definitely be frozen solid at that temperature!
questions.all_comments: 0 degrees Kelvin is known as “absolute zero”.  It corresponds to the theoretical temperature at which entropy reaches its minimum value.  (In classical theory it was considered the temperature at which molecular motion ceases, but we now know that’s not accurate).  0 degrees Kelvin = -273° C, so both water and you would definitely be frozen solid at that temperature!

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE for all endergonic reactions in open systems (e.g. a cell)?

answers.text: The products have less total energy than the reactants
The products have more total energy than the reactants
The products have less free energy than the reactants
The products have more free energy than the reactants

questions.correct_answer: The products have more free energy than the reactants
questions.neutral_comments: The definition of an endergonic reaction is a reaction where there is an increase in FREE energy. So, in an endergonic reaction the products of the reaction will have more FREE energy than the reactants used in the reaction. The fact that a reaction is an "endergonic" reaction does NOT tell you what the change in TOTAL energy, as opposed to FREE energy, will be.
questions.all_comments: The definition of an endergonic reaction is a reaction where there is an increase in FREE energy.  So, in an endergonic reaction the products of the reaction will have more FREE energy than the reactants used in the reaction.  The fact that a reaction is an "endergonic" reaction does NOT tell you what the change in TOTAL energy, as opposed to FREE energy, will be.

questions.question: In a particular metabolic pathway, “A” is converted to “B” which is converted to “C”. Which of the following is likely to be TRUE about catalysis of the steps in this pathway?

answers.text: Some steps in the pathway may be catalyzed by the same enzyme and some steps may be catalyzed by different enzymes.
It is not possible to know without more information about “A”, “B” and “C”.
Each step in the pathway will likely be catalyzed by the same enzyme.
Each step in the pathway will likely be catalyzed by a different enzyme.

questions.correct_answer: Each step in the pathway will likely be catalyzed by a different enzyme.
questions.neutral_comments: Different steps in a metabolic pathway are almost always catalyzed by different enzymes. This is because enzymes are very specific for the substrates they will recognize and the reaction they will catalyze using that substrate.
questions.all_comments: Different steps in a metabolic pathway are almost always catalyzed by different enzymes.  This is because enzymes are very specific for the substrates they will recognize and the reaction they will catalyze using that substrate.

questions.question: Choose the pair of terms that correctly completes this sentence: Catabolism is to anabolism as ________ is to ________.

answers.text: entropy; enthalpy
exergonic; spontaneous
free energy; entropy
exergonic; endergonic

questions.correct_answer: exergonic; endergonic
questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic reactions are exergonic reactions where large molecules are broken down to smaller molecules that have less free energy than the reactant molecule. Anabolic reactions are endergonic reactions where small molecules are combined to form larger molecules that have a greater amount of free energy than the reactant molecules.
questions.all_comments: Catabolic reactions are exergonic reactions where large molecules are broken down to smaller molecules that have less free energy than the reactant molecule.  Anabolic reactions are endergonic reactions where small molecules are combined to form larger molecules that have a greater amount of free energy than the reactant molecules.

questions.question: Which of the following is considered an open system?

answers.text: food cooking in a pressure cooker
a sealed terrarium
liquid in a corked bottle
an organism

questions.correct_answer: an organism
questions.neutral_comments: An open system is a system where energy and matter can enter and leave the system. That is true of an organism, but not of the other choices.
questions.all_comments: An open system is a system where energy and matter can enter and leave the system.  That is true of an organism, but not of the other choices.

questions.question: Most cells cannot harness heat to perform work because

answers.text: heat can never be used to do work.
heat is not a form of energy.
cells do not have much heat; they are relatively cool.
temperature is usually uniform throughout a cell.

questions.correct_answer: temperature is usually uniform throughout a cell.
questions.neutral_comments: Heat can only be used to perform work where there is a temperature differential. For example, using heat to cause the air in a piston to expand, allowing the piston to do work, only works if the temperature of the air inside the piston is greater than the temperature of the air outside of the piston. Because the temperature across a cell is generally fairly uniform, cells cannot typically use heat to perform work.
questions.all_comments: Heat can only be used to perform work where there is a temperature differential.  For example, using heat to cause the air in a piston to expand, allowing the piston to do work, only works if the temperature of the air inside the piston is greater than the temperature of the air outside of the piston.  Because the temperature across a cell is generally fairly uniform, cells cannot typically use heat to perform work.

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE for all exergonic reactions in open systems (e.g. a cell)?

answers.text: The products have more entropy than the reactants
The products have less free energy than the reactants
The products have less entropy than the reactants
The products have less total energy than the reactants

questions.correct_answer: The products have less free energy than the reactants
questions.neutral_comments: By definition, exergonic reactions are reactions that result in a decrease in free energy. Regarding entropy, remember that in an open system, depending on the reaction that occurs, the entropy of the SYSTEM may increase or decrease. However, also remember that, according to the 2nd law of thermodynamics, the entropy of the universe as a whole must always increase. So, if the entropy of the system decreases, that must be balanced by an even greater magnitude increase in the entropy of the rest of the universe.
questions.all_comments: By definition, exergonic reactions are reactions that result in a decrease in free energy. Regarding entropy, remember that in an open system, depending on the reaction that occurs, the entropy of the SYSTEM may increase or decrease. However, also remember that, according to the 2nd law of thermodynamics, the entropy of the universe as a whole must always increase. So, if the entropy of the system decreases, that must be balanced by an even greater magnitude increase in the entropy of the rest of the universe.

answers.text: T is the temperature in degrees Celsius.
∆S is the change in free energy.
∆H is the change in enthalpy.
∆G is the change in entropy.

questions.correct_answer: ∆H is the change in enthalpy.
questions.neutral_comments: ∆G = the change in the Gibb’s free energy of the system. ∆H = the change in the enthalpy of the system. T = the temperature of the system in degrees Kelvin (zero degrees Kelvin = -273 °C. Zero degrees Kelvin corresponds to the theoretical temperature at which entropy reaches a minimum). ∆S = the change in the entropy of the system.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about biological systems is FALSE?

answers.text: The entropy of a biological system can decrease
The total energy in a biological system cannot increase or decrease
The total energy in a biological system can increase
The total energy in a biological system can decrease

questions.correct_answer: The total energy in a biological system cannot increase or decrease
questions.neutral_comments: Because biological systems are open systems (i.e. they are systems where energy and matter can enter and leave the system), the total energy in a cell may increase or decrease. Similarly, the entropy of a biological system can decrease (and very often does decrease), as long as the decrease in the entropy of the system is balanced by an even greater magnitude increase in the entropy of the rest of the universe.
questions.all_comments: Because biological systems are open systems (i.e. they are systems where energy and matter can enter and leave the system), the total energy in a cell may increase or decrease.  Similarly, the entropy of a biological system can decrease (and very often does decrease), as long as the decrease in the entropy of the system is balanced by an even greater magnitude increase in the entropy of the rest of the universe.

The reaction would result in a decrease in entropy (S) and an increase in the energy content (H) of the system.
The reaction would result in products with a greater free energy content than in the initial reactants.
The reaction could be coupled to power an endergonic reaction with a ∆G of +8.8 kcal/mol.

The energy released by a reaction can only be used to power a reaction that requires an amount of energy to occur that is less than the amount of energy being released.

questions.question: Are most chemical reactions at equilibrium in living cells?

answers.text: yes
no
most reactions, except those powered by ATP
only the exergonic reactions

questions.correct_answer: no
questions.neutral_comments: At equilibrium, the free energy change is zero and no work can be done. So, a cell where most reactions are at equilibrium would not be able to do enough work and so would be dead. Also, the "products" of reversible reactions are frequently converted to other substances or transported to other cellular compartments before they can be metabolized via the reverse reaction, which also prevents many cellular reactions from reaching equilibrium.
questions.all_comments: At equilibrium, the free energy change is zero and no work can be done.  So, a cell where most reactions are at equilibrium would not be able to do enough work and so would be dead.  Also, the "products" of reversible reactions are frequently converted to other substances or transported to other cellular compartments before they can be metabolized via the reverse reaction, which also prevents many cellular reactions from reaching equilibrium.

answers.text: is a statement of the first law of thermodynamics
is true for closed and open systems, but not for the universe as a whole
is a statement of the second law of thermodynamics
is a statement of the third law of thermodynamics

decreases as a result of the reaction.  So, if you imagine a reaction where “A” is converted to “B”, the conversion of a molecule of A to a molecule of B will be spontaneous if the free energy of molecule A is greater than the free energy of molecule B.  So, if on average A molecules have a free energy of 5 kcal/mole and B molecules have a free energy of 4.9 kcal/mole, the average free energy of a molecule of A will be greater than the average free energy of a molecule of B and therefore the conversion of an average molecule of A to an average molecule of B will represent an exergonic, or spontaneous, reaction.  However, what we have to realize is that different molecules of A in a solution will have slightly different free energies and different molecules of B will have slightly free different energies.  So, if the AVERAGE free energy of a molecule of B is 4.9 kcal/mole, there may be some molecules of B that have a free energy of greater than 5 kcal/mole.  Those molecules of B that have a free energy that is greater than 5 kcal/mole can then be converted to molecules of A via a reaction that will be exergonic (spontaneous).  Note that this does NOT mean that the conversion of B to A will occur at as high a rate as the conversion of A to B.  If there are only a very small number of molecules of B that have a high enough free energy level to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction, the rate of conversion of A to B will be higher than the rate of conversion of B to A.  Eventually, the high rate of conversion of A to B will result in there being enough molecules of B with sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction that the rate of conversion of B to A will equal the rate of conversion of A to B.  At that point, the reaction will have reached equilibrium and both reactions will occur at the same rate (note that, in this example, at equilibrium there will be more molecules of B than of A, but a smaller percentage of the molecules of B will have sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction).

questions.question: Which of the following is (are) TRUE for anabolic pathways?

answers.text: They release energy as they degrade polymers to monomers.
They do not depend on enzymes.
They consume energy to build up polymers from monomers.
They are usually highly spontaneous chemical reactions.

questions.correct_answer: They consume energy to build up polymers from monomers.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of potential rather than kinetic energy?

answers.text: an increase in air temperature as a meteor passes through the atmosphere
a hockey puck hitting the boards
water flowing in a river
a food molecule

questions.correct_answer: a food molecule
questions.neutral_comments: Kinetic energy is energy due to movement whereas potential energy is energy that is stored in matter that is not due to movement. So, a food molecule has potential energy as a result of the energy stored in the chemical bonds holding together the atoms that form that molecule.
questions.all_comments: Kinetic energy is energy due to movement whereas potential energy is energy that is stored in matter that is not due to movement.  So, a food molecule has potential energy as a result of the energy stored in the chemical bonds holding together the atoms that form that molecule.

questions.question: The amount of energy in a system that is available to do work is represented by

answers.text: temperature (T)
enthalpy (H)
free energy (G)
entropy (S)

questions.correct_answer: free energy (G)

questions.question: Which of the following statements is representative of the second law of thermodynamics?

answers.text: Conversion of energy from one form to another is always accompanied by some gain of free energy.
Without an input of energy, organisms would tend toward decreasing entropy.
Every energy transformation by a cell decreases the entropy of the universe.
Cells require a constant input of energy to maintain their high level of organization.

questions.correct_answer: Cells require a constant input of energy to maintain their high level of organization.
questions.neutral_comments: According to the 2nd law of thermodynamics the entropy of the universe as a whole is always increasing. Living organisms, such as cells, are able to use energy inputs to maintain a high level of order, and thus a low level of entropy. However, by doing this living organisms cause an increase in the entropy of their surroundings that more than compensates for the decrease in entropy within the organism. So, the total amount of entropy within the universe increases and the 2ndlaw of thermodynamics is not violated.
questions.all_comments: According to the 2nd law of thermodynamics the entropy of the universe as a whole is always increasing.  Living organisms, such as cells, are able to use energy inputs to maintain a high level of order, and thus a low level of entropy.  However, by doing this living organisms cause an increase in the entropy of their surroundings that more than compensates for the decrease in entropy within the organism.  So, the total amount of entropy within the universe increases and the 2ndlaw of thermodynamics is not violated.

questions.question: If I try to hit a hockey puck, but miss and hit the ice instead, isn’t that a violation of the first law of thermodynamics because my stick is no longer moving and neither is the puck?

answers.text: This is a trick question since, of course, I NEVER miss the puck!
A hockey game is a closed system. The first law of thermodynamics applies to the universe as a whole.
None of these answers are correct.
No, because the kinetic energy from the motion of my stick will have been transferred/transformed into increased heat energy in the ice.

questions.correct_answer: No, because the kinetic energy from the motion of my stick will have been transferred/transformed into increased heat energy in the ice.

questions.question: Which of the following is most similar in structure to ATP?

answers.text: an anabolic steroid
a DNA helix
an amino acid with three phosphate groups attached
an RNA nucleotide

questions.correct_answer: an RNA nucleotide
questions.neutral_comments: The ATP molecules used in energy coupling are identical in structure to the ATP molecules used in RNA synthesis. It consists of a sugar (ribose), a nitrogenous base (adenine) and three phosphate groups.
questions.all_comments: The ATP molecules used in energy coupling are identical in structure to the ATP molecules used in RNA synthesis.  It consists of a sugar (ribose), a nitrogenous base (adenine) and  three phosphate groups.

questions.question: Choose the pair of terms that correctly completes this sentence: Catabolism is to anabolism as ________ is to ________.

answers.text: free energy; entropy

exergonic; spontaneous
exergonic; endergonic

questions.correct_answer: exergonic; endergonic
questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic reactions are exergonic reactions where large molecules are broken down to smaller molecules that have less free energy than the reactant molecule. Anabolic reactions are endergonic reactions where small molecules are combined to form larger molecules that have a greater amount of free energy than the reactant molecules.
questions.all_comments: Catabolic reactions are exergonic reactions where large molecules are broken down to smaller molecules that have less free energy than the reactant molecule.  Anabolic reactions are endergonic reactions where small molecules are combined to form larger molecules that have a greater amount of free energy than the reactant molecules.

is true for closed and open systems, but not for the universe as a whole
is a statement of the second law of thermodynamics
is a statement of the third law of thermodynamics

questions.question: Which of the following types of reactions would decrease the entropy of a cell?

answers.text: respiration
dehydration reactions
catabolism
hydrolysis

questions.correct_answer: dehydration reactions
questions.neutral_comments: Reactions, such as dehydration reactions, that result in the formation of one large molecule from multiple small molecules create more order and therefore less entropy. Reactions that break down a large molecule to more than one small molecule (e.g. hydrolysis reactions, respiration, catabolism) create less order in the system and therefore greater entropy.
questions.all_comments: Reactions, such as dehydration reactions, that result in the formation of one large molecule from multiple small molecules create more order and therefore less entropy.  Reactions that break down a large molecule to more than one small molecule (e.g. hydrolysis reactions, respiration, catabolism) create less order in the system and therefore greater entropy.

questions.question: In a particular metabolic pathway, “A” is converted to “B” which is converted to “C”. Which of the following is likely to be TRUE about catalysis of the steps in this pathway?

answers.text: Each step in the pathway will likely be catalyzed by a different enzyme.
Some steps in the pathway may be catalyzed by the same enzyme and some steps may be catalyzed by different enzymes.
Each step in the pathway will likely be catalyzed by the same enzyme.
It is not possible to know without more information about “A”, “B” and “C”.

questions.correct_answer: Each step in the pathway will likely be catalyzed by a different enzyme.
questions.neutral_comments: Different steps in a metabolic pathway are almost always catalyzed by different enzymes. This is because enzymes are very specific for the substrates they will recognize and the reaction they will catalyze using that substrate.
questions.all_comments: Different steps in a metabolic pathway are almost always catalyzed by different enzymes.  This is because enzymes are very specific for the substrates they will recognize and the reaction they will catalyze using that substrate.

Every energy transfer or transformation increases the free energy of the universe
Every energy transfer or transformation increases the enthalpy of the universe
Energy cannot be created or destroyed

that all reactions may proceed in only one direction unless ATP is added to the system.
that all reactions may proceed in only one direction unless there is an input of energy into the system to drive the reaction in the other direction.
that all reactions may proceed spontaneously in only one direction.

Those molecules of B that have a free energy that is greater than 5 kcal/mole can then be converted to molecules of A via a reaction that will be exergonic (spontaneous). Note that this does NOT mean that the conversion of B to A will occur at as high a rate as the conversion of A to B. If there are only a very small number of molecules of B that have a high enough free energy level to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction, the rate of conversion of A to B will be higher than the rate of conversion of B to A. Eventually, the high rate of conversion of A to B will result in there being enough molecules of B with sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction that the rate of conversion of B to A will equal the rate of conversion of A to B. At that point, the reaction will have reached equilibrium and both reactions will occur at the same rate (note that, in this example, at equilibrium there will be more molecules of B than of A, but a smaller percentage of the molecules of B will have sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction).

of a molecule of A will be greater than the average free energy of a molecule of B and therefore the conversion of an average molecule of A to an average molecule of B will represent an exergonic, or spontaneous, reaction.  However, what we have to realize is that different molecules of A in a solution will have slightly different free energies and different molecules of B will have slightly free different energies.  So, if the AVERAGE free energy of a molecule of B is 4.9 kcal/mole, there may be some molecules of B that have a free energy of greater than 5 kcal/mole.  Those molecules of B molecules of B with sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction that the rate of conversion of B to A will equal the rate of conversion of A to B.  At that point, the reaction will have reached equilibrium and both reactions will occur at the same rate (note that, in this example, at equilibrium there will be more molecules of B than of A, but a smaller percentage questions.question: What is the term for metabolic pathways that release stored energy by breaking down complex molecules?

answers.text: anabolic pathways
catabolic pathways
bioenergetic pathways
thermodynamic pathways

questions.correct_answer: catabolic pathways
questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic pathways are pathways where complex, energy-rich molecules are broken down (think of a “cat” tearing something up) to smaller, less complex and less energy-rich molecules. Anabolism is the opposite. In other words, in anabolism larger, more complex and energy-rich molecules are formed from smaller, less complex and energy-rich molecules.
questions.all_comments: Catabolic pathways are pathways where complex, energy-rich molecules are broken down (think of a “cat” tearing something up) to smaller, less complex and less energy-rich molecules.  Anabolism is the opposite.  In other words, in anabolism larger, more complex and energy-rich molecules are formed from smaller, less complex and energy-rich molecules.

questions.question: The rate of flow of materials through a metabolic pathway can be altered by

answers.text: all of these answers are correct
altering the amount of substrate for the reaction
changing the activity level(s) of one or more of the enzymes that catalyze steps in that pathway.
altering the amount of product for the reaction

questions.correct_answer: all of these answers are correct

questions.question: The ATP used by the cell for energy coupling

answers.text: All of these answers are correct.
has three phosphate groups.
is identical to one of the four nucleotides used for RNA synthesis.
is a high energy molecule due to having unstable covalent bonds

questions.correct_answer: All of these answers are correct.

questions.question: Which of the following is a statement of the first law of thermodynamics?

answers.text: Energy cannot be created or destroyed
The entropy of the universe is increasing.
The entropy of the universe is decreasing
The entropy of the universe is constant.

questions.correct_answer: Energy cannot be created or destroyed

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE for all endergonic reactions in open systems (e.g. a cell)?

answers.text: The products have more total energy than the reactants
The products have less free energy than the reactants
The products have less total energy than the reactants
The products have more free energy than the reactants

questions.correct_answer: The products have more free energy than the reactants
questions.neutral_comments: The definition of an endergonic reaction is a reaction where there is an increase in FREE energy. So, in an endergonic reaction the products of the reaction will have more FREE energy than the reactants used in the reaction. The fact that a reaction is an "endergonic" reaction does NOT tell you what the change in TOTAL energy, as opposed to FREE energy, will be.
questions.all_comments: The definition of an endergonic reaction is a reaction where there is an increase in FREE energy.  So, in an endergonic reaction the products of the reaction will have more FREE energy than the reactants used in the reaction.  The fact that a reaction is an "endergonic" reaction does NOT tell you what the change in TOTAL energy, as opposed to FREE energy, will be.

questions.question: Why is ATP an important molecule in metabolism?

answers.text: It provides energy coupling between exergonic and endergonic reactions.
It is formed by endergonic reactions.
It helps drive exergonic reactions.
All of these answers are correct.

questions.correct_answer: It provides energy coupling between exergonic and endergonic reactions.

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE for ALL exergonic reactions?

answers.text: If the reaction proceeds there will be a net decrease in free energy.
The products have more total energy than the reactants.
The reactions are nonspontaneous.
A net input of energy from the surroundings is required for the reactions to proceed.

questions.correct_answer: If the reaction proceeds there will be a net decrease in free energy.
questions.neutral_comments: By definition, exergonic reactions are reactions where the reaction results in a decrease in free energy. In contrast, it is possible for an exergonic reaction to result in an increase in the TOTAL energy of the system. For that to occur, the increase in the total energy of the system must be more than offset by an increase in entropy. Because exergonic reactions are reactions that result in a decrease in free energy, there is no need for an energy input in order for an exergonic reaction to occur.
questions.all_comments: By definition, exergonic reactions are reactions where the reaction results in a decrease in free energy.  In contrast, it is possible for an exergonic reaction to result in an increase in the TOTAL energy of the system.  For that to occur, the increase in the total energy of the system must be more than offset by an increase in entropy. Because exergonic reactions are reactions that result in a decrease in free energy, there is no need for an energy input in order for an exergonic reaction to occur.

questions.question: When chemical, transport or mechanical work is done by an organism, what happens to the heat generated?

answers.text: It is lost to the environment.
It is used to power yet more cellular work.
It is used to store more energy as ATP.
It is transported to specific organs such as the brain.

questions.correct_answer: It is lost to the environment.

questions.question: Choose the pair of terms that correctly completes this sentence: Catabolism is to anabolism as ________ is to ________.

answers.text: exergonic; spontaneous
entropy; enthalpy
free energy; entropy

questions.correct_answer: exergonic; endergonic
questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic reactions are exergonic reactions where large molecules are broken down to smaller molecules that have less free energy than the reactant molecule. Anabolic reactions are endergonic reactions where small molecules are combined to form larger molecules that have a greater amount of free energy than the reactant molecules.
questions.all_comments: Catabolic reactions are exergonic reactions where large molecules are broken down to smaller molecules that have less free energy than the reactant molecule.  Anabolic reactions are endergonic reactions where small molecules are combined to form larger molecules that have a greater amount of free energy than the reactant molecules.

questions.question: Which term precisely describes the cellular process of breaking down large molecules into smaller ones?

answers.text: catalysis
catabolism
metabolism
anabolism

questions.correct_answer: catabolism
questions.neutral_comments: Catabolism is the breaking down of large molecules (think of a “cat”, for “catabolism”, tearing something up). Anabolism is the cellular process by which large molecules are formed. Metabolism refers to both catabolism and anabolism.
questions.all_comments: Catabolism is the breaking down of large molecules (think of a “cat”, for “catabolism”, tearing something up).  Anabolism is the cellular process by which large molecules are formed.  Metabolism refers to both catabolism and anabolism.

questions.all_comments: The ATP molecules used in energy coupling are identical in structure to the ATP molecules used in RNA synthesis.  It consists of a sugar (ribose), a nitrogenous base (adenine) and  three phosphate groups.

questions.question: The rate of flow of materials through a metabolic pathway can be altered by

questions.question: A reaction has a ∆G of -5.6 kcal/mol. Which of the following would most likely be TRUE?

answers.text: The reaction could be coupled to power an endergonic reaction with a ∆G of +8.8 kcal/mol.
The reaction would result in a decrease in entropy (S) and an increase in the energy content (H) of the system.
The reaction would result in products with a greater free energy content than in the initial reactants.
The reaction would result in an increase in entropy (S) and a decrease in the energy content (H) of the system.

questions.correct_answer: The reaction would result in an increase in entropy (S) and a decrease in the energy content (H) of the system.
questions.neutral_comments: ∆G = ∆H – T∆S. If ∆G is a negative number, the products of the reaction must have a lower free energy content than the initial reactants. Also, in order for ∆G to be negative, it is not possible for ∆H to be positive and ∆S to be negative. The energy released by a reaction can only be used to power a reaction that requires an amount of energy to occur that is less than the amount of energy being released.
questions.all_comments: ∆G = ∆H – T∆S.  If ∆G is a negative number, the products of the reaction must have a lower free energy content than the initial reactants.  Also, in order for ∆G to be negative, it is not possible for ∆H to be positive and ∆S to be negative.  The energy released by a reaction can only be used to power a reaction that requires an amount of energy to occur that is less than the amount of energy being released.

questions.question: What term is used to describe the transfer of free energy from catabolic pathways to anabolic pathways?

answers.text: energy coupling
bioenergetics
feedback regulation
cooperativity

questions.correct_answer: energy coupling
questions.all_comments: Nice work!

questions.question: Which of the following is considered an open system?

answers.text: food cooking in a pressure cooker
an organism
a sealed terrarium
liquid in a corked bottle

questions.correct_answer: an organism
questions.neutral_comments: An open system is a system where energy and matter can enter and leave the system. That is true of an organism, but not of the other choices.
questions.all_comments: An open system is a system where energy and matter can enter and leave the system.  That is true of an organism, but not of the other choices.

questions.question: Which of the following is (are) TRUE for anabolic pathways?

answers.text: They consume energy to build up polymers from monomers.
They do not depend on enzymes.
They release energy as they degrade polymers to monomers.
They are usually highly spontaneous chemical reactions.

questions.correct_answer: They consume energy to build up polymers from monomers.
questions.all_comments: Nice job!

questions.question: The mathematical expression for the change in the free energy of a system is ∆G = ∆H – T∆S. Which of the following is (are) TRUE?

answers.text: ∆S is the change in free energy.
T is the temperature in degrees Celsius.
∆H is the change in enthalpy.
∆G is the change in entropy.

questions.correct_answer: ∆H is the change in enthalpy.
questions.neutral_comments: ∆G = the change in the Gibb’s free energy of the system. ∆H = the change in the enthalpy of the system. T = the temperature of the system in degrees Kelvin (zero degrees Kelvin = -273 °C. Zero degrees Kelvin corresponds to the theoretical temperature at which entropy reaches a minimum). ∆S = the change in the entropy of the system.
questions.all_comments: ∆G = the change in the Gibb’s free energy of the system.  ∆H = the change in the enthalpy of the system.  T = the temperature of the system in degrees Kelvin (zero degrees Kelvin = -273 °C.  Zero degrees Kelvin corresponds to the theoretical temperature at which entropy reaches a minimum).  ∆S = the change in the entropy of the system.

questions.question: Living organisms don’t violate the 2<sup>nd</sup> law of thermodynamics because:

answers.text: They typically increase their own entropy
They typically increase the entropy of their surroundings
Trick question, living organisms do violate the 2nd law of thermodynamics!
They increase the free energy of their surroundings

questions.correct_answer: They typically increase the entropy of their surroundings
questions.neutral_comments: The entropy of a biological system can decrease (and very often does decrease) without violating the 2nd law of thermodynamics, as long as the decrease in the entropy of the system is balanced by an even greater magnitude increase in the entropy of the rest of the universe.
questions.all_comments: The entropy of a biological system can decrease (and very often does decrease) without violating the 2nd law of thermodynamics, as long as the decrease in the entropy of the system is balanced by an even greater magnitude increase in the entropy of the rest of the universe.

questions.question: Why is ATP an important molecule in metabolism?

It is formed by endergonic reactions.
It provides energy coupling between exergonic and endergonic reactions.

questions.question: The statement “energy cannot be created or destroyed”

answers.text: is a statement of the first law of thermodynamics
is a statement of the third law of thermodynamics
is a statement of the second law of thermodynamics
is true for closed and open systems, but not for the universe as a whole

questions.correct_answer: is a statement of the first law of thermodynamics

questions.question: Which of the following statements is FALSE?

answers.text: Phosphorylation of a molecule usually makes the molecule less stable.
Hydrolysis of ATP to form ADP and inorganic phosphate is a highly exergonic reaction
Hydrolysis of ATP to form ADP and inorganic phosphate is a highly endergonic reaction
Phosphorylation of a molecule usually raises the potential energy of the molecule, making it more energetically favorable for that molecule to undergo spontaneous reactions.

questions.correct_answer: Hydrolysis of ATP to form ADP and inorganic phosphate is a highly endergonic reaction
questions.neutral_comments: Exergonic reactions are reactions that result in a decrease in free energy. Exergonic reactions occur when the total free energy of the reactants is greater than the total free energy of the products. ATP molecules have a lot of free energy, more than the ADP produced by their hydrolysis.
questions.all_comments: Exergonic reactions are reactions that result in a decrease in free energy.  Exergonic reactions occur when the total free energy of the reactants is greater than the total free energy of the products.  ATP molecules have a lot of free energy, more than the ADP produced by their hydrolysis.

questions.question: When ATP releases some energy, it also releases inorganic phosphate. What purpose, if any, does this serve in the cell?

answers.text: It can be added to other molecules in order to activate them.
It can only be used to generate more ATP.
It is released as excretory waste.
It can enter the nucleus and affect gene expression.

questions.correct_answer: It can be added to other molecules in order to activate them.
questions.neutral_comments: The third phosphate in ATP is often transferred to other molecules. Because the covalent bond between the phosphate and the rest of the molecule is a high-energy bond, phosphorylation of a molecule raises the free energy of that molecule. Raising the free energy of a molecule makes it more likely that it can participate in exergonic (spontaneous) reactions as a reactant, since it makes it more likely that the combined free energies of the reactant molecules will be greater than the combined free energies of the product molecules.
questions.all_comments: The third phosphate in ATP is often transferred to other molecules.  Because the covalent bond between the phosphate and the rest of the molecule is a high-energy bond, phosphorylation of a molecule raises the free energy of that molecule.  Raising the free energy of a molecule makes it more likely that it can participate in exergonic (spontaneous) reactions as a reactant, since it makes it more likely that the combined free energies of the reactant molecules will be greater than the combined free energies of the product molecules.

Without an input of energy, organisms would tend toward decreasing entropy.
Every energy transformation by a cell decreases the entropy of the universe.
Cells require a constant input of energy to maintain their high level of organization.

questions.correct_answer: Cells require a constant input of energy to maintain their high level of organization.
questions.neutral_comments: According to the 2nd law of thermodynamics the entropy of the universe as a whole is always increasing. Living organisms, such as cells, are able to use energy inputs to maintain a high level of order, and thus a low level of entropy. However, by doing this living organisms cause an increase in the entropy of their surroundings that more than compensates for the decrease in entropy within the organism. So, the total amount of entropy within the universe increases and the 2ndlaw of thermodynamics is not violated.
questions.all_comments: According to the 2nd law of thermodynamics the entropy of the universe as a whole is always increasing.  Living organisms, such as cells, are able to use energy inputs to maintain a high level of order, and thus a low level of entropy.  However, by doing this living organisms cause an increase in the entropy of their surroundings that more than compensates for the decrease in entropy within the organism.  So, the total amount of entropy within the universe increases and the 2ndlaw of thermodynamics is not violated.

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE for ALL exergonic reactions?

answers.text: The products have more total energy than the reactants.
A net input of energy from the surroundings is required for the reactions to proceed.
If the reaction proceeds there will be a net decrease in free energy.
The reactions are nonspontaneous.

questions.correct_answer: If the reaction proceeds there will be a net decrease in free energy.
questions.neutral_comments: By definition, exergonic reactions are reactions where the reaction results in a decrease in free energy. In contrast, it is possible for an exergonic reaction to result in an increase in the TOTAL energy of the system. For that to occur, the increase in the total energy of the system must be more than offset by an increase in entropy. Because exergonic reactions are reactions that result in a decrease in free energy, there is no need for an energy input in order for an exergonic reaction to occur.
questions.all_comments: By definition, exergonic reactions are reactions where the reaction results in a decrease in free energy.  In contrast, it is possible for an exergonic reaction to result in an increase in the TOTAL energy of the system.  For that to occur, the increase in the total energy of the system must be more than offset by an increase in entropy. Because exergonic reactions are reactions that result in a decrease in free energy, there is no need for an energy input in order for an exergonic reaction to occur.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about biological systems is FALSE?

The total energy in a biological system cannot increase or decrease

questions.correct_answer: The total energy in a biological system cannot increase or decrease
questions.neutral_comments: Because biological systems are open systems (i.e. they are systems where energy and matter can enter and leave the system), the total energy in a cell may increase or decrease. Similarly, the entropy of a biological system can decrease (and very often does decrease), as long as the decrease in the entropy of the system is balanced by an even greater magnitude increase in the entropy of the rest of the universe.
questions.all_comments: Because biological systems are open systems (i.e. they are systems where energy and matter can enter and leave the system), the total energy in a cell may increase or decrease.  Similarly, the entropy of a biological system can decrease (and very often does decrease), as long as the decrease in the entropy of the system is balanced by an even greater magnitude increase in the entropy of the rest of the universe.

questions.question: Living organisms increase in complexity as they grow, resulting in a decrease in the entropy of an organism. How does this relate to the second law of thermodynamics?

answers.text: As a consequence of growing, organisms create more disorder in their environment than the decrease in entropy associated with their growth.
Living organisms create lots of entropy after they die and the molecules in their bodies dissociate, which makes up for the decrease in entropy created while they were alive.
Living organisms do not follow the laws of thermodynamics.
As a consequence of growing, organisms create an amount of disorder in their environment that is equal to the decrease in entropy associated with their growth.

questions.correct_answer: As a consequence of growing, organisms create more disorder in their environment than the decrease in entropy associated with their growth.
questions.neutral_comments: The decrease in entropy within the organism is more than balanced by an even greater increase in the entropy of their surroundings. So, living organisms do not violate the 2nd law of thermodynamics as the processes carried out by living organisms increase the amount of entropy in the universe as a whole.
questions.all_comments: The decrease in entropy within the organism is more than balanced by an even greater increase in the entropy of their surroundings.  So, living organisms do not violate the 2nd law of thermodynamics as the processes carried out by living organisms increase the amount of entropy in the universe as a whole.

questions.question: Many of the reactions that occur during metabolism are reversible. Given the laws of thermodynamics, how is that possible?

answers.text: These reactions are reversible in theory, but proceed in only one direction so that the laws of thermodynamics are not violated.
Even in the same solution, some of the molecules of a particular species may have more energy than others.
Energy is used to drive a reversible reaction in one of the two possible directions.
The free energy of the system will decrease when the reaction proceeds in one direction, but the total energy of the system will decrease when the reaction proceeds in the other direction.

questions.correct_answer: Even in the same solution, some of the molecules of a particular species may have more energy than others.
questions.neutral_comments: For a reaction to be a spontaneous reaction, the free energy of the reactant molecules must be greater than the free energy of the product molecules, so that free energy decreases as a result of the reaction. So, if you imagine a reaction where “A” is converted to “B”, the conversion of a molecule of A to a molecule of B will be spontaneous if the free energy of molecule A is greater than the free energy of molecule B. So, if on average A molecules have a free energy of 5 kcal/mole and B molecules have a free energy of 4.9 kcal/mole, the average free energy of a molecule of A will be greater than the average free energy of a molecule of B and therefore the conversion of an average molecule of A to an average molecule of B will represent an exergonic, or spontaneous, reaction. However, what we have to realize is that different molecules of A in a solution will have slightly different free energies and different molecules of B will have slightly free different energies. So, if the AVERAGE free energy of a molecule of B is 4.9 kcal/mole, there may be some molecules of B that have a free energy of greater than 5 kcal/mole. Those molecules of B that have a free energy that is greater than 5 kcal/mole can then be converted to molecules of A via a reaction that will be exergonic (spontaneous). Note that this does NOT mean that the conversion of B to A will occur at as high a rate as the conversion of A to B. If there are only a very small number of molecules of B that have a high enough free energy level to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction, the rate of conversion of A to B will be higher than the rate of conversion of B to A. Eventually, the high rate of conversion of A to B will result in there being enough molecules of B with sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction that the rate of conversion of B to A will equal the rate of conversion of A to B. At that point, the reaction will have reached equilibrium and both reactions will occur at the same rate (note that, in this example, at equilibrium there will be more molecules of B than of A, but a smaller percentage of the molecules of B will have sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction). In addition, there is a tendency for reactions to be reversible because there is greater entropy in a mixture of substances than in a pure substance. In other words, a system that contains a mixture of "A" and "B" molecules will have greater entropy than a system that has just "A" or just "B" molecules.
questions.all_comments: For a reaction to be a spontaneous reaction, the free energy of the reactant molecules must be greater than the free energy of the product molecules, so that free energy decreases as a result of the reaction.  So, if you imagine a reaction where “A” is converted to “B”, the conversion of a molecule of A to a molecule of B will be spontaneous if the free energy of molecule A is greater than the free energy of molecule B.  So, if on average A molecules have a free energy of 5 kcal/mole and B molecules have a free energy of 4.9 kcal/mole, the average free energy that have a free energy that is greater than 5 kcal/mole can then be converted to molecules of A via a reaction that will be exergonic (spontaneous).  Note that this does NOT mean that the conversion of B to A will occur at as high a rate as the conversion of A to B.  If there are only a very small number of molecules of B that have a high enough free energy level to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction, the rate of conversion of A to B will be higher than the rate of conversion of B to A.  Eventually, the high rate of conversion of A to B will result in there being enough entropy in a mixture of substances than in a pure substance.  In other words, a system that contains a mixture of "A" and "B" molecules will have greater entropy than a system that has just "A" or just "B" molecules.

questions.question: Spontaneous reactions

answers.text: all of these answers are correct
always proceed rapidly
do not require an energy input to occur
always occur, and do not require an energy input

questions.correct_answer: do not require an energy input to occur
questions.neutral_comments: Spontaneous reactions are defined as reactions that do not require an energy input to occur. However, it is critical to realize that the word “spontaneous” is used in a different way when discussing chemical reactions than when discussing every day life. So a “spontaneous” chemical reaction may proceed very slowly or not at all, if the activation energy barrier for the reaction is high.
questions.all_comments: Spontaneous reactions are defined as reactions that do not require an energy input to occur.  However, it is critical to realize that the word “spontaneous” is used in a different way when discussing chemical reactions than when discussing every day life.  So a “spontaneous” chemical reaction may proceed very slowly or not at all, if the activation energy barrier for the reaction is high.

questions.question: A reaction has a ∆G of -5.6 kcal/mol. Which of the following would most likely be TRUE?

The reaction would result in a decrease in entropy (S) and an increase in the energy content (H) of the system.

The reaction would result in products with a greater free energy content than in the initial reactants.

questions.correct_answer: The reaction would result in an increase in entropy (S) and a decrease in the energy content (H) of the system.
questions.neutral_comments: ∆G = ∆H – T∆S. If ∆G is a negative number, the products of the reaction must have a lower free energy content than the initial reactants. Also, in order for ∆G to be negative, it is not possible for ∆H to be positive and ∆S to be negative. The energy released by a reaction can only be used to power a reaction that requires an amount of energy to occur that is less than the amount of energy being released.
questions.all_comments: ∆G = ∆H – T∆S.  If ∆G is a negative number, the products of the reaction must have a lower free energy content than the initial reactants.  Also, in order for ∆G to be negative, it is not possible for ∆H to be positive and ∆S to be negative.  The energy released by a reaction can only be used to power a reaction that requires an amount of energy to occur that is less than the amount of energy being released.

The products have less entropy than the reactants

questions.neutral_comments: By definition, exergonic reactions are reactions that result in a decrease in free energy. Energy from ATP is used to increase the potential energy of a reactant molecule, such that the total free energy of the reactant molecules is now greater than the total free energy of the product molecules that would be formed by the reaction.
All of these answers are correct.

questions.question: Which of the following statements concerning catabolic pathways is TRUE?

answers.text: They are usually coupled with anabolic pathways to which they supply energy in the form of ATP.
They are endergonic.
They combine molecules into more energy-rich foods.
They are spontaneous and do not need enzyme catalysis.

questions.correct_answer: They are usually coupled with anabolic pathways to which they supply energy in the form of ATP.
questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic pathways are metabolic pathways that result in the breakdown of large biological molecules to simpler molecules. As a result, they increase the entropy of the system. They are also exergonic reactions as the reactant molecules (i.e. the large biological molecules) have greater amounts of free energy than the product molecules (i.e. the smaller molecules that are formed by breaking down the large molecules). Reactions that result in a decrease in free energy are known as exergonic, or “spontaneous”, reactions. Please remember that the fact that a reaction is a “spontaneous” reaction does NOT mean that reaction will occur at a high rate. In fact, the reaction may not occur at all, depending on the height of the activation energy barrier.
questions.all_comments: Catabolic pathways are metabolic pathways that result in the breakdown of large biological molecules to simpler molecules.  As a result, they increase the entropy of the system.  They are also exergonic reactions as the reactant molecules (i.e. the large biological molecules) have greater amounts of free energy than the product molecules (i.e. the smaller molecules that are formed by breaking down the large molecules).  Reactions that result in a decrease in free energy are known as exergonic, or “spontaneous”, reactions.   Please remember that the fact that a reaction is a “spontaneous” reaction does NOT mean that reaction will occur at a high rate.  In fact, the reaction may not occur at all, depending on the height of the activation energy barrier.

questions.question: A chemical reaction that has a positive ∆G is correctly described as

answers.text: none of these answers are correct

endergonic
exergonic

questions.correct_answer: endergonic
questions.neutral_comments: Reactions that have a positive ∆G (i.e. reactions where the total free energy of the reactants is less than the total free energy of the products) are known as endergonic reactions. Reactions that have a negative ∆G are known as exergonic or spontaneous reactions.
questions.all_comments: Reactions that have a positive ∆G (i.e. reactions where the total free energy of the reactants is less than the total free energy of the products) are known as endergonic reactions.  Reactions that have a negative ∆G are known as exergonic or spontaneous reactions.

no net change

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE for ALL exergonic reactions?

answers.text: If the reaction proceeds there will be a net decrease in free energy.
The products have more total energy than the reactants.
A net input of energy from the surroundings is required for the reactions to proceed.
The reactions are nonspontaneous.

questions.correct_answer: If the reaction proceeds there will be a net decrease in free energy.
questions.neutral_comments: By definition, exergonic reactions are reactions where the reaction results in a decrease in free energy. In contrast, it is possible for an exergonic reaction to result in an increase in the TOTAL energy of the system. For that to occur, the increase in the total energy of the system must be more than offset by an increase in entropy. Because exergonic reactions are reactions that result in a decrease in free energy, there is no need for an energy input in order for an exergonic reaction to occur.
questions.all_comments: By definition, exergonic reactions are reactions where the reaction results in a decrease in free energy.  In contrast, it is possible for an exergonic reaction to result in an increase in the TOTAL energy of the system.  For that to occur, the increase in the total energy of the system must be more than offset by an increase in entropy. Because exergonic reactions are reactions that result in a decrease in free energy, there is no need for an energy input in order for an exergonic reaction to occur.

questions.question: Which of the following terms best describes the reaction described in the figure below?

answers.text: endergonic
allosteric
anabolic
exergonic

questions.correct_answer: exergonic
questions.neutral_comments: The free energy of the reactant molecules (A and B) is greater than the free energy of the product molecules (C and D). So, the reaction of A and B to C and D will result in a decrease in free energy of the system. Reactions where the free energy decreases are known as exergonic reactions. In contrast, reactions where the free energy increases are known as endergonic reactions. In metabolism, catabolic reactions, which breakdown complex, energy-rich molecules to smaller, less energy dense molecules are generally exergonic. In contrast, anabolic reactions, which require an input of energy to convert small molecules to more complex, energy-rich molecules, tend to be endergonic.

questions.question: During a laboratory experiment you discover that an enzyme-catalyzed reaction has a delta G of -20 kcal/mol. If you double the amount of enzyme in the reaction, what will be the delta G for the new reaction?

answers.text: +40 kcal/mole
+20 kcal/mole
-40 kcal/mole
-20 kcal/mole

questions.correct_answer: -20 kcal/mole
questions.neutral_comments: Because enzymes do not change the free energy change of a reaction, delta G will still be -20 kcal/mole. Please note that enzymes DO lower the energy activation barrier, which is the energy barrier that reactant molecules must surmount in order for a reaction to occur. But, enzymes do not change the free energy in the reactant or product molecules and thus do not change the difference between the free energies of the reactant and product molecules.
questions.all_comments: Nice job!Because enzymes do not change the free energy change of a reaction, delta G will still be -20 kcal/mole.  Please note that enzymes DO lower the energy activation barrier, which is the energy barrier that reactant molecules must surmount in order for a reaction to occur.  But, enzymes do not change the free energy in the reactant or product molecules and thus do not change the difference between the free energies of the reactant and product molecules.

questions.question: For the reaction described in the figure shown below, which of the following represents the activation energy barrier for the noncatalyzed reaction?

answers.text: arrow E
arrow B
arrow A
arrow C

So, the peak of the red curve represents the energy needed to overcome the activation energy barrier in the non-catalyzed reaction and the peak of the black curve represents the amount of energy needed to overcome the activation energy barrier for the enzyme catalyzed reaction. Arrow “B” thus represents the amount of energy molecules A and B need to gain above their normal, average state in order for the enzyme catalyzed reaction to occur. Arrow “C” represents the amount of energy molecules A and B need to gain above their normal, average state in order for the non-catalyzed reaction to occur.
