questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding enzymes is FALSE?

answers.text: Enzyme activity can be inhibited if the enzyme is bound by a noncompetitive inhibitor.
Enzyme function is dependent on the pH and temperature of the reaction environment.
Enzyme function is dependent on the three-dimensional structure or conformation of the enzyme.
Enzymes alter the free energy change (ΔG) of the reactions which they catalyze.

questions.correct_answer: Enzymes alter the free energy change (ΔG) of the reactions which they catalyze.
questions.neutral_comments: The statement that is NOT true is that enzymes alter the free energy change of the reactions which they catalyze. In fact, enzymes do not alter the free energy change of the reactions they catalyze. Instead, they decrease the activation energy needed for the reaction to occur. If the activation energy is decreased, more molecules will have enough energy for the reaction to occur and the reaction will occur more quickly. However, the change in energy for each molecule undergoing the reaction will NOT be affected by the enzyme. Think of it like this: Imagine a bunch of people trying to jump from a bed, over a dresser, onto the floor. If the dresser is very high, not too many people will be able to jump over it and make it to the floor. If you lower the dresser, more people will be able to jump over it and make it to the floor. However, the decrease in potential energy will be the same regardless of the height of the dresser, since the decrease in potential energy is dependent (in this example) on the difference between the starting height of each person on the bed and their final height on the floor, which is not affected by the height of the dresser.
questions.all_comments: Actually, this is a true statement.The statement that is NOT true is that enzymes alter the free energy change of the reactions which they catalyze.  In fact, enzymes do not alter the free energy change of the reactions they catalyze.  Instead, they decrease the activation energy needed for the reaction to occur.  If the activation energy is decreased, more molecules will have enough energy for the reaction to occur and the reaction will occur more quickly.  However, the change in energy for each molecule undergoing the reaction will NOT be affected by the enzyme.  Think of it like this: Imagine a bunch of people trying to jump from a bed, over a dresser, onto the floor.  If the dresser is very high, not too many people will be able to jump over it and make it to the floor.  If you lower the dresser, more people will be able to jump over it and make it to the floor.  However, the decrease in potential energy will be the same regardless of the height of the dresser, since the decrease in potential energy is dependent (in this example) on the difference between the starting height of each person on the bed and their final height on the floor, which is not affected by the height of the dresser.

questions.question: In a particular reversible reaction, “A” and “B” may be converted to “C” and “D”, or “C” and “D” may be converted to “A” and “B”. The direction of this reversible reaction will be determined by

answers.text: None of these answers are correct.
the relative concentrations of “A” and “B” versus “C” and “D”
Both “a” and “b” are correct.
whether the enzyme that catalyzes the reaction catalyzes the forward or reverse reactions

questions.correct_answer: the relative concentrations of “A” and “B” versus “C” and “D”
questions.neutral_comments: Enzymes do not alter the free energy change of a reaction and so do not alter the point at which equilibrium will be reached or the overall direction of the reaction. In contrast, the direction of a reversible reaction will be determined by the relative concentrations of the reactants and products of the reactions, together with the difference in the free energies of the reactant and product molecules.
questions.all_comments: Enzymes do not alter the free energy change of a reaction and so do not alter the point at which equilibrium will be reached or the overall direction of the reaction.  In contrast, the direction of a reversible reaction will be determined by the relative concentrations of the reactants and products of the reactions, together with the difference in the free energies of the reactant and product molecules.

questions.question: Feedback inhibition is used by cells to

answers.text: slow down the rate at which organisms excrete waste products.
slow down the rate at which organisms consume food.
decrease the free energy change of undesirable reactions.
keep from producing unnecessarily high levels of different products.

questions.correct_answer: keep from producing unnecessarily high levels of different products.
questions.neutral_comments: Feedback inhibition occurs when an end product of a metabolic pathway binds to, and inhibits, one of the enzymes that catalyzes an early step in that pathway. Feedback inhibition is thus used as a mechanism to slow down pathways that are producing product molecules more quickly than they are needed, so that the product molecules are accumulating in the cell.
questions.all_comments: A feedback inhibitor will bind an enzyme molecule, changing the three dimensional conformation of the enzyme molecule.  This change in conformation makes it harder for the enzyme to catalyze its reaction, with the result that the enzyme is not able to lower the activation energy barrier as much as it would be able to do in the absence of the inhibitor.  So, the effect of the inhibitor is to increase the activation energy barrier for the reaction.  However, remember that enzymes, and therefore things that regulate enzymes, do NOT change the free energies of the reactant or product molecules and thus do NOT alter the free energy change of a reaction.Feedback inhibition occurs when an end product of a metabolic pathway binds to, and inhibits, one of the enzymes that catalyzes an early step in that pathway.  Feedback inhibition is thus used as a mechanism to slow down pathways that are producing product molecules more quickly than they are needed, so that the product molecules are accumulating in the cell.

questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP. If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point. As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP. For a similar reason, many catabolic enzymes are activated by ADP. So, if ATP levels in the cell are low and ADP levels are high, you would expect catabolic reactions to proceed quickly.If you have trouble remembering the difference between catabolism and anabolism, picture a cat tearing something up to remember that catabolism is the breakdown of large, energy-rich molecules to produce smaller, less energy-rich molecules. Anabolism is the opposite (i.e. production of large, energy-rich molecules from smaller, less complex and less energy-rich molecules).

questions.question: How quickly do spontaneous reactions occur?

answers.text: Very quickly
It depends on the reaction. Some spontaneous reactions almost never occur.
Extremely quickly
Somewhat quickly

questions.correct_answer: It depends on the reaction. Some spontaneous reactions almost never occur.
questions.neutral_comments: Remember that, although exergonic reactions are also known as “spontaneous” reactions, the fact that a reaction is “spontaneous” does not mean that it will occur quickly or even that it will occur at all. Exergonic, or spontaneous, reactions are defined as reactions where the free energies of the reactant molecules are higher than the free energies of the product molecules. So, if the reaction occurs, there will be a net decrease in free energy. HOWEVER, for a reaction to occur the chemical bonds in the reactant molecules must be “stretched” into higher energy forms, so that the reactant molecules reach what is known as a “transition state”. The free energies of the reactant molecules in their transition states are higher than the free energies of the reactant molecules in their non-transition states. So, the reactant molecules may not have sufficient energy to achieve their transition states. If that is the case, the reaction will not proceed even though the overall effect of the reaction would be a decrease in free energy. Note that adding energy to some of the reactant molecules, so that those molecules are able to undergo the reaction, will result in a release of energy that may result in more reactant molecules having sufficient energy to surmount the activation energy barrier and undergo the reaction, leading to a further release in energy that allows more reactant molecules to undergo the reaction, and so on. In other words, once a reaction gets going, it may keep going.
questions.all_comments: Remember that, although exergonic reactions are also known as “spontaneous” reactions, the fact that a reaction is “spontaneous” does not mean that it will occur quickly or even that it will occur at all.  Exergonic, or spontaneous, reactions are defined as reactions where the free energies of the reactant molecules are higher than the free energies of the product molecules.  So, if the reaction occurs, there will be a net decrease in free energy.  HOWEVER, for a reaction to occur the chemical bonds in the reactant molecules must be “stretched” into higher energy forms, so that the reactant molecules reach what is known as a “transition state”.  The free energies of the reactant molecules in their transition states are higher than the free energies of the reactant molecules in their non-transition states.  So, the reactant molecules may not have sufficient energy to achieve their transition states.  If that is the case, the reaction will not proceed even though the overall effect of the reaction would be a decrease in free energy.  Note that adding energy to some of the reactant molecules, so that those molecules are able to undergo the reaction, will result in a release of energy that may result in more reactant molecules having sufficient energy to surmount the activation energy barrier and undergo the reaction, leading to a further release in energy that allows more reactant molecules to undergo the reaction, and so on.  In other words, once a reaction gets going, it may keep going.

questions.question: Wood is extremely flammable, so why don’t trees spontaneously burst into flame?

answers.text: The chemical bonds in wood have more potential energy than the chemical bonds in ash.
Burning wood is an endergonic reaction that requires energy from fire to drive it.
Burning wood is an exergonic reaction that requires energy from fire to drive it.
At room temperature, the molecules in wood do not have sufficient energy to overcome the activation energy barrier necessary for this reaction to occur.

questions.correct_answer: At room temperature, the molecules in wood do not have sufficient energy to overcome the activation energy barrier necessary for this reaction to occur.
questions.neutral_comments: Remember that, although exergonic reactions are also known as “spontaneous” reactions, the fact that a reaction is “spontaneous” does not mean that it will occur quickly or even that it will occur at all. Exergonic, or spontaneous, reactions are defined as reactions where the free energies of the reactant molecules are higher than the free energies of the product molecules. So, if the reaction occurs, there will be a net decrease in free energy. HOWEVER, for a reaction to occur the chemical bonds in the reactant molecules must be “stretched” into higher energy forms, so that the reactant molecules reach what is known as a “transition state”. The free energies of the reactant molecules in their transition states are higher than the free energies of the reactant molecules in their non-transition states. So, the reactant molecules may not have sufficient energy to achieve their transition states. If that is the case, the reaction will not proceed even though the overall effect of the reaction would be a decrease in free energy. Note that adding energy to some of the reactant molecules, so that those molecules are able to undergo the reaction, will result in a release of energy that may result in more reactant molecules having sufficient energy to surmount the activation energy barrier and undergo the reaction, leading to a further release in energy that allows more reactant molecules to undergo the reaction, and so on. In other words, once a reaction gets going, it may keep going. So, once a piece of wood begins to burn, it may keep on burning. To remember the difference between exergonic and endergonic, think of free energy exiting the system during an exergonic reaction (where the free energies of the reactants are greater than those of the products) and entering the system during an endergonic reaction (where the free energies of the reactants are less than those of the products).

questions.all_comments: Remember that enzymes act by lowering the activation energy barrier.  So, the peak of the red curve represents the energy needed to overcome the activation energy barrier in the non-catalyzed reaction and the peak of the black curve represents the amount of energy needed to overcome the activation energy barrier for the enzyme catalyzed reaction.  Arrow “B” thus represents the amount of energy molecules A and B need to gain above their normal, average state in order for the enzyme catalyzed reaction to occur.  Arrow “C” represents the amount of energy molecules A and B need to gain above their normal, average state in order for the non-catalyzed reaction to occur.

questions.question: You notice that many of the catabolic reactions in a cell have speeded up. Upon further characterization of the cell, you are NOT surprised to find that

answers.text: both the ATP and ADP levels in the cell are high.
both the ATP and ADP levels in the cell are low.
the ATP levels in the cell are high and the ADP levels are low.
the ATP levels in the cell are low and the ADP levels are high.

questions.correct_answer: the ATP levels in the cell are low and the ADP levels are high.
questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP. If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point. As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP. For a similar reason, many catabolic enzymes are activated by ADP. So, if ATP levels in the cell are low and ADP levels are high, you would expect catabolic reactions to proceed quickly.If you have trouble remembering the difference between catabolism and anabolism, picture a cat tearing something up to remember that catabolism is the breakdown of large, energy-rich molecules to produce smaller, less energy-rich molecules. Anabolism is the opposite (i.e. production of large, energy-rich molecules from smaller, less complex and less energy-rich molecules).
questions.all_comments: Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP.  If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point.  As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP.  For a similar reason, many catabolic enzymes are activated by ADP.  So, if ATP levels in the cell are low and ADP levels are high, you would expect catabolic reactions to proceed quickly.If you have trouble remembering the difference between catabolism and anabolism, picture a cat tearing something up to remember that catabolism is the breakdown of large, energy-rich molecules to produce smaller, less energy-rich molecules.  Anabolism is the opposite (i.e. production of large, energy-rich molecules from smaller, less complex and less energy-rich molecules).

positive ∆G, nonspontaneous
negative ∆G, spontaneous
∆G of zero, chemical equilibrium

questions.correct_answer: negative ∆G, spontaneous
questions.neutral_comments: The free energy of the reactant molecules (A and B) is greater than the free energy of the product molecules (C and D). So, the reaction of A and B to C and D will result in a decrease in free energy of the system (i.e. a negative ∆G). Reactions where the free energy decreases are known as exergonic, or spontaneous, reactions.

questions.question: Succinate dehydrogenase catalyzes the conversion of succinate to fumarate. The reaction is inhibited by malonic acid. Increasing the ratio of succinate to malonic acid reduces the inhibitory effect of malonic acid. What role does malonic acid play in this reaction?

answers.text: It is a noncompetitive inhibitor.
It is a competitive inhibitor.
It replaces the usual enzyme.
It blocks the binding of fumarate.

questions.correct_answer: It is a competitive inhibitor.
questions.neutral_comments: Competitive inhibitors compete with substrate (succinate, in this case) molecules for binding to the enzyme’s active site. Adding more substrate (e.g. succinate) molecules will alleviate this type of inhibition. In contrast, noncompetitive inhibitors bind to sites that are distinct from the enyzme’s active site. Increasing the substrate concentration does not alleviate inhibition by a noncompetitive inhibitor.
questions.all_comments: Competitive inhibitors compete with substrate (succinate, in this case) molecules for binding to the enzyme’s active site.  Adding more substrate (e.g. succinate) molecules will alleviate this type of inhibition.  In contrast, noncompetitive inhibitors bind to sites that are distinct from the enyzme’s active site.  Increasing the substrate concentration does not alleviate inhibition by a noncompetitive inhibitor.

questions.question: Binding of an allosteric regulator to the enzyme it regulates

answers.text: is irreversible.
may occur via covalent bonds.
is at the enzyme’s active site.
may occur via ionic bonds

questions.correct_answer: may occur via ionic bonds
questions.neutral_comments: By definition, allosteric regulators bind enzymes at locations that are distinct from the enzyme’s active site. Binding of allosteric regulators to enzymes is via noncovalent bonds, such as ionic or hydrogen bonds. The binding of an allosteric regulator to an enzyme is always reversible. This is in contrast to noncompetitive inhibitors, which may bind an enzyme via noncovalent bonds and usually bind irreversibly to enzymes. Noncompetitive inhibitors and allosteric regulators do share the trait that they bind at a site that is distinct from the active site they are reuglating.
questions.all_comments: By definition, allosteric regulators bind enzymes at locations that are distinct from the enzyme’s active site.  Binding of allosteric regulators to enzymes is via noncovalent bonds, such as ionic or hydrogen bonds.  The binding of an allosteric regulator to an enzyme is always reversible.  This is in contrast to noncompetitive inhibitors, which may bind an enzyme via noncovalent bonds and usually bind irreversibly to enzymes.  Noncompetitive inhibitors and allosteric regulators do share the trait that they bind at a site that is distinct from the active site they are reuglating.

questions.question: An allosteric regulator

answers.text: may decrease the activity level of the enzymes it regulates
may increase the activity level of the enzymes it regulates
All of these answers are correct.
usually acts on multi-subunit enzymes

questions.correct_answer: All of these answers are correct.
questions.neutral_comments: Allosteric regulators bind enzymes at locations that are distinct from the enzyme’s active site. Allosteric regulators often act on multi-subunit enzymes. The 3-dimensional shapes of these enzymes often oscillate between more and less active shapes. Binding of an allosteric activator to one of the subunits of the enzyme stabilizes all of the subunits in their more active shape. Conversely, binding of an allosteric inhibitor to one of the subunits of the enzyme stabilizes all of the subunits in their less active shape

Conversely, binding of an allosteric inhibitor to one of the subunits of the enzyme stabilizes all of the subunits in their less active shape

questions.question: How quickly do spontaneous reactions occur?

answers.text: It depends on the reaction. Some spontaneous reactions almost never occur.
Somewhat quickly
Extremely quickly
Very quickly

questions.correct_answer: It depends on the reaction. Some spontaneous reactions almost never occur.
questions.neutral_comments: Remember that, although exergonic reactions are also known as “spontaneous” reactions, the fact that a reaction is “spontaneous” does not mean that it will occur quickly or even that it will occur at all. Exergonic, or spontaneous, reactions are defined as reactions where the free energies of the reactant molecules are higher than the free energies of the product molecules. So, if the reaction occurs, there will be a net decrease in free energy. HOWEVER, for a reaction to occur the chemical bonds in the reactant molecules must be “stretched” into higher energy forms, so that the reactant molecules reach what is known as a “transition state”. The free energies of the reactant molecules in their transition states are higher than the free energies of the reactant molecules in their non-transition states. So, the reactant molecules may not have sufficient energy to achieve their transition states. If that is the case, the reaction will not proceed even though the overall effect of the reaction would be a decrease in free energy. Note that adding energy to some of the reactant molecules, so that those molecules are able to undergo the reaction, will result in a release of energy that may result in more reactant molecules having sufficient energy to surmount the activation energy barrier and undergo the reaction, leading to a further release in energy that allows more reactant molecules to undergo the reaction, and so on. In other words, once a reaction gets going, it may keep going.
questions.all_comments: Remember that, although exergonic reactions are also known as “spontaneous” reactions, the fact that a reaction is “spontaneous” does not mean that it will occur quickly or even that it will occur at all.  Exergonic, or spontaneous, reactions are defined as reactions where the free energies of the reactant molecules are higher than the free energies of the product molecules.  So, if the reaction occurs, there will be a net decrease in free energy.  HOWEVER, for a reaction to occur the chemical bonds in the reactant molecules must be “stretched” into higher energy forms, so that the reactant molecules reach what is known as a “transition state”.  The free energies of the reactant molecules in their transition states are higher than the free energies of the reactant molecules in their non-transition states.  So, the reactant molecules may not have sufficient energy to achieve their transition states.  If that is the case, the reaction will not proceed even though the overall effect of the reaction would be a decrease in free energy.  Note that adding energy to some of the reactant molecules, so that those molecules are able to undergo the reaction, will result in a release of energy that may result in more reactant molecules having sufficient energy to surmount the activation energy barrier and undergo the reaction, leading to a further release in energy that allows more reactant molecules to undergo the reaction, and so on.  In other words, once a reaction gets going, it may keep going.

questions.question: You realize that, for a particular reaction to occur, the molecules participating in that reaction need to have a certain minimum free energy level to get over the activation energy barrier. After measuring the average free energy levels of the potential reactant molecules, you discover that their average free energy levels are a little below that required to surmount the activation barrier. Should you be surprised when you then realize that the reaction is occurring, even though it is only occurring at a relatively low rate?

answers.text: No, you should not be surprised because the energy level at the top of the activation barrier represents only an average amount of energy. So, the activation barrier will actually be lower for some of the reactant molecules and higher for others.
Yes, you should be surprised because the chemical reaction is apparently occurring in violation of the laws of thermodynamics.

No, you should not be surprised because you only measured the average free energy levels of the potential reactant molecules. Some of the molecules likely have more than the average amount of free energy, meaning that they have enough free energy to surmount the activation barrier.
Yes, you should be surprised because someone must have published inaccurate data regarding the amount of energy needed to surmount the activation barrier.

questions.correct_answer: No, you should not be surprised because you only measured the average free energy levels of the potential reactant molecules. Some of the molecules likely have more than the average amount of free energy, meaning that they have enough free energy to surmount the activation barrier.
questions.neutral_comments: For a spontaneous reaction to occur, the free energy of the reactant molecules must be sufficient to get over the activation energy barrier. If the activation energy barrier is 7 kcal/mol and the average free energy of the reactant molecules is only 6.9 kcal/mole, the average reactant molecule will have insufficient free energy to get over the activation energy barrier. However, we have to consider that only the AVERAGE free energy of the reactant molecules was measured, and that different reactant molecules in a solution will have slightly different free energy levels. So, some percentage of the reactant molecules will have sufficient free energy to surmount the energy activation barrier.
questions.all_comments: For a spontaneous reaction to occur, the free energy of the reactant molecules must be sufficient to get over the activation energy barrier.  If the activation energy barrier is 7 kcal/mol and the average free energy of the reactant molecules is only 6.9 kcal/mole, the average reactant molecule will have insufficient free energy to get over the activation energy barrier.  However, we have to consider that only the AVERAGE free energy of the reactant molecules was measured, and that different reactant molecules in a solution will have slightly different free energy levels.  So, some percentage of the reactant molecules will have sufficient free energy to surmount the energy activation barrier.

questions.question: How can one increase the rate of a chemical reaction?

answers.text: Increase the activation energy needed.
Cool the reactants.
Add a catalyst
Increase the entropy of the reactants.

questions.correct_answer: Add a catalyst

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to lead to an increase in the concentration of ATP in a cell?

answers.text: a decrease in a cell’s catabolic activity
an increased flux of cofactor molecules
an increased amino acid concentration
a decrease in a cell’s anabolic activity

questions.correct_answer: a decrease in a cell’s anabolic activity
questions.neutral_comments: Anabolic, or biosynthetic, reactions use energy from ATP to form larger, more complex and energy-rich, molecules from smaller, less complex and energy rich, molecules. So, decreasing the rate of anabolic reactions would decrease the rate at which ATP is being used up, allowing ATP concentrations in the cell to increase.

questions.question: The enzyme phosphofructokinase catalyzes the conversion of fructose-6-phosphate and adenosine triphosphate (ATP) to fructose 1,6-bisphosphate and adenosine diphosphate (ADP). Adenosine monophosphate (AMP) activates the enzyme phosphofructokinase (PFK) by binding at a site distinct from the substrate-binding site. This is an example of

answers.text: activation by an enzyme cofactor
cooperative activation
the coupling of exergonic and endergonic reactions
allosteric activation

questions.correct_answer: allosteric activation
questions.neutral_comments: In this example, AMP is binding to a site that is distinct from the active site that it is regulating, which is consistent with AMP acting as an allosteric activator. Note that this is NOT an example of cooperative activation, as cooperative activation occurs when binding of a substrate molecule to the active site of one of the subunits in a multi-subunit enzyme changes the conformations of the other subunits such that they are able to bind substrate molecules more easily. In this example, AMP is not a substrate molecule and it is not binding to any of the active sites of phosphfructokinase (which does happen to be a multi-subunit enzyme).
questions.all_comments: Nice work!In this example, AMP is binding to a site that is distinct from the active site that it is regulating, which is consistent with AMP acting as an allosteric activator.  Note that this is NOT an example of cooperative activation, as cooperative activation occurs when binding of a substrate molecule to the active site of one of the subunits in a multi-subunit enzyme changes the conformations of the other subunits such that they are able to bind substrate molecules more easily.  In this example, AMP is not a substrate molecule and it is not binding to any of the active sites of phosphfructokinase (which does happen to be a multi-subunit enzyme).

questions.question: How does a noncompetitive inhibitor decrease the rate of an enzyme reaction?

answers.text: by changing the free energy change of the reaction
by binding at the active site of the enzyme
by changing the shape of the enzyme
by acting as a coenzyme for the reaction

questions.correct_answer: by changing the shape of the enzyme
questions.neutral_comments: Noncompetitive inhibitors bind at sites that are distinct from the active site of the enzyme they inhibit. Binding of a noncompetitive inhibitor causes the enzyme to change its shape in a way that makes the enzyme less effective at catalyzing the conversion of substrate to product. Just as enzymes do not alter the change in free energy of a reaction, inhibitors and activators of enzymes do not alter the change in free energy of a reaction.
questions.all_comments: Nice job!Noncompetitive inhibitors bind at sites that are distinct from the active site of the enzyme they inhibit.  Binding of a noncompetitive inhibitor causes the enzyme to change its shape in a way that makes the enzyme less effective at catalyzing the conversion of substrate to product.  Just as enzymes do not alter the change in free energy of a reaction, inhibitors and activators of enzymes do not alter the change in free energy of a reaction.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about substrate molecules in their transition state is FALSE?

answers.text: Molecules in their transition states have increased stability.
Molecules in their transition states are contorted into unusual shapes.
Molecules in their transition states have higher energies than when they are not in their transition states.
Energy is needed to move molecules from their normal to their transition states.

questions.correct_answer: Molecules in their transition states have increased stability.
questions.all_comments: Good job!

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding enzymes is FALSE?

answers.text: Enzymes alter the free energy change (ΔG) of the reactions which they catalyze.
Enzyme activity can be inhibited if the enzyme is bound by a noncompetitive inhibitor.
Enzyme function is dependent on the pH and temperature of the reaction environment.
Enzyme function is dependent on the three-dimensional structure or conformation of the enzyme.

questions.correct_answer: Enzymes alter the free energy change (ΔG) of the reactions which they catalyze.
questions.neutral_comments: The statement that is NOT true is that enzymes alter the free energy change of the reactions which they catalyze. In fact, enzymes do not alter the free energy change of the reactions they catalyze. Instead, they decrease the activation energy needed for the reaction to occur. If the activation energy is decreased, more molecules will have enough energy for the reaction to occur and the reaction will occur more quickly. However, the change in energy for each molecule undergoing the reaction will NOT be affected by the enzyme. Think of it like this: Imagine a bunch of people trying to jump from a bed, over a dresser, onto the floor. If the dresser is very high, not too many people will be able to jump over it and make it to the floor. If you lower the dresser, more people will be able to jump over it and make it to the floor. However, the decrease in potential energy will be the same regardless of the height of the dresser, since the decrease in potential energy is dependent (in this example) on the difference between the starting height of each person on the bed and their final height on the floor, which is not affected by the height of the dresser.
questions.all_comments: Nice job!The statement that is NOT true is that enzymes alter the free energy change of the reactions which they catalyze.  In fact, enzymes do not alter the free energy change of the reactions they catalyze.  Instead, they decrease the activation energy needed for the reaction to occur.  If the activation energy is decreased, more molecules will have enough energy for the reaction to occur and the reaction will occur more quickly.  However, the change in energy for each molecule undergoing the reaction will NOT be affected by the enzyme.  Think of it like this: Imagine a bunch of people trying to jump from a bed, over a dresser, onto the floor.  If the dresser is very high, not too many people will be able to jump over it and make it to the floor.  If you lower the dresser, more people will be able to jump over it and make it to the floor.  However, the decrease in potential energy will be the same regardless of the height of the dresser, since the decrease in potential energy is dependent (in this example) on the difference between the starting height of each person on the bed and their final height on the floor, which is not affected by the height of the dresser.

questions.question: Which of the following is the best explanation for how enzymes speed up the rates of reactions?

answers.text: Enzymes lower the energy required for reactant molecules to reach their transition state. Enzymes do not alter the free or total energies of the reactant or product molecules.
Enzymes increase the energy of the reactant molecules.
Enzymes increase the enthalpy of the reactant molecules.
Enzymes lower the free energy change of the reaction.

questions.question: A solution of starch at room temperature does not readily decompose to form a solution of simple sugars because

answers.text: The activation energy barrier cannot be surmounted.

questions.neutral_comments: The hydrolysis of starch to form sugars is a spontaneous process, meaning that it represents in an exergonic reaction (i.e. a reaction where the free energy of the products is less than the free energy of the reactants). The starch molecules do not have sufficient energy to assume the required high-energy transitional state for the reaction to occur in the absence of a catalyst.

questions.question: The oxidation of glucose to CO<sub>2</sub> and H<sub>2</sub>O is highly exergonic: ∆G = -636 kcal/mol. Why doesn’t glucose spontaneously combust?

answers.text: The glucose molecules lack the activation energy at room temperature.
The water molecules quench the reaction.
There is too much CO2 in the air.
CO2 has higher energy than glucose.

questions.correct_answer: The glucose molecules lack the activation energy at room temperature.
questions.neutral_comments: Remember that, although exergonic reactions are also known as “spontaneous” reactions, the fact that a reaction is “spontaneous” does not mean that it will occur quickly or even that it will occur at all. Exergonic, or spontaneous, reactions are defined as reactions where the free energies of the reactant molecules are higher than the free energies of the product molecules. So, if the reaction occurs, there will be a net decrease in free energy. HOWEVER, for a reaction to occur the chemical bonds in the reactant molecules must be “stretched” into higher energy forms, so that the reactant molecules reach what is known as a “transition state”. The free energies of the reactant molecules in their transition states are higher than the free energies of the reactant molecules in their non-transition states. So, the reactant molecules may not have sufficient energy to achieve their transition states. If that is the case, the reaction will not proceed even though the overall effect of the reaction would be a decrease in free energy. Note that adding energy to some of the reactant molecules, so that those molecules are able to undergo the reaction, will result in a release of energy that may result in more reactant molecules having sufficient energy to surmount the activation energy barrier and undergo the reaction, leading to a further release in energy that allows more reactant molecules to undergo the reaction, and so on. In other words, once a reaction gets going, it may keep going.
questions.all_comments: Remember that, although exergonic reactions are also known as “spontaneous” reactions, the fact that a reaction is “spontaneous” does not mean that it will occur quickly or even that it will occur at all.  Exergonic, or spontaneous, reactions are defined as reactions where the free energies of the reactant molecules are higher than the free energies of the product molecules.  So, if the reaction occurs, there will be a net decrease in free energy.  HOWEVER, for a reaction to occur the chemical bonds in the reactant molecules must be “stretched” into higher energy forms, so that the reactant molecules reach what is known as a “transition state”.  The free energies of the reactant molecules in their transition states are higher than the free energies of the reactant molecules in their non-transition states.  So, the reactant molecules may not have sufficient energy to achieve their transition states.  If that is the case, the reaction will not proceed even though the overall effect of the reaction would be a decrease in free energy.  Note that adding energy to some of the reactant molecules, so that those molecules are able to undergo the reaction, will result in a release of energy that may result in more reactant molecules having sufficient energy to surmount the activation energy barrier and undergo the reaction, leading to a further release in energy that allows more reactant molecules to undergo the reaction, and so on.  In other words, once a reaction gets going, it may keep going.

questions.question: You notice that many of the anabolic reactions in a cell have speeded up. Upon further characterization of the cell, you are NOT surprised to find that

answers.text: both the ATP and ADP levels in the cell are high.
the ATP levels in the cell are low and the ADP levels are high.
the ATP levels in the cell are high and the ADP levels are low.
both the ATP and ADP levels in the cell are low.

questions.correct_answer: the ATP levels in the cell are high and the ADP levels are low.
questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP. If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point. As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP. For a similar reason, many catabolic enzymes are activated by ADP. Conversely, because anabolic pathways require ATP and generate ADP, many of the enzymes that catalyze anabolic reactions are activated by ATP and inhibited by ADP. So, if ATP levels are high and ADP levels are low, you would expect anabolic reactions to proceed quickly. If you have trouble remembering the difference between catabolism and anabolism, picture a cat tearing something up to remember that catabolism is the breakdown of large, energy-rich molecules to produce smaller, less energy-rich molecules. Anabolism is the opposite (i.e. production of large, energy-rich molecules from smaller, less complex and less energy-rich molecules).
questions.all_comments: Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP.  If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point.  As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP.  For a similar reason, many catabolic enzymes are activated by ADP.  Conversely, because anabolic pathways require ATP and generate ADP, many of the enzymes that catalyze anabolic reactions are activated by ATP and inhibited by ADP.  So, if ATP levels are high and ADP levels are low, you would expect anabolic reactions to proceed quickly. If you have trouble remembering the difference between catabolism and  anabolism, picture a cat tearing something up to remember that catabolism is the breakdown of large, energy-rich  molecules to produce smaller, less energy-rich molecules.  Anabolism is  the opposite (i.e. production of large, energy-rich molecules from  smaller, less complex and less energy-rich molecules).

They do not depend on enzymes

They are usually highly spontaneous chemical reactions

questions.correct_answer: They consume energy to build up polymers from monomers
questions.neutral_comments: Anabolic pathways build polymers from monomers. They are endergonic pathways as the free energy of the products (polymers) is greater than the free energy of the reactants (monomers). As a consequence, anabolic pathways are nonspontaneous pathways that require an energy input, such as from ATP, to occur. The reactions in anabolic pathways are catalyzed by enzymes.
questions.all_comments: Anabolic pathways build polymers from monomers.  They are endergonic pathways as the free energy of the products (polymers) is greater than the free energy of the reactants (monomers).  As a consequence, anabolic pathways are nonspontaneous pathways that require an energy input, such as from ATP, to occur.  The reactions in anabolic pathways are catalyzed by enzymes.

questions.question: In a particular reversible reaction, “A” and “B” may be converted to “C” and “D”, or “C” and “D” may be converted to “A” and “B”. The direction of this reversible reaction will be determined by

answers.text: Both “a” and “b” are correct.
whether the enzyme that catalyzes the reaction catalyzes the forward or reverse reactions
the relative concentrations of “A” and “B” versus “C” and “D”
None of these answers are correct.

questions.correct_answer: the relative concentrations of “A” and “B” versus “C” and “D”
questions.neutral_comments: Enzymes do not alter the free energy change of a reaction and so do not alter the point at which equilibrium will be reached or the overall direction of the reaction. In contrast, the direction of a reversible reaction will be determined by the relative concentrations of the reactants and products of the reactions, together with the difference in the free energies of the reactant and product molecules.
questions.all_comments: Enzymes do not alter the free energy change of a reaction and so do not alter the point at which equilibrium will be reached or the overall direction of the reaction.  In contrast, the direction of a reversible reaction will be determined by the relative concentrations of the reactants and products of the reactions, together with the difference in the free energies of the reactant and product molecules.

questions.question: The enzyme phosphofructokinase catalyzes the conversion of fructose-6-phosphate and adenosine triphosphate (ATP) to fructose 1,6-bisphosphate and adenosine diphosphate (ADP). Adenosine monophosphate (AMP) activates the enzyme phosphofructokinase (PFK) by binding at a site distinct from the substrate-binding site. This is an example of

answers.text: the coupling of exergonic and endergonic reactions
cooperative activation
allosteric activation
activation by an enzyme cofactor

questions.correct_answer: allosteric activation
questions.neutral_comments: In this example, AMP is binding to a site that is distinct from the active site that it is regulating, which is consistent with AMP acting as an allosteric activator. Note that this is NOT an example of cooperative activation, as cooperative activation occurs when binding of a substrate molecule to the active site of one of the subunits in a multi-subunit enzyme changes the conformations of the other subunits such that they are able to bind substrate molecules more easily. In this example, AMP is not a substrate molecule and it is not binding to any of the active sites of phosphfructokinase (which does happen to be a multi-subunit enzyme).
questions.all_comments: In this example, AMP is binding to a site that is distinct from the active site that it is regulating, which is consistent with AMP acting as an allosteric activator.  Note that this is NOT an example of cooperative activation, as cooperative activation occurs when binding of a substrate molecule to the active site of one of the subunits in a multi-subunit enzyme changes the conformations of the other subunits such that they are able to bind substrate molecules more easily.  In this example, AMP is not a substrate molecule and it is not binding to any of the active sites of phosphfructokinase (which does happen to be a multi-subunit enzyme).

questions.question: For the reaction described in the figure shown below, arrow “C” represents

answers.text: The activation energy for the enzyme-catalyzed reaction.
The activation energy for the noncatalyzed reaction.
The decrease in free energy over the course of the reaction
The increase in energy of the products (C and D).

questions.correct_answer: The activation energy for the noncatalyzed reaction.
questions.neutral_comments: Remember that enzymes act by lowering the activation energy barrier. So, the peak of the red curve represents the energy needed to overcome the activation energy barrier in the non-catalyzed reaction and the peak of the black curve represents the amount of energy needed to overcome the activation energy barrier for the enzyme catalyzed reaction. Arrow “B” thus represents the amount of energy molecules A and B need to gain above their normal, average state in order for the enzyme catalyzed reaction to occur. Arrow “C” represents the amount of energy molecules A and B need to gain above their normal, average state in order for the non-catalyzed reaction to occur.

questions.question: You realize that, for a particular reaction to occur, the molecules participating in that reaction need to have a certain minimum free energy level to get over the activation energy barrier. After measuring the average free energy levels of the potential reactant molecules, you discover that their average free energy levels are a little below that required to surmount the activation barrier. Should you be surprised when you then realize that the reaction is occurring, even though it is only occurring at a relatively low rate?

answers.text: No, you should not be surprised because the energy level at the top of the activation barrier represents only an average amount of energy. So, the activation barrier will actually be lower for some of the reactant molecules and higher for others.

No, you should not be surprised because you only measured the average free energy levels of the potential reactant molecules. Some of the molecules likely have more than the average amount of free energy, meaning that they have enough free energy to surmount the activation barrier.
Yes, you should be surprised because the chemical reaction is apparently occurring in violation of the laws of thermodynamics.
Yes, you should be surprised because someone must have published inaccurate data regarding the amount of energy needed to surmount the activation barrier.

questions.correct_answer: No, you should not be surprised because you only measured the average free energy levels of the potential reactant molecules. Some of the molecules likely have more than the average amount of free energy, meaning that they have enough free energy to surmount the activation barrier.
questions.neutral_comments: For a spontaneous reaction to occur, the free energy of the reactant molecules must be sufficient to get over the activation energy barrier. If the activation energy barrier is 7 kcal/mol and the average free energy of the reactant molecules is only 6.9 kcal/mole, the average reactant molecule will have insufficient free energy to get over the activation energy barrier. However, we have to consider that only the AVERAGE free energy of the reactant molecules was measured, and that different reactant molecules in a solution will have slightly different free energy levels. So, some percentage of the reactant molecules will have sufficient free energy to surmount the energy activation barrier.
questions.all_comments: For a spontaneous reaction to occur, the free energy of the reactant molecules must be sufficient to get over the activation energy barrier.  If the activation energy barrier is 7 kcal/mol and the average free energy of the reactant molecules is only 6.9 kcal/mole, the average reactant molecule will have insufficient free energy to get over the activation energy barrier.  However, we have to consider that only the AVERAGE free energy of the reactant molecules was measured, and that different reactant molecules in a solution will have slightly different free energy levels.  So, some percentage of the reactant molecules will have sufficient free energy to surmount the energy activation barrier.

Firefly luciferase catalyzes the reaction:

Luciferase makes the reaction irreversible.

questions.correct_answer: Luciferase lowers the transition energy of the reaction.
questions.neutral_comments: Luciferase is an enzyme. Like all enzymes, luciferase acts by lowering the energy activation barrier necessary for the reaction to occur. questions.all_comments: Luciferase is an enzyme.  Like all enzymes, luciferase acts by lowering the energy activation barrier necessary for the reaction to occur.  As a result, a greater percentage of the substrate molecules will have sufficient energy to surmount the energy activation barrier (i.e. to achieve their highest-energy transition state), allowing the reaction to proceed more quickly.

questions.question: Succinate dehydrogenase catalyzes the conversion of succinate to fumarate. The reaction is inhibited by malonic acid. Increasing the ratio of succinate to malonic acid reduces the inhibitory effect of malonic acid. What role does malonic acid play in this reaction?

answers.text: It is a competitive inhibitor.
It blocks the binding of fumarate.
It is a noncompetitive inhibitor.
It replaces the usual enzyme.

questions.correct_answer: It is a competitive inhibitor.
questions.neutral_comments: Competitive inhibitors compete with substrate (succinate, in this case) molecules for binding to the enzyme’s active site. Adding more substrate (e.g. succinate) molecules will alleviate this type of inhibition. In contrast, noncompetitive inhibitors bind to sites that are distinct from the enyzme’s active site. Increasing the substrate concentration does not alleviate inhibition by a noncompetitive inhibitor.
questions.all_comments: Competitive inhibitors compete with substrate (succinate, in this case) molecules for binding to the enzyme’s active site.  Adding more substrate (e.g. succinate) molecules will alleviate this type of inhibition.  In contrast, noncompetitive inhibitors bind to sites that are distinct from the enyzme’s active site.  Increasing the substrate concentration does not alleviate inhibition by a noncompetitive inhibitor.

questions.question: Binding of an allosteric regulator to the enzyme it regulates

answers.text: is irreversible.
may occur via ionic bonds
is at the enzyme’s active site.
may occur via covalent bonds.

questions.correct_answer: may occur via ionic bonds
questions.neutral_comments: By definition, allosteric regulators bind enzymes at locations that are distinct from the enzyme’s active site. Binding of allosteric regulators to enzymes is via noncovalent bonds, such as ionic or hydrogen bonds. The binding of an allosteric regulator to an enzyme is always reversible. This is in contrast to noncompetitive inhibitors, which may bind an enzyme via noncovalent bonds and usually bind irreversibly to enzymes. Noncompetitive inhibitors and allosteric regulators do share the trait that they bind at a site that is distinct from the active site they are reuglating.
questions.all_comments: By definition, allosteric regulators bind enzymes at locations that are distinct from the enzyme’s active site.  Binding of allosteric regulators to enzymes is via noncovalent bonds, such as ionic or hydrogen bonds.  The binding of an allosteric regulator to an enzyme is always reversible.  This is in contrast to noncompetitive inhibitors, which may bind an enzyme via noncovalent bonds and usually bind irreversibly to enzymes.  Noncompetitive inhibitors and allosteric regulators do share the trait that they bind at a site that is distinct from the active site they are reuglating.

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to lead to an increase in the concentration of ATP in a cell?

answers.text: a decrease in a cell’s catabolic activity
an increased amino acid concentration
a decrease in a cell’s anabolic activity
an increased flux of cofactor molecules

questions.correct_answer: a decrease in a cell’s anabolic activity
questions.neutral_comments: Anabolic, or biosynthetic, reactions use energy from ATP to form larger, more complex and energy-rich, molecules from smaller, less complex and energy rich, molecules. So, decreasing the rate of anabolic reactions would decrease the rate at which ATP is being used up, allowing ATP concentrations in the cell to increase.
questions.all_comments: Catabolic reactions are reactions where larger, more energy-rich molecules are broken down to smaller, less energy-rich molecules (remember a cat tearing something up).  Some of the energy stored in the energy-rich molecules is used to generate more ATP, which is an energy rich molecule.  So, decreasing catabolism would mean decreasing ATP levels.Anabolic, or biosynthetic, reactions use energy from ATP to form larger, more complex and energy-rich, molecules from smaller, less complex and energy rich, molecules.  So, decreasing the rate of anabolic reactions would decrease the rate at which ATP is being used up, allowing ATP concentrations in the cell to increase.

questions.all_comments: Catabolic reactions are reactions where complex, energy rich, molecules are broken down to smaller, less complex and energy rich, molecules.  Some of the energy from catabolic reactions is used to form ATP.

questions.question: In a particular reversible reaction, “A” and “B” may be converted to “C” and “D”, or “C” and “D” may be converted to “A” and “B”. The direction of this reversible reaction will be determined by

answers.text: None of these answers are correct.
whether the enzyme that catalyzes the reaction catalyzes the forward or reverse reactions
the relative concentrations of “A” and “B” versus “C” and “D”
Both “a” and “b” are correct.

questions.correct_answer: the relative concentrations of “A” and “B” versus “C” and “D”
questions.neutral_comments: Enzymes do not alter the free energy change of a reaction and so do not alter the point at which equilibrium will be reached or the overall direction of the reaction. In contrast, the direction of a reversible reaction will be determined by the relative concentrations of the reactants and products of the reactions, together with the difference in the free energies of the reactant and product molecules.
questions.all_comments: Enzymes do not alter the free energy change of a reaction and so do not alter the point at which equilibrium will be reached or the overall direction of the reaction.  In contrast, the direction of a reversible reaction will be determined by the relative concentrations of the reactants and products of the reactions, together with the difference in the free energies of the reactant and product molecules.

questions.question:
Firefly luciferase catalyzes the reaction:



What is the role of luciferase?

answers.text: Luciferase makes the reaction irreversible.
Luciferase makes the ∆G of the reaction more negative.
Luciferase lowers the transition energy of the reaction.
Luciferase alters the equilibrium point of the reaction.

questions.correct_answer: Luciferase lowers the transition energy of the reaction.
questions.neutral_comments: Luciferase is an enzyme. Like all enzymes, luciferase acts by lowering the energy activation barrier necessary for the reaction to occur. As a result, a greater percentage of the substrate molecules will have sufficient energy to surmount the energy activation barrier (i.e. to achieve their highest-energy transition state), allowing the reaction to proceed more quickly.
questions.all_comments: Luciferase is an enzyme.  Like all enzymes, luciferase acts by lowering the energy activation barrier necessary for the reaction to occur.  As a result, a greater percentage of the substrate molecules will have sufficient energy to surmount the energy activation barrier (i.e. to achieve their highest-energy transition state), allowing the reaction to proceed more quickly.

questions.question: For the reaction depicted in the figure below, the activation energy barrier for converting C and D to A and B via the enzyme catalyzed reaction is represented by

questions.neutral_comments: Remember that the activation energy barrier is the energy needed for molecules to achieve their highest energy transition state. In this diagram, the average energy of molecules of C + D in their non-transition state is indicated by the bottom of arrow A and the energy of molecules of C + D in their transition state during the enzyme catalyzed reaction is indicated by the top of arrow A. Arrow A thus indicates the activation energy barrier that would need to be overcome for C and D to be converted to A and B via an enzyme catalyzed reaction.
questions.all_comments: Remember that the activation energy barrier is the energy needed for molecules to achieve their highest energy transition state.  In this diagram, the average energy of molecules of C + D in their non-transition state is indicated by the bottom of arrow A and the energy of molecules of C + D in their transition state during the enzyme catalyzed reaction is indicated by the top of arrow A.  Arrow A thus indicates the activation energy barrier that would need to be overcome for C and D to be converted to A and B via an enzyme catalyzed reaction.

questions.question: If an enzyme is added to a solution where its substrate and product are in equilibrium, what will occur?

answers.text: Nothing; the reaction will stay at equilibrium.
The free energy of the system will change.
Additional product will be formed.
The reaction will change from endergonic to exergonic.

questions.correct_answer: Nothing; the reaction will stay at equilibrium.
questions.neutral_comments: Enzymes do not alter the free energy change of a reaction. Instead, they speed up the rate at which reactions occur by lowering the activation energy barrier. Because enzymes do not change the free energies of the reactant or product molecules, enzymes do not alter the point at which reactants and products will be in equilibrium.
questions.all_comments: Enzymes do not alter the free energy change of a reaction.  Instead, they speed up the rate at which reactions occur by lowering the activation energy barrier.  Because enzymes do not change the free energies of the reactant or product molecules, enzymes do not alter the point at which reactants and products will be in equilibrium.

questions.question: In contrast to non-competitive inhibitors, competitive inhibitors of enzyme activity

answers.text: can NOT have their effects reversed by addition of more substrate.
always utilize an enzyme's active site.
cause enzymes to denature.
act allosterically.

questions.correct_answer: always utilize an enzyme's active site.
questions.neutral_comments: Competitive inhibitors “compete” with substrate molecules for binding to the enzyme’s active site. Addition of more substrate does, therefore, help reverse the effects of a competitive inhibitor by allowing the increased number of substrate molecules to occupy the active sites of more of the enzyme molecules. Because competitive inhibitors bind at the enzyme’s active site, they are by definition NOT allosteric regulators, because the definition of an allosteric regulator is a regulator that binds at a site that is distinct from the enzyme’s active site.
questions.all_comments: Competitive inhibitors “compete” with substrate molecules for binding to the enzyme’s active site.  Addition of more substrate does, therefore, help reverse the effects of a competitive inhibitor by allowing the increased number of substrate molecules to occupy the active sites of more of the enzyme molecules.  Because competitive inhibitors bind at the enzyme’s active site, they are by definition NOT allosteric regulators, because the definition of an allosteric regulator is a regulator that binds at a site that is distinct from the enzyme’s active site.

questions.question: If ATP levels increase and ADP levels decrease

answers.text: The rates of many anabolic reactions will increase due to increased allosteric activation by ATP.
All of these answers are correct.
The rates of many anabolic reactions will increase due to decreased allosteric inhibition by ADP.
The rates of many catabolic reactions will decrease due to increased allosteric inhibition by ATP.

questions.correct_answer: All of these answers are correct.
questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP. If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point. As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP. For a similar reason, many catabolic enzymes are activated by ADP. Conversely, because anabolic pathways require ATP and generate ADP, many of the enzymes that catalyze anabolic reactions are activated by ATP and inhibited by ADP.
questions.all_comments: Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP.  If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point.  As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP.  For a similar reason, many catabolic enzymes are activated by ADP.  Conversely, because anabolic pathways require ATP and generate ADP, many of the enzymes that catalyze anabolic reactions are activated by ATP and inhibited by ADP.

questions.question: You realize that, for a particular reaction to occur, the molecules participating in that reaction need to have a certain minimum free energy level to get over the activation energy barrier. After measuring the average free energy levels of the potential reactant molecules, you discover that their average free energy levels are a little below that required to surmount the activation barrier. Should you be surprised when you then realize that the reaction is occurring, even though it is only occurring at a relatively low rate?

answers.text: Yes, you should be surprised because someone must have published inaccurate data regarding the amount of energy needed to surmount the activation barrier.

No, you should not be surprised because the energy level at the top of the activation barrier represents only an average amount of energy. So, the activation barrier will actually be lower for some of the reactant molecules and higher for others.
Yes, you should be surprised because the chemical reaction is apparently occurring in violation of the laws of thermodynamics.

No, you should not be surprised because you only measured the average free energy levels of the potential reactant molecules. Some of the molecules likely have more than the average amount of free energy, meaning that they have enough free energy to surmount the activation barrier.

questions.correct_answer: No, you should not be surprised because you only measured the average free energy levels of the potential reactant molecules. Some of the molecules likely have more than the average amount of free energy, meaning that they have enough free energy to surmount the activation barrier.
questions.neutral_comments: For a spontaneous reaction to occur, the free energy of the reactant molecules must be sufficient to get over the activation energy barrier. If the activation energy barrier is 7 kcal/mol and the average free energy of the reactant molecules is only 6.9 kcal/mole, the average reactant molecule will have insufficient free energy to get over the activation energy barrier. However, we have to consider that only the AVERAGE free energy of the reactant molecules was measured, and that different reactant molecules in a solution will have slightly different free energy levels. So, some percentage of the reactant molecules will have sufficient free energy to surmount the energy activation barrier.
questions.all_comments: For a spontaneous reaction to occur, the free energy of the reactant molecules must be sufficient to get over the activation energy barrier.  If the activation energy barrier is 7 kcal/mol and the average free energy of the reactant molecules is only 6.9 kcal/mole, the average reactant molecule will have insufficient free energy to get over the activation energy barrier.  However, we have to consider that only the AVERAGE free energy of the reactant molecules was measured, and that different reactant molecules in a solution will have slightly different free energy levels.  So, some percentage of the reactant molecules will have sufficient free energy to surmount the energy activation barrier.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is representative of the second law of thermodynamics?

answers.text: Cells require a constant input of energy to maintain their high level of organization.
Without an input of energy, organisms would tend toward decreasing entropy.
Every energy transformation by a cell decreases the entropy of the universe.
Conversion of energy from one form to another is always accompanied by some gain of free energy.

questions.correct_answer: Cells require a constant input of energy to maintain their high level of organization.
questions.neutral_comments: According to the 2nd law of thermodynamics the entropy of the universe as a whole is always increasing. Living organisms, such as cells, are able to use energy inputs to maintain a high level of order, and thus a low level of entropy. However, by doing this living organisms cause an increase in the entropy of their surroundings that more than compensates for the decrease in entropy within the organism. So, the total amount of entropy within the universe increases and the 2ndlaw of thermodynamics is not violated.
questions.all_comments: According to the 2nd law of thermodynamics the entropy of the universe as a whole is always increasing.  Living organisms, such as cells, are able to use energy inputs to maintain a high level of order, and thus a low level of entropy.  However, by doing this living organisms cause an increase in the entropy of their surroundings that more than compensates for the decrease in entropy within the organism.  So, the total amount of entropy within the universe increases and the 2ndlaw of thermodynamics is not violated.

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE for ALL exergonic reactions?

questions.neutral_comments: By definition, exergonic reactions are reactions where the reaction results in a decrease in free energy. In contrast, it is possible for an exergonic reaction to result in an increase in the TOTAL energy of the system. For that to occur, the increase in the total energy of the system must be more than offset by an increase in entropy. Because exergonic reactions are reactions that result in a decrease in free energy, there is no need for an energy input in order for an exergonic reaction to occur.
questions.all_comments: By definition, exergonic reactions are reactions where the reaction results in a decrease in free energy.  In contrast, it is possible for an exergonic reaction to result in an increase in the TOTAL energy of the system.  For that to occur, the increase in the total energy of the system must be more than offset by an increase in entropy. Because exergonic reactions are reactions that result in a decrease in free energy, there is no need for an energy input in order for an exergonic reaction to occur.

questions.question: How does a noncompetitive inhibitor decrease the rate of an enzyme reaction?

Because enzymes do not alter the free energies of reactant or product molecules and thus do not alter the change in free energy that occurs as a result of the reaction, the factors that alter enzyme activities (e.g. noncompetitive inhibitors) also do not do these things. Instead, a non-competitive inhibitor makes it more difficult for an enzyme to lower the activation energy barrier. In other words, the activation energy barrier in the presence of enzyme + noncompetitive inhibitor is higher than in the presence of enzyme alone.

Instead, a non-competitive inhibitor makes it more difficult for an enzyme to lower the activation energy barrier.  In other words, the activation energy barrier in the presence of enzyme + noncompetitive inhibitor is higher than in the presence of enzyme alone.

questions.question: High levels of citric acid inhibit the enzyme phosphofructokinase, a key enzyme in glycolysis. Citric acid binds to the enzyme at a different location from the active site. This is an example of

questions.question: You realize that, for a particular reaction to occur, the molecules participating in that reaction need to have a certain minimum free energy level to get over the activation energy barrier. After measuring the average free energy levels of the potential reactant molecules, you discover that their average free energy levels are a little below that required to surmount the activation barrier. Should you be surprised when you then realize that the reaction is occurring, even though it is only occurring at a relatively low rate?

answers.text: Yes, you should be surprised because someone must have published inaccurate data regarding the amount of energy needed to surmount the activation barrier.

No, you should not be surprised because the energy level at the top of the activation barrier represents only an average amount of energy. So, the activation barrier will actually be lower for some of the reactant molecules and higher for others.

No, you should not be surprised because you only measured the average free energy levels of the potential reactant molecules. Some of the molecules likely have more than the average amount of free energy, meaning that they have enough free energy to surmount the activation barrier.
Yes, you should be surprised because the chemical reaction is apparently occurring in violation of the laws of thermodynamics.

questions.correct_answer: No, you should not be surprised because you only measured the average free energy levels of the potential reactant molecules. Some of the molecules likely have more than the average amount of free energy, meaning that they have enough free energy to surmount the activation barrier.
questions.neutral_comments: For a spontaneous reaction to occur, the free energy of the reactant molecules must be sufficient to get over the activation energy barrier. If the activation energy barrier is 7 kcal/mol and the average free energy of the reactant molecules is only 6.9 kcal/mole, the average reactant molecule will have insufficient free energy to get over the activation energy barrier. However, we have to consider that only the AVERAGE free energy of the reactant molecules was measured, and that different reactant molecules in a solution will have slightly different free energy levels. So, some percentage of the reactant molecules will have sufficient free energy to surmount the energy activation barrier.
questions.all_comments: For a spontaneous reaction to occur, the free energy of the reactant molecules must be sufficient to get over the activation energy barrier.  If the activation energy barrier is 7 kcal/mol and the average free energy of the reactant molecules is only 6.9 kcal/mole, the average reactant molecule will have insufficient free energy to get over the activation energy barrier.  However, we have to consider that only the AVERAGE free energy of the reactant molecules was measured, and that different reactant molecules in a solution will have slightly different free energy levels.  So, some percentage of the reactant molecules will have sufficient free energy to surmount the energy activation barrier.

questions.question: Hair is extremely flammable, so why doesn’t your hair spontaneously burst into flame?

answers.text: Since your hair is generally a mess, burning it would result in a decrease in the total entropy of the universe, which would be a violation of the second law of thermodynamics.
Burning hair is an endergonic reaction that requires energy from fire to drive it.
The molecules in your hair lack sufficient energy at room temperature to overcome the activation energy barrier for this reaction.
Burning hair is an exergonic reaction that requires energy from fire to drive it.

questions.correct_answer: The molecules in your hair lack sufficient energy at room temperature to overcome the activation energy barrier for this reaction.
questions.neutral_comments: Remember that, although exergonic reactions are also known as “spontaneous” reactions, the fact that a reaction is “spontaneous” does not mean that it will occur quickly or even that it will occur at all. Exergonic, or spontaneous, reactions are defined as reactions where the free energies of the reactant molecules are higher than the free energies of the product molecules. So, if the reaction occurs, there will be a net decrease in free energy. HOWEVER, for a reaction to occur the chemical bonds in the reactant molecules must be “stretched” into higher energy forms, so that the reactant molecules reach what is known as a “transition state”. The free energies of the reactant molecules in their transition states are higher than the free energies of the reactant molecules in their non-transition states. So, the reactant molecules may not have sufficient energy to achieve their transition states. If that is the case, the reaction will not proceed even though the overall effect of the reaction would be a decrease in free energy. Note that adding energy to some of the reactant molecules, so that those molecules are able to undergo the reaction, will result in a release of energy that may result in more reactant molecules having sufficient energy to surmount the activation energy barrier and undergo the reaction, leading to a further release in energy that allows more reactant molecules to undergo the reaction, and so on. In other words, once a reaction gets going, it may keep going. So, once hair catches fire it will continue to burn.
questions.all_comments: Nice work!Remember that, although exergonic reactions are also known as “spontaneous” reactions, the fact that a reaction is “spontaneous” does not mean that it will occur quickly or even that it will occur at all.  Exergonic, or spontaneous, reactions are defined as reactions where the free energies of the reactant molecules are higher than the free energies of the product molecules.  So, if the reaction occurs, there will be a net decrease in free energy.  HOWEVER, for a reaction to occur the chemical bonds in the reactant molecules must be “stretched” into higher energy forms, so that the reactant molecules reach what is known as a “transition state”.  The free energies of the reactant molecules in their transition states are higher than the free energies of the reactant molecules in their non-transition states.  So, the reactant molecules may not have sufficient energy to achieve their transition states.  If that is the case, the reaction will not proceed even though the overall effect of the reaction would be a decrease in free energy.  Note that adding energy to some of the reactant molecules, so that those molecules are able to undergo the reaction, will result in a release of energy that may result in more reactant molecules having sufficient energy to surmount the activation energy barrier and undergo the reaction, leading to a further release in energy that allows more reactant molecules to undergo the reaction, and so on.  In other words, once a reaction gets going, it may keep going.  So, once hair catches fire it will continue to burn.
