questions.question: How does a noncompetitive inhibitor decrease the rate of an enzyme reaction?

answers.text: by changing the free energy of the products
by increasing the activation energy barrier of the reaction
by changing the free energy of the reactants
by changing the free energy of the reaction

questions.correct_answer: by increasing the activation energy barrier of the reaction
questions.neutral_comments: Enzymes work by altering the activation energy barrier of reactions. Enzymes do not alter the free energies of reactant or product molecules and thus do not alter the change in free energy that occurs as a result of the reaction. Because enzymes do not alter the free energies of reactant or product molecules and thus do not alter the change in free energy that occurs as a result of the reaction, the factors that alter enzyme activities (e.g. noncompetitive inhibitors) also do not do these things. Instead, a non-competitive inhibitor makes it more difficult for an enzyme to lower the activation energy barrier. In other words, the activation energy barrier in the presence of enzyme + noncompetitive inhibitor is higher than in the presence of enzyme alone.
questions.all_comments: Nice work!Enzymes work by altering the activation energy barrier of reactions.  Enzymes do not alter the free energies of reactant or product molecules and thus do not alter the change in free energy that occurs as a result of the reaction.  Because enzymes do not alter the free energies of reactant or product molecules and thus do not alter the change in free energy that occurs as a result of the reaction, the factors that alter enzyme activities (e.g. noncompetitive inhibitors) also do not do these things. Instead, a non-competitive inhibitor makes it more difficult for an enzyme to lower the activation energy barrier.  In other words, the activation energy barrier in the presence of enzyme + noncompetitive inhibitor is higher than in the presence of enzyme alone.

questions.question: If an enzyme is added to a solution where its substrate and product are in equilibrium, what will occur?

answers.text: The free energy of the system will change.
Additional product will be formed.
The reaction will change from endergonic to exergonic.
Nothing; the reaction will stay at equilibrium.

questions.correct_answer: Nothing; the reaction will stay at equilibrium.
questions.neutral_comments: Enzymes do not alter the free energy change of a reaction. Instead, they speed up the rate at which reactions occur by lowering the activation energy barrier. Because enzymes do not change the free energies of the reactant or product molecules, enzymes do not alter the point at which reactants and products will be in equilibrium.
questions.all_comments: Nice work!Enzymes do not alter the free energy change of a reaction.  Instead, they speed up the rate at which reactions occur by lowering the activation energy barrier.  Because enzymes do not change the free energies of the reactant or product molecules, enzymes do not alter the point at which reactants and products will be in equilibrium.

questions.neutral_comments: Feedback inhibition occurs when an end product of a metabolic pathway binds to, and inhibits, one of the enzymes that catalyzes an early step in that pathway. Feedback inhibition is thus used as a mechanism to slow down pathways that are producing product molecules more quickly than they are needed, so that the product molecules are accumulating in the cell.
questions.all_comments: Good job!Feedback inhibition occurs when an end product of a metabolic pathway binds to, and inhibits, one of the enzymes that catalyzes an early step in that pathway.  Feedback inhibition is thus used as a mechanism to slow down pathways that are producing product molecules more quickly than they are needed, so that the product molecules are accumulating in the cell.

questions.question: The mathematical expression for the change in the free energy of a system is ∆G = ∆H – T∆S. Which of the following is (are) TRUE?

answers.text: ∆G is the change in entropy.
∆S is the change in free energy.

questions.correct_answer: ∆H is the change in enthalpy.
questions.neutral_comments: ∆G = the change in the Gibb’s free energy of the system. ∆H = the change in the enthalpy of the system. T = the temperature of the system in degrees Kelvin (zero degrees Kelvin = -273 °C. Zero degrees Kelvin corresponds to the theoretical temperature at which entropy reaches a minimum). ∆S = the change in the entropy of the system.
questions.all_comments: ∆G = the change in the Gibb’s free energy of the system.  ∆H = the change in the enthalpy of the system.  T = the temperature of the system in degrees Kelvin (zero degrees Kelvin = -273 °C.  Zero degrees Kelvin corresponds to the theoretical temperature at which entropy reaches a minimum).  ∆S = the change in the entropy of the system.

questions.question: Living organisms increase in complexity as they grow, resulting in a decrease in the entropy of an organism. How does this relate to the second law of thermodynamics?

answers.text: Living organisms do not follow the laws of thermodynamics.
Living organisms create lots of entropy after they die and the molecules in their bodies dissociate, which makes up for the decrease in entropy created while they were alive.
As a consequence of growing, organisms create more disorder in their environment than the decrease in entropy associated with their growth.
As a consequence of growing, organisms create an amount of disorder in their environment that is equal to the decrease in entropy associated with their growth.

questions.correct_answer: As a consequence of growing, organisms create more disorder in their environment than the decrease in entropy associated with their growth.
questions.neutral_comments: The decrease in entropy within the organism is more than balanced by an even greater increase in the entropy of their surroundings. So, living organisms do not violate the 2nd law of thermodynamics as the processes carried out by living organisms increase the amount of entropy in the universe as a whole.
questions.all_comments: The decrease in entropy within the organism is more than balanced by an even greater increase in the entropy of their surroundings.  So, living organisms do not violate the 2nd law of thermodynamics as the processes carried out by living organisms increase the amount of entropy in the universe as a whole.

questions.question: How do living organisms create macromolecules, organelles, cells, tissues, and complex higher-order structures?

answers.text: The laws of thermodynamics do not apply to living organisms.
Living organisms create order by using energy from the sun.
Living organisms create order locally, but the energy transformations generate waste heat that increases the entropy of the universe as a whole.
Living organisms create order using energy from food molecules.

questions.correct_answer: Living organisms create order locally, but the energy transformations generate waste heat that increases the entropy of the universe as a whole.
questions.neutral_comments: The 2nd law of thermodynamics states that the entropy of the universe as a whole must increase. If the entropy of a cell decreases, that decrease can be made up for by an even greater increase in the entropy of the environment around the cell, so that the total amount of entropy in the universe increases.
questions.all_comments: The 2nd law of thermodynamics states that the entropy of the universe as a whole must increase.  If the entropy of a cell decreases, that decrease can be made up for by an even greater increase in the entropy of the environment around the cell, so that the total amount of entropy in the universe increases.

questions.question: You notice that many of the catabolic reactions in a cell have speeded up. Upon further characterization of the cell, you are NOT surprised to find that

answers.text: both the ATP and ADP levels in the cell are low.
the ATP levels in the cell are high and the ADP levels are low.
the ATP levels in the cell are low and the ADP levels are high.
both the ATP and ADP levels in the cell are high.

questions.correct_answer: the ATP levels in the cell are low and the ADP levels are high.
questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP. If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point. As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP. For a similar reason, many catabolic enzymes are activated by ADP. So, if ATP levels in the cell are low and ADP levels are high, you would expect catabolic reactions to proceed quickly.If you have trouble remembering the difference between catabolism and anabolism, picture a cat tearing something up to remember that catabolism is the breakdown of large, energy-rich molecules to produce smaller, less energy-rich molecules. Anabolism is the opposite (i.e. production of large, energy-rich molecules from smaller, less complex and less energy-rich molecules).
questions.all_comments: Good job!Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP.  If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point.  As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP.  For a similar reason, many catabolic enzymes are activated by ADP.  So, if ATP levels in the cell are low and ADP levels are high, you would expect catabolic reactions to proceed quickly.If you have trouble remembering the difference between catabolism and anabolism, picture a cat tearing something up to remember that catabolism is the breakdown of large, energy-rich molecules to produce smaller, less energy-rich molecules.  Anabolism is the opposite (i.e. production of large, energy-rich molecules from smaller, less complex and less energy-rich molecules).

questions.question: You notice that many of the anabolic reactions in a cell have speeded up. Upon further characterization of the cell, you are NOT surprised to find that

answers.text: the ATP levels in the cell are low and the ADP levels are high.
the ATP levels in the cell are high and the ADP levels are low.
both the ATP and ADP levels in the cell are low.
both the ATP and ADP levels in the cell are high.

questions.correct_answer: the ATP levels in the cell are high and the ADP levels are low.
questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP. If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point. As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP. For a similar reason, many catabolic enzymes are activated by ADP. Conversely, because anabolic pathways require ATP and generate ADP, many of the enzymes that catalyze anabolic reactions are activated by ATP and inhibited by ADP. So, if ATP levels are high and ADP levels are low, you would expect anabolic reactions to proceed quickly. If you have trouble remembering the difference between catabolism and anabolism, picture a cat tearing something up to remember that catabolism is the breakdown of large, energy-rich molecules to produce smaller, less energy-rich molecules. Anabolism is the opposite (i.e. production of large, energy-rich molecules from smaller, less complex and less energy-rich molecules).

questions.question: When ATP releases some energy, it also releases inorganic phosphate. What purpose, if any, does this serve in the cell?

answers.text: It is released as excretory waste.
It can only be used to generate more ATP.
It can be added to other molecules in order to activate them.
It can enter the nucleus and affect gene expression.

questions.correct_answer: It can be added to other molecules in order to activate them.
questions.neutral_comments: The third phosphate in ATP is often transferred to other molecules. Because the covalent bond between the phosphate and the rest of the molecule is a high-energy bond, phosphorylation of a molecule raises the free energy of that molecule. Raising the free energy of a molecule makes it more likely that it can participate in exergonic (spontaneous) reactions as a reactant, since it makes it more likely that the combined free energies of the reactant molecules will be greater than the combined free energies of the product molecules.
questions.all_comments: The third phosphate in ATP is often transferred to other molecules.  Because the covalent bond between the phosphate and the rest of the molecule is a high-energy bond, phosphorylation of a molecule raises the free energy of that molecule.  Raising the free energy of a molecule makes it more likely that it can participate in exergonic (spontaneous) reactions as a reactant, since it makes it more likely that the combined free energies of the reactant molecules will be greater than the combined free energies of the product molecules.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of potential rather than kinetic energy?

an increase in air temperature as a meteor passes through the atmosphere
a food molecule

questions.correct_answer: a food molecule
questions.neutral_comments: Kinetic energy is energy due to movement whereas potential energy is energy that is stored in matter that is not due to movement. So, a food molecule has potential energy as a result of the energy stored in the chemical bonds holding together the atoms that form that molecule.
questions.all_comments: Kinetic energy is energy due to movement whereas potential energy is energy that is stored in matter that is not due to movement.  So, a food molecule has potential energy as a result of the energy stored in the chemical bonds holding together the atoms that form that molecule.

questions.question: During a laboratory experiment you discover that an enzyme-catalyzed reaction has a delta G of -20 kcal/mol. If you double the amount of enzyme in the reaction, what will be the delta G for the new reaction?

answers.text: +20 kcal/mole
-40 kcal/mole
+40 kcal/mole
-20 kcal/mole

questions.correct_answer: -20 kcal/mole
questions.neutral_comments: Because enzymes do not change the free energy change of a reaction, delta G will still be -20 kcal/mole. Please note that enzymes DO lower the energy activation barrier, which is the energy barrier that reactant molecules must surmount in order for a reaction to occur. But, enzymes do not change the free energy in the reactant or product molecules and thus do not change the difference between the free energies of the reactant and product molecules.
questions.all_comments: Nice job!Because enzymes do not change the free energy change of a reaction, delta G will still be -20 kcal/mole.  Please note that enzymes DO lower the energy activation barrier, which is the energy barrier that reactant molecules must surmount in order for a reaction to occur.  But, enzymes do not change the free energy in the reactant or product molecules and thus do not change the difference between the free energies of the reactant and product molecules.

questions.question: Increasing the substrate concentration in an enzymatic reaction could overcome which of the following?

answers.text: insufficient cofactors
allosteric inhibition
competitive inhibition
denaturization of the enzyme

questions.correct_answer: competitive inhibition
questions.neutral_comments: Competitive inhibition occurs when an inhibitor competes with substrate molecules for binding to the active site of the enzyme. Increasing the concentration of substrate molecules will help them out compete a competitive inhibitor. In contrast, allosteric inhibitors bind to sites on the enzyme that are distinct from the active site. So, increasing the concentration of substrate molecules will not alleviate allosteric inhibition.
questions.all_comments: Nice job!Competitive inhibition occurs when an inhibitor competes with substrate molecules for binding to the active site of the enzyme.  Increasing the concentration of substrate molecules will help them out compete a competitive inhibitor.  In contrast, allosteric inhibitors bind to sites on the enzyme that are distinct from the active site.  So, increasing the concentration of substrate molecules will not alleviate allosteric inhibition.

questions.question: If ATP levels increase and ADP levels decrease

answers.text: The rates of many catabolic reactions will decrease due to decreased allosteric activation by ADP.
All of these answers are correct.
The rates of many catabolic reactions will decrease due to increased allosteric inhibition by ATP.
The rates of many anabolic reactions will increase due to increased allosteric activation by ATP.

questions.correct_answer: All of these answers are correct.
questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP. If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point. As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP. For a similar reason, many catabolic enzymes are activated by ADP. Conversely, because anabolic pathways require ATP and generate ADP, many of the enzymes that catalyze anabolic reactions are activated by ATP and inhibited by ADP.
questions.all_comments: Good job!Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP.  If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point.  As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP.  For a similar reason, many catabolic enzymes are activated by ADP.  Conversely, because anabolic pathways require ATP and generate ADP, many of the enzymes that catalyze anabolic reactions are activated by ATP and inhibited by ADP.

questions.question: Which of the following is the best explanation for how enzymes speed up the rates of reactions?

answers.text: Enzymes lower the free energy change of the reaction.
Enzymes lower the energy required for reactant molecules to reach their transition state. Enzymes do not alter the free or total energies of the reactant or product molecules.
Enzymes increase the enthalpy of the reactant molecules.
Enzymes increase the energy of the reactant molecules.

questions.correct_answer: Enzymes lower the energy required for reactant molecules to reach their transition state. Enzymes do not alter the free or total energies of the reactant or product molecules.
questions.neutral_comments: Enzymes lower the free energy needed for reactant molecules to achieve their transition states, which is another way of saying that enzymes lower the activation energy barrier.
questions.all_comments: Good job!Enzymes lower the free energy needed for reactant molecules to achieve their transition states, which is another way of saying that enzymes lower the activation energy barrier.

questions.question: How do living organisms create macromolecules, organelles, cells, tissues, and complex higher-order structures?

answers.text: Living organisms create order by using energy from the sun.
The laws of thermodynamics do not apply to living organisms.
Living organisms create order locally, but the energy transformations generate waste heat that increases the entropy of the universe as a whole.
Living organisms create order using energy from food molecules.

questions.correct_answer: Living organisms create order locally, but the energy transformations generate waste heat that increases the entropy of the universe as a whole.
questions.neutral_comments: The 2nd law of thermodynamics states that the entropy of the universe as a whole must increase. If the entropy of a cell decreases, that decrease can be made up for by an even greater increase in the entropy of the environment around the cell, so that the total amount of entropy in the universe increases.
questions.all_comments: The 2nd law of thermodynamics states that the entropy of the universe as a whole must increase.  If the entropy of a cell decreases, that decrease can be made up for by an even greater increase in the entropy of the environment around the cell, so that the total amount of entropy in the universe increases.

questions.question: At zero degrees Kelvin, in theory,

(In classical theory it was considered the temperature at which molecular motion ceases, but we now know that’s not accurate). 0 degrees Kelvin = -273° C, so both water and you would definitely be frozen solid at that temperature!
questions.all_comments: 0 degrees Kelvin is known as “absolute zero”.  It corresponds to the theoretical temperature at which entropy reaches its minimum value.  (In classical theory it was considered the temperature at which molecular motion ceases, but we now know that’s not accurate).  0 degrees Kelvin = -273° C, so both water and you would definitely be frozen solid at that temperature!

questions.question: The oxidation of glucose to CO<sub>2</sub> and H<sub>2</sub>O is highly exergonic: ∆G = -636 kcal/mol. Why doesn’t glucose spontaneously combust?

answers.text: There is too much CO2 in the air.
CO2 has higher energy than glucose.
The water molecules quench the reaction.
The glucose molecules lack the activation energy at room temperature.

questions.correct_answer: The glucose molecules lack the activation energy at room temperature.
questions.neutral_comments: Remember that, although exergonic reactions are also known as “spontaneous” reactions, the fact that a reaction is “spontaneous” does not mean that it will occur quickly or even that it will occur at all. Exergonic, or spontaneous, reactions are defined as reactions where the free energies of the reactant molecules are higher than the free energies of the product molecules. So, if the reaction occurs, there will be a net decrease in free energy. HOWEVER, for a reaction to occur the chemical bonds in the reactant molecules must be “stretched” into higher energy forms, so that the reactant molecules reach what is known as a “transition state”. The free energies of the reactant molecules in their transition states are higher than the free energies of the reactant molecules in their non-transition states. So, the reactant molecules may not have sufficient energy to achieve their transition states. If that is the case, the reaction will not proceed even though the overall effect of the reaction would be a decrease in free energy. Note that adding energy to some of the reactant molecules, so that those molecules are able to undergo the reaction, will result in a release of energy that may result in more reactant molecules having sufficient energy to surmount the activation energy barrier and undergo the reaction, leading to a further release in energy that allows more reactant molecules to undergo the reaction, and so on. In other words, once a reaction gets going, it may keep going.
questions.all_comments: Remember that, although exergonic reactions are also known as “spontaneous” reactions, the fact that a reaction is “spontaneous” does not mean that it will occur quickly or even that it will occur at all.  Exergonic, or spontaneous, reactions are defined as reactions where the free energies of the reactant molecules are higher than the free energies of the product molecules.  So, if the reaction occurs, there will be a net decrease in free energy.  HOWEVER, for a reaction to occur the chemical bonds in the reactant molecules must be “stretched” into higher energy forms, so that the reactant molecules reach what is known as a “transition state”.  The free energies of the reactant molecules in their transition states are higher than the free energies of the reactant molecules in their non-transition states.  So, the reactant molecules may not have sufficient energy to achieve their transition states.  If that is the case, the reaction will not proceed even though the overall effect of the reaction would be a decrease in free energy.  Note that adding energy to some of the reactant molecules, so that those molecules are able to undergo the reaction, will result in a release of energy that may result in more reactant molecules having sufficient energy to surmount the activation energy barrier and undergo the reaction, leading to a further release in energy that allows more reactant molecules to undergo the reaction, and so on.  In other words, once a reaction gets going, it may keep going.

questions.all_comments: Exergonic reactions are reactions that result in a decrease in free energy.  Exergonic reactions occur when the total free energy of the reactants is greater than the total free energy of the products.  ATP molecules have a lot of free energy, more than the ADP produced by their hydrolysis.

questions.question: Vioxx and other prescription nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are potent inhibitors of the cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) enzyme. High substrate concentrations reduce the efficacy of inhibition by these drugs. These drugs are

answers.text: allosteric regulators
competitive inhibitors
feedback inhibitors
noncompetitive inhibitors

questions.correct_answer: competitive inhibitors
questions.neutral_comments: Competitive inhibitors act by competing (hence the name “competitive” inhibitor) with substrate molecules for binding at the enzyme’s active site. Because of their mechanism of action, the effects of competitive inhibitors may be alleviated by increasing the concentration of substrate molecules, allowing the substrate molecules to occupy a higher percentage of the active sites of the enzyme molecules. Because high substrate concentrations reduce the efficacy (effectiveness) of NSAIDs, you can thus deduce that NSAIDs are competitive inhibitors.
questions.all_comments: Competitive inhibitors act by competing (hence the name “competitive” inhibitor) with substrate molecules for binding at the enzyme’s active site.  Because of their mechanism of action, the effects of competitive inhibitors may be alleviated by increasing the concentration of substrate molecules, allowing the substrate molecules to occupy a higher percentage of the active sites of the enzyme molecules.  Because high substrate concentrations reduce the efficacy (effectiveness) of NSAIDs, you can thus deduce that NSAIDs are competitive inhibitors.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about ATP and ADP is TRUE?

ATP and ADP act as allosteric inhibitors of many enzymes in anabolic pathways.
ATP acts as an allosteric inhibitor of many enzymes in catabolic pathways while ADP acts as an allosteric activator of many enzymes in catabolic pathways.

questions.correct_answer: ATP acts as an allosteric inhibitor of many enzymes in catabolic pathways while ADP acts as an allosteric activator of many enzymes in catabolic pathways.
questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP. If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point. As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP. For a similar reason, many catabolic enzymes are activated by ADP. Conversely, because anabolic pathways require ATP and generate ADP, many of the enzymes that catalyze anabolic reactions are activated by ATP and inhibited by ADP.
questions.all_comments: Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP.  If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point.  As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP.  For a similar reason, many catabolic enzymes are activated by ADP.  Conversely, because anabolic pathways require ATP and generate ADP, many of the enzymes that catalyze anabolic reactions are activated by ATP and inhibited by ADP.

answers.text: endergonic
none of these answers are correct
exergonic
spontaneous

questions.correct_answer: endergonic
questions.neutral_comments: Reactions that have a positive ∆G (i.e. reactions where the total free energy of the reactants is less than the total free energy of the products) are known as endergonic reactions. Reactions that have a negative ∆G are known as exergonic or spontaneous reactions.
questions.all_comments: Reactions that have a positive ∆G (i.e. reactions where the total free energy of the reactants is less than the total free energy of the products) are known as endergonic reactions.  Reactions that have a negative ∆G are known as exergonic or spontaneous reactions.

questions.question: A consequence of the fact that Gibb’s free energy must decrease in a spontaneous reaction is

answers.text: that all reactions may proceed spontaneously in only one direction.
that all reactions may proceed in only one direction unless ATP is added to the system.
that all reactions may proceed in only one direction unless there is an input of energy into the system to drive the reaction in the other direction.
that a given reaction may proceed spontaneously in both directions, due to the fact that different reactant and product molecules will have slightly different energies.

questions.correct_answer: that a given reaction may proceed spontaneously in both directions, due to the fact that different reactant and product molecules will have slightly different energies.
questions.neutral_comments: For a reaction to be a spontaneous reaction, the free energy of the reactant molecules must be greater than the free energy of the product molecules, so that free energy decreases as a result of the reaction. So, if you imagine a reaction where “A” is converted to “B”, the conversion of a molecule of A to a molecule of B will be spontaneous if the free energy of molecule A is greater than the free energy of molecule B. So, if on average A molecules have a free energy of 5 kcal/mole and B molecules have a free energy of 4.9 kcal/mole, the average free energy of a molecule of A will be greater than the average free energy of a molecule of B and therefore the conversion of an average molecule of A to an average molecule of B will represent an exergonic, or spontaneous, reaction. However, what we have to realize is that different molecules of A in a solution will have slightly different free energies and different molecules of B will have slightly free different energies. So, if the AVERAGE free energy of a molecule of B is 4.9 kcal/mole, there may be some molecules of B that have a free energy of greater than 5 kcal/mole. Those molecules of B that have a free energy that is greater than 5 kcal/mole can then be converted to molecules of A via a reaction that will be exergonic (spontaneous). Note that this does NOT mean that the conversion of B to A will occur at as high a rate as the conversion of A to B. If there are only a very small number of molecules of B that have a high enough free energy level to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction, the rate of conversion of A to B will be higher than the rate of conversion of B to A. Eventually, the high rate of conversion of A to B will result in there being enough molecules of B with sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction that the rate of conversion of B to A will equal the rate of conversion of A to B. At that point, the reaction will have reached equilibrium and both reactions will occur at the same rate (note that, in this example, at equilibrium there will be more molecules of B than of A, but a smaller percentage of the molecules of B will have sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction).
questions.all_comments: For a reaction to be a spontaneous reaction, the free energy of the reactant molecules must be greater than the free energy of the product molecules, so that free energy decreases as a result of the reaction.  So, if you imagine a reaction where “A” is converted to “B”, the conversion of a molecule of A to a molecule of B will be spontaneous if the free energy of molecule A is greater than the free energy of molecule B.  So, if on average A molecules have a free energy of 5 kcal/mole and B molecules have a free energy of 4.9 kcal/mole, the average free energy of a molecule of A will be greater than the average free energy of a molecule of B and therefore the conversion of an average molecule of A to an average molecule of B will represent an exergonic, or spontaneous, reaction.  However, what we have to realize is that different molecules of A in a solution will have slightly different free energies and different molecules of B will have slightly free different energies.  So, if the AVERAGE free energy of a molecule of B is 4.9 kcal/mole, there may be some molecules of B that have a free energy of greater than 5 kcal/mole.  Those molecules of B that have a free energy that is greater than 5 kcal/mole can then be converted to molecules of A via a reaction that will be exergonic (spontaneous).  Note that this does NOT mean that the conversion of B to A will occur at as high a rate as the conversion of A to B.  If there are only a very small number of molecules of B that have a high enough free energy level to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction, the rate of conversion of A to B will be higher than the rate of conversion of B to A.  Eventually, the high rate of conversion of A to B will result in there being enough molecules of B with sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction that the rate of conversion of B to A will equal the rate of conversion of A to B.  At that point, the reaction will have reached equilibrium and both reactions will occur at the same rate (note that, in this example, at equilibrium there will be more molecules of B than of A, but a smaller percentage of the molecules of B will have sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction).

questions.question: Which pathway is generally followed by a protein produced for secretion?

answers.text: Golgi, vesicle, rough ER, vesicle
Rough ER, vesicle, Golgi, vesicle
Smooth ER, vesicle, Golgi, vesicle
Golgi, vesicle, smooth ER, vesicle

questions.correct_answer: Rough ER, vesicle, Golgi, vesicle
questions.neutral_comments: Remember that proteins produced for secretion and proteins that will become part of one of the membranes of the endomembrane system are made by bound ribosomes (= ribosomes bound to the rough ER or nuclear envelope). Proteins made by ribosomes attached to the rough ER are transported via vesicles to the Golgi apparatus where they may be modified. The proteins are next transported via vesicles to their next destination (= the plasma membrane, in the case of secreted proteins). In contrast, “free ribosomes” (= ribosomes that are NOT bound to the rough ER or to the nuclear envelope) produce proteins that float freely in the cytosol or that are transported into the nucleus, mitochondria or chloroplasts.
questions.all_comments: Remember that proteins produced for secretion and proteins that will become part of one of the membranes of the endomembrane system are made by bound ribosomes (= ribosomes bound to the rough ER or nuclear envelope). Proteins made by ribosomes attached to the rough ER are transported via vesicles to the Golgi apparatus where they may be modified. The proteins are next transported via vesicles to their next destination (= the plasma membrane, in the case of secreted proteins). In contrast, “free ribosomes” (= ribosomes that are NOT bound to the rough ER or to the nuclear envelope) produce proteins that float freely in the cytosol or that are transported into the nucleus, mitochondria or chloroplasts.

questions.question: Which structure is the site of the synthesis of protein that may be exported from the cell?

answers.text: Golgi vesicles
smooth endoplasmic reticulum
mitochondrion
rough endoplasmic reticulum

questions.correct_answer: rough endoplasmic reticulum
questions.neutral_comments: Secreted proteins are synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough endoplasmic reticulum. Remember that the rough ER gets its name from the fact that it has a “rough” appearance when looked at using a microscope. The reason is has a “rough” appearance is because of the ribosomes that are bound to it. After proteins destined for export are synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough ER, vesicles bud off of the rough endoplasmic reticulum and transport those proteins to the Golgi apparatus where they are modified. Vesicles than bud off of the Golgi apparatus and transport the proteins to the plasma membrane. The vesicles fuse with the plasma membrane, releasing the proteins to the outside of the cell.
questions.all_comments: Secreted proteins are synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough endoplasmic reticulum.  Remember that the rough ER gets its name from the fact that it has a “rough” appearance when looked at using a microscope.  The reason is has a “rough” appearance is because of the ribosomes that are bound to it.  After proteins destined for export are synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough ER, vesicles bud off of the rough endoplasmic reticulum and transport those proteins to the Golgi apparatus where they are modified.  Vesicles than bud off of the Golgi apparatus and transport the proteins to the plasma membrane.  The vesicles fuse with the plasma membrane, releasing the proteins to the outside of the cell.

questions.question: If a modern electron microscope (TEM) can resolve biological images to the nanometer level, which is much better than the best light microscopes, this is due to which of the following?

answers.text: Electron microscopes have much larger objective lenses.
The focal length of the electron microscope is significantly longer.
Electron beams have much shorter wave lengths than visible light.
Contrast is enhanced by staining with atoms of heavy metal.

questions.correct_answer: Electron beams have much shorter wave lengths than visible light.
questions.neutral_comments: Resolving power is limited by the wavelength of the radiation used for imaging. The longer the wavelength of the radiation used for imaging, the poorer the resolution. Because electrons have much shorter wavelengths than visible light, electron microscopes have better resolutions than light microscopes.
questions.all_comments: Resolving power is limited by the wavelength of the radiation used for imaging.  The longer the wavelength of the radiation used for imaging, the poorer the resolution.  Because electrons have much shorter wavelengths than visible light, electron microscopes have better resolutions than light microscopes.

questions.question: Which statement correctly characterizes bound ribosomes?

answers.text: Bound ribosomes are enclosed in their own membrane.
Bound and free ribosomes are structurally different.
All of these answers are correct.
Bound ribosomes generally synthesize membrane proteins and secretory proteins.

questions.correct_answer: Bound ribosomes generally synthesize membrane proteins and secretory proteins.
questions.neutral_comments: Bound and free ribosomes are structurally the same. Bound ribosomes are ribosomes that are in the process of synthesizing proteins that are attached to the endoplasmic reticulum. These bound ribosomes are thus linked to the endoplasmic reticulum while they are synthesizing these proteins. Free ribosomes are synthesizing cytosolic proteins.
questions.all_comments: Bound and free ribosomes are structurally the same.  Bound ribosomes are ribosomes that are in the process of synthesizing proteins that are attached to the endoplasmic reticulum.  These bound ribosomes are thus linked to the endoplasmic reticulum while they are synthesizing these proteins.  Free ribosomes are synthesizing cytosolic proteins.

Because the vast majority of cells in plants are connected by plasmodesmata, plants have been called “supracellular” organisms, in contrast to multi-cellular organisms and single-celled, or unicellular organisms.
questions.all_comments: Plasmodesmata are membranous pores through plant cell walls. Plasmodesmata connect different plant cells to each other, allowing small molecules to diffuse between cells.  Because the vast majority of cells in plants are connected by plasmodesmata, plants have been called “supracellular” organisms, in contrast to multi-cellular organisms and single-celled, or unicellular organisms.

questions.all_comments: Plasmodesmata are membranous pores through plant cell walls. Plasmodesmata connect different plant cells to each other, allowing small molecules to diffuse between cells.  Because the vast majority of cells in plants are connected by plasmodesmata, plants have been called “supracellular” organisms, in contrast to multi-cellular organisms and single-celled, or unicellular organisms.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Golgi apparatus is TRUE?

answers.text: Vesicles that bud off from the cis side of the Golgi apparatus always travel to the plasma membrane.
Vesicles that bud off from the trans side of the Golgi apparatus have molecules on their surfaces that can recognize “docking” sites on the surface of the plasma membrane.
Vesicles that bud off from the cis side of the Golgi apparatus have molecules on their surfaces that can recognize “docking” sites on the surface of the plasma membrane.
Vesicles that bud off from the trans side of the Golgi apparatus always travel to the plasma membrane.

questions.correct_answer: Vesicles that bud off from the trans side of the Golgi apparatus have molecules on their surfaces that can recognize “docking” sites on the surface of the plasma membrane.
questions.neutral_comments: Some of the vesicles that bud off from the trans side of the Golgi apparatus travel to the plasma membrane, but some travel to other organelles within the cell instead.
questions.all_comments: Some of the vesicles that bud off from the trans side of the Golgi apparatus travel to the plasma membrane, but some travel to other organelles within the cell instead.
